PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that, pursuant to standing order 81, Senator Reid and Senator Spindler have each raised with me a matter of privilege and asked that I give precedence to a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee. The matter raised by the senators is that of Mr James Gaffey, which was the subject of the report presented to the Senate on 14 September 1992 by the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. The Committee reported that a charge under the Public Service Act was laid against Mr Gaffey in respect of his evidence to the Joint Committee, but was withdrawn when the Committee drew it to the attention of the Chairman of the Commission.

PARA.TAB: Under the relevant resolution of the Senate, I am required to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence, having regard to:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

The matter in question is clearly capable of being held by the Senate to meet criterion (a), and there is no other readily available remedy. Senator Reid and Senator Spindler have indicated that Mr Gaffey may have further evidence to present in relation to the matter. If this is so, it is an additional reason for giving precedence to a motion. I therefore rule that a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee may have precedence under standing order 81.

I table the letters from Senator Reid and Senator Spindler. With the concurrence of Senator Kemp, I also table a letter which Mr Gaffey addressed to him. Senator Reid or Senator Spindler may now give a notice of motion accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Committee of Privileges:
Having regard to the report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities entitled Privilege—Mr James Gaffey, presented to the Senate on 14 September 1992:
(a) the circumstances of the laying of charges under the Public Service Act against Mr James Gaffey, an officer of the Australian Securities Commission;
(b) whether any penalty or injury was inflicted on Mr Gaffey in consequence of his giving evidence to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities; and
(c) whether any contempt of Parliament was committed in respect of those matters.

Dear Minister
I refer to your letter of 27 May 1992 on aspects raised by the Committee of Public Service Determination 1992/27.

Officers of your Department have since then assisted the Committee by appearing before it to speak to a paper and, after that meeting, by preparing another paper. The Committee considered that second paper at its meeting of 18 June 1992.

The Department's second paper covered various courses of action available in this matter. Under the heading "Conclusion" the paper advised that "the preferred option" is to deal with this problem by direct appropriation "through the current budget process". This confirms earlier advice in the paper that these arrangements "could be achieved in the 1992/93 budgetary process". The Department also advised, in a covering letter, that the paper would be the basis of a submission to you.

The Committee would be completely satisfied if the matter was dealt with under the Department's preferred option. However, the Committee considers that another appropriate solution would be to amend the parent Act.

The Committee emphasises its view that the present position for relevant officers, characterised by the Merit Protection and Review Agency as unfair and inequitable and the existence of which has been known for almost 20 years by the administering authorities, should be addressed.

The Committee would be grateful for your advice on proposed action on the Department's preferred option. It would be appreciated if this could be received by, say, the end of July, to enable the Committee to finalise its consideration of this matter by the start of the Budget sitting. Given that the preferred option is to operate in the context of the 1992/93 budgetary process we do not suppose that this will cause any difficulties.

The Committee also noted that Public Service Determination 1992/46 replaced the substantive provisions of subclause 11.1 of Public Service Determination 1992/27. Your Department advised that this was because "it was realised that subclause 11.1 did not have the intended effect". In order to preserve the options of the Committee I will give a notice of disallowance on this second Determination during the next sitting week.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair

My dear Minister
I am writing in response to your letter of 15 July 1992 seeking my agreement to a scheme to correct under-payments of recreation leave in the Australian Public Service.

In view of the actions taken by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to give notice or motion to disallow a determination under the Public Service Act relating to recreation leave, and in view of the issues of equity raised by the under-payments, I have agreed to the course of action outlined in your letter.

Senator the Hon Peter Cook
Minister for Industrial Relations
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Peter
I refer to your letter to the Prime Minister, which was copied to me on 15 July 1992, regarding recreation leave credits for pre-1966 Australian Public Service Officers.

I agree that the anomaly of recovering recreation leave credits at a 4 weeks rate rather than the 3 weeks rate at which the leave accrued should be corrected. This correction should be made retrospectively, to include those pre-1966 officers who left the service between January 1973 and March 1992. I note that it is not possible in this case to correct the problem through a section 82D determination. Accordingly, the scheme you have proposed appears to be the most effective method of achieving the desired outcome and will properly give Parliament the opportunity to scrutinise the process.

A one-line appropriation has the advantage, over the other options canvassed in your letter, of clearly setting out the purpose and amount of the payments in the Budget Papers. Thus Parliament will have been given the opportunity to scrutinise the scheme and, if it authorises the purpose expressed through the one-line appropriation, satisfies any concern that the proposed scheme might not have Parliamentary sanction.
I am copying this letter to the Prime Minister.
Yours sincerely
Ralph Willis

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983, amid a lot of jubilation and fanfare, the ALP Government introduced and acted under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act to stop the Franklin dam.

In May 1988 the Helsham Commission recommended the nomination of Exit Cave for World Heritage listing. In doing so the heads of agreement that were worked out between the Federal and Tasmanian Governments, and signed by Senator Cook and Mr Ray Groom on 29 November 1988, fully recognised the possible incompatibility between a quarry operation and the values inherent in World Heritage listing. I quote:

The Commonwealth agrees that the operation of Bender's quarry within the Exit cave area nominated for World heritage listing can continue provided that acceptable limits are set to the scale and development of the operation. Should any financial loss result from any limits placed on the operation, the Commonwealth will pay compensation direct to the company concerned.

In November 1991, in a report prepared for the Tasmanian Government by Mr Kevin Kiernan, the operations of Benders Quarry were proven to have an impact on the World Heritage values of Exit Cave system. This information was contained in an hydrogeological report and in field survey notes.
Benders Pty Ltd prepared an Environmental Management Plan to support its continued operation of the quarry to which public submissions were invited.

PARA.TAB: On February 5 1992 Benders Spreading Services Pty Ltd was permitted to undertake some blasting under licence conditions drawn up by Tasmanian Department of Environment and Planning and endorsed by the Commonwealth. This was to provide a sample of limestone to form part of a tender for the supply of limestone to Pasminco-Ez.

It is my contention and the position of the Democrats that this should never have been permitted. It is at this point that the lack of responsibility of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) towards her World Heritage responsibilities becomes clearly evident. No further blasting should ever have been permitted following receipt of evidence showing that blasting was affecting the cave system.

On Monday 24 February, only three weeks after the `sample blast', the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Standing Committee assessed the Environmental Management Plan submitted by Benders Spreading Services Pty Ltd and concluded that:

SPEECH.PARA: past and present quarrying operations have indisputably damaged solution cavities, sink holes and caves that are now known to be part of the Exit Cave karst subsystem.
and that even under the strictest environmental conditions continuation of quarrying jeopardises the area's World Heritage values.
This recommendation was to go to a meeting of the Ministerial Council which was to meet on 29 February to discuss the matter, but the meeting was postponed.

PARA.TAB: It was clear from comments made on ABC radio that the Tasmanian Minister, Mr John Cleary accepted the position of the Standing Committee but that he was concerned about the question of compensation. While this was a legitimate concern with which the Democrats would have a lot in common, it should not have stood in the way of a decision to close down the existing quarry.
On that same day I gave notice of a motion in the Senate which called on the Senate to note that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Commonwealth Government has recognised that Exit Cave, Australia's longest cave system, extends beneath the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area,

(ii)in 1988 the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments agreed that the operation of Bender's quarry within the Exit Cave area could continue, subject to acceptable limits being set on the scale and development of the operation, and

(iii)the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Standing Committee has concluded that `even under the strictest environmental conditions continuation of quarrying jeopardises the area's World heritage values'; and

PARA.TAB: and called on:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Commonwealth Government to advise the Governor-General immediately to proclaim the Exit Cave system to be a property to which Sections 9 and 10 of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 applies, and

(ii)the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to immediately convene the meeting of the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Areas Ministerial Council which was planned for 29 February 1992 to provide a statement on alternative quarrying operations and to expedite negotiations with Mr Bender.

SPEECH.PARA: The World heritage listing obligates the Federal Government to do all in its power to protect the areas it nominates for listing. To sit idly by as the Minister did, Nero like outside burning Rome, while quarrying operations continued to eat away at the fundamental values for which the area was nominated for world recognition is Ministerial irresponsibility of the kind that has led to decades of environmental neglect and decay in this and other countries. But Minister Kelly sat on the problem and refused to budge, despite motions and speeches in this chamber calling on her as Minister responsible for managing our World Heritage responsibilities to proclaim the area and stop the blasting.

PARA.TAB: In early May the Democrats sought to suspend standing orders to debate the motion that the Senate calls on the Government to immediately announce that it would use its World Heritage powers to close down quarrying, a motion which was opposed by both the Liberal and Labor Parties in this chamber. Yet later in the month the Minister announced that quarrying would have to cease. Although this was welcomed by the Democrats we were concerned at the absence of any concrete action being taken. We were also alarmed by the lack of detail in the Minister's announcement. The lack of detail led to speculation about what could or might occur at the quarry site.

Only a couple of weeks later, there developed strong speculation that further blasting was going to occur. It had become abundantly clear that on environmental matters, neither this Government nor this Minister could be trusted. That blasting did not occur is probably due to the outrage that erupted.

Why then should we have any faith even in the Minister's gazettal notice of Tuesday 15 September which refused consent for further blasting by Benders Spreading Services Pty Ltd? Another Minister, or indeed this Minister could presumably just as easily issue another notice cancelling the order.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, it is precisely the Minister's lack of commitment and decisiveness that has been the principal cause of the confrontations, anger and confusion that has been evident at the quarry site now for some weeks. She had not stated clearly and precisely her plans for protecting the cave system and upholding her responsibilities to manage and discharge her World Heritage obligations. Indeed I believe that the confrontations have been the direct result of the Minister's silence and inaction.

PARA.TAB: Even the answer provided to this chamber this week by Senator Collins does not lay to rest the fears surrounding this issue. Instead it highlights yet again the insensitivity and equivocation of this Minister. This week we learned for the first time that there is to be an independent adviser to supervise the rehabilitation work at the quarry. We do not know who that person is to be. And we still do not know precisely what rehabilitation work is required, nor who will prepare the rehabilitation plan. Nor is it at all clear why the Minister is to allow a further 9,000 tonnes of rock to be extracted from the quarry. How is that 3,000 tonnes of this is needed for rehabilitation work when there is yet no rehabilitation plan?

In answer to my question, the Minister also informs us that a further 600 tonnes will become available for commercial sales. Is this the amount which the quarry is capable of yielding without further compromising World Heritage values, or is this the amount which was commercially `negotiated' to secure an agreement? The fact that any negotiations at all were necessary at this stage is entirely due to the Minister's earlier lack of precision.

The Exit Cave saga is another sorry saga in the Minister's performance of her environmental responsibilities. Simply put, neither she, nor her government can be trusted. And of course neither can the Liberals be relied upon to continue to protect the cave system. This Bill is therefore a necessity.

It should be recalled that the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, under which the Minister issued the recent Gazettal notice, is not regarded as an instrument for the ongoing management of Australia's World Heritage properties. The Act is only enabling legislation. It enables the Commonwealth to prevent damage to World Heritage values through the prohibition of prescribed acts.

For a site to be subject to the Act it must first be an `identified property' and it must have be proclaimed by the Governor-General to be in danger of being damaged by some proposed activity. The activity must then be specifically prescribed by the Minister. This was done by the Gazettal notice of 15 September 1992.

By advising the Governor-General to make a proclamation the Government is showing that it considers that the identified property is in danger of damage or destruction. The Minister should therefore be consistent and ensure that the proclamation and the Minister's subsequent refusal to consent to further blasting at the quarry should not be revoked or amended. The only way to now permanently do this is by legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Foreman) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Super and the Financial System.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

Debate resumed from 7 October, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Short had moved by way of amendment:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (a)notes that the Bills:

TAB.TAB: (i)are unprecedented in being introduced simultaneously with Appropriation Bills 1 and 2;
(ii)are politically motivated; and
(iii)reflect the Government's continuing fiscal mismanagement.

PARA.TAB: (b)Condemns the Prime Minister for being so out of touch with the reality of the continuing economic recession and hardship of which he was, on his own acknowledgment, the chief architect, that he can assert that Australia's recession ended long ago".

TALK.START.PARA: —When we left this debate last night, we were discussing the financial failure of this Government as is evidenced not only in its appalling Budget performance, but also, of course, in these two Supply Bills which have come before the Senate. Just to recap very briefly on exactly how poor the financial and economic management of this Government has been, I need only remind honourable senators that it was only in August that the Government came before the Senate with a Budget that had a deficit on its own figures of $13.4 billion—$13.4 billion that this Government does not have; $13.4 billion of further debt for this nation. Of course, during this financial year there is a financing requirement in excess of that, a financing requirement of $18.5 billion. That is a financing requirement in excess of $1,000 for every man, woman and child in this nation. That is the achievement of this Government, its planned achievement in the space of just 12 months. That is what it is aiming to do. It is aiming to increase our indebtedness and it is aiming to further bankrupt this nation and the businesses that comprise this nation.

PARA.TAB: The disturbing thing is: where is the money coming from? Where is the Government borrowing the money that it is going to spend this year? If one looks at the Budget Papers, one finds that most of the Government's borrowings will be at the longer end of the maturities. That means that, instead of taking short term money, it is going to be taking longer term money. It is going to be financing its operations on the basis of bonds rather than on the basis of treasury notes. This means that the sort of money it is sucking up into its spending programs is exactly the sort of money that is needed to finance new investment in this country for businesses from one end of the nation to the other.

The Government is leaving all the hot money out there. It is leaving all the credit card money out there because it wants Australians to spend more on credit cards. But where is it taking the money from? It is taking the money from the deposits which would be available to lend to businesses or the deposits that would be available to lend to Australians who wish to buy their own home.

What this Government is engineering is not a real recovery; it is a phoney, short term recovery paid for with hot money. What this Government is going to do, of course, is seriously set back the prospects of real recovery, the prospects of economic growth, the prospects of new investment in the corporate sector, the prospects of operations, such as those referred to by Senator Tierney today in his notice of motion, being able to continue.

Had the Government not been plundering the money that should be available for new investment, those sorts of companies and businesses from Cairns to Canberra, from Moreton Island to Marandoo, would be allowed to continue in this country. This Government has taken that money and put it in its own coffers. The Government could not wait to get its hands on the money that it intended to appropriate to itself. It could not wait even until the Appropriation Bills had been passed before it started spending willy nilly on this nation's credit card.

The Government has come before this Parliament and said, `In addition to the money that is in the Advance to the Minister for Finance, we want more. Please, give us more'. The Government has asked for another $170m, which it believes it needs now, before the Appropriation Bills come through. The Government cannot wait until Parliament deals with the Appropriation Bills. It is interesting to note that the Appropriation Bills were supposed to come on this month, but they have been held up yet again. If Senator McMullan, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, could do his job properly, maybe we would not need these Supply Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has got a good adviser next to him. The trouble is, he doesn't listen to him.

—As Senator Panizza says, Senator McMullan has a good adviser next to him. But where is Senator Walsh? He is relegated to the back bench. Here we find a situation where the Government cannot get its program right and has to keep asking for Supply Bills because it cannot get the Appropriation Bills into the Senate on time.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that when we come to the end of this session we will see Senator McMullan standing over there telling us that there are a whole heap of Bills that now need to be considered as urgent, a whole heap of Bills the Government intends to guillotine through the Parliament without proper debate or consideration. We have the time available now to deal with the Appropriation Bills instead of the Supply Bills, but the Government has the Appropriation Bills languishing down the other end of the building. That is an example of how poor the management of this Government really is.

What is the Government going to spend that $170m on? The $65m in Supply Bill (No. 3) is supposed to be for labour market programs and road safety programs and the $105m in Supply Bill (No. 4) is for local government capital works. In other words, this is the sort of money the Government wants for its phoney job creation schemes and it cannot wait until the Appropriation Bills get through Parliament to start spending the money. The Government wants to run out of this chamber, out of this Parliament, and spend, spend, spend to try to create some phoney jobs so that it can pretend that there is a recovery from the recession. It is interesting that just this week in the other place the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stood up in Question Time and steadfastly affirmed that not only is there not a recession but that we were out of recession long ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is the stock market where it is if we are out of recession?

—Exactly. That is a very good interjection from my friend Senator Panizza. If we are out of recession, why is the stock market continuing to go down? Why is it that this nation's economic performance makes Australia the sick man of South East Asia? Why is it that we have a country which used to be one of the finest and most prosperous in this region increasingly being looked upon, unfortunately, as a joke by our competitors and our trading partners overseas? The reason that situation has occurred is very simple: the Hawke-Labor Government of the last nine years. That is why our economic performance has been so bad. But here is a government that spends its time lambasting New Zealand and saying, `We do not want to become like New Zealand'.

PARA.TAB: Let us take the opportunity to examine the track record of the Government in relation to New Zealand. Last year the Government congratulated itself on running only a balance of payments deficit, which means that we imported more than we exported by about $11 1/2 billion. It thought that was an achievement. The economy was haemorrhaging money at the rate of a billion dollars a month offshore while the Government congratulated itself on its performance. Yet it lambasted New Zealand, which actually managed to run a balance of payments surplus of $88m. New Zealand was doing substantially better—roughly $11 1/2 billion better—than we were, and the Government was saying to the people of Australia, `We do not want to become like New Zealand'. Why on earth not?

Here we have a government that continued to see unemployment rise in the quarter to June 1992 while in New Zealand, a much smaller country, unemployment fell by 10,000 people. But the Government does not want us to be like New Zealand. Here we have food processing industries and plants closing, particularly in New South Wales and Victoria, and New Zealand has a 30 per cent advantage over Australia in food processing because it has got its tax system right and because it has got its industrial relations system right. But this Government does not want us to become like New Zealand. I ask the question: why on earth not?

Why should the Government be allowed, year after year after year, to continue to run down the economy of this nation without getting the condemnation it deserves? We now have the Supply Bills in front of us. The Government has come before us saying, `We would like you to give us $170m for our electoral campaign chest so that we can go out and spend the money in the hope that it might salvage the unsalvageable in Victoria'. We saw what happened in Victoria the other week. It really was unsalvageable. The people of Victoria realised that years and years and years of Labor government have wreaked their damage upon that economy.

The damage has been done not just to Victoria; it has also been done to the national economy. Last year this Parliament was asked to help bail out the State Bank of Victoria to the tune of about $1.6 billion. That Australian taxpayers' money was used to subsidise the Victorian Labor Government's economic mismanagement. Here we have the Government saying, `We need another $170m before the Appropriation Bills come through because we cannot wait to start spending the money'. What this is designed to do is to hoodwink the Australian people into believing that the recovery is starting and that the recession was over long ago. It is designed to inflate the national account figures to make it look as though the economy is growing. But all the growth in the economy is in one sector only. All the growth in the economy at the moment is in the public sector.

The Government has borrowed the money to pump into the economy to make it look as though there is some real growth. But out in real Australia, where the real men and women of this nation work, where the ordinary, hardworking, blue-collar workers are, where the struggling middle classes of this nation are, we know that there is no recovery. We know that the recession is still here. We know that unemployment, poverty and financial difficulties continue to abound and drive family after family after family in this nation to despair. We know that there are 600,000 children in this nation in families where neither partner is a breadwinner. We know that the Government continues only on its hollow promises, only on its poor rhetoric and only on its ability to disguise the real economic plight of Australia. But out in the households, out in the heartland of Australia, the truth is clear to see.

There was a time in this nation when hard work, honesty and thrift were qualities to be admired. There was a time when people were encouraged to work to better the lot of their families. There was a time when honesty was considered to be a good Australian characteristic and when saving, thrift and putting away for the future were also considered to be things that every good Australian should do. But what do we find now? We find conspicuous consumption. We find a government that has to spend and spend and spend because it knows nothing better. We find a government for whom dishonesty is a way of life and for whom sloth is a desirable characteristic. The Government has forced it on almost a million unemployed Australians and on the hundreds of thousands of underemployed Australians.

This Government will get its $170m; it will get its money. The Senate should also support the amendments moved by my colleague Senator Short in condemning these two Supply Bills as politically motivated, and as evidence of the fact, which every Australian knows, that this Government cannot balance the books and that this Government cannot manage the economy. Sooner or later the Australian people will throw this Government out on its ear. At the next election, the Australian people will clearly say, `Enough is enough. Enough of Paul Keating, enough of Labor and enough of the financial despair which they have placed upon this nation's economy'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to support the views of my colleague Senator Short and others on the Supply Bill (No. 3), which seeks $65m for recurrent expenditure, and Supply Bill (No. 4) which seeks $105m to meet capital works and other non-recurrent outlays. I also rise to speak to the Loan Bill which finalises the prospective 1992-93 Budget deficit of $13.389 billion. This is the usual practice of funding the deficit of the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

PARA.TAB: However, Supply Bill (No. 3) and Supply Bill (No. 4) are unprecedented; they are additional to Supply Bill (No. 1) and Supply Bill (No. 2) which were passed in June to carry on with the usual expenses incurred by the Government, leading up to the end of November when the Appropriation Bills finally go through. But, as Senator O'Chee so ably pointed out, the Government cannot see itself as being able to get to that stage without looking for more supply for the unfunded promises that it may make in the future. The Government is certainly bringing these Bills on early. They have been introduced at the same time as the Appropriation Bills, which is very unusual.

Normally, any shortfall is taken up as an Advance to the Minister for Finance. But the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, said in his second reading speech that that is not the right way to go. I have been following the proceedings of the Parliament for the last 30 years and that has always been the way to go. However, in his second reading speech he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Reliance on the Advance to the Minister for Finance for these purposes would run the very real risk that there would be insufficient funds available to meet other urgent and unforeseen requirements.

I stress the words `other' and `unforeseen'. Most governments can generally foresee what will happen from 1 July to 1 December but, obviously, this Government cannot. I think that `unforeseen circumstances' can only mean what the Government may promise between now and the next election. That is obviously—due to the results in Victoria a few days ago—a moveable feast.

PARA.TAB: I do not think that these measures are quite so unforeseen; otherwise we would not have had the Supply Bill in so early. I believe that the Government did have an election date in mind—5, 12 or 19 December—when it brought these Supply Bills into the House of Representatives. I think the events in Victoria last Saturday have probably put that idea off to the last Saturday before Easter. We will see what happens in time. The unfunded promises between now and then will continue to grow. That is why the Supply Bills are out now and we might have another one before 1 November.

I believe that these Supply Bills are about the One Nation package and the One Job package. There has been a huge increase in spending coming up to the election and I believe that is just to soften up the electorate. Incidentally, talking about softening up the electorate, some of the projects that the Government proposed in the One Nation package—where it talks about the real jobs and real benefits to Australia—are not happening so fast. One of those cases is the promised amount for Australian Railways to improve the railways between, say, Sydney and Brisbane, Kwinana and Kalgoorlie and the South Australian section.

Reading the press in the last few days, I find that there has been continual action from the railways of Australia because that money is not coming forward quickly. Yet that is a place where it can do some good. I believe that this is a buying votes exercise and more and more will be needed because the election has—no doubt—been put off. I believe that having Supply Bill (No. 3) and Supply Bill (No. 4) brought in at this stage of the year with the Appropriation Bills is an admission that the Budget is already in a mess. We have seen examples of that already.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was introduced at the same time as the Budget. It is part of the Budget.

—Yes, it was introduced; it is unusual that it was. It is unusual and the honourable senator knows it and the boss Minister down the other end says so too—as people will see if they read his speeches.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the Government's attempting to bring in money early. Using methods to bring money in early does not necessarily mean any extra money. There was the idea, which has already been thrown out in the Budget, that the Government would put a withholding tax on interest. Senator McMullan will remember this very well; it was one of the ways the Government was going to bring the money forward. What it did not work out and what it did not allow for was the fact, as I said, that this does not bring any more money in, it only brings it forward. All it was doing was taking the place of provisional tax. It was already allowed for in provisional tax. The Government was going to look at the idea of withholding tax on top of that on interest. Anyone who gets more than $1,000 interest a year knows that they have to pay provisional tax, so there was only that small amount that was not already covered between zero—or whatever it was—and the $1,000 that the Government was attempting to bring in early. Of course, when the tax returns were put in on, say, 31 March, a lot of that money had to flow back. The Government then worked out that the measure had failed. I do not know why it was put in originally, but the Government worked out that it had failed so it threw it out.

Bringing in that sort of measure—or attempting to; it has gone out the window—is an admission that the tax file number has failed. We have got the tax file number; we were supposed to have an Australia Card which was going to fix any rorts on income tax in Australia, especially through interest, through rents and through other sorts of things. The tax file number was supposed to be the end of it all. We supported the tax file number as a workable instrument and here we are: the Government brought in a measure which it has since thrown out again. Either it did not think through the measure properly or it is admitting that the tax file number has failed. If the Government wants to improve the tax file number let it do so, but do not let it use other actions that might jeopardise it, rather than improve it.

Let us look at the local government capital works program. That was a program that was thrown around to buy votes in the selective way that it was used. Take the example of Stirling in Western Australia: it is a rather well-to-do sector of Perth and, incidentally, a marginal seat. It received some $7m. Another local government, the city of Wanneroo, is right alongside it. I think it is the fastest expanding metropolis in Australia and it got zero. Where there is expansion one would think that this is where this sort of allocation would be needed. There was no rhyme or reason for the allocations anywhere in Western Australia. Kalgoorlie got zero; a small town not far away got some; Derby got quite an allocation; and Broome, not far away from it, got none. There was no rhyme or reason. These allocations created a lot of mickey mouse jobs; they were thrown around with no real reason except to get the votes where maybe this Government did not have them.

I talk about mickey mouse jobs. Some of the money that was allocated in One Nation I certainly agreed with, especially with regard to the railways, the roads and the black spots and so on—though the black spots are not necessarily where unemployment is. But there were the ones that did create mickey mouse jobs. I said to a local government in Western Australia last week, `You got an allocation. What are you doing with it?'. They said, `Oh, well, we are going to do some cycle paths'. I asked, `How many people ride bicycles in this area?'. From my observation there were not many at all.

The Government has to look at these local government grants and see whether this money did create jobs. With a lot of the capital works that are going to be done with it tenders are called. The firms that tender and are successful have already got their work crews. Worse still, the work crew generally come from somewhere else where that contractor is based. So without being too negative, I would like to know whether it creates jobs. I do not mean prop-up ones, those that prevent people going out of work. I suppose it is an advantage if the money does that, but does it really create jobs? I would like that one to be really looked at.

We have been told in the last couple of days that the recession is long over. If the recession is long over, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has stated in the last couple of days, I would like the Government to tell me—or anyone to tell me—why it is, as reported in the Australian in the last day or so, that the Australian Stock Exchange is at its lowest point in 18 months. If the recession was over yesterday that is a different matter, but if it is long over one would think it would have caused a reaction on the Australian Stock Exchange. But no, it is at the lowest point for 18 months. Can someone tell me about that?

If the recession is long over, please tell the farmers who are onto me every day of the week with their problems. Also tell that to those on the job queues. The job queues have not shortened at all. If the recession is over, why should they not shorten? Also tell the school leavers. A lot of the school leavers of last year have not got jobs. The new term is due to start any time now, so there will be another lot of school leavers out there. Please tell them that the recession is over and tell them why they are not getting jobs. I believe that the way to go is for the Government to encourage small business—and even big business—because they are the ones that create the employment. Small business, as everyone knows and without my saying it again, is the biggest employer. We have seen a slight improvement in the numbers they are employing. They are the biggest employer of people in Australia.

We need the big mining companies and industries to take up the slack in Australia. Honourable senators would have seen the announcement that the mining project Marandoo in Western Australia finally has been given the go-ahead after about two years, 13 reports and three more reports pending. I believe a project with a capital structure of about $500m, creating some 4,000 jobs during construction, with 350 permanent jobs, would be welcomed by everyone in Australia as possibly being a turnaround, that this Government is going to see the light after all and not listen to fringe groups that want to stop all sorts of development. One would think it would be welcomed by everyone in Australia.

But it seems to be not very welcome with the Australian Democrats. Senator Coulter yesterday put out a press release calling on the Western Australian Government not to go ahead with that project—that $500m project in the Karijini National Park. I will describe the national park a bit later on. But here he is calling for it not to go ahead. It is only a $500m project, but it will keep the life of the central Pilbara going for 20 years. It is very necessary to do that one, to get through the national park and extend the railway down to Mount Newman. But Senator Coulter is now on the record as saying that there is absolutely no reason to mine inside the Karijini National Park.

Let me describe that national park. In 1946, I am told—and I have read the history—it was still a cattle station. The owners abandoned it because it was not longer viable. It could not carry any more stock, it was short of underground water, and it was being taken over by feral animals. To fill the void that left, the Lands Department—in conjunction with the Government of Western Australia, no doubt—called it a national park. It is as much a national park as the Simpson Desert. I have travelled part of the Simpson Desert and it is far more hospitable than that section. I have been in there and travelled over it myself: it is an absolute wasteland. Yet here is Senator Coulter saying that it is one of the top national parks of Australia.

I say this, briefly, especially to the Australian Democrats, to show that not all Australia has woken up to the fact that Australia needs investment in small business, in big business, in mining, if we are to turn Australia around. I call on all Australians to look on development with favour and to take these developments on board, as they are cleared by governments throughout Australia, as being for the good of all Australia, without finding every reason to knock them over.

The excuse that this is a unique park has been used as a red herring all over Australia. The same unreasonable excuses are being used time and time again. We had a debate on whether there should be mining in Kakadu National Park. I believe that mining should have gone ahead there; I visited the park as part of an inquiry into mining in Kakadu National Park. At least part of the park was a top national park and would have ranked with anything in the world but a lot of it was not. Senator Evans, some time back, called it clapped out buffalo country. Even that clapped out buffalo country of Kakadu National Park, however, would be kilometres ahead of what exists at this former Mount Bruce cattle station.

The station was abandoned as being unviable—no surface, could not grow anything, useless—thrown open and then turned into a national park, just to give it a go. I understand that there could have been a bit of play between a Premier of Western Australia and one mining fellow about using it to hold things up, but that is just a bit of side play. Here we are with a $500m project ready to help Western Australians—3,500 jobs immediately to set the mine up and 350 more, as well as the production that comes out of it in iron ore—yet we have the Australian Democrats trying to knock it.

The Supply Bills will be passed, no doubt, but the Government certainly has not given us the right reasons why it is looking at these Bills at the present moment. It could have used the right system, that is, the Advance to the Minister for Finance, but we are never surprised at what the Government comes up with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (a), omit the paragraph.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats cannot agree with the sentiments expressed in paragraph (a). We do not believe that it is wrong to introduce these Bills simultaneously. If the Government has a program to create jobs, that is an urgent need and overrides the other considerations the Opposition has put forward.

PARA.TAB: We do not believe that the simultaneous introduction of the Bills is politically motivated and we do not agree with subparagraph (iii) of paragraph (a). We can accept the statement expressed in paragraph (b). While, technically, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) may be able to argue that we have come out of a recession or, to use the Opposition's words, that `Australia's recession ended long ago', we do not believe that that is a fair way to approach the economic pain and suffering of so many Australians at the moment. It does reflect being out of touch with reality to assert boldly that, because, technically, we may have come out of a recession, this is the most important consideration. I commend my amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been three issues involved in the debate on Supply Bill (No. 3) and Supply Bill (No. 4). Very little of the debate has been about the substance of the Bills, although some of it has been. There has been significant debate about the process and some about the economic context, and the questions of process and economic context are those that are reflected in Senator Short's amendments. I will turn to those in a moment. Let me refer first to the substance.

PARA.TAB: These Bills are essentially to ensure the availability of funds for socially worthwhile projects which will also create jobs, particularly in the regions of greatest need. So, to the extent to which the amendment says that these Bills are politically motivated, in the proper sense of the word `political', meaning that they are motivated by a desire to achieve agreed social objectives by the Government, that is technically true. As with every Bill that comes into the Senate, these Bills have as an objective to achieve a desired social outcome, and we are working through the institutions of government to achieve that agreed social outcome. So, in that technical sense, one could say that they are political, and no-one would apologise for it. That should be the case with every piece of legislation that comes into this chamber. If it is meaning that the legislation is simply partisan, that is a nonsense, and I will come to that in dealing with the question of process.

We have had a fascinating, if terribly repetitive, discussion about the inappropriateness of the process of introducing these Bills. I will remind people, in thinking about the process, to go back to the much more fundamental question of the purpose of these Bills and the substance of the Bills, because the two are related. It is true that the Government desires, as it has already announced, to make the money available quickly. One example has been used predominantly, including by Senator Panizza. I do not agree with his comments about it but he is correct in saying that one of the things that these Bills are designed to deal with is local government capital works projects. That is a correct and appropriate example to choose. We have already announced some projects for which funds will be made available. In fact, we have made offers to local authorities to fund particular, specified projects which have been announced, and there will be more announced very soon in accordance with the timetable outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins).

There are three ways in which the Government can fund these proposals. The funds all come from the same pool of money. There is no extra money. It is the money in the Budget. In the Minister's second reading speech on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) he said that there are three Bills to provide the funds for these various projects: the previous Supply Bills, the Appropriation Bills and these Supply Bills. We are not appropriating extra money. This is part of the money announced in the Budget. There are three ways in which the Government can make this money available more quickly to enable the jobs to be made available more quickly. There is no secret about that. It is exactly why these Bills have been introduced.

That is what the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said in his second reading speech on the Bills. It is so that we can start the projects more quickly and create the jobs more quickly, and I believe that is a socially desirable and justifiable purpose. Others are entitled to have alternative views and say that we should not be creating the jobs so quickly. I do not object to their saying that. I just wish they would be more explicit.

There are three ways in which we can fund these proposals. One is through the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The second is that we can use exactly this process but call them extra appropriation Bills instead of extra supply Bills. Senator Short made some reference to that in the Estimates Committee. I do not know whether he did so in his speech in this debate. I did not pick it up if he did. The third is the mechanism that we have used, which is extra supply Bills.

I will come back to the AMF as the third of the three options. It is, in my view, more appropriate to deal with this by way of Supply Bills rather than Appropriation Bills. I do not regard that as a very significant distinction in terms of these Bills but they are essentially performing the function of Supply Bills; that is, making money that would otherwise be appropriated in the Budget available during this supply period. So I think that is a more appropriate nomenclature, although I accept that that is not a fundamental distinction and, had they been called `Appropriation Bills', the whole debate would have been exactly the same.

Senator Short said that this is unprecedented, and as far as I can tell that is correct. I have to say in response to that, `So what?'. As far as I can tell, it is unprecedented to introduce extra Supply Bills on the same day as the Budget, as it would have been unprecedented to do that with Appropriation Bills. There is no precedent for that either. It is nevertheless an entirely proper process; the alternative was simply to turn to the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

There are two reasons why I think that is not the appropriate course, one which was made explicit by the Minister for Finance in the second reading speech to these Bills and one which was made explicit by me in the Estimates Committee discussions. The first is that, as a matter of prudence, it is possible that making these large calls upon the AMF—calls now foreseen but not, of course, foreseeable at the time the original Supply Bills came in—may cause other urgent and unforeseen calls upon the AMF not to be able to be funded. Therefore, other important things for which the AMF is usually set aside may not be able to be done.

Senator Panizza saw some significance in these terms `urgent' and `unforeseen'. They are the criteria that have to be met for an expenditure to be funded out of the AMF. That is why those words are used: they are the criteria that have to be met.

In my opinion, it is likely that we would have been able to fund all this out of the AMF. It is probable. I will just divert briefly to make a comment I was going to make at the end. Senator Bishop, in speech at the second reading stage, said that she was waiting to hear the answer to a question she asked at page 126 of the Estimates Committee Hansard. The only reason she is waiting to hear is that she was not listening. The answer, relating to the amount of money then available in the AMF, was given by the officer, Mr Pearson, and appears at page 147 of the Hansard for Estimates Committee B. It is more than likely, but not certain, that we could have funded this from the AMF but it would not, in my view, have been the prudent thing to do.

Another thing surprises me about this debate. In my view, funding by the AMF would not have been the proper process because there would not have been this explicit bringing before the Parliament of the funding arrangements for a major initiative. This way we are saying, `We are not doing it by an advance that is subsequently declared to the Parliament. We are explicitly legislating'. It is entirely the proper process. It was my advice to the Minister for Finance that this was the better parliamentary process. It is of no political significance to the Government which way we fund it. We have the same amount of money to perform exactly the same function so there is no political significance in which way we do it. It is a question of proper process and prudence.

There has been a bit of enthusiasm from Senator O'Chee, in particular, for the idea that if we had handled the parliamentary timetable properly we could have done this via the ordinary passage of the Appropriation Bills. There is no precedent of which I am aware, as far back as I have checked, for the Appropriation Bills ever being passed by this date. These Bills will be passed today. I know of no precedent for their being passed by 8 October. So there was some necessity to have another mechanism—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you need the money today?
—Because they want to spend it now.

—We do; exactly. We want to create jobs more quickly, and those opposite are entitled to be opposed to that. It is a legitimate matter of public debate to say that we should not create these jobs so quickly. In my view, for proper process, for prudence and to create the jobs, this is the appropriate course of action. Members of the Opposition are entitled to be opposed to it; it is consistent with their approach to the economy overall. It reflects their concerns and priorities and they are entitled to have that opinion. However, I believe it is appropriate that we bring this matter before the Parliament specifically by legislation, and that is why we have done it in this way.

PARA.TAB: I should now like to say something about the economic context—some aspects of that that are reflected in Senator Short's amendment. In some ways, this has been dealt with by some of the Opposition speakers in this debate and also, briefly, by Senator Kernot. I take honourable senators back to the debate, which generated more heat than light, on whether or not Australia was in recession in the 1990-91 financial year. At that time, there was the articulation of the conventional criteria that measure whether or not an economy is in recession; that is, two successive quarters of negative growth. It is a matter of fact that that is no longer the case in Australia and has not been for some time. We now seem to be in the absurd situation where there are only two categories of economy—those in recession and those booming. I regret to say that is not the case. We can have a continuum of classification, but there is, at the very least, a third category—those that are growing, but growing too slowly. This is the case for every Western economy that is not in recession, and there are many that are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we in recession?

—No. That is what I am trying to explain to honourable senators opposite, but they will not understand. There are many economies in recession; there are many others that are growing too slowly, of which we are one. There is no doubt that it would be desirable if Australia's economy was growing more quickly. It is growing—we are not one of those economies going down—but it is growing too slowly, although some bankers are warning that we may be about to grow too quickly. There are a number of examples I could refer to, but I will quote just one as I do not want to take up too much time.

PARA.TAB: Each month the Economist magazine does a survey of the 13 leading OECD economies. It is a survey of the international forecasts of the leading economists and their judgment as to the prospects for the 13 leading economies in the OECD, of which Australia is one. In its 8 August edition it published the forecasts for those 13 leading economies for 1992 and 1993. Which economy, of those 13, did they predict would grow most quickly in 1992? It was Australia's. Which economy, of those 13, did they predict would grow most quickly next year, 1993? It was Australia's again. That is not to say that our economy will be growing at a rate about which we can all be complacent—far from it. It means that our economy will be growing faster than any of the other 12 of the 13 leading OECD economies. That is not grounds for complacency and for saying, `There is no problem'. Too many Australians are unemployed. We are still growing too quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do we compare with Asia?

—Compared to some Asian economies, we are doing better, but compared to many we are not doing so well. It is because of our effective linking with Asia that we are able to grow more quickly than some of those other economies. We are able to plug in, with our exports, to those Asian markets. But it is a nonsense to say that if we are not booming we will remain in recession. We are growing too slowly. There is much work to be done. This Bill is part of doing that work. But to condemn someone for telling an unpalatable truth is the logical equivalent of applauding them for telling lies. That is a ridiculous proposal but it is the right of the Senate to pass it. If it does so, it will be treated with all due significance.

PARA.TAB: I want to conclude by saying once again the passage of these Bills is supported by everybody; they are going to be passed. There is debate about whether we should be funding these particular projects which this legislation is designed to fund. I am very firmly of the view that we should. It is my view that the process is appropriate: it gives the proper priority to the parliamentary process of appropriation of expenditure rather than the use of the AMF.

The timetable is conventional; there is nothing untoward about it. It is unprecedented to do it by this mechanism, but through the normal processes of the passage of appropriation we would not have been able to get the money available in time to fund these projects which are both socially worthwhile and creating jobs for Australians. The economic context is a debate we will have on a number of occasions, but the logic of the amendment leaves much to be desired. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Senator Kernot's amendment to Senator Short's amendment agreed to.
Senator Short's amendment, as amended, agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Consideration resumed from 7 October 1992, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —This piece of legislation is an omnibus Bill which was originally meant to deal with three separate items and now has had an amendment by the Government added to it so that we are dealing with a proposal to extend the life of the Automotive Industry Authority itself. We are dealing with a proposal regarding the Science and Industry Research Act and we are dealing with the most important part of this omnibus Bill which deals with weights and measures and the National Measurement Act. Added to that, and bearing no nexus at all, are proposed amendments concerning trademarks.

PARA.TAB: The two parts of the Bill to which the Opposition is strenuously opposed relate to the Automotive Industry Authority Act and the National Measurement Act. I intend to deal in some detail with both of those proposals as the Opposition believes that these amendments ought not to be passed. I can say at the outset that the proposal to extend the life of the Automotive Industry Authority to the year 2000 is opposed by us for the very simple reason that we are winding down tariffs with regard to the automotive industry, and by the year 2000 we will be looking at a top tariff rate of 5 per cent. Thus the continuation of the Authority, in the terms in which it is proposed in this Bill, from our stance serves no point at all. Furthermore, we point out that to continue the Authority would have a financial impact on running costs of about $1.1m per annum to cover just administrative expenses and salaries, and a further $215,000 for annual property operating expenses—expenses which quite clearly we do not think are justified.

The automotive industry has shown that the Government's policy of picking winners—and the Button car plan has been just that; it has been a picking winners exercise—has meant that Australians have paid more for locally made cars. It has promoted an atmosphere where efficiency is not the thing the industry has sought to pursue. In spite of the presence of high tariffs—in absolute terms and in relative terms—to the majority of Australian manufacturing industries, industry protection has failed to make a winner of the car industry. It has added $4,000 to the cost of a car in this country.

Besides this, the Industry Commission has found that the average replacement period for private vehicles on our roads is now 17 years. I can remember a time when Australians used to laugh at New Zealanders for driving old rust buckets. Now the boot is on the other foot and they laugh at us. In the OECD the average is between eight and 11 years, so we are exceeding even the highest figure of that average.

Clearly, the empirical evidence shows that tariffs—and tariffs are a tax; that is all they are—do not encourage efficiency. It is worth while looking at some of that empirical evidence. If one looks at the automation levels of our assembly plants and how they compare, for instance, with the NIEs—the newly industrialising economies—one will see that we are way behind those levels. It will be seen also that the industry has one of the highest rates of labour turnover and absenteeism, which is estimated to add $850 to the cost of each car manufactured.

Unfortunately, our quality rate, in comparative terms, ranks among the worst in the world. I know that there has been an endeavour on the part of local industry to raise the standard and the quality of the cars that are made. Nonetheless, the empirical evidence is that the average number of defects per 100 cars manufactured in an Australian assembly plant is 150. In the newly industrialising economies it is fewer than 100 errors, and in Japan it is only 60 errors per 100 manufactured vehicles. In terms of quality, it is no wonder that imported cars are taking a greater share of the vehicle market. It is simply a question of quality and not a question of tariff tax.

Our poor performance was confirmed in a study last year by the Swiss Lausanne Business School, which assessed the international competitiveness of the various countries manufacturing automobiles. Australia ranked third last: we beat only Brazil and Mexico. With this sort of record, one can only say that the Button car plan, a picking winners exercise, has been a dismal failure. This part of the Bill, which would seek to extend the life of part of that plan, that is, the Authority itself, is from our point of view a waste of taxpayers' money in spending that additional $1.1m a year to keep it in business.

If one looks at the Industry Commission calculations on the effect of maintaining the Government's policy, that is, to maintain a 15 per cent tariff rate until the year 2000, one finds that that would create an effective rate of protection of some 30 per cent, when the rest of industry in this country will be attracting a rate of only around 5 per cent. In other words, the pattern of picking winners means that the efficiency of the industry trails behind the other industries which are competing for capital and for labour. That, indeed, is why tariff tax and the policies of protection are so unfair: other industries in the economy have to compete at an unfair rate for capital and for human resources. Thus we will be moving to oppose the passing of those provisions in the omnibus Bill when we come to the committee stage.

Part 4 of the omnibus Bill relates to the Science and Industry Research Act 1949. Clauses 12 and 13 are simply of a technical nature and seek to amend the Act. Clause 13 relates to the office of the Chief Executive of the CSIRO and provides that decisions about the residual terms and conditions of the appointment shall be made by the Minister rather than the Governor-General. This proposed amendment merely brings the CSIRO into line with other current legislative practice, and is not opposed by the coalition.

Then we come to, in my opinion, the most important part of the Act, which deals with the National Measurement Act 1960. Until recently, the question of weights and measures and the National Measurement Act had not attracted much attention, including mine. It has been an area that people might have thought was rather grey and not of interest. Yet, once one starts to go into the ramifications of these amendments, one sees that this is part of the new protectionism—the non-tariff barrier.

The proposed amendments, which are contained in part 3 of the Bill, affect the operations of the National Standards Commission. It was not until I was approached by the Weighing Industry Association of Australia that it was revealed to me just what over-regulation of standards in weights and measures is proposed and just how this can impact upon industry.

Clearly, the Government has failed to appreciate that the inefficient over-regulation of measuring instruments leads to greater costs for manufacturers, who must either transfer those costs onto consumers or cut back in other areas such as labour, which can ultimately lead to greater unemployment. In the Estimates Committee meetings, where we asked many questions of Mr Birch, of the Commission, we received unsatisfactory answers. I am amazed to have received by fax today a letter—a nine-page epistle—written by the Minister, Senator Button, and dated yesterday, attempting at this late stage to answer some of the criticisms put forward by the Weighing Industry Association. The letter also fails to meet the objections that the Association raised to this legislation.

During this worst recession we are having—the one `we had to have' but which we have been told recently is now over, except that we have not bothered to tell the one million people who are unemployed—there cannot be a worse time to put further burdens on industry. Yet that is precisely what the Government is choosing to do.

It has been the concern of the measuring industry that excessive time has been taken to establish Australia's uniform trade measurement system. The system has been agreed upon by the States and is to be coordinated by the National Standards Commission. State based legislation has been slow in coming, and the industry complains of differences in procedures between the States and excessive costs in some areas—all valid criticisms. In particular, there have been difficulties arising from variations between States as to fees, accreditation criteria, and availability of verification and certification test procedures. This Bill represents in its very worst form an attempt to achieve uniformity. By its regulations it attempts to bring about a system that is more stringent and allows for further overregulation by delegated legislation.

Those of us who sit on the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances are always concerned by the fact that we encounter from time to time, too regularly, the situation where regulations are doing what ought to be in the Act. When these regulations finally come before that Committee I will be making very careful scrutiny of them to see whether they infringe the principles of that Committee.

The current trade measurement system includes an approval of patent procedure, where each model and capacity of weighing instrument is required to be certified. Before the certification period expires, the procedure must be carried out again to ensure that the instrument conforms to current National Standards Commission requirements. This procedure amounts to overregulation by international standards, as other countries provide for a certification period of 10 years followed by a much less severe renewal.

A fundamental concern of the weighing industry is that, although Australia is a signatory to the International Convention on Legal Metrology, that Convention is interpreted in an overrigid fashion in this country and is superimposed by further requirements by the National Standards Commission. At times, this has led to the absurd outcome where the Commission would not accept characters of 3.7 millimetres on legend notices and insisted upon 4 millimetres height.

The weighing industry was not even consulted in the preparation of this Bill. That became quite evident during the Estimates hearings. Indeed Senator Button himself, in a letter he wrote to the Weighing Industry Association on 8 September, recognised that there was no consultation. In that letter, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Your Association has also criticised the lack of consultation on the legislative amendment, and expressed fears that this is a means for the Commission to introduce a load cell pattern assurance scheme by stealth. I understand the Commission accepts that consultation on the legislative amendments was deficient and more attention will be paid to informing and consulting stakeholders in future.

That is a bit like shutting the gate after the horse has bolted. According to the weighing industry, the strictness of the National Standards Commission's interpretations of the Convention I mentioned previously, combined with the levels of approval fees and other National Standards Commission charges in the present recession, is putting excessive pressure on the industry, which is largely comprised of small business. Indeed, many of the firms are finding it increasingly difficult to remain viable.

PARA.TAB: To give an example to back up that proposition, the weighing industry has been disadvantaged by the rigid interpretation of international recommendations relating to the humidity test, which is applied to instruments intended for use in supermarkets. A test of the duration of four days, at 40 degrees celsius, at a relative humidity at 93 per cent, has been required by the Commission. Surely that is an excessive requirement.

Proposals for load cell sampling have also been put up by the Commission in a way that would be very costly in terms of time and resources. Not only was the standard itself excessive, but the National Standards Commission proposed to charge a fee of $1,550 for each sample load cell tested, irrespective of model capacity. Such strict tests are a costly impost upon business in the industry that ultimately transfers to consumers the high costs.

A large part of the overregulation imposed by the Commission is brought about by the patronising notion that the National Standards Commission exists to protect the interests of consumers. Wrong. It does not occur to the Government, or indeed to the Commission, that there is such a thing as an overly accurate instrument or an overly rigid standard; nor does it occur to the Commission that the very best form of consumer protection is to enable freer competition to give consumers a greater range of choice at more competitive prices. It is not logical to accept that the measurement for trade use dictates the production of instruments capable of accurate results to satisfy worldwide requirements. There is a demonstrated demand for such accuracy. As a matter of principle, I believe that this will be provided via the market mechanism more accurately than by some bureaucratic determination of the Standards Commission.

Perhaps some of these problems could be overcome by greater representation on the Commission of the measuring and weighing industries and relatively less control from those with a purely academic, scientific or bureaucratic focus. It does seem to be a constant criticism that the people who are actually in the business not only have not been consulted but also are not represented. Presently there is only one commissioner drawn from the measuring industry, and that commissioner is in the petroleum industry. There are no representatives from the weighing industry per se. Thus the composition of the Commission is out of balance, given that about one-third of the Commission's activities relate directly to the viability of the trade measurement industry. Surely this imbalance must be rectified. An overly scientific focus has been at the expense of firms that operate in the weighing and measuring industry. The losers at the end of the day are the consumers.

The Bill itself contains, amongst other things, powers that will enable us to search and seize. It has a very broad-ranging power to make regulations which, in my view, at this stage ought to be more properly in the Bill. We will see when they are finally made. The current arrangements for the checking of equipment, as I have said, and compliance tests are presently carried out by the State authorities and not by the National Standards Commission. The amendments are aimed at transferring the compliance tests to the Commission so that they become a laboratory function rather than a field inspection, which is not a sound practice for the industry.

The Opposition's intention, as I said earlier, is in the committee stage to oppose these proposed amendments so that they would be effectively deleted. There is one further point I would like to bring forward with regard to this section of the Bill, and that is the question of cost. In the current appropriations, the National Standards Commission in the recent Budget gets an increase in operating expenses from $1.45m in 1991-92 to $2.17m in 1992-93. This represents a 50 per cent increase in operating expenses in one year alone. The Government should justify this dramatic increase. I assure the Commission that I will be pursuing this matter further in the Committee of the Whole following the Estimates reports. In particular, I would like some answers in light of the statement in the explanatory memorandum of the Bill before us today that there is no financial impact of the proposed changes.

I now turn to the proposed amendments to the Trademarks Act, which were received subsequently by way of an amendment by the Government. They propose to toughen up penalties for counterfeiting and forgery of trademarks for falsely describing imported goods or goods intended for export. I have no argument with the need for laws to protect property, which includes intellectual property. The Opposition will not be opposing these sections. But it concerns me personally that we intend to have available a prison sentence of some two years, which would mean that somebody who prints a T-shirt with the words `Hermes' or `Chanel' on it and sells it in Paddy's Markets could go to gaol. That to me seems to be a sledge-hammer to crack a nut.

The proposed amendment by the Democrats to increase the financial penalty to an even greater height will not be supported by the Opposition. As I said, we will not be opposing these proposed amendments, but I feel that they are excessive in treating the problem that they see needs to be rectified. I can only repeat that I find excessive the proposition of putting people in gaol for printing T-shirts and selling them in a market.

In conclusion, omnibus Bills of this nature I find poor legislative form. To bring together such disparate matters and put them in a single Bill, with the last one being tacked on only as an afterthought, I do not think shows that there is good management of the legislative program. As I said, the question of weights and measures is the most important part of the Bill, as it is onerous that it is not going to advantage the consumer and that it amounts to a non-tariff barrier. I have also said that this area of industry has not attracted much attention before. I would not like to see it overlooked again. When we look at the question of micro-economic reform and the need to make the cost of doing business cheaper, we simply do not need to be adding to the impost to business as we are by that section of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 amends six separate Commonwealth Acts. What seemed like an innocuous little omnibus Bill at first glance turned out to be bigger than Ben Hur. Lobbyists descended on to me like flies to bad meat. Rolls of fax paper have been consumed, printing volumes of letters and information. Lots of people have been getting into a tizz. In the light of my experience with this piece of legislation I would have to agree with Senator Bishop: I have decided that I do not like omnibus Bills. There are so many different issues covered in such a wide-ranging fashion. It would be much simpler for all concerned if some of these omnibus Bills were split up into their separate components, especially where very complex amendments are proposed and where the issues are very different.

PARA.TAB: I shall deal with the proposed amendments in descending order of angst. Changes to the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 give the Minister the power to determine the remuneration of the chief executive of the CSIRO. This is a fairly valid and reasonable amendment and the Democrats will not be opposing it.Secondly, amendments to the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1985 extend the termination date for the Authority to 31 December 2000. This measure is in line with the Government's March industry statement correlating with the cessation of the tariff reduction program flagged in that announcement. The Automotive Industry Authority is charged with the responsibility of oversight of the Government's car plan, including the contentious tariff cuts. In the past we have said a lot about tariff cuts. We have suggested that in this time of high unemployment and in this recessionary climate there should be a 12-month pause in the Government's tariff cuts policy, but that has gone unheeded by this Government.

We have expressed our concern about this accelerated policy of tariff cuts; but we necessarily feel, be that as it may, that the AIA has an important role at this time in advising the Government on this important industry sector. In our view, there is nothing wrong with sectoral industry policies. Indeed, many of the newly industrialised countries, and not a few industrialised countries such as Japan and Germany, have built an economy on targeted policies aimed at developing a comparative advantage in selected industry sectors. We see nothing particularly wrong with that. The Democrats will therefore not oppose this minor amendment to the Automotive Industry Authority Act.

I am aware that abolition of the AIA is the Opposition's policy, and that is the reason for opposing the amendment to the Act. I say to the Opposition that we will not be supporting its amendment at this time, but we will look at the issue of abolishing the Automotive Industry Authority on its merits if and when the Opposition gets into government.
