At this time we are presented with a fairly minor amendment to a government program that we have decided to accept, and we will assess whatever the Opposition cares to throw at us after the election, if and when it is elected.

The proposed amendments to another four Acts—the National Measurement Act 1960, the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905, the Trade Marks Act 1955 and the Designs Act 1906—have some elements of controversy and have become objects of concern to industry groups. Over the past few weeks I have received strong representations from both the Weighing Industry Association and the Anti-counterfeit Action Group. The Anti-counterfeit Action Group has come to me in relation to those amendments to the Trade Marks Act and related Acts. I believe that there has been some justification for their concerns which I intend to examine herewith.

The amendments to the Trade Marks Act and related Acts have caused a great deal of concern in the clothing industry and in the retail industry. Here I must make some complaint on my own behalf about lack of consultation. The amendments to the first two Acts appeared just a day before they were due to be debated back in August. They were not included in the original package of Bills and no Alert Digest report was done on them, nor do they appear in the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report. They literally fell out of the sky. It would have been better for everyone if a little more time had been given to assess the implications of those amendments.

Further, amendments to the Designs Act were not given to me until the following Tuesday, 8 September. These were revised amendments that were circulated. I do appreciate that the Government has put off this legislation until now in order to allow honourable senators to have an opportunity to examine those amendments. However, at the time when it looked as though the Bill was on or off, it made it all very difficult to sit down and listen to the concerns of industry in a quiet and rational manner. It is very difficult to address legislation in a responsible way when amendments appear suddenly, especially when we are deluged by industry groups complaining about lack of consultation on their part and listing a whole raft of concerns.

It is indeed fortunate that the Bill was postponed until today, and I thank the Government for having listened to the many representations made by industry. It has enabled all of us to give the legislation some serious thought. I am very pleased, I have to say, that the Government is addressing the serious problems faced by Australian manufacturers and importers of popular fashion items, who have seen their profits and reputations eroded by cheap copies bearing their labels.

The amendments to the Trade Marks Act are based on the anti-counterfeiting forgery recommendations of the report of the working party to review the trademarks legislation. The report, entitled Recommended Changes to Australian Trademarks Legislation July 1992, prescribes substantially stiffer penalties for forging registered trademarks and dealing in counterfeit goods.

The amendments to the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act substantially increase the penalties under the Act. The amendments to the Designs Act were caused by two recent court decisions which had the unfortunate effect of invalidating many registered designs. This error has now been corrected. For far too long the Australian Government and the legal system have condoned the import, manufacture and sale of cheap copies by failing to implement substantial fines and gaol terms. Turning a blind eye to the wider implications of this trade, the Government has ignored the lost jobs, lost tax revenue, damage to small business and danger in the use of faulty counterfeit parts, particularly in planes and cars.

These three Acts are vitally important. This trade in fakes must be stopped. The footwear and clothing industry is perhaps the most visible sufferer from imported and locally manufactured fake trademarks. Clothes can be imported cheaply from overseas and sold cheaply at markets, stalls and the like, thereby violating the intellectual and trade property of legitimate business operations. These amendments are an important non-tax, non-tariff measure which will protect Australian industry without passing costs on to consumers. Legitimate Australian businesses are finding it hard enough to survive in the recession without being ripped off by the unscrupulous use of fake labels.

As it stands, this Bill concentrates more on penalties for counterfeiting and forgery of trademarks and for falsely describing imported goods or goods intended for export. I have been advised that local manufacturers of fake goods would already be covered under the concepts of `forgery' and `falsely applied' used in section 98 of the Trade Marks Act. So at this stage there is no need to move further on that point. The Anti-counterfeit Action Group estimates that there are around 500 manufacturers of fake goods in Australia, and that an individual selling 1,000 items per week will earn almost $300,000 per year in cash, with minimum overheads, as these businesses are generally operated by families working a different market every day of the week. Multiply that by several hundred markets operating Australia-wide and the scale of the rip-off operation can be clearly seen.

Since this Bill came to my attention several weeks ago there has been quite a deal of media coverage of the problems faced by importers and manufacturers of popular brand goods. Overseas manufacturers such as Coca-Cola, Cardin, Rolex, Reebok, et cetera, spend millions of dollars protecting their brand names from fakes, yet they have still been unable to stem the tide. They quote as a major reason the fact that the law does not have strong penalties and that judges do not view this white collar crime with the same abhorrence as they view most violent forms of criminal activity.

I hope the judiciary will realise that there is a trickle-down effect with this type of crime that impacts much further than is immediately apparent. They need to impose stronger sentences and fines than they have in the past to deter these criminals. The legislation now before us will strengthen considerably those penalties. However, it is our belief that the proposed penalties are insufficient, and we will be moving more amendments to address this.

The second amendment I shall move relates to the test of reasonableness in relation to knowledge of whether a trademark was registered or not. This amendment springs from concerns raised by the Anti-counterfeit Action Group that the existing amendment proposed by the Government could provide a loophole for those seeking to defend themselves in a counterfeit action. The reasonableness test will ensure that those acting illegally will have to satisfy this criteria rather than hide behind language barriers and pleadings of ignorance, as has been the case in the past. This, we believe, is a sensible and simple amendment that we hope may have Government support.

The next set of amendments relates to the National Measurement Act, and Senator Bishop has already elaborated quite lucidly on the wide-ranging effects of those amendments. The amendments are to the National Measurement Act 1960 and will broaden the power and scope of the National Standards Commission. The Commonwealth, of course, does have power to legislate in regard to weights and measures, and this is enshrined in the Constitution under section 51(xv). The proposed amendments to the National Measurement Act 1960, while on the surface appearing to be innocuous, will have some far-reaching effects on the weighing industry, both in the apparent excess of regulation and the likely increased cost to industry.

Accurate measurement is very complex; far more complex than I would have ever thought possible. It is also vitally important, both to local consumers of weighed products, who require accurate measurement to ensure they are not being cheated by short weight, and to Australia's international trading partners, who need to be confident that measures made in Australia conform to international standards. In addition, measures are used for various legal purposes, such as breathalyser units and radar speed measurements, so it is important that the community can have confidence that measuring devices are accurate.

As I have said, it is crucial to Australia's trade performance and international competitiveness that we be seen to recognise international agreements such as the Convention Establishing an International Organisation of Legal Metrology—legal metrology, of course, being the field of law dealing with weights and measures. The Government is attempting to clarify the implementation of this Convention in Australia through the proposed amendments to this Bill.

While recognising the importance for Australia to be seen as firmly embracing international standards, some sections of the weighing industry in Australia have questioned the necessity for the excessive monitoring of the industry that these amendments may possibly bring about. Indeed, the National Standards Association has admitted that these Australian standards are breaking new ground. Whilst I admire the National Standards Association's aspiration to place Australia in the forefront of uncompromising international standards, I believe its timing is poor and its objectives very stringent. Australia is currently experiencing a severe recession and the weighing industry is very concerned that there will be a severe cost impact resulting from these amendments.

Much of this concern, I am afraid to say, has been largely due to the lack of consultation between members of the weighing industry and the National Standards Association. This has been acknowledged by both sides and it has been acknowledged by the Department of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). I believe that steps have now been taken to ensure that it does not happen again. I really do hope this is so because, as I have said, I think a lot of the problems with these amendments have stemmed from this lack of consultation. It will only be through consultation and perceived good will that changes will be implemented.

The current regime operates on the basis of an approval and certification of a pattern for a measuring instrument used for trade purposes only. The Act does not provide that measuring instruments used for trade be of an approved pattern. This is an important distinction to be drawn between the various Federal and State responsibilities for these matters—a distinction that I believe is drawn in this legislation.

It should be remembered that these amendments will allow the National Standards Commission to undertake measures to verify compliance with pattern approvals. The absence of this power previously has meant that the NSC has been unable to investigate offences and the amendments proposed will hopefully deal with these issues.

However, there has been a great deal of conflicting information about what this Bill seeks to do—information that I have been weighing up very carefully over recent weeks. The Weighing Industry Association claims that the Bill will implement a pattern assurance program for load cells with a scale of fees. However, I understand this proposal and its fee schedule was shelved in March this year as a result of industry outcry. It is to be hoped that if the Government does plan to introduce this pattern assurance program for load cells, more consultation will occur with the industry than has been the case in the past. The industry was right to withdraw the very heavy schedule of fees and that proposal, if in fact that lack of consultation had not occurred. It should be recognised that the NSC does not have the power to set fees and there is nothing in this Bill which gives it the power to do so in relation to the verification of pattern approvals.

I am concerned that, with the legislation on the table ready to be amended, some sections of the Weighing Industry Association have still not had their arguments resolved. I must point out that there are other sections of the weighing industry which are quite content with these proposed amendments, with one exception, and I have received letters confirming their approval. A faxed message was sent to the Minister from Mr Bill Wedderburn, the Managing Director of Wedderburn Scales who, in fact, does support the amendments proposed here. I did speak with him about this and he was very adamant that the amendments were needed. I would certainly commend his advice to the Senate.

I have been assured by the Minister and his Department that full consultation will take place when the associated regulations are being put in place. I will take close interest to see that this is indeed done. I have also been assured that for the Commission to establish a pattern assurance program, two requirements are necessary: the Commission would need to have the power to charge and to be able to obtain sample information. These powers have not been given to the Commission by these amendments.

However, I have a major concern with this legislation. I will be moving an amendment to delete one very small clause relating to the search and seize powers that will be given to the NSC. An increasing feature of legislation, not only in this Parliament but also in parliaments in other States, is that far more legislation is being written by bureaucrats in the form of delegated legislation than perhaps was the case 15 or 20 years ago. In relation to the search and seize powers, we have tremendous concerns that the powers to provide for regulations given in this Bill are very broad. In fact, it has been suggested to me that the search and seize powers are so broad that they are almost gestapo-like in their application. I suggest to the Minister that, if he wants to give the NSC powers to search and seize, we should be assessing those by way of legislation coming before this Parliament rather than by way of seeking to disallow regulations.

I also note that the issue of these search and seize powers was not picked up by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. That is a pity as the powers conferred here by regulation are tremendously wide and are not supported by the Australian Democrats. However, we will discuss that further in committee. I am not opposed to enforcement procedures being given to the NSC or its delegates but I am opposed to very wide regulatory powers being given to bureaucrats to draft regulations that should more properly be presented to this Parliament as legislation.

In concluding, I simply say that I have given very long and serious consideration to all sides of the argument on this Bill. I have come to the conclusion that the Democrats should support the bulk of the proposed amendments to the National Measurement Act, with the exception I have raised. It is important that our trading partners and the community have confidence in our weights and measures. It is important that the authorities that are given power to approve patents and verify those patents have the legislative ability to do so. I think these amendments will certainly allow the NSC to carry out those functions that previously it was believed it had but on which legal advice was received to suggest that it did not.

I believe that there is fault with the amendments before us in relation to the search and seize powers as they do not limit the length of time the Commission can hold weighing instruments for testing. There is nothing in the legislation about preventing the NSC from entering residential premises; there is nothing about a whole range of important civil liberties issues which I think need to be addressed by way of a further Bill.

I will present these amendments to the Senate in committee and hope that the Opposition will consider supporting a number of those in relation to both trade marks and the National Measurement Act. I commend the Bill and the amendments to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. Many of the issues have been canvassed fairly well, and I will go through them briefly. One of the major amendments considered here is an amendment to the Automotive Industry Authority Act to continue the life of the Automotive Industry Authority. That was a recommendation made to the Government by the Industry Commission. It is a recommendation the Government is keen to support because, throughout these debates on various sectors of industry, the question of informed comment about a variety of issues, as we have seen in the last few weeks, has become immensely important.

PARA.TAB: The Automotive Industry Authority has been a source of important statistics on the industry. It has had a close working relationship with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on global trends in the automotive industry. It has compiled a very useful set of measures for assessing quality in automotive manufacture. With changes in productivity improvements in design and so on, these are all crucial issues for an industry of this kind. It is very important to have objective measures of what has been happening. For that purpose, the life of the Automotive Industry Authority, in the view of the Government, should be extended. That is proposed in the Bill.

With regard to the amendments to the National Measurement Act, this is a discussion which I concede has engendered a lot of heat—and some light. Essentially, these provisions are designed to ensure that measurements are made on a consistent basis throughout Australia and are compatible with measurements in other countries. They seek to enforce, if that is the right word, our treaty obligations, and with the introduction of uniform trade measurement legislation they seek to ensure verification of measuring instruments for use for trade.

There are two issues in this. There is the question, first of all, of pattern assurance. I think there is sometimes some confusion between the process of pattern assurance and pattern compliance. The issue of pattern compliance is the one which raises the most concerns. That particularly relates to the search and seize provisions which Senator Sowada has referred to, which we will deal with in the committee stage of the Bill. I just make the point that it is of the utmost importance that we have the highest possible standards in Australia in relation to these matters, that these standards are enforced and that they are not capable of being rorted—if that is the right expression. One way of seeing that they are enforced, that compliance is carried out, is to provide the Commission with the right to check on compliance. Currently, no mechanism exists for instruments to be checked for compliance and I think it is important that there are appropriate mechanisms for that to happen.

There is a very minor amendment in the Bill relating to the Chief Executive of the CSIRO. There are also amendments which I will move on behalf of the Government to increase the penalties for counterfeiting and forgery of trademarks, and for falsely describing imported goods or goods intended for export, and to remedy an undesired effect of two recent Federal Court decisions in relation to the registrability of designs. These changes to the Trade Marks Act are based on the recommendations of the working party to review the trademark legislation, which recently reported to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free). The working party report recommended changes in the Australian trademarks legislation, and includes a number of recommendations to increase the present penalties for selling or importing counterfeit goods and for forging trademarks. So the penalties are made much stiffer, in line with the report recommendations. I announced, on behalf of the Government, an intention to carry out the recommendations as far as possible, and as soon as possible after the report was received. This legislation merely gives effect to that. I commend the second reading of the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum circulated on 19 August 1992, and a replacement supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to Government amendments and new clauses to be moved to this Bill.

PARA.TAB: Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2.
Amendment (by Senator Button) agreed to:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 2, page 1, lines 6, 7 and 8, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "2.(1) Subject to subsection (2), this Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.
"(2) Part 2B is taken to have commenced on 30 July 1975.".
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 3 and 4—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clauses 3 and 4, in part 2. We are taking this course of action to oppose the motion that they stand as printed rather than move an amendment to delete. The effect is the same.

—As I indicated in my speech at the second reading stage, the Democrats will not be supporting the deletion of these clauses. We accept that the Automotive Industry Authority has been put in place to oversee the administration of the Government's car plan and we accept that extending the life of the Automotive Industry Authority to the year 2000 is in line with the Government's announcement in the March industry statement. I am aware, however, that the Opposition's concern and its opposition to this clause stems from the Fightback proposal to abolish the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984. I have indicated to Senator Bishop and to the Opposition that we do not pass judgment on that question at this time but would, obviously, seek to assess the issue on its merits as and when the Opposition got into government. At this stage, we see no reason why the clause as printed should be opposed, and we will not be supporting the Opposition's move.

—I would like to say for the record that the reason why we oppose these clauses and why we wish them to be effectively deleted is that it is consistent with our policy on reducing tariffs to a maximum of 5 per cent by the year 2000, whereas the Government wishes to leave them at 15 per cent. We believe that to spend an additional $1.1m a year, plus property expenses, over that number of years is a waste of taxpayers' money and that ordinary Australians will have their opportunity enhanced to buy Australian-made cars more cheaply if the life of this Authority is not lengthened.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government certainly does not accept that these clauses should be deleted. The Opposition thrives on misinformation regarding the Australian car industry. The Automotive Industry Authority has been a source of objective information about a whole range of issues, and it has been partly its guidance that has brought the automotive industry in this country into very much better integration in the world automotive industry. That is something for which the Authority is to be very much congratulated. It performs a very useful function. It has nothing at all to do with the size of the tariffs we have as an end point. It has to do with whether we see this industry as operating as part of a global market, as it has to do, and whether we see it as being required to meet and be guided towards global standards in what it does. So we do not accept this opposition to the clauses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must answer the points made by Senator Button. If the aim of the Authority is to achieve world parity of standards, on that test alone its life ought not to be extended. It has clearly failed. During my speech at the second reading stage I gave some clear empirical evidence of how we rate on international standards in terms of errors per 100 cars. Where our error rate is 150 errors per 100 cars, in newly industrialising economies it is 100 per 100 cars, and in Japan it is 60 per 100 cars. We have a long way to go before we meet world's best standard, and I do not think the existence of the Authority is assisting in that endeavour.

PARA.TAB: Clauses agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 5 to 9—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is opposing clauses 5 to 9 in line with the statement I made in my speech in the second reading debate. We believe that the whole framework and the imposition of a much harsher regulatory system upon the weighing industry are not in the best interests of consumers or the industry itself. Therefore, we oppose clauses 5 to 9.

—The Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment to delete clauses 5 to 9. I said in my second reading speech that we believe that certification and verification of patterns of weights and measures are an important element of ensuring that consumers and our trading partners can have confidence in the weights and measures and in the regulatory regime surrounding weights and measures in Australia. While I understand where the concerns of Senator Bishop are coming from, we believe that these powers are necessary.

PARA.TAB: The particular clauses to which the amendments moved by the Opposition refer do not impose any specific financial impost on industry by way of additional costs or fees. We feel, after having examined the question fairly closely, that these powers of verification are certainly valid additional powers to be given to the NSC. They will ensure that those who are involved in the industry surrounding weights and measures will have to ensure that their weights and measures are complying with international standards and standards set by the Government. We will not be supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned in the second reading debate that yesterday, and only yesterday, the Minister had chosen to write a nine-page letter to the Weighing Industry Association, and only at page 5 does he get down to these specific concerns. One of the matters that the Weighing Industry Association raised with me, and presumably with Senator Sowada and the Government as well, was the question of whether or not there was power under the Constitution to implement this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Sowada dismissed the argument. I do not dismiss it out of hand and from the letter that Senator Button has written to the Weighing Industry Association he presumably does not dismiss it entirely either. It is on the question of acquisition of property without fair compensation that he has given ground. On page 6 of the letter that he wrote to the Association he says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to put the matter beyond doubt I have had the Commission prepare an amendment to provide for any seized measuring instrument to be returned and will move this as a Government amendment.
I would be interested in whether Senator Button could point that amendment out to me at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to Senator Bishop's statement about my having dismissed the Weighing Industry Association's concerns about the possible unconstitutionality of some of these amendments. I agree that the acquisition of property on just terms is a valid one. However, in relation to weights and measures, it is quite clear that the Constitution gives the Federal Government the power to legislate in respect of weights and measures. I do not believe that the acquisition on just terms issue relates to her specific request at this time to delete clauses 5 to 9, although, it does come into effect in her move to delete clause 10. But in respect of clauses 5 to 9, the issue of acquisition of property on just terms is not an issue. I believe that the Commonwealth is acting within its constitutional responsibilities in respect of these clauses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commission received advice from the Attorney-General about this matter, and I have nothing to add to what Senator Sowada has said on the question of legality. In relation to a question Senator Bishop asked about an amendment I referred to in the letter, and which I will move on behalf of the Government, I understand that Senator Sowada has an amendment she intends to move. If that is carried, as I believe it will be, the proposed amendment by the Government becomes redundant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Am I to understand that the answer to my question is that the amendment is not before us?
—That is right.

—I would also like at this stage again to draw attention to the Estimates hearings that related to this matter. I said in my speech in the second reading debate that many of the answers given by Mr Birch from the National Standards Commission were far from satisfactory. Members of the Weighing Industry Association read the Hansard, observed Mr Birch's answers, and have gone through them in great detail. They have given information which shows that his answers were far from satisfactory. If I said misleading, I would be generous; if I said untruthful, I might be getting closer to the mark. Accordingly, I seek leave to have incorporated into the Hansard 11 pages that comment upon many of the answers given by the National Standards Commission. When people read the Hansard they can judge just how good or how poor are the answers given by the Standards Commission, into whose hands it is proposed to put such enormous power.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Question by Senator Bishop and Reply by Mr J Birch
Issue A: Whether the NSC has issued documents in relation to the moral obligation of OIML convention signatories to implement convention. (Hansard Reference): A157-A158

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Standards Commission has issued standards saying that Australia is morally obliged to follow IOLM (= OIML) recommendations?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—The convention basically says that the signatories to the convention will use their best endeavours to implement and harmonise the implementative requirements as part of international harmonisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you have put out a statement saying that Australia is morally obliged?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—I am not aware of any statement that we have put out on such a thing, no.

TALK.START.PARA: —What statement have you put out?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—We have not put out any statement. The convention was acceded to in 1959 by the Government at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you recently put out anything saying that you are obliged to follow the recommendations of that body?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—It may be in our annual report now. We usually make some reference to the International Organisation for Legal Metrology and its purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not published anything other than what is in your annual report?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—I am certainly not aware of anything, no. Put it this way: we put out international recommendations on the organisations and we write publications on them. I am not aware of any particular statement. But I would be only too happy to—

SPEECH.PARA: Commentary by Weighing Industry Association of Australia: Mr Birch states in his evidence that he is not aware of any document which the NSC has issued in relation to a moral obligation on signatories to follow IOLM (= OIML) obligations. In fact, Circular 335 issued by the National Standards Commission (Annexure A) clearly states in its second paragraph that the NSC is morally obliged to adopt OIML recommendations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Issue B: The position with respect to Pattern Assurance in the European Community. (Hansard Reference): A158

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to look at the international scene for pattern approval. There is a proposal in the European Community to standardise 10-year periods of validity for pattern approvals. This has been the case in the United Kingdom and Europe. In the United States, pattern approval is for the life of the model without any time limitation. Why has Australia chosen a six-year period with a very expensive review to achieve a further six years.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—I am not aware that that is the case in the European Community. I do not believe that it is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Commentary by Weighing Industry Association of Australia: The WIAA has made an independent investigation of the matter vis-a-vis the United Kingdom. In a fax from a prominent weighing industry company Mettler-Toledo Ltd (UK), the U.K. and European positions in relation to pattern approval are set out. Ten year period is accepted with "no further testing required in theory." (Annexure B1). At an Industry Liaison Committee (ILC) meeting on 26 August 1992, the proposed EC Directive in this matter was tabled. This document was sent to WIAA by Mr Birch himself on 12 August 1992. (Annexure B2). WIAA has also obtained a copy of a letter addressed to Mr Birch dated 14 September 1992 from Toledo Scale (Australia) Ltd (Annexure B3) clearly identifying: (1) significantly less costs in United States; (2) stating (of first sentence p2) that US approvals are indefinite and never expire.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Issue C: Recommendations emanating from A Macquarie University Seminar (7-9 July 1982). (Hansard Reference): A160

TALK.START.PARA: —You made the statement that the industry had urged you to get greater powers. Could you give me some evidence of that?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—Can I give you an example of how industry has asked for that power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, evidence.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—This goes back some time. Basically, the difficulties arose in the early eighties when industry was concerned about the variety of interpretations by the States in terms of compliance of instruments in the field. As a result of a conference held at Macquarie University in 1983, one of the recommendations made there was that, in fact, the Commission should be made responsible for all the compliance of instruments in the field and that power should be transferred quite unequivocally to the Commission. . . ..

SPEECH.PARA: Commentary by Weighing Industry Association of Australia: Mr Birch's reference is presumably to Paper 3 delivered at a Macquarie University Conference held in 1982 (not 1983). (Annexure C1). The paper also recommended greater reliance on industry self-regulation. Industry, however, has always been concerned at the cost implications of on-site testing carried out after approval of a pattern. As long ago as 1986, at an ILC meeting held on 28 May 1986, industry's concerns with costs and the extension of the NSC's role were expressed: see minutes from meeting, p.2 (Annexure C2). See also Annexure G.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Issue D: Comparisons with Current State Legislation. (Hansard Reference): A161

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not talking about the pattern approval. I am talking about the right the Commission will get to randomly enter and take equipment. There is no stricture on when you may exercise that, is there?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—Not at present, no. As I say, it is very similar to the requirements in the uniform trade measurement legislation and, if the Commission Western Australias really concerned, it could ask the State authorities to exercise their powers and to enter and seize the property. That is sections 60 to 64 of the uniform trade measurement legislation in Australia, with similar provisions in all other trade measurement legislation in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Commentary by Weighing Industry Association of Australia: Sections 60-61 of the Trade Measurement Act, 1989 (SA Version) appear as Annexure D. It is clear that the powers there conferred are not the same as those proposed. There are important differences; namely:

PARA.TAB: 1. An inspector's powers under Section 61 are limited to measuring instruments used for trade. The proposed amendments to Section 19A(1)(b) of the National Measurement Act will ensure the NSC's investigatory powers apply to all measuring instruments.

2. Section 60 (2) provides residential premises may not be entered except with the occupier's consent or with a search warrant. In the proposed Section 19AAB, the reference to "premises" is not apparently so limited.

3. Under Section 61, an instrument may only be taken if an "inspector reasonably believes an offence against the Act" has been committed. The power in the proposed Section 19AAB is not limited to sampling in cases of suspected offences.
4. State laws are not subject to the (federal) constitutional requirement (Section 51 pl (xxxi) of the Constitution) prohibiting acquisitions of property without just compensation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Issue E: Use of Sampling Powers. (Hansard Reference): A162-A163

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you need them then (viz, sampling powers).

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—Because most regulatory authorities believe they need these powers as a way of providing a flexible regulatory response. To an extent, it is like asking, "Why do you have the offences provisions?" You have the offences provisions to make it clear that it is an offence, but the offences provisions without the ability to actually fully prosecute them do not mean very much and they—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Birch—
—Order! Mr Birch has not finished his answer.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—Generally, most regulatory authorities in Australia have such powers, but very few of them use them. That has been fully analysed in a study by the Australian Institute of Criminology in 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a legislator I am not in the business of handing out powers or debating issues where we give powers to people who do not intend to use them. That is bad legislation. That is not what we are paid to do.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—We would intend to use them in the most difficult cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not say that a minute ago. You said you did not intend to use them.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—No, I said we have not used them up to now.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. You said the new powers you do not intend to use.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—We have powers under the Act with regard to pattern approval to retain instruments which we pattern approve. That has been in our Act since 1965, but we have never retained those instruments. We have always returned them to the submitters, but it is still a power which may be important for a particular type of instrument.

SPEECH.PARA: Commentary by Weighing Industry Association of Australia: The answer in this regard runs the risk of giving a false impression:

PARA.TAB: 1. The powers (cf commentary in relation to Issue D (above)) are wider than those given to State regulatory agencies.
2. The powers of sampling do not relate as such to criminal offences, or to suspicion of the commission of a criminal offence, but are much wider.
3. The power currently available under the Act is a power to prescribe regulations for the retention of instruments and:
(a) it is not clear that any regulation in this regard has been made;
(b) it is a "one off" power used in relation to one sample of an instrument for an entirely different purpose; ie initial pattern approval; and
(c) it may be constitutionally invalid for the same reasons: ie an authorising an expropriation of property without just compensation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Issue F: Are Good Relations Maintained with Industry by NSC? (Hansard Reference): A163

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Birch you can go on at great length, however, you told me a moment ago that these were new powers and you were not going to use them. I said that legislators are not in the business of doing that.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—If I said that, I would have to say that that is not the emphasis. They are powers which we see as reserve powers which are necessary for an organisation such as ours to have, but they are not the sorts of powers you would wish to use. It is much better to work the system on the basis of ensuring that the system continues to operate. We have tried to keep a very good relationship with all our submitters and solve problems as they come up without going to the courts to solve those problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Birch, with respect, this is gobbledegook; but we will move on.

SPEECH.PARA: Commentary by Weighing Industry Association of Australia: The WIAA has multiple objections to the manner in which the NSC operates. First, it is clear that the NSC attempted to instigate a random sampling procedure in the past without legal authority. Annexure F(1) is a copy of a document issued by the NSC, namely, detailing a proposal to instigate random sampling. (cf p.3)

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the WIAA were not informed of the current amendments (for which, see Issue H). The NSC Bulletin was highly misleading in its treatment of the effect of the amendments currently proposed. Annexure F(2) is an extract (p.2) of NSC Bulletin, Issue 32, received by the WIAA in August 1992, when the amendments were already before the Parliament. There is no mention therein of the sampling powers proposed to be included.
The Amendments have been buried in an omnibus Bill.

The WIAA has had to seek legal advice to understand the purport of the amendments. Mr Birch represented to the Committee and has represented to WIAA that the amendments do not seek to introduce a "random sampling" procedure. This is simply untrue as he was forced to acknowledge to the Committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Issue G: The WIAA is represented on the NSC and has the opportunity to be represented in all matters. (Hansard Reference): A165

TALK.START.PARA: —So you made a deliberate decision not to consult with the Weighing Industry Association?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—Not a deliberate decision, no.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was it—a half deliberate decision?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—Put it this way; the National Measurement Act has been amended every year for the last five years and there has been no discussion in industry on any of those amendments, even though they related to increasing the penalty provisions and a whole host of things. That has not been seen as an issue of importance to industry, because the amendments have always been within the ambit of the policies which the industry had established.

TALK.START.PARA: —One set in 1959. Are you really saying you thought that you did not need to consult with the industry because it has been your practice not to so consult? Is that the justification?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—No, we have a structure within the Commission which provides the consultative mechanism. The legislative amendments are dealt with at the commission level. As such, we have a representative fall the various groups on the Commission. . . . . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting power to randomly enter and seize. You will impose great cost burdens on the industry. The interests of the weighing industry as a whole and the petroleum industry, which you cite as being 40 per cent relevant to this matter, are not the same. You have not consulted with the industry and you tell me that you did not bother to consult with the office of regulation review because you did not think it was anything new.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—I did not quite say that. What I said was that the Commission has in its membership representatives from the industry who look after those interests of the industry. The view of the industry representative on the Commission was that it was well established policy of the industry and, therefore, it was really just an amendment to clarify a piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Commentary by Weighing Industry Association of Australia: The WIAA currently has only one representative on the NSC, Commissioner Ian Scott. His expertise lies, however, in the field of Petroleum Equipment, not in the area of weighing instrumentation. The WIAA supported the re-appointment of Mr Scott, but only because it feared it would not otherwise be represented at all. The WIAA has long been requesting additional representation of the NSC, but has not received it. Annexure G is a copy of WIAA's notes of meeting with Minister S Crean on 25 June 1990, which reveal WIAA's concerns.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Issue H: Has there been consultation with WIAA before amendments reached Parliament and is there support for the amendments in Industry. (Hansard Reference): A164-A165

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some good empirical evidence for it. I ask you first, Mr Birch, whether at any stage you consulted with the Weighing Industry Association prior to the Bill coming into Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—The Weighing Industry Association has been campaigning for 10 years for these types of amendments. As I say, a large number of the Weighing Industry Association members are strongly in support of them. I think we should get the empirical evidence. The trade measurement industry is made up of about 40 per cent of the weighing industry; about 40 per cent made up of the petroleum industry; and 20 per cent from other areas. The petroleum industry strongly supports the amendments. Large sections of the weighing industry support it, and the only manufacturer in Australia who is not a member of the Weighing Industry Association strongly supports it, and a number of the very long time members of the Weighing Industry Association have strongly supported those amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that information, but would you answer my question. Did you consult with the Weighing Industry Association and, if so, when?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—The specific amendments were not brought before the Weighing Industry Association because it was well within the policy it would have been well established.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you did not consult with them?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—Not at that time, no. Part of the reason for that is that the amendments had been dealt with at the National Standards Commission. The National Standards Commission is a fairly broadly representative body with a representative from the trade measurement industry on it.

SPEECH.PARA: Commentary by Weighing Industry Association of Australia: Mr Birch finally, but only under repeated questioning answered (correctly) that there had been no prior consultation with WIAA. Upon learning of the amendments, WIAA sought a meeting with NSC to discuss the amendments on 1 September 1992. Senator Button later alleged this amounted to "belated consultation". Annexure H(1) is a copy of a letter received by WIAA from him in response to a letter we sent inquiring about the lack of consultation. Annexure H(2) is a copy of the reply we subsequently sent the Senator. We have yet to receive an answer from him explaining why there was a lack of consultation in the first place.

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch alleges that the Weighing Industry has sought (even vigorously) the proposed powers for the NSC. Annexure H3 is a copy of a letter WIAA sent to all nine members required to be submitters requesting them to outline their views on the amendments. The nine replies from WIAA members are annexed thereto. WIAA has been assured orally that no member supports the amendments to introduce sampling and has received written replies from seven of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you aware that the weighing industry has sought legal advice on the constitutionality of the proposed law and whether the legislation or the regulations made thereunder would provide for the acquisition of property under Section 51 of the Constitution?

PARA.TAB: Mr Birch—I am aware that that advice has been sought; I have been given a letter about that particular advice. I have also received many representations from members of the Weighing Industry Association supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Commentary by Weighing Industry Association of Australia: WIAA is unaware of support for the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed that the Democrats will not be supporting me in opposing the clauses of the Bill that relate to the weighing industry, particularly clauses 5 to 9. Perhaps we might have more luck on clause 10.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That clauses 5 to 9 stand as printed.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 10, page 4, proposed subsection 19AAB(3), lines 36 to 41, omit the subsection.

SPEECH.PARA: My amendment seeks to delete from the Bill the very broad search and seize powers that will be contained in the regulations. As I said in the second reading debate, what we have seen over the last decade or so is a proliferation of delegated legislation, which is essentially legislation written by bureaucrats and Ministers. The Parliament does have the authority to disallow delegated legislation, but I think everybody would agree that disallowance is a somewhat more difficult mechanism in the Parliament than simply scrutinising legislation and dealing with it as it is presented to us through the very extensive methods of debate here in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned at the very broad gestapo-like powers given to bureaucrats to make regulations to search and seize without actually having any details of what those regulations might contain. For example, as I said in the second reading debate, there is nothing here about how long the authorities may keep weighing instrument for testing. It may be that the regulations could provide for a maximum period of six months. In our view, it would be totally unacceptable for a company to be without its very important instruments for such a long time. There is nothing is this regulatory power that will actually limit the amount of time for which the National Standards Commission or its delegated authorities can keep instruments.

There is nothing about restricting the right of the NSC to enter residential premises. I would draw the attention of the Senate to clauses in the Trade Measurements Act in South Australia which provide a very specific power of entry to residential premises. That is enshrined in legislation in South Australia. What we are doing here is basically giving the power to bureaucrats to make regulations that we may or may not disallow at some stage in the future. As a legislator, I would prefer to have those very important powers scrutinised by this Parliament in a further Bill.

I have already indicated to the Government, in my speech at the second reading stage, that we would be more than happy to look at how these compliance measures may be enforced by further amendment to the National Measurement Act, but we are at this stage not prepared to accept the very broad and sweeping powers here given to bureaucrats to make regulations to search and seize premises, without knowing something of what those regulations might contain, without having some input and without having some assurance that the regulations will be drafted in consultation with the industry.

I know that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has expressed concern that the initial amendments to the National Measurement Act were not drafted in consultation. The Government has taken steps to rectify that and I have been assured that further amendments to the National Measurement Act will be drafted in consultation, as will the regulations. I have to say, however, that the experience on this matter so far has not been a good one. I am a little nervous to accept the assurances I have been given so far that consultation will take place when the Government has a very sorry record of consultation to this point.

I recognise that the Government needs to have powers of enforcement, but we are very reluctant to provide for these powers of enforcement by way of regulation. It is our hope that the Government will present to us at some later stage an amendment to the National Measurement Act that will provide for these enforcement powers, spelling them out in detail so that the Parliament and honourable senators can scrutinise those powers in detail, not simply leaving it up to bureaucrats and to a disallowance motion at some later stage.

We believe that the proposal is totally unacceptable and simply represents the greater proliferation of delegated legislation, which takes legislating out of the hands of the Parliament and puts it into the hands of bureaucrats. That is something that should be opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Sowada has said it all. There is no need for me to say much more, other than this: over many years, this issue has come up before this chamber, on many occasions and in respect of a variety of issues and a variety of questions. It is about time that the Senate took note of many of the statements and recommendations that have been made about this issue, which really concerns the defence of individuals' rights and, indeed, the defence of the rights of the Parliament over those of the executive government.

PARA.TAB: I think even the executive government should baulk at the proposition that we in this chamber should buy a pig in a poke, yet that is precisely what we have been asked to do in this legislation. We are being asked to approve of wide-ranging search and seizure powers in respect of regulations we have not even seen. I agree with what Senator Sowada said. Of course we all know that regulations are able to be disallowed, but one of the problems about that is that it does not enable this Parliament to engage in a meaningful way in discussing the merits of particular regulations, where some of them may be satisfactory and others not.

I have, as honourable senators know, promoted a Bill which would enable this Parliament to do more than it is capable of doing now in respect of regulations. I suppose it is about time that Bill received some discussion in this chamber. I am concerned that on this occasion, however, we are being asked to approve of wide-ranging powers of search and seizure in areas about which we have no accurate knowledge at this present point of time. Therefore, I support Senator Sowada's amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sowada's remarks relating to her second amendment, which she has moved first, indicate that she accepts the need for appropriate compliance but disagrees with the methodology of getting to that level of appropriateness. Because of that the Government will accept this amendment from the Democrats. Regarding Senator Sowada's first amendment, which she did not speak to, that seems to me to be in the same spirit. She may want to make a second speech about it; I do not. I indicate now that we accept that amendment too.

—The Opposition had indicated in the document circulated that it would be opposing this clause as well. In having discussions with Senator Sowada, she and I are in agreement about the question of the search and seizure powers and the manner in which they are proposed to be imposed. I have already expressed my lack of confidence in at least parts of the National Standards Commission. I think the best way to deal with this matter is for me to have it on the record that we had chosen the method of opposing the motion that the clauses stand as printed as the method of deleting the clauses.

PARA.TAB: In view of the fact that we are taking the amendment prior to testing our opposition to the clauses, I think commonsense dictates that I indicate we will agree to Senator Sowada's amendments concerning clause 10, which will avoid the need for a division and speed up the process. I put on the record that we are opposed to the clause in total, but because of discussions that have taken place, I will agree to her amendment concerning that clause.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 10, page 4, after proposed subsection 19AAB(5), add the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: (6) Any regulations made under this section must provide adequate safeguards for the rights of persons affected.".

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that the Government has already indicated that it will accept this amendment as well. It again relates to the regulatory power given to the bureaucrats by this proposed new subsection. In the light of the very broad and sweeping powers that were proposed to be given, it is my feeling that some signal needs to be sent to the Department that this Parliament will not tolerate regulations that will ride roughshod over the rights of individual citizens and of business. Whilst it may seem on the surface to be a fairly commonsense amendment and one that presumably the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would take into account when examining legislation, it is our belief that the Department does need to be given a very clear signal that we will not tolerate the trampling of individual rights. I ask the Opposition to consider supporting this in the light of the arguments it has already suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my capacity as Deputy Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, I have to say that the Committee prides itself on looking after the rights of individuals in accordance with our four principles. The amendment Senator Sowada has moved is in no way in contradiction of what I have to say. Therefore, I can see no reason why we ought not to support it as it does no harm.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 11.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, the Opposition is opposed to this entire part of the Bill. Clause 11 is the clause that gives further regulation making powers. We are opposed to it as it will be, in part, the instrument of bringing on the harsh and unconscionable regime to which we singularly object. Therefore, we oppose the printing of the clause.

—We will not be supporting the Opposition's move to have this clause deleted from the Bill. I have expressed our concern already about the search and seizure powers and we have moved to have that clause deleted. However, in so far as clause 11 goes, we can see no major problems with that and, therefore, we will not be supporting the Opposition. I do not know whether the Opposition intends to call a division on this but, given that some honourable senators are at a press conference—the same press conference that was interrupted by the previous division—perhaps they might like to reconsider.
—I do not think that consideration of a press conference is a good reason to pass bad legislation. We will be calling a division.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak today on a matter which is of great significance to development and management in Australia. That is, of course, the decision for the operation of the Marandoo mine in Western Australia to go ahead. I want to put to rest a few of the furphies that have been put around about the situation there in regard to sacred sites and various species. I shall refer directly to what Hamersley has done to address these issues.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate Hamersley and, in particular, Tony Finucane on his patience and perseverance and the way he has operated throughout this whole unfortunate episode. The first thing that needs to be understood very clearly with regard to the operations of Hamersley at Tom Price and the various iron ore operations there is that, had Marandoo not gone ahead, Tom Price and that operation would have been finished by the year 2000, or within approximately nine years. The fact that Marandoo will now go ahead means that its life has been extended to around the year 2050 and a significant number of jobs will be created. That is the first of the furphies I want to put to rest.

Before I talk about the new jobs, I want to talk about the old jobs. Currently the Hamersley operation employs some 15,000 people—12,000 of them indirectly in jobs off site and 3,000 directly on site. Had Marandoo not gone ahead, all of those jobs would have been gone by the year 2000. But there would have been a phasing down period, one would have anticipated, of three or four years or maybe even less, because Tom Price was ceasing to be an open-cut mine that could provide the quality of iron ore required for export to Japan. So we would have seen a very rapid run-down in those jobs, which would have exacerbated the situation.

On the other side of the coin, the development of Marandoo will mean that in the first two years of the construction phase there will be some 4,000 jobs created—800 on site and at least 3,200 off site in fabrication and the other things that need to be done in establishing a mining operation. On top of that, there will be an additional 350 permanent jobs created, with the protection of those jobs I have spoken about.

What needs to be understood about the Hamersley mining operation in the Pilbara is that, very simply, apart from the high grade ore that has come from Tom Price and the high grade ore that will come from Marandoo, the other larger iron ore deposits that have been discovered and are being mined are not of a suitable quality to meet the export standards required by the Japanese market, which is our principal market, and other markets around the world. It is needed for mixing with that iron ore so that the operation can continue. That is the second furphy I want to kill.

We read reports in the press and hear comments by various individuals that there is plenty of iron ore to meet the export requirements, but it is not true. It is just not true of the discovered iron ore bodies that are required to bring that iron ore up to grade. As I have already said, Hamersley's mining operation there would have been finished in nine years. The implications of that go far beyond job creation and maintenance of those jobs. It would also impact dramatically on Australia's export earnings and, in particular, those of a remote part of Western Australia.

The third furphy I want to deal with is the situation with regard to sacred sites. It has been reported consistently that there will be interference with sacred sites by the development of that mine. That is absolutely false. I believe there have been nine studies done into the area since 1975, there have been 12 reports commissioned from those studies since that time, and within the project area there are no sacred sites.

It is also worth noting, in terms of the operations there, that there are no sites of significance either—which sits alongside what I have already mentioned about sacred sites. But Hamersley has undertaken to make sure that buffers are kept around archaelogical sites that are outside the area and that they will be protected. It is going beyond the requirements to meet the concerns of the elders who have inhabited the area.

It is worth noting that Tony Finucane, on behalf of Hamersley, received yesterday a fax from the nine elders that company representatives have been dealing with in that respect, congratulating them for the way they have conducted themselves in at last achieving the development of Marandoo, which will give employment opportunities to the Aboriginals who live in the area. It has been a policy of Hamersley, over the years, to give Aboriginals opportunity for employment. Hamersley should be congratulated on that part of its policy also.

If we look just a little bit further we find another thing that comes into the whole situation, the fourth of the furphies that have been thrown up: the situation of the pebble mound mouse. It is worth noting that just two years ago CALM, the Conservation and Land Management Department in Western Australia, sought funding from the Federal Government to do a study of the area, where there has been very little scientific study carried out to see what flora and fauna exist there. When that funding was not forthcoming, Hamersley itself funded the research. What it has discovered and put together is that there is an area at least the size of Victoria under which this pebble mound mouse exists. It is now believed, from recent trappings elsewhere, that the size of the area is actually double that of Victoria.

To come back to the total size of the area where the mine will be, in the initial stages while the rail corridor is being put through it will amount to an area of about 2 per cent of the total national park which exists there. Once the rail project is finished that will be reduced to one per cent. So claims that the pebble mound mouse is being put at risk are also false. That is not true. Nobody would have any idea of the extent of the habitat of the pebble mound mouse if it were not for Hamersley itself, which not only paid for the research that has been done but assisted in the carrying out of that research.

The last point that I want to bring up here relates to tourism and the national park. It is interesting to note that, currently, some 40,000 tourists a year go through the Hamersley operation. The number of tourists to the national park is 20,000. So Hamersley's operation has twice as many tourists going through it as go through the national park.

What this development will do is actually build roads and allow more tourists to enjoy the pristine conditions of that national park. There is much to offer, as I am sure many people in this chamber would know, in terms of what exists in that part of Western Australia. Much of it is unique in the world. In actual fact, the opening up of Marandoo by Hamersley and the restrictions under which the company will be operating from an environmental point of view will give people access by properly constructed roads and the opportunity for a tourist bus, for example, to go into that national park for tourists to see what exists there.

When we look at that national park and the opportunity for tourism, if it had not been for the initial opening up of that particular area by pastoralists and, in particular, Hamersley mining company, that opportunity would not have occurred. We would have found that in fact the 20,000 who visited on an annual basis would not have had that opportunity because the country would not be accessible without properly constructed roads and infrastructure. Those roads and that infrastructure have been constructed by Hamersley mine, not by taxpayers through the Western Australian Government or the Federal Government.

Some of the noises that we have read about in the press were ill informed and, I believe, deliberately misleading. I hope in addressing this particular issue today that, in particular, the position the Democrats have adopted on this, not only publicly but in this chamber, is put to rest because it is just not true; it is false. The important thing about this, not only from a national perspective but from a Western Australian perspective, is that we are going to see those people keep their jobs and we are going to see Hamersley continue to operate at least to the year 2050 in the Pilbara of Western Australia, rather than being forced to close down in approximately nine years.

DEBATE.TITLE: GRAIN LEGUMES LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1992OILSEEDS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills that we are debating, the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill and the Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill, change the basis of research levies on grain legumes and oilseed from a specific rate per tonne to a farm gate ad valorem rate. Initially that rate will be set at one per cent of the farm gate value, but there is potential within the legislation for that rate to be raised to 3 per cent. The Grains Council, on behalf of grain growers, has recommended that this is a more equitable form of contribution because it is proportional to the net return and takes into account, obviously, the varying prices or returns for different types of grain.

PARA.TAB: We have before us two separate Bills, but since 1990-91 there has actually been one corporation to cover the wholegrains, oilseeds and legumes area, the Grains Research and Development Corporation. Oilseeds include sunflower seed, safflower seed, soya beans, rape seed, cotton seed and linseed, which are mainly grown for their oil content. The main areas of oilseed cultivation are the New South Wales north coast, the central highlands of Queensland, western Victoria and the south-east of South Australia.

In 1990-91 production of oilseeds reached 1,072 kilotons, valued at $209m. The major grain legumes produced in Australia are field peas, lupins and peanuts. Field pea production in 1990-91 totalled 309 kilotons produced from an area of land of 309,000 hectares and valued at $35m. Lupin production in 1990-91 totalled 752 kilotons produced from an area of 789,000 hectares and valued at $140m. The major end use of lupins has been in the manufacture of pig and poultry feed, although quantities of lupins are now being used in the preparation of high protein food for human consumption in Asia and Australia.

Peanut production in 1990-91 totalled 36 kilotonnes, produced from an area of 22,000 hectares and valued at $40m. In Australia, peanuts are grown mainly for human consumption, although small quantities of low quality peanuts are crushed for oil and vegetable meal. Peanuts are produced mainly in Queensland with only a small area grown in New South Wales, the Northern Territory and north-west Western Australia.

The idea of moving from a flat rate per tonne to a percentage levy is obviously designed to ensure that each industry plays a fairer share of the costs of rural research. No-one can argue with that in principle. The establishment of a single grain research and development corporation has meant that there has been a commingling of the funds raised from the various rural industries and States, with basically a common pool being distributed to research projects which are assessed to be a particular value.

There has been general support within the industry for the changes proposed in this Bill. Everyone agrees that we need to spend more money on research. When times get tough in a rural industry and when the farmers can least afford to provide additional money, they become additionally conscious of the need to do better in the various practices associated with their industry. They want better varieties, they want to do things more efficiently and they want other aspects of their industry to be the best possible. They acknowledge the vital role of research in ensuring that we have the best possible practices. The Minister has argued that the proposed ad valorem rate will ensure that growers' contribution to research and development will be proportional to their net return for the particular crop growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank all honourable senators for their contribution to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING

TALK.START.PARA: —The Honey Legislation (Repeal and Amendment) Bill 1992 terminates the Australian Honey Board from 1 January of next year and transfers certain functions to the Australian Horticultural Corporation. The Honey Board has operated for some 30 years, but the Government announced that it will terminate the Board and transfer some of its functions to the Australian Horticultural Corporation until 30 June 1995 when the Horticultural Corporation and that arrangement will be further reviewed.

PARA.TAB: To a certain extent, this was the result of the Davis review committee on Commonwealth primary industry statutory marketing authorities. It reported that the smaller marketing authorities, including the Honey Board, faced high costs relative to the income provided by levy on producers. The Honey Board had been operating on a budget of $500,000, about half of which went in administration costs. It is very important that the administration of these organisations, corporations or whatever, is kept under control so that the value of levies paid by producers is there for research, marketing, promotion or other purposes.

The gross value of production of the honey industry is about $40m, with 40 per cent going for export. This is a good example of a small but very effective and efficient industry, contributing to Australia's international trade and balance of payments. The role of the Honey Board was the setting of a minimum price export for bulk honey, but that was not effective because Australia had only about one per cent of the world trade and the Board no longer appointed overseas selling agents.

The industry, represented by the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations and the Honey Packers and Marketers Association of Australia, negotiated the changes with the Government. It is in agreement with the legislation and has requested that the Board be terminated at the end of this year.

The Australian Honey Board Review Committee, established to consider future options, wanted the Board abolished but recommended the continuation of domestic promotion, consumer education, quality assurance and information dissemination through the Australian Horticultural Corporation.

Research and development will continue through the Honeybee Research and Development Corporation. One raises here again whether or not there is a cost-effective situation with a small industry such as that or whether it is better placed under the umbrella of the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation or, for that matter, some other organisation.

The change is expected to save the industry about $100,000 a year in administrative costs. As this industry is becoming more involved in commercial pollination, the closer association with horticulture could be beneficial. The marketing component of the honey export charge is being repealed and should save growers a further $70,000 per year. It was considered that this amount was too small for generic export promotion.

The honey industry will need to monitor the new arrangement to ensure that it is cost-effective and that it is worth while for it to be part of the Horticultural Corporation. The Horticultural Corporation itself will need to be reviewed to see that it is performing a cost-effective role for that range of horticultural industries which it has under its umbrella. The coalition will be supporting this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: NORFOLK ISLAND (ELECTORAL AND JUDICIAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation we are considering, the Norfolk Island (Electoral and Judicial) Amendment Bill 1992, is for an Act to enable certain residents of Norfolk Island to vote in parliamentary elections, and for other purposes. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in the report Islands in the Sun: The Legal Regimes of Australia's External Territories and the Jervis Bay Territory, March 1991, reported that Australian citizens resident in Norfolk Island remain the only resident Australians not entitled, as a right, to representation in the Commonwealth Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Committee received representations indicating that the Norfolk Islanders themselves had mixed views regarding representation in the Commonwealth Parliament. I can certainly vouch for that statement from the various visits that I have made to Norfolk Island and my discussions on this matter with the residents. However, the report concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the right to vote is an absolute right which should not be denied to those people of Norfolk Island who wish to exercise their right. However, the Committee recognises that the constitutional history of the Territory is complex and that Norfolk Island warrants special consideration in this regard. In addition, the Committee is cognisant of the strongly held views of the elements of the Norfolk Island population, most likely a majority, for whom Commonwealth parliamentary representation is an anathema.
The Committee went on to say:

PARA.TAB: The Committee is aware that provision exists within the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 for optional voting for the following categories: an Antarctic elector; an eligible overseas elector; or an itinerant elector. The Committee is mindful of the strongly held views and the historical reasons which make Norfolk Island a unique case. The Committee is therefore prepared to accept, contrary to the important principles which apply anywhere else in Australia, that the residents of Norfolk Island who are Australian citizens should have the right of optional enrolment. Once a citizen exercises this right, voting would be compulsory and normal provisions under the Commonwealth Electoral Act would apply.

SPEECH.PARA: The report recommended that:

. . . the Commonwealth Parliament amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to give optional enrolment rights to the people of Norfolk Island; the electorate to which the voters would be attached to be determined on the advice of the Australian Electoral Commission.

The Government response to the report tabled on 10 September 1991 agreed that optional enrolment recognises the unique circumstances of Norfolk Island and provides to those Australian citizens who wish it, the opportunity to exercise this basic democratic right to vote in elections for the Federal Parliament. As a result of the Norfolk Island plebiscite on the voting rights for Australian citizens, the then Minister for Territories, the Honourable David Simmons, suggested that for the purpose of Australian Federal elections, Norfolk Island voters would be aligned with a single electorate—that is, Canberra. The Norfolk Island Government has lobbied against the single electorate proposal and for compulsory voting for all Norfolk Island residents. The current Minister, the Honourable Wendy Fatin, has backed down and has now introduced legislation which enables Australian citizens to enrol in an electorate of their choosing. The purpose of this Bill is to extend to Australian citizens living on Norfolk Island the opportunity to vote in Federal elections and referendums. This is consistent with the coalition's repeated views.

PARA.TAB: I note in yesterday's Northern Territory News an item regarding Senator Margaret Reynolds's comments to the constitutional conference specifically on the matter of the Norfolk Island Act and self-government for Aboriginal communities. I caution against the parallels drawn by Senator Margaret Reynolds in her speech between Norfolk Island and Aboriginal communities, because I feel—and certainly I know from my visits—that Norfolk Island is in a unique situation. The comments made by Senator Reynolds in Darwin at the conference, in which she was addressing issues relating to aspirations of some people with regard to Aboriginal self-government within Australia, need to be very carefully considered.
