I am very suspicious of some of the intent behind the speech of Senator Reynolds to the conference in Darwin.

She claims that there is a precedent for self-government that applies under the Norfolk Island Act, which passed through this Parliament in 1979. But to suggest that that precedent is just as relevant today to now bring forward the aspirations of Aboriginal citizens of Australia, who live within Australia, who vote within Australia, its States and its Territories, would, I think, be treading on some very dangerous ground.

The residents of Norfolk Island are a unique blend: descendants of the original Pitcairners, Australians, New Zealanders and others, with 25 per cent of the population being temporary residents. The legislative framework of the island also has its own unique history: a constitutional battle for independence which in 1979 resulted in the creation of the Norfolk Island Act and a degree of self-government for the island. Norfolk Island has achieved a high degree of self-government and has proved since 1979 that it is able to act with goodwill in developing a range of laws designed to safeguard and meet the expressed desire of the Norfolk Island Territory residents.

I draw attention to the Budget allocations to Norfolk Island. They are very meagre. About $1m a year goes towards the administration of that island, the Commonwealth services and the heritage provisions on the island. If Norfolk Island is compared with Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands in the Indian Ocean, there is a very wide disparity on the issue of Federal funding. Some $20m is allocated to the Federal Government's responsibilities and provisions on Christmas and Cocos Islands, whereas on Norfolk Island the residents do not request it. In fact, they do not want it, because of the independent nature of their own establishment. The way in which they manage their economy and provide all of the services is very important and draws some very important parallels. I would certainly commend to Senator Reynolds, for her comments with regard to Aboriginal self-government aspirations, the parallels of finance that exist with Norfolk Island. She may find that her own arguments could well fall apart on many of those grounds.

There is no doubt that self-government on Norfolk Island should continue and proceed with the principles of social justice and fundamental human rights; the preservation of the Territory's environmental and cultural heritage for the benefit of present and future generations; and social equity and the efficient discharge of Commonwealth responsibilities, under Territory legislation.

The Bill we have before us will amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to provide a form of optional enrolment for eligible Norfolk Island residents to enable them to enrol in a mainland electoral division with which they can establish a connection. Where such a connection cannot be established, the option of enrolling in a particular Territory division will be available. The Bill will also amend the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act of 1984 to allow those Norfolk Islanders enrolling in this way to participate in referendums as required by section 128 of the Constitution. The electoral provisions of the Bill will have negligible impact on Commonwealth revenues and expenditure.

There will also be a minor amendment to section 56 of the Norfolk Island Act 1979 in relation to the travelling expenses of judges of the Norfolk Island Supreme Court so as to encompass `travelling allowances' and to place beyond doubt the legality of past payments of travelling expenses purportedly made under that section. The Norfolk Island Government meets the travel related costs of judges visiting the island from its own budget. The amendments to the Norfolk Island Act will therefore have no impact on Commonwealth revenues and expenditure.

The coalition holds the view that participation in the Australian electoral system by Norfolk Island residents should not be forced. Rather, where permanent residents on Norfolk Island have made agreements between the individual and the community, then it is for the permanent community through the local parliament to decide whether permanent residents wish to participate in Australian Federal elections. We also believe that the right of those temporary Australian residents of the island who wish to have their voices heard in elections at home in their Australian electorates should have those rights preserved. Residents who do not hold permanent status but who hold Australian citizenship should be entitled to retain their enrolment in an Australian electorate. The coalition supports the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation involves two matters, as we have heard. The first matter relates to a technical amendment which has been introduced to clarify any uncertainty concerning the validity of travelling allowances paid to Norfolk Island Supreme Court judges. The provision has been reworded to ensure that previously paid amounts have been validly paid. The second matter is far more important and far more interesting. Indeed, in some ways, it is an historic provision. This legislation extends to Australian citizens, living on Norfolk Island, the opportunity to vote in Federal elections and referenda for the first time.

PARA.TAB: Australian citizens who are Norfolk Island residents have previously been denied the right to participate in electing the national government—a bizarre situation. It has come about because of the remoteness of Norfolk Island, of course, the small size of the community and the fierce independence and pride which many islanders feel. We are pleased to see that these special characteristics have been recognised by the Government in this legislation.

Without spending too much time, it is pertinent to point out that this legislation was not originally in this form. The original Bill allowed optional registration by voters but then proposed to incorporate Norfolk Island into the Federal seat of Canberra. This generated a huge amount of anti-Canberra sentiment on Norfolk Island and was rejected by a local referendum held on the issue. While the referendum question was a little emotional, and was voted on by many people who are not entitled to vote in Australian elections, the Government did listen to the will of the people of Norfolk Island.

While maintaining the option for citizens to register to vote, this Bill also allows those voters who have some connection with the mainland electorate to be able to vote in that electorate, if they so wish. If there is no such connection to any particular electorate, their vote will be cast in the Canberra division. This is an outcome which has the support of the residents of Norfolk Island. The measure improves democracy in Australia by removing a barrier to participate in an election, which has always applied to residents of Norfolk Island. It is welcomed by the Australian Democrats and we support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —For those of us who are historical buffs, Norfolk Island is indeed a fascinating place. It is a little piece of paradise. I think the temperature at Norfolk Island remains between 18 and 25 degrees centigrade at all times of the year. Its history is truly fascinating. Indeed, it is fiercely argued as to which place was settled first—Norfolk Island or Sydney. It would seem that on the balance of probabilities that Norfolk Island may have the edge in that argument. I mention in passing the spectacularly successful restoration of the historical buildings at Norfolk Island, particularly those along Quality Row, as it is called. I found the restoration fascinating. If visitors go to Norfolk Island today and look at the early settlement buildings that are still used as government offices and as the Administrator's residence, they will see that the restored buildings are indistinguishable from early etchings of that area. The restoration has been spectacularly successful. Of course, it was done with the assistance of Federal Government finance.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Tambling has mentioned, the residents of Norfolk Island are fiercely independent. The community is indeed quite remote from Australia. In relation to Senator Tambling's attempt to draw parallels between Christmas Island and Norfolk Island, I could not think of two communities which are more dramatically different, in terms of history, demography, and racial mix of the inhabitants than Christmas Island and Norfolk Island. They are dramatically different places.

I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate and for their support for the legislation. It is worthy of support because, as has been referred to earlier in this debate, the legislation which is currently before us represents a successful achievement of the parliamentary committee's recommendations and the constitutional correctness of the result. It also has the endorsement of the Norfolk Island government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill 1992 which transfers responsibility for the management of marine mammals and reptiles from commercial fisheries legislation to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. The new Fisheries Management Act specifies that the term `fish' does not include reptiles and mammals, unlike the previous Act. This sensible realignment may marginally affect the empires of two Canberra mandarins and the extent of the powers of two Ministers. The fact that these two Ministers—the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and the Minister for the Environment (Mrs Kelly)—have agreed on this sensible realignment of responsibilities is a matter we strongly support.

PARA.TAB: Currently, the national parks and wildlife regulations do provide protection to certain sea creatures, specifically sea snakes, seals and birds. After these changes there will be additions to the schedules of that Act which will cover turtles, crocodiles and dugongs. There may be some concerns about the extent of protection of crocodiles and that is a matter of some disagreement, but the Opposition is not taking a view on that matter at this stage. No doubt there will be opportunities for localised concerns to be expressed and dealt with over time.

When these additions to the schedules in the Act do take place it will mean that all marine reptiles, birds and mammals will receive protection in Commonwealth waters under legislation administered by one body, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Whales and dolphins are already protected by the Whale Protection Act 1980 which is under the control of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service although much of the enforcement of the legislation is in fact delegated to State fisheries or to conservation agencies.

The Whale Protection Act is particularly relevant in this situation because the powers of enforcement that are proposed under this legislation have been drafted to be consistent with those applying under the Whale Protection Act and to be of the same level of stringency as applied under the old Fisheries Act which was used to protect these species. The Bill will extend the powers of wardens appointed to enforce the legislation to the waters of the continental shelf. I understand that the Australian Fishing Industry Council has no objections to this Bill.

The reference to the Whale Protection Act reminds me of the fact that this Act was introduced into this Parliament 13 years ago by one of my former colleagues, the Honourable David Thomson, who was Minister for Science and Environment in the Fraser Government. I think it is worth remembering that it was the Fraser Government that introduced this protection of whales following the Government's commissioning of an independent inquiry headed by Sir Sydney Frost which was tabled in Parliament in February 1979. It was only a couple of months later in April that Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister, announced the Government had accepted all recommendations made in that report. The central conclusion accepted by the Government was that the Whaling Act 1960 be repealed and that we pursue a vigorous and active policy for the protection of whales. The Bill introduced such a policy for all cetaceans, that is, whales, porpoises and dolphins.

The legislation on which the present arrangements are based prohibits the killing, capturing, injuring or interference with cetaceans in the 200-mile Australian fishing zone, and by Australians domiciled in Australia and Australian vessels and aircraft and their crews beyond the 200-mile Australian fishing zone, with penalties up to $100,000. Support for a total worldwide ban on whaling was to have been sought immediately at that time through international forums, such as the International Whaling Commission. It is interesting to note that there have been some pressures for a resumption of whaling, which the Government is properly opposing.

The protection of these other species of the sea fits into that category. The enforcement mechanisms that were put in place by Mr Thomson at that time, using the National Parks and Wildlife Service as the protective instrument, have been adopted for this measure. As a result, because it fits in totally with the coalition's policies on this matter, we have great pleasure in supporting the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be present on one of the extremely rare occasions when I am able to support through the Senate something from the Government that actually has the approval of Senator Baume. I must say also that I am perfectly happy to acknowledge that it was the Fraser Government that introduced this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, I have often acknowledged, despite being the old Labor Party apparatchik that I am, that Malcolm Fraser did a great many good things as Prime Minister. Two of them that I have often acknowledged, both publicly and to my own colleagues, resulted from the consistent support that Malcolm Fraser gave—against enormous opposition from his coalition partners, the then Country Party—to both conservation issues and Aboriginal issues. It should not be forgotten that it was the Fraser Government that introduced the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

I was present when Malcolm Fraser opened Kakadu National Park; I still remember that occasion with a great deal of satisfaction. The reason I remember it is the great deal of satisfaction that clearly it gave Malcolm Fraser to be there to officially open Kakadu National Park, the ownership of which, as part of the arrangement, was vested in the Aboriginal people who still, to this day, inhabit it.

I have felt some sympathy for Malcolm Fraser, who now is obviously persona non grata with the new leadership of the coalition and, as a result, a member of a highly endangered species—a liberal. Others have all been shot and destroyed in the coalition currently. Indeed, poor old Malcolm is now, at fairly regular intervals, publicly traduced by the new leadership. I have no hesitation in acknowledging the very good things that were done in the time of the Fraser Government in respect of conservation.

As Senator Baume has said, rightly, this is a sensible piece of legislation. It enables us to maintain our protection of the cetacean species that we deem worthy of protection, such as whales and dolphins, and animals such as dugong, which inhabit the waters above the continental shelf of Australia outside of those waters which are controlled by State and Territory jurisdictions. I am amazed by the absence of the Australian Democrats, who I thought would be here to contribute to this debate. I am surprised because of the contribution that Senator Coulter, particularly, made to this matter when it was first raised, in the concerns he had about the continued description of animals such as dugong as fish. I acknowledge that the Democrats did indeed have a contribution to make to this legislation and, obviously, would have supported it had they been here. I thank Senator Baume for his support for the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Senator Colston:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I happily advise you that the Opposition will not be opposing this Bill.
—If I may say so from the chair, I thank the Senate for its support.

PARA.TAB: Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button.
—I'll bet you won't ask him about Mitsubishi.

—I refer the Minister to today's appalling unemployment figures—which should also concern Senator Bolkus, from South Australia—which reveal another fall in employment. I remind the Minister that, since the Prime Minister successfully hounded out his predecessor in December last year, in net terms not one additional job has been created in this country. I ask the Minister: how can the recession be over—to pick up Mr Keating's expression—when statistics show that a further 43,800 jobs were lost in September of this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was subjected to some questions yesterday about the recession being over, and I repeat what I said then: employment is always a lagged indicator, and employment growth will follow from recovery in output. There is some recovery in output taking place in Australia. For four quarters we have had growth in the economy, as distinct from the Opposition's model of yesteryear—the Thatcher Government in Britain, which has now had nine quarters of negative growth—
—Is your's the Argentinian model?

—No. Thatcher was your model; that is where Fightback comes from. As I say, growth has taken place, although admittedly at a slow rate. The unemployment rate fell to 10.8 per cent in December. Despite the fall in the unemployment rate, part time employment fell and full time employment was relatively steady. I quote from the ABS figures on that. Full time employment fell by 400 in September, but is still 4,400 above the June trough. The leading indicator for employment is positive, with the number of vacancies rising 3 per cent last month. I refer to the ANZ Bank indicator, which is regarded as a leading one.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister is correct in stating that this Government has saved the country from the ravages of alternative policies. When this Government, for example, started to lower interest rates through the medium of the Reserve Bank, the first six lowerings of interest rates were opposed by the Leader of the Opposition, who said that it would be over-stimulatory to lower interest rates. The Opposition was totally opposed to the fiscal policy in the One Nation statement, too. If those policies had been adopted at that time we would be looking towards a 20 per cent unemployment rate, rather than the figure we now have.
The Governor of the Reserve Bank put it pretty well the other day when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Opponents of the monetary and fiscal policy easings have no right to be in the vanguard of those now voicing concerns about unemployment.

That is what he is talking about; those Opposition senators over there. Members of the Opposition are in the vanguard of voicing concerns about this issue but they opposed both the monetary and the fiscal policy easings to which the Governor refers.

PARA.TAB: We find it strange that an Opposition, for example, in these circumstances wants to take the employment goal out of the Reserve Bank charter. I just want to make a couple of other points for the edification and education of the Opposition. The unemployment rate in Canada is now—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the answer has expired.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the details of the Sheraton Southgate Hotel's workplace agreement? Is it true that this agreement has replaced penalty rates and other allowances with an all-up wage rate? Has the Sheraton agreement given the hotel the flexibility to offer world class service to its guests 24 hours a day seven days a week? Is the Minister aware of the recent criticism of the agreement and, if so, does he think the criticism is justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, I am aware of the Sheraton Southgate workplace agreement; it was registered in the Industrial Relations Commission, I think, fairly recently. It is an agreement that has been negotiated between the Sheraton Hotel chain and the ACTU, and representing the Sheraton Hotel chain was a former Minister for Industrial Relations in the Fraser Government, Mr Ian Macphee. I must give due regard to Mr Macphee, on behalf of Sheraton, and the ACTU who have achieved a quite important industrial relations agreement—a workplace or, to use its fashionable term, enterprise agreement for the hospitality industry in Australia which recognises the 24-hour seven day a week needs of that type of operation.

PARA.TAB: The distinguishing feature of this agreement is that it takes the penalty rates for shift loadings, totals them up, and wraps them into a bottom line rate, so that one gets all of the penalty rates in the bottom line outcome, which is then applied as the uniform rate. So no-one's wages are reduced by removing the penalty rate expressed as a separate component of the wage; it is all rolled up into a total bottom rate. As well, the Sheraton Hotel added a productivity bonus.

It is a good example of management, unions and workers creating a constructive environment to deliver a quality service in the hospitality industry and it stands, as I said at the beginning of this answer, as something of a landmark.

I have been asked whether I am aware of criticism of it. I am aware of criticism of it. Yesterday at the National Press Club the shadow spokesman on industrial relations, Mr Howard, in answer to a question from Bruce Juddery from the floor, after Mr Howard completed what was a fairly old fashioned, conflict riddled style approach to industrial relations, criticised this agreement.

It is interesting to see why he criticised this agreement. He criticised this agreement because the Sheraton Hotel did not eliminate the penalty rates completely; it wrapped them into a total rate. In Mr Howard's view, the wages of the employees of the Sheraton Hotel should have been reduced by denying them any penalty rate at all, and the total rate outcome should have been less than what the Sheraton Hotel agreed.

This holds some very interesting lessons. It proves that the cat is now out of the bag once again. The Opposition's industrial relations policy is a low wage policy. It is a policy about reducing wages, imposing higher taxes, reducing skills in the community and introducing massive doses of confrontation—a low wage, high tax, low skill, high confrontation policy. Mr Howard criticised this agreement, I remind the chamber, because it did not reduce the wages. That simply goes to put the lie to the words that Mr Howard has been uttering just this day.

Just this day, Mr Howard suddenly discovers that he ought to describe his policy as a high wage one. What a load of rubbish! It is a low wage policy meant to remove the protections of the Industrial Relations Commission from the workplace, meant to undermine and remove the award structure in Australia that Australian workers depend on for fairness and introduce low wages into the Australian workplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to Dr Ed Shann's comments today when he revealed that combined official unemployment and underemployment was a scandalous 17.8 per cent or over 1.6 million Australians. Does the Government accept the estimate of Dr Shann on underemployment and, if not, what is the Government's estimate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear Dr Ed Shann's remarks—I missed AM this morning, and I apologise to the ABC for that—but I have had the general thrust of what he said referred to me. The truth is that the unemployment statistics that have been published measure, as best we can measure it, the proper representation of unemployment. But there is a degree—and this is admitted and recognised—of hidden unemployment. What Dr Shann was doing was estimating, as I understand it, what he, as a consultant and someone who has worked in support of putting together the Fightback package of the Opposition, thinks is the degree of hidden unemployment. He may be right; I do not know. Those figures seem quite high to me.

PARA.TAB: But, surely, the point here is that the comparison in terms of employment and the way in which we measure the movements of employment and unemployment is the Australian Bureau of Statistics series. If we compare, for example, the participation rate under this Government with the participation rate under the Fraser Government—if we compare the same participation rate, which was the point of a question to Senator Button earlier in Question Time—then by the measure of the participation rate of those opposite under the Fraser Government the unemployment rate would have been around 13.5 per cent, not 10.8 per cent, and doubtless the level of hidden unemployment, even estimated by a Fightback consultant like Dr Shann, would have been much greater.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware that regional airlines have expressed concern about the possible imposition of a goods and services tax on the aviation industry? Are such concerns justified and would increases in tax lead to higher air fares and freight charges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed their concerns are justified and they will lead—
—Under whose measure?

—I know that the Leader of the Opposition has attempted recently to tell the car manufacturing industry how to make cars, the social welfare industry how to look after social welfare recipients, and the rank and file members of his own Party to leave the room if they did not agree with him, and he is now attempting to tell the people who actually operate the extremely difficult business of running regional airlines how to run their business too, presumably.

PARA.TAB: In recent publications of the trade newspaper Aviation Report, in an article headlined `Hewson's GST Proposal Worries Regional Operators', the operators of three of the country's largest regional airlines all told Senator Short, who was comprehensively failing to convince them about the benefits of Fightback, that their analysis of the Fightback document indicated they would be lucky to achieve 5 per cent savings to attempt to offset—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?

—I will tell Senator Short who said this. It obviously made a huge impact on Senator Short. He was talking to them and he cannot even remember who they were. Max Hazelton, the General Manager of Hazelton Airlines, Peter Ryan from Eastern Australian Airlines and Tony Mathews from Southern Australia all said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . they could not find savings to match the 15 percent price rise.
That is the 15 per cent price rise provided in the Fightback document.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are very quiet.

—Yes, the Opposition has suddenly gone quiet. The Opposition failed to satisfy the airline operators, who have in fact done their sums. They cannot find savings in their operations with the removal of wholesale sales tax and payroll tax that will even come close to the detrimental effect that these proposals will have on their operations by the application of a whopping 15 per cent Federal Government tax on every airline ticket purchased by every one of their customers.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Opposition believes that it knows it all. It knows more than car manufacturers about making cars and it knows more than Max Hazelton—and that would be a joke—about running a regional airline. Senator Short failed not only to convince them but even to remember who he was talking to at this particular meeting. I will quote the last paragraph of this report:

ANSWER.PARA: Hazelton said his company's best estimate was a four or five percent saving. The other two were not convinced that savings from the abandonment of the whole-sale and pay roll taxes would even amount to that.

The regional airlines themselves have predicted a catastrophic impact on their operations from the imposition of a goods and services tax, as there will be generally on the tourist industry in Australia from the imposition of this iniquitous tax.

PARA.TAB: In recent weeks, as a result of this Government's policy changes in aviation, we have seen the announcement by Air New Zealand of the immediate injection into the Queensland economy of $14m a year and the creation of 1,500 jobs in Queensland in the next 12 months, rising to the creation of 10,000 jobs and the injection of almost $90m a year into the Australian economy directly as a result of the sensible policy changes that this Government has made. The application and imposition of a 15 per cent goods and services tax will destroy all of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would ask the Minister to table the paper that he was just quoting from.
—Do you mean the aviation report?
—I just want to have a look at it.
—Not only will I table it, but I will rub Senator Brownhill's nose in it.
—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: even though the Minister outweighs me a lot, I would like him to come across the chamber and actually rub my nose in it.
—Why don't I see Senator Brownhill outside instead?
—Order!
—On reflection, I seek leave to incorporate this document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In compliance with the request from Senator Brownhill, I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.
—I have asked whether leave is granted and leave was not granted.
—I seek leave to table the document.
—The Minister does not need leave; he may table it.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the figures issued today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics which indicate that, despite the long past end to the recession claimed by the Prime Minister, there are still some 928,000 people unemployed in this country. I also note the earlier answer to a question asked by Senator Ferguson in which Minister Cook accepted the 17.8 per cent figure. Is the Minister aware that the Australian Bureau of Statistics considers that any person who is employed for as little as one hour per week, whether paid or not, is regarded as employed for the purposes of the unemployment statistics? Does the Minister share with the Prime Minister a fascination with the unadorned economic indices which allow him to ignore the dimension of the human tragedy which these unemployment figures indicate? Finally, does he really think the claim can be fairly made that the recession is over when there is that scale of human misery still present and should a more human based index—
—Order!
—of what constitutes a recession be used?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Time!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are time limits on the asking of questions and the answering of questions. When the Chair calls that it is time, the honourable senator will resume his or her seat.

—As Senator Coulter well knows, in answering questions on this issue on a number of occasions I have said that the Government regards the level of unemployment as tragically and unacceptably high. We have sought to put in place through One Nation and through the Budget expansionary policies, which I think the Democrats by and large agree with, to try to address that issue as far as possible.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the specifics of Senator Coulter's question, the Prime Minister, in talking about the recession, was talking about a situation where we have now had four quarters of growth in the economy compared with other countries which have had persistent long periods of negative growth—such as the United Kingdom with nine quarters of negative growth, New Zealand with more than four quarters of negative growth and a number of other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The unemployed are cheering!
—We do not expect the unemployed to cheer as a result of that sort of information. We certainly do not expect them to cheer as a result of the alternative policies offered by the Opposition.
—Just answer the question.
—If Senator Herron interjects, he is entitled to an answer, I suppose.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter specifically asked me about the question of part time work. The significant fall in employment was in part time work. In aggregate, unemployment fell from 10.9 to 10.8 per cent and that is the aggregate for both part time work and for full time work. The fall in full time work was very small indeed and in part time work it was significant; I concede that.

In so far as redefining figures in order to redefine a recession and redefine what unemployment means, the Government is using the same measures which have been used historically in this country in terms of a recession. A recession in the Prime Minister's concept was continued negative growth in the economy. In terms of redefining the unemployment figures, we use exactly the same figures as we have historically used in this country. Whether there is some better methodology I do not know.

Unemployment is always a lagged statistic in terms of recovery from a recession. This economy was in recession and unemployment was relatively low at the start of the recession, but it is a lagged indicator. Of course, the employment situation will improve more slowly than the other indicators of improvement in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister not concede that it is extremely cruel on the unemployed to continue to use that index by which the Prime Minister can claim the recession is over when there are still nearly a million people unemployed? Is it not cruelty to use that sort of expression, to continue to use that index?
—Political expediency.

—Senator Hill says, `political expediency'. The point I was making is that there are measures of a recession and there are measures of unemployment. As I conceded to Senator Coulter after his original question about the measure of unemployment, of course the Government is very upset by the continuation of that very high measure of unemployment. As I said, that is a lagged indicator when one comes out of a recession.

PARA.TAB: By the way, I wish to correct Senator Coulter on one point. In addressing his original question to me, he said that Senator Cook accepted the figure of 17 per cent in relation to hidden unemployment, which was referred to by Dr Ed Shann, one of the Fightback contractors. I do not believe that Senator Cook accepted that figure at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy would have seen reports in today's and yesterday's media naming four possible sites for a radioactive waste repository in Australia. Can the Minister inform the Senate as to the accuracy of these comments and reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, made a statement on this subject yesterday. As is normal in these circumstances, he provided me with a brief on it. A fascinating line in this brief about where a national radioactive waste repository should be located says that all States agreed that they should have one provided that it is not located within their own boundaries. If ever I have heard a NIMBY statement—in other words, we agree in principle but do not do it in our own backyard—that is clearly the case in this circumstance with the States.

PARA.TAB: I will go to the brief that I have been provided with to answer the question. I can assure Senator West and her constituents, for example, that Broken Hill is not mentioned in the paper released by Mr Crean and nor is any other specific site. It is unfortunate that the media have chosen to draw unwarranted conclusions from figures in the papers that have been released. Several figures in the paper illustrate the areas that could be suitable, using the selection criteria described. These figures provide examples of the type of output that can be obtained from applying the selection criteria and the method described in the paper. These figures are neither designed nor should be used to identify specific sites.

It is clear in the paper and in the Minister's press release that the purpose of the paper is to invite public comment on the criteria and how they are applied. Therefore, it is premature to discuss specific sites. It is also quite clear that the next stage in the process is to take this public comment into account, reapply the selection criteria and, using more detailed information and field studies, prepare a short list of suitable sites. Public comment would again be sought on this short list, following which more detailed on-site investigations would lead to a preferred location.

I reiterate the Minister's words from yesterday that this is not an issue that can be wished away. Every State and Territory has a number of stockpiles of radioactive waste, mostly in metropolitan areas. We are proposing that it is more sensible to house these wastes in a single, secure, purpose-built facility at a remote site. Then occur in this brief the famous words, `All States agree, provided that it is not located within their boundaries'.

However, we need to move beyond agreement in principle and have a mature debate that is as free as possible from unfounded and emotive reactions to what is essentially a straightforward matter. A clear process has been outlined and ample opportunity is being provided for sensible public comment. I encourage any person with concerns and comments on the paper to avail themselves of the opportunity to make their views known through the mechanisms established for such comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, relates to the tariff treatment of four-wheel drive vehicles. I refer the Minister to his comments in Question Time on Tuesday when he said that members of the mining industry had made statements on four-wheel drive tariffs `based on lies'. Will the Minister now inform the Senate whether the Government has received any proposal to increase tariffs on four-wheel drive vehicles recently? If so, what consideration has the Government given to this proposal?

—In referring to this issue the other day, I was trying to make the point that in terms of fixing tariff levels for an industry such as this, the Government always has representations made to it by various interests. For example, when we fixed the end point tariff level of 15 per cent on the basis of an Industry Commission report large sections of the automotive industry opposed that end point tariff of 15 per cent, saying it was too low. The Government listened to their views and did not accept it.

PARA.TAB: In respect of four-wheel drive vehicles, light commercial vehicles and so on, every year we receive representations on an ongoing basis on these issues. I think we have received some this year. They will be considered, as they have been in the past, in light of the developments in the automotive market but I do not think there are any particular representations which are different from the ones we normally receive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that he has received representations recently on the tariff treatment of four-wheel drive vehicles?
—No, not recently.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services.
—Is this another dorothy dixer?

—No, it is not. I refer to the outrageous action taken by the Australian Cricket Board in, firstly, rewording a clause in the contract it is offering to test players so that they cannot participate in quit smoking campaigns and, secondly, in fining test cricketer Greg Matthews an exorbitant amount, reportedly between 20 per cent and 30 per cent of his contract fee, for appearing in an anti-smoking advertisement. I ask the Minister—
—Order! Time has expired.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—What is the question?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on my left! Interjections are bad enough but to have somebody cupping her mouth and shouting out is beyond the pale.
—I understand that Senator Faulkner has asked me to comment on the matter he has put forward. I applaud Greg Matthews for taking part in—
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President.
—Don't cup your mouth.
—I did not and would not; it is not my style.
—Senator Bishop, if you have a point of order you will make it.

—Yes, I do, Mr Deputy President. Senator Faulkner failed to ask his question because of his own ineptitude. I do not believe that Senator Tate is clairvoyant and therefore it would be impossible for you to rule whether or not he is answering the question. Therefore, I suggest that we move on to the next question.
—Sufficient of the question was asked of Senator Tate to respond.
—I certainly applaud Greg Matthews for acting as a proper role model—

—I rise on a point of order again, Mr Deputy President. For the edification of the Senate and those watching, could you please tell us what the question was to which the Minister is attempting to respond.
—I indicated earlier that sufficient of the question was asked for Senator Tate to respond.

—On the third go, despite attempts to muzzle me by the Opposition which says it believes in free speech, I believe that Greg Matthews is to be applauded for taking on the role of a role model for young Australians, who obviously always idolise their sporting heroes. He has taken the view that to smoke impairs sports performance and health. He is concerned to outline to young Australians how smoking can impair their health as it causes disease and, as we know, death.

PARA.TAB: In this respect I believe that Greg Matthews is acting, as many other sporting heroes do, in a very salutary way in our community. Stephen Hawkins, the double sculls gold medal winner from Tasmania, is at this very moment going around 30 schools in Tasmania as a drug offensive ambassador spreading exactly the same message as Greg Matthews. I applaud both of them for taking on that role because, quite clearly, young people will listen to them in a way that they do not listen to others.

The Australian Cricket Board should not take such punitive action, as reported by the AAP news this morning. Reports state that Matthews has been fined between 20 and 30 per cent of his contract fee. That is a very punitive amount of money if that report be true and, even if the amount be something lesser than that, it is quite clear that here one has a situation where a punitive financial burden has been imposed on Greg Matthews because he has decided to convey particularly to young people that smoking impairs health and diminishes sporting performance.

This is doubly unfortunate in that the tobacco lobby is obviously exercising great power over the Australian Cricket Board. It is this very lobby which, in recent days, has said it is willing to go to the High Court to try to get an extension of the idea of the last judgment of which we have spoken in this chamber over the last 24 hours, whereby it is somehow going to try to equate a right to advertise tobacco products—which deal in death and disease—with the right to communicate political opinions in our democratic society. That is a totally bizarre notion. Here we have the tobacco lobby—always bleating about free speech—in this instance with the Australian Cricket Board, preventing Greg Matthews from exercising his freedom of speech to talk about the death and disease dealing aspects of tobacco consumption in our community.

I believe that to fine Greg Matthews is to portray him as being the guilty party. All honourable senators would realise that no magistrate or judge would fine someone 20 or 30 per cent of his income, which is what has apparently occurred in this case. It is quite clear that the guilty party in this instance is the tobacco lobby, which is impairing the freedom of speech of one of Australia's greatest sporting heroes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to a report in today's Australian that the Victorian Trades Hall has prepared a draft paper on how to deal with the newly elected Kennett Government's industrial relations policy—a government which has been given a record mandate by Victorian voters. I ask the Minister whether the Government supports the options canvassed in this paper, in particular the following: industrial shock tactics with State-wide stoppages; and guerilla warfare involving continuous industrial action on a sector by sector, company by company basis which is unpredictable and uncertain.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not support any action, as Senator Crane knows, and as I have said in this place many times, that breaches the rule of law. But I do understand unions in Victoria being concerned about what may await them in terms of State industrial relations legislation.
—What the people voted for.

—The people did not vote for it. The exit polls in Victoria show that, overwhelmingly, people voted against what they saw as poor financial management by the outgoing government. It was a classic case of voting out a government rather than electing a new one. The exit polls also show that the then Kirner Government, now Opposition, narrowed the gap between it and the then Kennett Opposition, now Government, on the issue of industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: What is indisputable and should be recognised is that the Kennett Government does have a big majority and it does have a mandate to enact the law. But I can understand that the Victorian unions are apprehensive, given the draconian nature of the law that is being proposed in Victoria and given the statements by Opposition spokespersons in Victoria at the time and Federal spokespersons, including in this case Dr Hewson—the increasingly inflexible Leader of the Opposition in Australia—who have proclaimed that their mission in life is to destroy the trade union movement. Given those declarations, I can understand some apprehension. But I do not support options which break the law. What I am interested in and will look at with an open mind is what I understand to be one of the other options, that is, that Victorian unions seek to transfer State awards in Victoria into the Federal jurisdiction as parts of Federal awards.

In my period as Minister for Industrial Relations over the last 2 1/2 years, I have been trying to bring about, by negotiation with the States—and everyone, from a Federal point of view, knows how difficult it is to get six States and two Territories to agree with the Commonwealth on things of this nature—a more uniform single national system of industrial relations. I notice that Mr Gude, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party and Minister for Industrial Relations in Victoria, supports a single industrial relations system. If the steps to transfer State awards to the Federal jurisdiction will help to bring that about, that will be a positive thing, and I will look to see what proposals are put to me by the ACTU and the Confederation of Australian Industry and discuss those proposals in order to make that reform.

In conclusion, during our period of office in Australia we have achieved a record of industrial peace in which the graph for industrial disputes runs off the bottom of the table. That is one of the reasons why we are getting an international reputation for being able to handle industrial relations in this country. I hope that nothing that the Kennett Government does ruins that reputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I refer him to the evaluation of the national better health program which was announced in April last year. This evaluation looked at the implementation and funding of the national better health program as well as at making recommendations on its future. Firstly, was this evaluation in fact completed in June? Secondly, if so, why, some four months later, has no report been made publicly available? Finally, when will the evaluation be made publicly available?

—I understand that the evaluation of the national better health program was completed in June of this year. It was undertaken, as the honourable senator would know, by a team headed by Professor Laurence Malcolm from New Zealand. I think the report found generally that the program had many points to its credit, but that it had suffered from being regarded as the principal Australian response to the World Health Organisation health for all policy, and it endeavoured to cover too many areas and was too widespread in its endeavours. The findings of the evaluation were taken into account by the Government in drawing up arrangements for the new national better health program which was announced by the Minister in the 1992 Budget—and I am sure that the honourable senator saw that. The program will be refocusing on four priority areas: food and nutrition, environmental health, injury prevention and the development of national health goals and targets.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the report is being made available to libraries, health departments and interested organisations—and certainly is available to senators. I would be very happy to provide the honourable senator with a copy later this afternoon if she has not yet been provided with one.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. In view of this week's newly found determination by the Government to attack corporate wrongdoing, I ask whether the Minister will refer to the Australian Securities Commission the annual return of Mr Keating's pig group holding company, Euphron Pty Ltd, dated 12 August 1992, just two months ago, which lists the cost of the 10,000 A shares issued to Mr Keating's family company—and representing a half interest in Euphron—at only $43,000, a figure repeated in the Australian Securities Commission's latest company extract, whereas the company's allotment of shares return, dated 16 May 1991, lists the placement cost as $43 per share fully paid, making a total cost to Mr Keating's family company of $430,000. Will the Minister ask the ASC to investigate which of these returns is false, particularly in the context of public concern at the size of Mr Keating's investment—
—Order! The time for the question has expired.

—It is far from true to speak of the Federal Government's interest in corporate wrongdoing as being a new-found passion. In fact, I would say that it has been the crowning glory of the former Attorney-General's term of office. Lionel Bowen created a situation where, out of the total shambles of the old National Companies and Securities Commission scheme, one now has an Australia-wide national scheme of company and security regulation where in fact the national parliament and the national government take political responsibility for dealing with companies and securities throughout Australia. I believe that this enables us to restore confidence in the stock market, both from within Australia by domestic investors and from overseas.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Securities Commission, of course, is an independent statutory organisation, and properly so, so far as its regulation of particular companies and securities matters is concerned. I certainly would not be willing to try to influence, interfere with or give a directive to the Australian Securities Commission as to how it should regard any particular matter. I am quite confident in the integrity, the capacity and the ability of the Australian Securities Commission to deal with any so-called discrepancy that might be alleged and brought to its attention. But I certainly will not be in the business—and I believe the Attorney would not either—of giving to the Australian Securities Commission any particular direction in relation to a particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. As the Minister in the other place has already this week given directions in general terms to the head of the Australian Securities Commission, I ask the Minister: what action does the Australian Securities Commission take when false statements are made? What are the rights of this Government to require that action be taken to examine false statements, particularly in this case where the investment is of public interest and is shown in the latest Euphron annual return as being represented by a shareholders' equity worth $4.2m?

—This Parliament and this chamber voted on the method by which the Attorney could give a direction to the Australian Securities Commission. It enables a directive to be given in general terms. I would say it specifically excluded the possibility of giving a direction in relation to any particular matter for the obvious reason that that body is to have its integrity and independence statutorily guaranteed so that investors, both domestic and overseas, can believe quite properly that it is not subject to political influence. So, for that reason, there will be no direction from the Attorney in relation to any particular matter.

PARA.TAB: If, in fact, the Australian Securities Commission becomes aware of a particular discrepancy that is alleged, I have no doubt that it has, as I said, the capacity and the will to ensure that the law is upheld so far as putting in proper statements is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Maguire.
—Well said Pontius Pilate.
—Mr Deputy President, I take strong exception to the offensive remark by Senator Bishop, `Well said Pontius Pilate'. I find that an offensive allusion and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—I did not hear the remark. But if the remark was made, I would ask that it be withdrawn.

—To the contrary, Mr Deputy President. I think it is in the public interest that the public know that the Minister is acting as Pontius Pilate. He is washing his hands of a matter which is clearly in the public interest. It is in the public interest to know whether or not what Senator Baume has said should be investigated. We have a situation where we perhaps have the richest Prime Minister we have ever had, if this documentation is to be believed. We have seen two conflicting reports. Senator Baume has asked that it be investigated. The Minister is acting as Pontius Pilate.
—The honourable senator will resume her seat. That remark is unparliamentary and I ask that Senator Bishop withdraw it.
—Would you prefer Judas Iscariot?
—I ask that you withdraw the remark.
—Withdraw `Pontius Pilate' or `Judas Iscariot'?
—I think you should withdraw both, Senator Bishop.
—One and a half.
—One and a half? I withdraw `Pontius' and `Judas'.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask that you require of the Senator that she withdraw both remarks concerning Pontius Pilate and Judas Iscariot in full terms.
—Yes, in full terms please, Senator Bishop.
—In full terms, Mr Deputy President—
—If you will just withdraw—
—I will withdraw both the terms that I applied to Senator Tate, namely that of Pontius Pilate and/or Judas Iscariot, in relation to this matter.
—Virgin Mary.
—Senator Bishop, you will withdraw unconditionally—not just in relation to this matter. You will withdraw unconditionally.
—Mr Deputy President, I will withdraw unconditionally the term that I used in relation to Senator Tate—that is, that I inferred he had behaved like Pontius Pilate and Judas Iscariot. I withdraw that.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President, would you direct Senator Button to withdraw his remark?
—Oh!

—We got a lecture from Senator Tate a minute or two ago about standards. Senator Button is demonstrating his own standards, which are not in accordance with the standard the Government seems to require of us.

—Order! There is so much loud conversation in the chamber that it is very difficult for the Chair to hear anything. I did not hear what Senator Button is alleged to have said, but if he said something that is unparliamentary I would ask him to withdraw it.
—What I said was, I thought, complimentary to Senator Bishop in terms of what she said. But I withdraw unequivocally, if it is regarded as offensive.
—With respect, Mr Deputy President, I would be delighted to be let into the secret of whatever it was he said. It might indeed, Mr Deputy President, be something sent in a postcard to me.
—Order! It might be worthwhile for us all to read the Hansard tomorrow. I call Senator Maguire.

—At long last, Mr Deputy President. I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, in this case Senator Tate, to the latest information on building activity and new housing commencements in Australia. Do the successive rises in quarterly housing starts indicate that a recovery is under way in this key labour intensive sector of the Australian economy?

—The housing sector is on track for growth again in 1992-93. There has been an increase in housing activity throughout 1991-92, as Senator Panizza would be aware. Housing starts have risen for five consecutive quarters and are at their highest level since September 1989. That is a very worthwhile matter to observe. In the June quarter 1992, total dwelling commencements were 38,390—9.3 per cent higher than in the March quarter of 1992. Over the year 1991-92, dwelling commencements rose to 139,875, a rise of 15.3 per cent compared to the previous year. Leading indicators suggest another increase in dwelling commencements in the September quarter of this year. That is also to be welcomed.

PARA.TAB: The Government has played its part in assisting this housing recovery. Home mortgage interest rates are now at their lowest level since 1980. This has contributed to the highest level of housing affordability since the September quarter of 1985. Information from the banking industry suggests a continued high level of home lending in August. The Housing Industry Association survey of volume builders reported a small increase in net sales, about one per cent, in the three months to July 1992.

In summary, the ABS statistics on dwelling approvals, housing finance approvals and dwelling commencements and market information suggests that the forecast by the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry of 152,000 starts for 1992-93 will be realised. This forecast is contained in the IPC's April 1992 short term prospects report. I thank Senator Maguire for giving me the opportunity to bring this to the attention of the Senate because it is extremely good news that there will be 152,000 new dwelling starts this financial year to help Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Is the Minister aware that there is a steadily growing number of married couples seeking to go on the IVF program? Is he also aware that these families are not able to adopt children, as there are no longer many babies available this way because of the increasing number of single supporting mothers and those having abortions? In view of the fact that the Government provides Medicare benefits for mothers seeking abortions, will the Government provide more funds to the IVF programs to enable more families to take part? Furthermore, will the Government consider providing Medicare benefits to cover the high medical costs for donors and recipients?

—Senator Bjelke-Petersen has raised a very sensitive area, where medical technology and science have been put at the service of those couples who wish to conceive a child but where one or other or both are for some reason infertile. There is no doubt that the in-vitro fertilisation program has brought a lot of joy to many couples. But for many women it is a very traumatic medical procedure.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the Medicare benefit is payable for six cycles of the treatment which stimulates the hormonal activity in relation to the female recipient of the procedure. So I believe that the Government has already shown a compassion for that situation. It does support in-vitro fertilisation procedures and treatment up to six cycles. I think Senator Herron would be able to confirm this, but I understand that it is up to about four cycles that one has a good prospect of conceiving and the embryo implanting in the womb in a way which leads to a successful birth.

In that situation, the taxpayer support, which I think is about $2,000 a cycle, is very substantial. I will pass on the honourable senator's question to see whether there is any plan to further extend taxpayer support for this procedure for couples. But it is already quite substantial, which ought to be acknowledged in this extremely difficult area of infertility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce say whether the Government agrees with Professor Sloane's forecast in the Australian Bulletin of Labour that unemployment will remain high for many years? Why does the Government persist with wage taxation and family policies which for thousands of families require both parents to be in the paid work force just to make ends meet? The recent unemployment figures show a drop in the work force participation rate with 43,900 people being forced out of the paid work force. Is it not callous for the Government to persist with policies which push more people to seek to go into the paid work force whilst doing nothing for those who are now forced out of the paid work force?

—Senator Harradine has asked me this question every month in various forms. I am not in a position to agree or disagree with Professor Sloane's figures. They are probably consistent with other figures which have been prepared for EPAC and so on, but I am not sure about that. I should have thought that Senator Harradine would have been pleased in a sense to see the participation rate fall. That means, if one looks at the unemployment figures for September, that there has been a fall in the participation rate and there has been a fall in part time employment, not in full time employment.

PARA.TAB: The participation rate is, to some degree, an indication of the extent to which married women are participating in the labour force. I do not know whether they are participating because they are forced to, as Senator Harradine wants to say each time he asks this question, or whether they are participating because of changed social views and improved opportunities for women in the work force and so on which have taken place over a number of years. I do not think it is very easy to assess those things.

But it is certainly true that there have been significant social changes in a number of countries, with Australia well up amongst them, which have led to women participating in the labour force much more regularly than they did in the past. It is not an Australian phenomenon, so it is a very easy thing to try to blame it on Australian policies, as Senator Harradine does. But it is not a phenomenon confined to this country; it is pretty general throughout the OECD.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. It is quite incorrect for Senator Button to suggest that I am saying that the participation of married women in the paid work force is a result of their being forced out. I asked the Minister what analysis has been done of those people who have been forced out by his Government's policies and who were forced into the paid work force for economic reasons; that is to say, two parents being required to work when one of them would prefer to be in the home. It is unfair and improper for the Minister to suggest that I support the decline in the participation rate without proper family policies. I ask again: what will the Government do to put those family policies in place so that a family can live on one income if it desires?
—Order! Time for the question has expired.

—There is a lot of debate in this country about lower income earners, but the family allowance plus the FIS payments are, I think, regarded in world terms as fairly generous in terms of a social net to help low income families. Senator Harradine went back, I am afraid, and illustrated the point I was trying to make by talking about people who were forced into the labour market and now he says they are being forced out. In so far as they have been forced into the labour market, that depends on a whole range of highly subjective analyses, and I do not think Senator Harradine—
—What about doing a survey of the ones who have been forced out?

—I do not think Senator Harradine can assert that people have been forced into the labour market and if we do undertake a survey, as he suggests, a survey of that kind will produce all sorts of very subjective results.

PARA.TAB: So in so far as the question of people being forced out of the labour market, it is true—as I said in answer to an earlier question—that there has been a decline in part time employment. But in aggregate, the unemployment situation is marginally better than it was.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the Estimates hearing on 17 September where Senator Cook and Mr Landos from AQIS referred to Minister to Minister discussions between Mr Crean and the Danish Minister of Agriculture, Mr Tornaes, and a briefing paper from AQIS to Minister Griffiths stating at this meeting that the Danish Minister raised the notion of access for uncooked pig meat and pig semen. I ask the Minister: why did he mislead the Senate when he said, on 19 June this year and again on 14 September, that there were no ministerial discussions on the issue of live pigs or genetic material imports from Denmark?

—I have heard of people flogging a dead horse but not of people flogging a dead pig. This is what National Party members have been doing through a long series of questions, hoping that they are on to something at last when in fact they are on to nothing. I have said on numerous occasions in the Senate that there were no discussions between Ministers relating to the importation of live pigs—that is true. So I do not know where Senator Boswell's question is now seeking to get him. Is he recycling old information or what? I have read the transcript of what was said at the Estimates committee. I would have thought if any senator had read that transcript, to use a colloquialism—I cannot think of anything else any more—he would pull his head in on the basis of the answers given by the officers concerned. So perhaps Senator Boswell has a supplementary question which can elucidate the original, but I cannot understand it at the moment.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question.
—This pig isn't going to fly.

—I do not need any assistance from the Senator, thank you. I have in my hand here a memo from Minister Griffiths which says that the Danish Minister for Agriculture raised the matter of access for uncooked Danish pig meat and pig semen during discussions with Mr Crean in April 1992. I would suggest to the Minister that it is very clear there was Minister to Minister discussion. I seek leave to table the document. Would the Minister care to comment on that?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could Senator Boswell please try to understand this as a National Party senator supposedly interested in rural interests. The people who raised this issue of pig meat, and also I think live pig imports, into Australia were the Queensland Agent-General in London, a former member of the National Party here in Canberra, and the New South Wales Government through its Minister. Indeed, they pursued this issue a lot. But Senator Boswell is trying to pursue somebody else, and I really think he is on the wrong tram. I have told him that many times before and I tell him again.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time yesterday Senator Alston asked me a question concerning the new rules to apply to the treatment of shares under the income test for the pension. Honourable senators will remember that he sought to illustrate his point by reference to the Prime Minister's private business. I have an answer to that, and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: The new rules which will apply to the treatment of shares under the income test are considered necessary as the existing rules provide an inequitable treatment of shares when compared with the treatment of other types of investments and provide an opportunity for circumvention of the income test.
At present only the value of dividends paid from shares is regarded as income. Capital growth is ignored. Losses from one parcel of shares cannot be offset against gains on other shares.
From September 1993 there will be two changes:

.Income will be calculated by multiplying the current value of the shares by the rate of return over the previous 12 months based on the change in value of that type of shares and any dividends or bonuses during the period.
.Where this rate of return is negative, the `negative income' from shares will be able to be offset against other income from shares or managed investments.

Senator Alston's example involved a pensioner with 1000 ordinary shares in BHP. Six months ago in March 1992, the value of these shares would have been $13,420. If the new rules were already in place, the rate of return based on the 12 months to the end of March 1992 would be 22.66%. The annual income assessed from these shares would be $3,040—$116.90 a fortnight.

If the pensioner had no other income, the income from the shares would result in the fortnightly pension being reduced by $15.45. If the pensioner had other income which exceeded the pension income test free area the income from the shares would reduce the fortnightly pension by $30.90.

However, under the proposed rules, it is also possible for the pensioner to ask for a reassessment at any time. In September 1992, as a result of a decrease in the market value of the shares, the 1000 shares would be worth $11,860. The rate of return to the end of September 1992 is—13.58%. This means that the rate of income is now negative:—$1,611 or $60 a fortnight. Under the new rules for shares, this amount could be offset against any other income from shares or managed investments owned by the pensioner.
Under current rules, a pensioner with BHP shares would not get any recognition in the pension income test for the decrease in the value of their share investment.
