ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Tierney asked me a question in my representative capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. I have a detailed answer to that question here. I wonder if the Senate would be kind enough to grant me leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: The question is based on false information presumably given to the Senator by someone involved in the University Partnerships (UP) group who is not prepared to accept the outcome of a due process of evaluation.
It follows other extravagant claims by Senator Tierney who obviously does not support the expanded access to higher education that the open learning initiative will provide.

On 18 June 1992 the Minister wrote to all universities inviting them to express interest in participating as a broker or provider of programs for an Open Learning Initiative (OLI). Requests for formal expressions of interest against detailed requirements were sought on 1 July 1992. The closing date for those expressions was 7 August 1992.

On the closing date a request came from UP seeking to make a late submission. Agreement was given to that request. On 21 August 1992 the Selection Panel of officials met with a representative group of UP and on the same day met with representatives of other proponents.

The Panel had many problems with the UP proposal as then developed but encouraged them to talk with Monash University to see if they could resolve some of the differences between consortium partners in the interest of achieving the best possible national result. A meeting of Monash and UP representatives was attended by a member of the Panel. The Panel convened another round of meetings and had further discussions with UP and the other major proponents on 4 September 1992.

A large number of the matters raised by UP as points of revision to the Monash proposal were in fact accommodated. However, in the view of the Panel the UP proposal in its revised form fell short of meeting the requirements set down in the request for expressions of interest. The Panel subsequently recommended that the Minister give in-principle approval to Monash to further develop its proposal in collaboration with other universities, including some members of the UP group. Negotiations are continuing with Monash to ensure that all government requirements for the open learning initiative are met prior to final approval.

As to the supplementary question of the Honourable Senator, the Minister is unaware of such allegations. The fact of the matter is that Monash University has encouraged the participation of others and modified its proposed arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday during Question Time Senator Panizza asked me a question about the ABC's reporting of a hoax in Western Australia involving an aircraft. I undertook to provide him with an answer today and I will do so now. The ABC has advised me that the report about the airline crash was provided to the ABC's Perth radio newsroom by a caller claiming to be from another media organisation. Prior to broadcasting the newsflash, the ABC contacted the police at Meekatharra, who I understand confirmed that they were investigating a plane crash.

PARA.TAB: Apparently, the ABC continued checking the story after the initial newsflash and found that neither the Civil Aviation Authority nor Ansett Australia had any reports of trouble with aircraft. Upon further investigation, the story was found to be a hoax which had been perpetrated upon a number of media organisations as well as the police. I understand that Perth's commercial GWN news also ran a crawl across its programs before the hoax was discovered.

The ABC has advised that its radio and TV news management will remind all journalists of the need to check with the appropriate sources before reporting news of an aircraft incident. In this instance it is acknowledged that the story should have been checked with the Civil Aviation Authority. I add that I think it is a good idea for journalists always to check with the primary source of a story, and that is something that I would remind Tom Burton of the Sydney Morning Herald of as well as the ABC journalists referred to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill on 8 October 1992 relating to unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel no alternative but to rise on this matter now, because of Senator Button's deficient answer and really the deficient answer of the Government in relation to today's appalling unemployment figures. Instead of facing up to the deficiencies in its own economic model which is the cause of these horrific figures, all this Government wants to do is look at the models of others.

PARA.TAB: I raised with Senator Button today the fact that since Mr Keating—who assassinated the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, last December—came to office, since the One Nation statement and all these much lauded programs that were going to bring about a recovery and an improvement in the unemployment position in this country, not one further job has been created. This horrific situation is continuing. Not one further job has been created. In fact, the figures put out today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicate to us that during the month of September of this year a further 43,800 jobs have been lost.

When I asked the Minister how the Prime Minister could answer to this appalling situation and how in such circumstances he could claim that the recession was long over, the only answer I could get was, `You should look at the model that exists in Britain; you should look at the model that is in Fightback!; and you should look at the model in New Zealand'. That model is now starting to show an improvement, and may well be one this Government should be looking at. In other words, the Government's answer has been to look at others rather than look at itself; it should be looking at itself.

The Government's economic model has failed in anyone's language. What is so frustrating the people of Australia at the moment is the fact that, although these unemployment figures are at record high levels and remain at record high levels, the Government will not face up to the responsibility of those figures and face up to the failure of its own economic program. All it can do, as is Mr Keating's usual behaviour, is attack the Opposition. That is not what the Australian people are expecting of a government in office. Certainly, the Government can question the Opposition's policies and so forth, but it is responsible for nearly one million people in this country being out of work. One would have thought that by now it would have revised the economic model that led to that appalling situation.

Mr Deputy President, you will remember the words of Mr Keating when he said, `There will be no recession'. Then when there was a recession he said, `This was the recession we had to have'. Now when we see this horrific situation of a million Australians unemployed what does he say? He says, `The recession is long over'. It is no wonder the Australian people are sick and tired of hearing this instead of a government seriously addressing the failings of its program and the disastrous consequences of those failings.

Mr Deputy President, I remind you of the figures released today: 33,800 more unemployed. The Bureau tells us that part time employment fell and for full time employment the trend of decline continues—a worsening situation. If I look at my own State for example, I see that 11.4 per cent of South Australians are unemployed. It is awful.

What is the trend estimate? The trend estimate, according to the Bureau, is that the unemployment rate continues to increase and now stands at 11 per cent. That situation was today backed by Dr Ed Shann who said that the underemployment rate could be pushing up to somewhere near 17.8 per cent. It is a horrific situation in anyone's language. The Chairman of Woolworths has come out today and reminded us that the manufacturing industry is still putting people off. That is the extent of the problem, and this Government ought to face up to it for a change. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The nonsense the Government came out with on unemployment in Question Time today is really quite appalling. We were told here in this chamber today that the participation rate was holding up brilliantly under this Government. That is simply false. In the last 12 months, there has been a massive addition to the number of hidden unemployed because the participation rate has fallen. When one goes behind the figures, one will see that they are even worse than my Leader just outlined. The participation rate was 63.3 per cent in September 1991; it is now 62.7 per cent. That represents 82,000 people who do not now show in the unemployment figures. In other words, well over one million people are really unemployed because 82,000 extra people have been discouraged from even participating in the work force over the last 12 months. Actually, the number of hidden unemployed is something like 800,000, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

PARA.TAB: This leads us to one point the Government was making today which was blatantly and clearly dishonest. That dishonest claim related to underemployed people. We heard the Government here today make the claim, through Senator Cook, that the figures were even worse in 1982-83. That is directly and knowingly false. The Minister cannot pretend he does not know what the figures are unless he is much more incompetent than we recognise him to be, although I must concede that that is a real probability.

The fact is that the Australian Bureau of Statistics, not Mr Ed Shann, compiles these figures via a survey. The latest survey for September 1992 shows a 17.6 per cent underemployment and unemployment rate, because 603,500 people are underemployed according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. When the underemployed are added to the figures for the officially unemployed, the total becomes 1,529,700 people underemployed or unemployed, which is 17.6 per cent of the work force.

Compare that to September 1982, the last September of the Fraser Government, when the underemployment and unemployment rate was only 10.7 per cent. That is the rate that Senator Cook tries to pretend to displace as being worse than the present 17.6 per cent. Nobody since the War has approached the level of unemployment and underemployment that this Government has perpetrated on the Australian people. The average for the 1982-83 financial year, which has been provided to me by the statistics section of the Parliamentary Library, was 12.8 per cent compared to this September's 17.6 per cent.

We and the people of Australia are being constantly and deliberately misled by this Government about the true nature of the unemployment disaster that it has imposed on Australians. The Victorian electorate has demonstrated that it will not tolerate, firstly, this kind of incompetence and, secondly, this kind of deception.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My greatest concern arising out of Senator Button's answers today and over this last week is the Government's refusal to acknowledge any share of responsibility for its own actions. One thing that particularly perturbs me is that, last Tuesday, following a speech to the Manufacturing Outlook Conference, Senator Button said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have also undertaken a good deal of micro-economic reform—in the Government's opinion about as much as the community can digest in such a short time.

That answer was received with shock, horror and disappointment in the business community. John Paterson, the national chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, said that Senator Button's comments showed that he was out of phase and out of touch. Bob Dunkerly, the New South Wales president of the Metal Trades Industry Association, called them ludicrous and not good enough. The Business Review Weekly said that it was a truly amazing statement.

PARA.TAB: When I raised this matter with Senator Button on Tuesday last, he tried to pretend that somehow his remarks were directed to tariff reform. That is a complete distortion of the facts. If it does represent Senator Button's genuine state of mind, it is a sad reflection on the Government's refusal to acknowledge responsibility. When I put those remarks to him, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . tariff reform . . . is a key element of micro-economic reform.

PARA.TAB: I said at the time that the speed limit in relation to tariff reform is as announced by the Government. . . . If Senator Alston would like to consult my speech, he will see a number of other statements relating to other types of micro-economic reforms which follow tariff reform. I did not suggest for a moment we were stalling the process.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that he absolutely did.

PARA.TAB: In his statement, which I have now read, Senator Button said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government announced two programs of gradual and pre-announced tariff cuts.
He then went on to say:
We have also undertaken a good deal of micro-economic reform—
the notorious words—
in the Government's opinion about as much as the community can digest in such a short time.
He then went on to say:
Of course, we still have a long way to go. But I submit that there is a speed limit shaped by cultural and historical factors.

In other words, the speed limit had nothing to do with tariff reform. Senator Button quite clearly said that the Government had hit the wall on micro-economic reform. If he is now saying that it has run out of speed on both, he ought to come clean and say that.

PARA.TAB: I call on Senator Button to come into this chamber and apologise for obviously misleading the Senate and trying to pretend that somehow his remarks ought to be construed in the context of tariff changes. The fact is that micro-economic reform under this Government has ground to a halt. As the Business Review Weekly points out:
The waterfront costs of exporting BHP steel from Australia are four times those in New Zealand and the mess threatens the growth of many of our exporters.

SPEECH.PARA: One does not have to be too bright to go through transport and telecommunications and all those other critical areas of micro-economic reform to see that the Government simply does not bite the bullet. Some of Senator Collins's remarks indicate that the Government has thrown in the towel in his area as well. What Senator Button has done is a clear case of denial of the overwhelming facts and a refusal to face up to his own admission that the Government has truly failed the micro-economic reform agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most, if not the most, crucial issue in Australia today is the unemployment crisis. I am most disappointed in the response and attitude that Senator Button shows and provides in answers to questions on this most important matter. That was seen in his answer to Senator Hill, which we are taking note of. Unfortunately, that sort of attitude is typical of Senator Button's approach to this matter in the last few months. It could be said that that sort of attitude is a substitute for substantial policy. Over a number of months I have been on the receiving end of little snide remarks by Senator Button when I have raised serious issues about the participation rate. When I have raised issues about government policies which are forcing many families to have both parents in the paid work force just to make ends meet, he comes back and snidely suggests that I am virtually saying to the women that they ought to get back to the kitchen. Nothing could be further from the truth.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am concerned, the issue is one of choice. Obviously, it is not an issue of choice as far as the Government is concerned. Its policies have been so constructed as to require both parents to be in the paid work force in thousands of cases. We all know of mothers in the paid work force who would much rather be at home caring full time for their children. The Government is persisting in those policies. Worse still, it is not analysing what is happening to the paid work force. In this particular instance I have simply asked why the Government is not doing a survey to ascertain how many of those 43,900 people who have lost their jobs in the last month are mothers, for example, who were forced into the paid work force or had to stay in the paid work force for longer than they wanted and are now being forced out of the paid work force.

Senator Baume and Senator Hill mentioned hidden unemployment. This situation of discouraged job seekers is a tragedy. They are the hidden unemployed. The Government obviously wants to keep them hidden and wants to keep their plight hidden. I have been asking the Minister what has happened to those families who are reliant on two incomes and now have to rely on only one income. How many of them have gone bankrupt? The Government will not come up with a survey. It wants to keep them and their plight hidden and that is a tragedy for Australia. It is the action of a callous government and an incompetent Minister.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—I call Senator Coulter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I wondered why you called Senator Coulter. The Democrats do not support the procedure of taking note of answers after Question Time. In the last two weeks they have moved to limit our right to take note of answers after Question Time. Senator Coulter knows that we have only another five minutes. He is standing up and taking up the time of people who value this particular procedure. I do not see why my right to take note of an answer should be effectively stopped by Senator Coulter.

—Senator Kemp, there is no point of order. The point you make is a debating point. I have called Senator Hill, Senator Baume and Senator Alston from the Opposition; Senator Harradine, an Independent; and Senator Coulter was the Senator who next seized my eye. I ask Senator Kemp to resume his seat. I call Senator Coulter.

—I raise a further point of order. The point I was making, which you did not rule on, was that Senator Coulter has deliberately inhibited this procedure for members of the Opposition. Now he is taking up our time and I do not see, in the sense of fairness and equity—which the Democrats are always talking about—why he should have the floor rather than myself.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the same point of order, you have pointed out that you called a number of Opposition senators, that you then called an Independent senator and now you are calling another senator from the crossbenches. Taking the point that Senator Kemp has made—that it is the Democrats who have forced this procedure upon us—I would have thought that if it is to apply, there ought to be a pro rata arrangement. I would have thought one Independent out of six was quite adequate, not two out of six, thereby giving them far too high a percentage of the time available.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on this point of order, it is absolutely remarkable that the Opposition cannot even get its facts straight. We supported the time limit of half an hour, with an allocation of four minutes for each person to speak. It is simply untrue that we did not support that procedure. Furthermore, on the point of order made by Senator Bishop, you will recall that the occupant of the Chair changed; in fact I did have the call earlier, and when you took the Chair you gave the call to Senator Baume. Clearly, the information that I had the next call was not on your desk.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the same point of order, in support of the points made by Senator Kemp and Senator Bishop, what Senator Coulter has just said is simply not correct. Senator Coulter frustrated the Senate and the coalition in the endeavour to get the time period allocated for taking note of answers extended for each speaker from four minutes to six minutes. In the most convoluted language and logic that we have ever heard in this chamber, he refused to accept that, whilst at the same time accepting an extension of four minutes to six minutes for answers given by Government Ministers during Question Time. I also point out to the Senate that the Democrats refused to accept a time limit of 60 minutes on the period in which to take note of answers. It is because of the Democrats that we are so frustrated and constrained in the time that we now have available to take note of answers. Quite frankly, what Senator Coulter said is just plain wrong.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a very quick point of order. You have to apply the Standing Orders. How those Standing Orders came to be in existence is quite irrelevant. Clearly Senator Coulter is entitled to the call as you have given it to him. To make their point, those on the other side have frustrated Senator Coulter in what he wants to do. They have punished Senator Coulter, but he should be allowed to get on with his speech. We ought to have an extension of time to allow him to do so.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—I have heard the four points of order and will rule on them. I have already indicated that the matters that Senator Kemp, Senator Short and Senator Coulter have raised are all debating points. The resolutions of the Senate—and this matter is subject to resolution of the Senate—are binding on all senators alike. Whether or not senators see individual senators being in favour of a particular resolution or to what degree they are in favour is irrelevant. The resolutions of the Senate are binding upon all senators.

With regard to Senator Bishop's point, I note that it is the convention of the Chair to take a speaker from one side of the chamber and then one from the other side of the chamber and to give appropriate weight to those who are standing and the mover of the motion. It is clear that the Opposition has moved to take note and seeks to speak to that motion. That is why there has been a predominance of Opposition speakers to this point.

Finally, I will deal with Senator Coulter's point about any list of names. Senator Coulter, I was not given your name; I was taking the chair after Senator Baume was called and I did not know that you were seeking to rise on this matter. Therefore, I think you were working under a misapprehension. I now call Senator Coulter to speak to Senator Hill's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to make a personal explanation under standing order 190.
—You can't until after Senator Coulter has been called.
—Yes, I can.
—Senator Bishop, I ask you to resume your seat.
—I am speaking to a point of order.

—You have indicated that you wish to give a personal explanation under standing order 190. This allows a senator to speak only if that senator has been misrepresented in the speech immediately beforehand. But in this situation we have had points of order being taken to the Chair. So, in my view, it is not the time to make a personal explanation.
—With respect, I wish to seek leave under standing order 190 because Senator Coulter in fact has misrepresented my position.
—You may seek leave.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps we should divide on this.
—There will be no division. Any one senator indicating that he does not agree leads to the refusal of leave. Because Senator Coulter is no longer in the chamber, I now call Senator Kemp.

—I, too, want to support the remarks of my colleagues on Senator Button's answer on this vital issue that has come before the chamber today, in view of the very dramatic figures which have been released on the employment trends—and the unemployment trends—in this country. It is important that one of my colleagues drew attention to the rather trivial nature of the answer that the Opposition received from Senator Button. This is a serious matter. It is very clear that it is the major issue concerning most Australians. When Senator Button was asked the question, what the Opposition wanted to know was what he proposed to do about it and whether the recession was over. All the Opposition really got from Senator Button in response to this very important and reasonable question—and certainly a question that many people in the public are concerned about—was, once again, a trivial and misleading attack on Dr Hewson and the Fightback plan. That is the very problem that we have had in Question Time day after day. Serious questions are put to Ministers, and the Ministers are under instructions from Mr Keating not to answer the questions that the Opposition puts to them but to get out and attack the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button has come into the chamber—and I hope that he will respond to this. Senator Button has been told by Mr Keating not to answer our questions but to try to turn the attack onto Dr Hewson and the Fightback plan. That was the very reason why, two weeks ago, this chamber moved to restrict the length of time that Ministers have to answer questions, feeling that, for most questions that are put, the two-minute time limit provides plenty of time for them to answer. But it did seriously inhibit Ministers from taking up that time, not by answering the question but instead by attacking the Opposition. We have had this ridiculous result that, after a four-day experiment on this important new initiative to see how the proposal shook down and how it worked its way through the procedures of this chamber, the Democrats crumpled under pressure from the Government and brought in the four-minute rule. We are now back to the bad old days where there are constant attacks on the Opposition and no answers to questions.

I do not have the final figures for today, but it seems that Question Time today went on for marginally more than an hour and we had 21 questions. This takes us back to the same old average that we have had over the period of the Hawke and Keating Governments. Question Time is being taken up not by Ministers attempting to answer questions but by Ministers attempting to attack the Opposition.

I put it to honourable senators that what we have seen today and what we have seen this week is a consequence of the very thoughtless and weak reaction of the Australian Democrats. They buckled under pressure from the Government and gave the Government what it so earnestly desired—the licence not to answer serious questions dealing with matters of serious concern to the public, but merely to use Question Time as a launching platform from which to attack the Opposition. I hope that what we have seen today and earlier this week will cause the Australian Democrats to reconsider their pathetically weak position on Question Time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am provoked, as usual, by Senator Kemp. I want to address briefly two allegations that the honourable senator made during the course of his speech. The first allegation was that I was under instructions from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to come in here and attack the Opposition. I have to tell Senator Kemp that I have no such instructions, and I do not need them.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition presents itself as an alternative government. The most honest man in its alternative government is John Howard. He said, `People who pretend that if we fell into government'—which is the only hope it has of getting into government; falling in like a drunk in the gutter outside a pub—`we would do something about unemployment in the short term are kidding themselves and the public'. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given earlier today by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice from Senator Foreman relating to aviation matters.

SPEECH.PARA: In his response today to the question from Senator Foreman about various aviation matters, Senator Collins quoted from a release called `Aviation Report' which reported on some aspects of a speech I gave and subsequent discussions I had with the Regional Airlines Association in Sydney a couple of weeks ago, on 24 September. Senator Collins claimed, and again he was quoting from the `Aviation Report' newsletter, that some of the key regional operators—and he mentioned in particular Mr Max Hazelton, the general manager of Hazelton Airlines—had said in the course of the discussions with me at that meeting following my speech that his company's best estimate of the savings as a result of the Fightback proposal was 4 or 5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins went on from there to claim the great concern that the airlines may feel as a result of a 15 per cent GST on sales of their airlines tickets. As is common nowadays with virtually all Ministers, there were some very significant omissions from the answer that Senator Collins gave. In particular, he completely omitted to mention that 80 per cent of Hazelton Airlines ticket sales are business sales and only 20 per cent are sales to private and leisure commuters. Of course, the 15 per cent paid by business on an airline ticket will be fully rebatable as a business input. When we average that out, taking the 80 per cent of Hazelton's total fare structure, which in effect will not be subject to GST at all, it means that across the board Hazelton's air ticket prices as a result of the GST would rise by only 3 per cent. That is a smaller figure than the amount of cost savings that Hazelton Airlines has accepted—it is a conservative costing—of 5 per cent in terms of its cost reductions. So Hazelton, on its own figures, will be better off and the price to business commuters after GST will fall.

So far as private or leisure commuters are concerned, any increase in the price of airline tickets will be far outweighed by the major benefits they receive from other elements of the Fightback package. I refer in particular to the average 30 per cent reduction in their personal income taxes, the 19c a litre reduction in their petrol prices, the additional $2,000 per year tax free income that they will be able to earn from additional savings, the much wider availability of superannuation coverage and its more equitable distribution, the higher productivity, higher real wages and higher levels of employment as a result of the major industrial relations and other reforms that will be introduced by a coalition government. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the report of Mr Graham Glenn on the removal of the Gillespie children from Australia in July 1992. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On 1 September 1992 the Attorney-General, the Hon. Michael Duffy, wrote to Mr Graham Glenn asking him to inquire into and report on the circumstances of the removal of the Gillespie children from Australia. The report was completed on 2 October 1992 and that is the report I am tabling. I wish to inform honourable senators that the report is also being tabled in the House of Representatives today by the Attorney-General, the Hon. Michael Duffy.

PARA.TAB: The Attorney-General and I welcome this report, noting that it concludes that the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Customs Service acted in an appropriate and generally timely manner using longstanding, proven practices for executing family law custody warrants.

Assistance was sought from and given by various Australian Federal Police regions, all Portswatch branches, the Australian Customs Service, the Victorian, New South Wales and Western Australian police and many private organisations. Surveillance and searches of premises were carried out and special checks made of passengers on selected international flights. But no information or intelligence was produced that might have led to the children being found.

Mr Glenn concludes that a reassessment of the action taken should have occurred involving all relevant agencies when it was not showing signs of a result and he indicated that some procedures needed to be improved. I can assure the Senate that those aspects of the report will be addressed as a matter of priority.

I might conclude by noting, as did Mr Glenn, that in the case of the Gillespie children, their removal occurred so early in the investigation, a change of direction following reassessment would not have produced a different outcome. It is a tragic outcome, particularly obviously for the Gillespies, but unfortunately there are some occasions when law enforcement agencies do not succeed regardless of their efforts. I seek leave to incorporate the report in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Introduction
I was asked by the Attorney-General on 1 September 1992 to inquire into the removal of the Gillespie children from Australia in the terms set out below.

`It appears that on or about 14 July 1992 contrary to orders of the Family Court of Australia Raja Kamarul Bahrin, a Malaysian national and resident, removed from Australia his two children, Iddin and Shahirah (know as `the Gillespie children'). It further appears that that action was taken despite the existence of a Family Court warrant to all police officers in Australia (issued 12 July 1992) to take possession of the children and deliver them to their mother, Yasmin Gillespie, the person entitled to custody by court order.
You are requested to inquire into and report on:
ta) the means by which the departure of Bahrin and the children from Australia was effected; and

(b) whether the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Customs Service (having regard to both its passenger processing and coastwatch functions) took all action reasonably required and reasonably open in the circumstances in seeking to locate, arrest, take possession of or prevent the departure from Australia of Bahrin and the children.

As the Government may wish to make public your findings and conclusions, and as criminal proceedings may arise out of the same matters, you should consult the Attorney-General's Department in preparing your final report to avoid so far as possible a situation where your report would not be able to be made public without prejudice to the fair trial of any person who may be the subject of such proceedings.

2. The inquiry required an examination of the events leading to the removal of the children, the procedures and practices followed by the Commonwealth agencies involved and the investigations they have undertaken subsequently. It also called for an assessment of the actions taken by those agencies responsible for preventing unlawful departures from Australia.

3. The Commonwealth agencies involved were the Australian Federal Police, Australian Customs Service, Australian Maritime Safety Authority (Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre), Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

4. While State Police played a part in the case, the primary responsibility rests with the Commonwealth agencies and it is on the latter that the inquiry concentrates. Any suggestion that State authorities should have a different role would clearly be something to be taken up with State Governments separately.

5. The inquiry has been conducted by examining files and other documents held by the Commonwealth agencies, detailed statements provided by them of the events and the outcome of subsequent investigations and discussions with agency principals and their officers who had a direct involvement in what occurred.
6. A meeting was also held with Mr and Mrs Gillespie and their solicitors.

7. In view of the time allowed the inquiry has only sought verification of the material presented where this was clearly essential to meet the terms of reference. Some of the material may be tested before a court in due course.

8. The report is divided into two parts. The first sets out in a chronological form the background to the case and the various events that occurred in July and earlier. The findings and conclusions of the inquiry are dealt with in the second part.

9. I have consulted with the Attorney-General's Department as directed and we have agreed certain matters which could prejudice the fair trial of a person the subject of criminal proceedings should be omitted from the report.
PART 1
Background

10. The Gillespie children Iddin (9 years) and Shahirah (7 years) were removed from Australia in July contrary to an order of the Family Court of Australia. Their removal followed an access visit by their father, Raja Kamarul Bahrin Shah, a Malaysian prince of the royal court of Trengganu.

11. On Thursday 9 July 1992 in Melbourne Raja Bahrin exercised access to the children, who are Australian citizens, in accordance with a consent order of 1991. The children were collected at their home at 5 pm and taken to the Victoria Hotel, Little Collins Street, Melbourne, where Raja Bahrin had reserved accommodation. They were to be returned at 12.30 pm on Sunday 12 July.

12. The children were seen at the Victoria Hotel on 9 July but not after that date. Raja Bahrin failed to return them to their mother on 12 July. On 26 July he held a press conference in Kuala Lumpur, shown later on Malaysian television, at which he claimed the children were also in Malaysia. This was subsequently confirmed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Proceedings in the Family Court of Australia

SPEECH.PARA: 13. Since 1985, when this matter first came before the Family Court of Australia, various proceedings have taken place and orders issued. In addition there were counter actions taken by Raja Bahrin in the Kadi Court (the Islamic Court) in Malaysia.

14. On 28 November 1985 the Honourable Justice Treyvaud made an interim order that Mrs Gillespie have sole guardianship and custody of the children of her marriage with Raja Bahrin. Among other things the Judge restrained Raja Bahrin from removing the children out of Victoria and Australia.

15. This order was sent to the Australian Federal Police in Melbourne by Mrs Gillespie's solicitors on 3 December 1985 with a request that the children be noted "on your Federal Watch List". The Australian Federal Police entered the names of the children on the passenger alert system managed by the Australian Customs Service on 5 December 1985. There have been regular updates of that entry since then.

16. Raja Bahrin then applied to the Family Court for a discharge of the November 1985 orders and sought orders for the guardianship of the children and custody of the older child. He submitted that the matter was a "kidnapping case" and that the wife and children should be returned to Malaysia.

17. In February 1986 Justice Treyvaud ordered that the children be returned to Malaysia in the wife's care on various conditions including upon an undertaking that steps would be taken to ensure that the matter would be litigated in the High Court of Malaysia and not the Kadi Court.

18. An appeal by Mrs Gillespie was effectively upheld by the Full Court of the Family Court in a judgment delivered on 27 June 1986. It was decided that the children should not be returned to Malaysia and that the custody application should be heard in the Family Court of Australia.

19. On 1 November 1991 a consent order was made by the Family Court providing for joint guardianship of the children but giving sole custody of them to Mrs Gillespie. It also dealt with access arrangements which would apply to Raja Bahrin. The conditions of access required that Raja Bahrin
. give Mrs Gillespie one month's notice in writing of his intention to exercise access and advise her of the hotel arrangements with respect to access;
. deliver to his solicitors prior to the commencement of access his passport and airline ticket which were to be held by them until the children were returned to Mrs Gillespie;
. allow the children to telephone Mrs Gillespie daily.
The restraint on Raja Bahrin removing the children out of Victoria and Australia was maintained.

20. In chambers on Sunday 12 July 1992 the Honourable Justice Joske ordered the issue of a warrant to the Marshal, the Australian Federal Police and all State and Territory Police Forces to take possession of the children and deliver them to Mrs Gillespie. The Judge also gave authority for Mrs Gillespie and her solicitors, Price Brent, to publish details of the case as they thought fit in order to ascertain the whereabouts of the children. The warrant was issued and delivered to the Australian Federal Police in Melbourne that day.

21. The following day the passenger alert system was up-dated to show the existence of this warrant. At the same time the Australian Federal Police enhanced the alerts on the children under various names—twenty for Iddin and eleven for Shahirah instead of two and three respectively.
22. On 15 July 1992 a warrant was issued for the arrest of Raja Bahrin and the passenger alert system activated in two names.

23. Raja Bahrin came to Australia in July to visit his children having earlier given notice to Mrs Gillespie in June, as required by the Family Court order of 1 November 1991. He advised her that he required access on three separate occasions between 6 and 15 July and would reside at the Victoria Hotel, Lit~e Collins Street, Melbourne.

24. He arrived in Melbourne on Malaysian Airlines Flight MH 121 early on Saturday 4 July 1992. He travelled on a Malaysian passport with a multiple entry visitor visa issued by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in Kuala Lumpur on 10 February 1992. The visa was valid for one year and allowed Raja Bahrin to stay in Australia for three months on each occasion he entered.

25. The Incoming Passenger Card presented to the Australian Customs Service on arrival indicated that Raja Bahrin had boarded the aircraft in Malaysia, intended to stay in Australia for 10 days, that his main reason for coming to Australia was a holiday and that he intended to reside at the Victoria Hotel.

26. At 6 pm on 4 July Raja Bahrin checked into the Victoria Hotel. The Hotel has advised that he was booked to stay from 4 July to 15 July although the Hotel Registration Card shows a departure date of 14 July. Two adjoining twin rooms Nos. 212 and 214 were allocated to him.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Means of Departure from Australia

SPEECH.PARA: 27. Evidence obtained by the Australian Federal Police indicates that

(a) Raja Bahrin left Melbourne with the children and an accomplice on 10 July, the day after the second access visit commenced . Making essential stops only they travelled by car to Weipa in Queensland arriving on the evening of 12 July.

(b) Two vehicles were used for the journey. A station wagon rented by the accomplice in Melbourne was used for the first stage to Cairns. There they transferred to a utility with canopy owned by the accomplice to drive to Weipa.

(c) The accomplice had two weeks earlier taken his Starcraft cabin cruiser to Weipa where he had arranged for mechanical repairs to be made. The vessel is similar in appearance to a game fishing boat and had been fitted with long range fuel tanks that gave it capacity to cover approximately 700 nautical miles.

(d) Following some further mechanical trouble the vessel sailed from Weipa either on the night of 14 July or early in the morning of 15 July. While Raja Bahrin and the children were not seen in Weipa, all the available evidence points clearly to them being on board the vessel with the accomplice and to the vessel sailing north.
(e) The vessel had been refuelled to capacity giving it range to easily reach countries to the north of Australia and return.

Subsequently Raja Bahrin is reported as stating that he left Australia by vessel and travelled to Malaysia through Indonesia. The vessel has not been seen/identified by Australian authorities since leaving Weipa.

28. The disappearance of the Gillespie children first came to the attention of Commonwealth agencies on Saturday 11 July 1992. Mrs Gillespie telephoned the Australian Federal Police in Melbourne on the afternoon of that day expressing concern about her children. They had failed to telephone her during the access visit and it appeared the children and their father had not been at the Victoria Hotel for two days. Her last contact with the children had been at 5 pm on 9 July when Raja Bahrin had collected them from their home.

29. The Australian Federal Police made an immediate check of the outwards passenger movements at the Melbourne International Airport but no movement record for the children or their father was found. This was conveyed to Mrs Gillespie who was also advised about legal action that she might take through her solicitor.

30. Mrs Gillespie telephone the Australian Federal Police again on the following day and was referred to Family Law Squad members then on duty. She later visited the Australian Federal Police Headquarters in Melbourne where she met the Squad members and provided photographs of both children.

31. The photographs were delivered to the Melbourne Airport that afternoon and arrangements were made for them to be distributed to all Australian Customs Service officers working in departure/outward areas and those coming on duty on later shifts.

32. The warrant for the children to be taken into possession and returned to their mother was issued by the Family Court later on 12 July and was received by the Australian Federal Police at about midnight.

33. On 13 July the Australian Federal Police updated the passenger alert system to show the existence of the warrant . Its Portswatch Branch at the Melbourne Airport was also informed of the upgrade. Following normal practice a series of checks were then undertaken involving all five members of the Family Law Squad in Melbourne including:
. Australian telephone numbers called by Raja Bahrin during his stay at the Victoria Hotel.
. The Solicitors for Raja Bahrin holding his passport and return airline ticket.
. The airline with which Raja Bahrin had a return booking for a departure on 15 July.
. All rental companies which could have rented a car to Raja Bahrin .
. Financial institutions with whom Raja Bahrin may have conducted business.
. The Victoria Hotel staff and the rooms occupied by Raja Bahrin during his stay there.
. Contacts suggested by Mr and Mrs Gillespie.
. Sightings of the children (of which there were 12 on the first day and 10 subsequently) reported by members of the public as a result of the media exposure.

34. The Police found that most of the Australian telephone calls had been made to hotels, guest houses and parks in the Healesville/Warburton area near Melbourne, and that Raja Bahrin had made bookings at several for 9 and 10 July but did not arrive at any of them. Subsequently all listed hotels and guest houses in the area were contacted with a negative result. Similarly all the other checks and investigations failed to produce any information on the possible location of the children.

35. The circumstances of the disappearance of the children and photographs of them were circulated to all Portswatch Branches in Australia (i.e. all international airports) late on 13 July requesting that the photographs be provided to all Australian Customs Service officers working in the departure/outward area at the airports. In one case, Sydney, hard copies of the photographs were sent by air when the facsimile copy proved unsatisfactory.

36. On 14 July the Family Court warrant, photographs of the children and descriptions of them and their father were sent to the Victorian and NSW Police requesting that they notify all country Police Stations. Family Law Squads in other Regions were also provided with the warrant, orders and photographs.

37. On the following days up until 24 July the Family Law Squad in Melbourne coordinated and conducted many investigations of the type listed above. Assistance was sought from and given by other Australian Federal Police Regions, all Portswatch Branches, Australian Customs Service, the Victorian, NSW and WA Police and many private organisations. Surveillance and searches of premises were carried out and special checks made of passengers on selected international flights. But no information or intelligence was produced that might have led to the children being found.

38. During this period the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade had contact with Mr and Mrs Gillespie about possible consular activity and legal processes in the event it turned out the children had been removed from Australia. The Department through the Australian High Commissioner in Kuala Lumpur also notified the Malaysian Ministry of Foreign Affairs of its interest in the case and requested assistance to ascertain whether the children were in Malaysia and, if so, their general well being. This action did not produce any information either.

39. Late on 24 July the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade told Mr and Mrs Gillespie that they were reasonably certain the children were in Indonesia on their way to Malaysia. The Australian Federal Police received similar advice that night. Confirmation was given on 26 July by Raja Bahrin's appearance in Kuala Lumpur.
40. The Family Law Squad activities ceased the following week as the matter had become a criminal investigation.

41. It has been suggested that a vessel called "Pencheroboh", (a name bearing no resemblance to that of the vessel referred to in para 27 above) may have been involved in the removal of the Gillespie children from Australia. In the days following Raja Bahrin's departure from Weipa there was a search and rescue incident involving a vessel identifying itself by that name. The vessel had broken down north of Australia and had requested assistance which was given by the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre.

42. On 15 July 1992, Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre received reports from all over Australia concerning possible distress calls from an unknown vessel, believed initially to be in South Australian waters. The messages were received on Citizens Band (CB) radio and were very garbled, with no accurate position given.

43. Further information received indicated that the vessel which was then thought to be an Indonesian fishing vessel could be 80 nautical miles north west of Weipa. One call in Indonesian also contained the message "Please help two small children on board Indonesian". At the request of the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre, Coastwatch diverted an aircraft to that position but when contact with the vessel could not be made, the aircraft was released by the Centre to resume its scheduled surveillance task.

44. On 16 July, reports to the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre indicated that a vessel was broken down some 80 nautical miles south of Merauke, Indonesia and that it required a tow into Merauke. (Merauke is a small port on the southern coastline of Irian Jaya, Indonesia, some 160 miles north west of Thursday Island, Queensland. The position given was in international waters JUSt outside the Australian search and rescue area and in Indonesia's area of responsibility.)

45. A Coastwatch aircraft was tasked by the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre to undertake a search and rescue mission to locate the vessel. The aircraft sighted the vessel in international waters 80 nautical miles SSW of Merauke and communications were established. The vessel was described as an eleven metre game boat with white hull, beige deck, white cabin with a wooden door and guardrails on the forward deck. The drift of the vessel was carrying it towards the Indonesian coast.

46. The person contacted on the vessel advised that his name was Abdul Rahman Said, that he was the only person, he was safe, had plenty of food and water and the vessel's name was "Pencheroboh". He also indicated that he had total engine failure and requested that a specific person in Merauke be informed that a mechanic was needed. This message was relayed by the Coastwatch aircraft to Merauke aviation authorities and by the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre to the Indonesian search and rescue authorities. In addition the Centre broadcast urgency messages to shipping in case any vessel in the area was able to assist.

47. On 17 July more distress calls were received from the "Pencheroboh" prompting offers of assistance from other vessels in the area. The Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre also sought assistance from the Royal Australian Navy. Late that day RAN patrol vessel HMAS Dubbo advised that it was diverting to the distressed vessel and would assist with engine repairs or if this was not possible would transport the crew member to Thursday Island. Its expected time of arrival in the area was 12.30 pm the following day.

48. On 18 July certain CB operators around Australia established two-way communications with the `Pencheroboh". One operator reported that the `Pencheroboh' was 30 nautical miles off Merauke, had five persons on board with no food or water and had an urgent need for medical assistance. A message that HMAS Dubbo would be in the area to assist in approximately five hours was passed on to the `Pencheroboh".. Shortly afterwards the `Pencheroboh" indicated that it was underway, that it did not require assistance from HMAS Dubbo and expressed regret for the trouble caused. The Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre then advised the RAN and Coastwatch that assistance was no longer required and cancelled its urgency message to other shipping.

49. Further distress calls were reported the following day including separate messages that there were women and children on board and that there were three children on board. There were other messages that the vessel had drifted ashore. The information was passed on to the Indonesian search and rescue authority.

50. On 20 July the Indonesian search and rescue authority advised that a fishing boat from Merauke had been sent to tow in the "Pencheroboh" and followed up with a message on 23 July that five crew from the vessel had been rescued safely.
51. Evidence available to me suggests that:

(a) The Gillespie children, their father and an accomplice departed from Weipa, Queensland, on the Starcraft cabin cruiser on 14 or 15 July 1992. They travelled with their father and the accomplice to Weipa by car leaving Melbourne on 10 July and arriving at Weipa on 12 July.

(b) Only the accomplice, who had earlier purchased the vessel in Perth and taken it to Weipa, was seen in Weipa. Repairs to the vessel probably delayed the departure by two days and even then they left with mechanical problems including to the engine.
(c) Considerable funds were expended in the purchase of a vehicle and the vessel, repairs to both and in international and domestic travel. Almost all transactions were in cash.

52. Raja Bahrin observed all the requirements of the Family Court order of 1 November 1991 by giving due notice of his desire for an access visit including the hotel where the children would reside during the visit and by surrendering his passport and tickets when he arrived
53. He entered Australia on a valid visitor visa in the proper manner with a return ticket to Malaysia for 15 July.

54. He had an access visit on 6 and 7 July in the normal way before returning the children to their mother. He collected the children from their home on 9 July for a second access visit as earlier arranged.
55. There was no suggestion in this behaviour of the events that followed.

56. Personal possessions and documents were left in the Victoria Hotel rooms that gave the impression Raja Bahrin would return with the children and was simply sightseeing in or near Melbourne. The accommodation bookings made at various hotels in the Healesville/Warburton area for 9 and 10 July added to this impression. They also set up a false trail.

57. The means by which the departure was effected had significant risks. To undertake such a risky venture suggests some desperation but more importantly that a judgment was made that departure by the normal means was not open to them.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Role and Operations of Commonwealth Agencies

SPEECH.PARA: 58. Primary responsibility for this family law matter rests with the Australian Federal Police. The Australian Customs Service has a principal involvement through its management of international passenger processing, Coastwatch and barrier control.
59. The Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre has become implicated inadvertently because of the "Pencheroboh" incident.

60. The other two agencies, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, have interests related to entry visa control and consular activities.

61. Australian Federal Police Regional Commands are responsible for handling individual cases in their Regions and deploying resources to meet priority demands. In this case the Southern Region has managed the Gillespie family law matter since it began in 1985.

62. This is an appropriate devolution of authority by the Australian Federal Police—it is supported by policy guidelines and reporting arrangements which enable the Commissioner to maintain overall control of performance.

63. There is, however, a standing arrangement for various operations declared to be national operations and for sensitive matters to be centrally monitored to ensure they are being effectively managed and resourced. While the Gillespie case remained for the entire period a Southern Region responsibility, it was monitored from 13 July.

64. The Southern Region does not have written procedures for executing Family Court orders but it does maintain a check list for inquiries in relation to custody warrants. The actions taken in this case followed the standard practice of checking with other police records, with State and Commonwealth agencies, with financial institutions, reported sightings etc.

65. Information obtained from these sources is usually sufficient to enable children to be located. In the financial year 1991/92 75 Family Court custody warrants were executed in the Southern Region and 111 children returned to their legal guardian. In the last three financial years all the children the subject of a custody warrant were found and returned to the appropriate person.
66. There were different features in the Gillespie children case, however, to most of the custody warrant investigations referred to above:
. connections with family members or friends which are normally available were not present;
. Raja Bahrin being a short term foreign visitor did not appear in the records of most other agencies and institutions;
. the investigation commenced more than three days after the children had been last seen;
. the investigation required contact to be made with more people than normal to follow up reported sightings and the inquiries in the Healesville/Warburton area;
. reported sightings were totally unproductive (with the knowledge we now have they could not have been the Gillespie children).

67. Marginally more resources than normal were therefore allocated from within the Family Law Squad to the investigation. It is customary for a case to be allocated to an individual member, who takes all the action required, assisted by others on a needs basis only, for example when effecting an arrest. Two officers, including the Detective Sergeant in charge of the Squad, worked on a full time basis while the remaining three contributed at various times when needed. Assistance was provided as required by other parts of the Australian Federal Police and other agencies both Commonwealth and State.
68. Generally the investigation followed standard practices for executing Family Court custody warrants and was treated in a routine way.

69. The Australian Customs Service passenger alert system PASS, was operating effectively. The entries on the system for the Gillespie children were up-graded and enhanced in a timely manner by the Australian Federal Police. The addition of Raja Bahrin to the system was effected on the day the arrest warrant was issued.

70. On the other hand notification of an alert to Australian Customs Service Passenger Processing areas at airports other than Melbourne was not satisfactory. An all ports warning was not issued by the Australian Federal Police until late on 13 July 1992, the photographs of the children were not of high quality and the information was received over a period of several days, the last on 16 July. An ameliorating factor in this case, however, was the extensive media coverage which alerted staff at other airports—in addition at some ports newspaper photographs were found to be of more use than those distributed by the Australian Federal Police.

71. No Australian Customs Service Barrier Control outports were notified of the alert. Normal outward movement through those points, however, would have activated the PASS alert system. The Australian Customs Service's national computer network INTERCEPT links all Barrier Control points, including remote outports and gives access to the PASS alert system.

72. Similarly Coastwatch was not notified of the alert. (Mr and Mrs Gillespie assert that the Australian Federal Police informed them that this had occurred. For its part the Australian Federal Police is adamant that reference was made to its Portswatch Branch but not Coastwatch.)

73. Notification of the alert was confined to the Victorian and NSW Police primarily their country network—and the WA Police in Fremantle in response to reported sightings and externally provided leads.

74. The Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre treated the "Pencheroboh" incident as a regular search and rescue situation following its standard practices which include diverting Coastwatch aircraft (as happened twice) and seeking the aid of other vessels nearby. The HMAS Dubbo (and other vessels) responded to the latter request.

75. Initially the very garbled messages received on Citizens Band (CB) Radio rather than Marine HF frequencies with no accurate position being given suggested to the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre and Coastwatch that they could be hoax calls. With the assistance of radio operators around Australia—another common practice an accurate position and eventually two-way communications were established.

76. During the incident there was a discrepancy in the reports of the number of people on board the vessel, which varied from one to five. The very sudden release of the HMAS Dubbo by the "Pencheroboh" and later more may day calls also suggested something different about the situation.

77. Given the type of incidents that occur in these waters, the garbled nature of the reports and possible language difficulties these aspects were not regarded as significant or unusual. Indeed throughout the incident the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre and Coastwatch believed the `Pencheroboh" to be an Indonesian fishing vessel out of the port of Merauke, which had broken down and was requesting a tow back to Merauke. No vessel with that name was known to have been in Australian waters.

78. The actions of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in this matter were not directly related to the removal of the children. They accorded, however, with proper practice and procedures and were effectively carried out.

79. Australia has well developed computer technology, management techniques and systems, sophisticated equipment and well trained people to manage movement of vessels, aircraft, people and goods to and from Australia.

80. The investment of resources has been considerable over many years and continues as innovative programs and processes are developed here and overseas. In a number of areas, Australia is in the forefront of these developments.

81. Resources are appropriately allocated to meet business demands and to target high risk areas. The Australian Customs Service, for example, has a network of more than 90 offices strategically located around Australia, mainly protecting our 37,000 kilometres of coastline. Resources are nevertheless, thinly spread, especially to manage movement of people in isolated areas.

82. The procedures and processes in place adequately cope with lawful movement into and out of Australia. We have much more difficulty though than most responding to the unlawful, unusual and unexpected movement of people. The events of July amply demonstrate this.

83. It needs to be emphasised that the Gillespie children were taken out of Australia secretly just two to three days after it became apparent that they would not be returned to their mother. (Had there not been mechanical trouble with the vessel they may well have left earlier.) The chances of preventing their departure were therefore extremely remote.

84. The passenger processing arrangements in place would have prevented the children being removed from Australia had they attempted to depart by air or sea in a lawful way. The systems that support them are effectively maintained and managed.

85. Consequently an elaborate operation was mounted and with the assistance of an accomplice the children taken out of Australia unlawfully by a small vessel from the remote northern port of Weipa. Normal arrangements and procedures cannot stop this happening.

86. In responding to the disappearance of the children in Melbourne the Australian Federal Police employed their standard search processes and techniques for such cases. They rely almost entirely on information provided by external sources. Their excellent recent record in recovering children has shown that the methods used are generally effective.

87. The resources allocated (or available) by the Australian Federal Police to the search were adequate for the approach being taken. Assistance was also freely supplied by other authorities. The coordination of the activities by the Family Law Squad in Melbourne were satisfactory for the task as well. There was no need for a special task force to be established.

88. When this approach was not showing any signs of success, however, a reassessment of it should have occurred. That it did not occur calls into question the effectiveness of the Australian Federal Police monitoring process for such investigations.

89. Only occasionally would family law cases warrant any special treatment, given the other serious matters under investigation by the various authorities, but there should be a place for exceptions. The adherence to standard practices is not sufficient to meet all situations.

90. A more coordinated effort—including greater sharing of information, intelligence and workload with other Commonwealth, and where appropriate State, agencies would be a desirable outcome from such a reassessment. In the Gillespie case a meeting of the principal agencies did not take place until after the children reached Malaysia.

91. The circumstances under which alerts are distributed to other agencies and the extent of their distribution requires further examination. While being conscious of the need not to overburden others or lessen the impact of material circulated in this way, wider distribution in selected cases would be justified. In the Gillespie case distribution to the Australian Custom Services' Barrier Control at outposts was warranted for example.

92. Similarly Coastwatch and the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre could have been alerted. This is not really useful, however, unless other intelligence relating it to a vessel or incident is available and in the case of Coastwatch, they are tasked appropriately.

93. The procedures for distributing material should be more clearly defined and understood by all agencies and the lines of communication (the cause of delay) more direct. A centrally managed system would have been more effective in the Gillespie case.

94. With the benefit of hindsight, the possibility of the Gillespie children being on board the "Pencheroboh" cannot be dismissed. Despite views to the contrary the events were not so unusual for search and rescue incidents north of Australia as to draw attention. There was no reason at the time for Coastwatch or the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre to suspect the vessel was other than what it claimed to be.

95. In summary, the inquiry found that the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Customs Service acted in an appropriate and generally timely manner using longstanding, proven practices for executing Family Court custody warrants. When the action being taken was not showing any signs of producing a result, a reassessment of it should have occurred involving all relevant Commonwealth and State agencies. On infrequent occasions a higher priority needs to be given to family law matters by the Australian Federal Police. Some of their procedures also need to be improved. In this case as the removal of the Gillespie children had been effected so early in the investigation, a change of direction following reassessment would not have produced a different outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for tabling this report, which is the document produced by Mr Glenn. I might remind the Senate that the Government undertook this inquiry largely as a result of my questions and concerns relating to this matter and the suggestion that I might press for a Senate inquiry into matters concerning the removal of these young Australian citizens from the protection of the Australian jurisdiction.

PARA.TAB: Upon reading the report, I am deeply disturbed. I am more convinced than ever that the search for the Gillespie children was inadequate. If there had been an adequate search, the children might well have been recovered before they were removed from this country.

In his statement, the Minister said that a change of direction following reassessment would not have produced a different outcome. I dispute that. On the basis of the information put before us, I do not believe that one can reach that conclusion. I accept that Mr Glenn said that he thought that if a different procedure had been adopted even then the recovery of the children would have been unlikely. The trouble is that we do not know because other procedures in this investigation were not included.

Let me briefly remind the chamber of what occurred as we know it. It seems that the father of these children, a Malaysian citizen, was taking proper access of his children under the Family Law Act in this country and that he abducted those children in breach of the order of the Australian Family Court and took them from this country back to his homeland in Malaysia.

We know that he arrived in this country under a proper passport and that he complied with the proper entry requirements of Australia and deposited his ticket and his passport with the due authorities—in this case the solicitors for the Gillespies—in accordance with the order of the Family Court.

We then know that the children disappeared. The distraught Gillespies, Mrs Gillespie and her husband, contacted the AFP, the Australian Federal Police, seeking its help to discover the whereabouts and return of the children. The Australian Federal Police adopted procedures which seem to be consistent with those which it has adopted before in previous such cases with, it seems, quite good success. That is the key in this instance. The Australian Federal Police considered that the practices it had adopted—the methods of investigation that it had adopted—in the past would be adequate in this case.

But I ask you, Madam Deputy President, to address the likelihood of what the father of these children would have done to get them out of the country. He may have taken them out through airports, put them on an international flight, but one would have thought that that was probably unlikely because a Malaysian citizen with two very young Australian-Malay children would have stood out at the normal Customs checks and they would have been discovered. One would have thought that probably he would have sought to remove them either by air, through light aircraft, from northern Australia or by boat from northern Australia. The AFP took the procedure of monitoring airports through the Australian Customs Service. As a safeguard, it should have done that even though it was probably unlikely that the Malaysian Prince would have been so foolish as to attempt to use that avenue.

But the AFP did not alert Coastwatch to watch for any unusual boat movements to the north of Australia and it did not alert police forces of Australia outside of New South Wales and Victoria, particularly police forces in northern Australia. One would have thought—and I am surprised that it did not strike Mr Glenn as obviously as it strikes me—that they would have been very basic decisions made in the investigation process early on.

Mr Glenn in his report—and I accept his bona fides in his efforts, of course, in this report—says that, when it was apparent that its earlier strategy was failing, perhaps the AFP should have looked at these additional options. But I suggest that it should have been obvious that these other options should have been taken into account and covered from the very start of this investigation, because Mrs Gillespie, the distraught mother, said to the AFP, `What we suspect is going to happen is that he is going to try to take them out of the country away from the protection of the Australian courts and return them to Malaysia, his home'. The failure to take this action by the AFP and of course of the administration of justice in this instance by the Australian Government is that Coastwatch was not alerted and the State police forces, particularly in Queensland and Western Australia, also were not alerted.

It seems that what happened was that the Prince and an accomplice took the children by car to northern Australia, to Weipa, where they picked up a smallish game-fishing boat that had earlier been purchased for the purpose of removal of the children. Then they took them offshore, it seems, through Indonesia back to Malaysia. What happened by a series of coincidences, we now believe, was that Coastwatch intercepted the boat on which we believe the children had been placed because there were calls being made for assistance from that boat, but Coastwatch did not link the possible presence of the children on the boat to the Gillespie case; it did not link the facts of the Gillespie case to the boat it was investigating.

The Minister shakes his head but, if he reads Mr Glenn's report, he will find that the calls for assistance that were given from this boat in one instance even referred to the presence of two young children on the boat. Then we get into a confusing pattern where not only the Coastwatch aircraft of Australia intercepted the vessel or took account of the mayday calls but also an Australian naval vessel went to give assistance. Surprisingly, when the Australian naval vessel went to give assistance, it got a response from the vessel that the engine trouble had been overcome, and so it turned away. Yet the following day, it seems that the calls continued.

There was this mysterious set of circumstances of calls for assistance and then, when Australian naval vessels went to give assistance, they were told they were not required and the calls for assistance continued, with several of those calls making reference to the fact that there were children on the boat—in one instance, two small children, and another suggestion was that there were three small children. One would have thought that the Coastwatch officials, who were taking that course of action, would have been also looking for the possibility of these children being spirited off the north of Australia by boat. But they were not because they had not been tasked to do so. That is the major failing in my view.

When I put that to representatives of the AFP in the Estimates Committee, their answer to that was, `We did not do it because we could not apply a specific task to Coastwatch'. To me, that is an unsatisfactory explanation because all they should have simply instructed Coastwatch was that there was a possibility that these children could be taken offshore in an effort to return them to Malaysia by small vessel, and that Coastwatch should keep a look out for such a possibility. But it did not occur. If they had been keeping a look out for such a possibility, as circumstances developed when there was this series of mysterious calls from this vessel and the suggestion that there may have been two young children on the vessel, obviously their interception of that vessel, I respectfully suggest, would have been in a different light.

The other possibility and shortcoming I mentioned a moment ago was the fact that north Australian police had not be tasked also. As I said, the fishing boat took off from Weipa. The children and their father were in Weipa, it seems, for possibly two days before the vessel left Australian shores. But was there any check being made on small boats leaving Australia in mysterious circumstances during this period of time when the AFP believed that there were attempts being made to remove these two young children from Australia? No. I would have thought that that would have been an elementary procedure that would be taken in these circumstances.

When the officers of the AFP sat down presumably after they were instructed by the Gillespie family that they believed their children had been abducted, one would have thought they would have addressed the possibilities that were open for the removal of these children from the jurisdiction, would have recognised the possibilities of removal of them from north Australia by boat or small aircraft, and would have at least made efforts to cover that possibility. That, in this instance, they did not. If they had done so then, as circumstances developed, I think there would have been a very real chance that these children would have been apprehended and protected by the Australian jurisdiction before they were lost from the protection of our courts.

That is what particularly disturbs me in this matter. I believe that the Government should face up to that failing. It should recognise that it was a failing that occurred in these circumstances; it should ensure that the AFP is properly instructed in future circumstances where attempts are being made to remove children from the protection of the Australian courts; and it should ensure that options such as removal by light aircraft and boat from the north of Australia are covered.

I finish on just a few other matters also remaining which cause me concern in this matter. I still do not know why officers of the Australian Federal Police on July 24—that is some nine or 10 days after the children had left Australia—were telling the Government they were confident that the children were still in this country. I thought we would get an answer to that in this document, and we have not. As I said, I still do not know why the search was concentrated in southern Australia.
