That also is not explained in this document when, as I said, it should have been so obvious that the north of Australia should have been covered and was just as important if not more important than searches within southern Australia.

I do not know why a meeting of the principal agencies involved in the search did not take place until the children had, in fact, reached Malaysia. One suspects, of course, that that coordinating meeting took place to look at ways to explain the deficiencies in the investigation. I hope that is not the case, but I certainly have not had an explanation as to why the key bodies, the key instrumentalities that should have been involved in this search did not meet early on and coordinate their actions properly. Of course I do not know why the vessel that was in Weipa for some considerable time before it took the children offshore was not discovered in the circumstances of this whole matter.

This is not only an extremely distressing matter for the Gillespies but it also demonstrates, in my view, a major shortcoming in the system of enforcement and protection of justice in this country. It is a demonstration of a state of affairs that is unsatisfactory. I regret, as I said, that the Australian Government has not been willing to face up to that shortcoming and at least put in place mechanisms that can give the Australian people greater confidence in the future.

The only other matter that I want to mention is my continuing concern about what is now not being done in relation to the return of the children from Malaysia. I do not know whether or not, for example, a warrant has been issued for the arrest of the accomplice. That is not covered by this document. I do not know what action has been taken through the Australian courts against the father who abducted these children. Enforcement of the action is another question, but I do not know what action has actually been instituted against the father, who is clearly in breach of Australian laws.

Following my efforts in the Estimates Committee it seems to me that there has been insufficient effort to get consular access to the children in Malaysia and to try to reunite the mother with the children in Malaysia. On humane grounds alone, one would have thought the mother ought to be entitled to meet with her children who have been taken from her in such traumatic circumstances.

This is not, as the Australian foreign Minister says, purely a matter of Australian family law. This is a matter in which the laws of Australia have been offended against in a blatant and appalling way, and it is a matter on which the Australian Government should be strongly making representations to Malaysia.

I might say in passing that I do not know what efforts were made when it seems the Australian Government may have believed that the children were in Indonesia to recover the children before they reached Malaysia. Were representations made to the Indonesian Government to try to seek the return of these children, or was it just all too difficult?

As I said at the outset, this is a disturbing matter. It has certainly not been satisfactorily resolved by this report today. I will be continuing to press it and I trust the Australian Government, even at this late stage, might start to accept its responsibility and do a lot more than it has done to date to try to reunite these children with their mother in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering a report to the Attorney-General on the removal of the Gillespie children from Australia in July this year, the purpose of which is to determine the means by which the children and their natural father left Australia, and whether the Australian Federal Police and Customs Service took all reasonable action to prevent that departure.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry concluded that Raja Bahrin and the Gillespie children travelled to Weipa from Melbourne in cars obtained by an accomplice. Two or three days after they were due to be returned to their mother, they left Weipa on a cabin cruiser bought by the accomplice in Perth. It is very obvious from that information that a lot of thought was put into this matter. It is easy for us to say in hindsight that we could have stopped it, although perhaps it is not quite as easy as we think.

The inquiry found that both the Federal Police and the Customs Service acted in an appropriate and generally timely manner using longstanding, proven practices for executing Family Court custody warrants, but that a reassessment should have taken place when the action taken failed to produce any result. However, the speed with which Raja Bahrin acted precluded the outcome from being different, according to Mr Glenn. I must say at this point that I tend to agree with Senator Hill that we do not know that for a fact and we should be looking at it a little more closely to see what else we can do. We cannot say that they would not have been effected; we do not know.

There are several recommendations in the conclusions which the Democrats would like to be taken up by the Attorney-General. I will be interested to hear whether he has any intention of doing that. In particular, paragraph 90 on page 17 states:

SPEECH.PARA: A more coordinated effort, including greater sharing of information, intelligence and workload with other Commonwealth, and where appropriate State, agencies would be a desirable outcome from such a reassessment.
Also paragraph 93 on page 18 also states:

The procedures for distributing material should be more clearly defined and understood by all agencies and the lines of communication (the cause of delay) more direct. A centrally managed system would have been more effective in the Gillespie case.

PARA.TAB: It would be a good idea to examine several of the recommendations in the report. Many of them would not help in other cases, and perhaps the Gillespie children's case would have been the only one and therefore perhaps these things do not need to be done. But certainly the report's recommendations should be looked at. The Democrats think that Senator Hill is right when he says that not enough was done at the time and there was not enough coordination. We believe this is fairly indicative of what has happened in several cases. With hindsight, again it is easier for us to say that now than it would have been for the Federal Police and the Customs Service to have done it at the time.
Finally, the crux of the report is in paragraph 82 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The procedures and processes in place adequately cope with lawful movement into and out of Australia. We have much more difficulty though than most responding to the unlawful, unusual and unexpected movement of people. The events of July amply demonstrate this.

For years the Democrats have been arguing that Australia is spending lavishly on military hardware, which is almost irrelevant to what we believe our real security needs are, while skimping on equipment and operations which we really need to defend our coastline and waters. This is a classic case in point.

PARA.TAB: As the report says, we have great difficulty responding to unusual movements of people. It is not that long ago that a boatload of Chinese citizens reached the Western Australian coast without detection. If they could slip through the net with no evil intent, so too could terrorists, smugglers or even small, roving armed bands which our defence strategy has identified as the only realistic military threat which we actually face. It strikes us as a fundamental case of skewed priorities. This report adds still more weight to our view that coastal surveillance and protection are badly neglected and really need to be redressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hill and Senator Bourne for their contributions to the debate on this most important report concerning the abduction of the Gillespie children from Australia out of the jurisdiction. As we now know, they are in Malaysia.

PARA.TAB: One has to keep in mind the sequence of events in the early days following the abduction as we can now reconstruct them. The father—who had properly come into Australia and sought and obtained access to the children for visits while he stayed at the Victoria Hotel in Melbourne—contacted Mrs Gillespie and took the children quite properly and lawfully at about 5 p.m. on 9 July.

It was on Saturday, 11 July that Mrs Gillespie first alerted the Australian Federal Police expressing her concern about the children. Of course, then the AFP immediately contacted the international airport and got matters under way. The AFP received a warrant for the children to be taken into possession at about midnight on Sunday, 12 July. As Mr Glenn has reconstructed events, it appears that Raja Bahrin and the children departed Weipa on the night of 14 July or early in the morning of 15 July. One can see that the notice to the AFP was only two days before the removal of the children from Australia by Raja Bahrin via Weipa.

One has to take the sequence into account in trying to assess whether in fact even a different methodology, if it had been adopted by the Federal Police as the principal agency involved, might have resulted in the children being located before they left the jurisdiction. All I can say is that Mr Glenn concluded that a change of direction following any reassessment that should have occurred as to the progress of the investigation would not have produced a different outcome. In paragraph 83 he states:

SPEECH.PARA: It needs to be emphasised that the Gillespie children were taken out of Australia secretly just two to three days after it became apparent that they would not be returned to their mother. (Had there not been mechanical trouble with the vessel they may well have left earlier.) The chances of preventing their departure were therefore extremely remote.
In all fairness to the agencies involved, that point has to be emphasised.

PARA.TAB: It is also true to say that the Australian Federal Police did allocate resources which I believe were adequate to the task as they saw it, particularly in those early days. After all, it is a fact that when one looks at the financial year 1991-92 which has just past, one sees that 75 Family Court custody warrants were executed in the southern region of the AFP and 111 children were returned to their legal guardians. In the last three financial years—and I know you will be interested in this, Madam Acting Deputy President—all the children the subject of a custody warrant were found and returned to the appropriate person. That is a pretty good starting point for thinking that the procedures which the Australian Federal Police got under way would hopefully be able to find the children and allow their return to Mrs Gillespie.

It is not true to say that this matter was dealt with as absolutely ordinary or routine at all. The family law squad itself, and the detective sergeant in charge of the squad, worked very assiduously on this matter. Assistance was provided from other areas within the Australian Federal Police.

I know from my own conversations with the Deputy Commissioner Operations of the Federal Police that there was a monitoring, as Mr Glenn acknowledges, from the centre of the investigation being undertaken. Whilst it is true that a different sort of investigation might have been mounted, I do not think real criticism can be levelled at the way in which the investigation seeking to find these children was undertaken, except in one matter which I will come to in a moment. I do want to emphasise that this was not an operation undertaken by just the family law squad of the AFP in Melbourne. Many other elements of the AFP and other agencies were involved.

I do want to take up the Coastwatch matter raised by Senator Hill. I share some of Senator Hill's misgivings about whether Coastwatch might have been alerted in a general way as to the possibility of the people being in the area. Right from the start I have wondered why that might not be an appropriate course of action and why it was not undertaken. I accept fully what Mr Glenn says and what I have been briefed on; namely, that for Coastwatch realistically to undertake a sweep of the area it needs to be tasked to look for a particular vessel. In this case, the Starcraft cabin cruiser of course had not been identified.

I think it is also important to say in relation to some remarks Senator Hill made that Mr Glenn notes that Raja Bahrin and the children were not seen at Weipa so there was no sense in which Coastwatch could have been alerted to the fact that this particular Starcraft cabin cruiser was the one they should be searching for. I accept all of that, but I also share Senator Hill's general query and misgiving about why perhaps some general alert might not have been put out to Coastwatch.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why could they not have monitored all of the vessels in the area?

—There are so many thousands of fishing boats and vessels that one would not know which one to circle and go down to have a look at. There are problems. I do have a misgiving about whether in fact it might not have been appropriate to alert Coastwatch in a general way. Whether doing so would have led to a different result—Senator Hill nods in agreement—must be thought to be very problematic. The chances are remote, but we do not know. I believe in these instances that some more general alert might have been appropriate, but I do accept that Coastwatch would not have known precisely which of the many hundreds of vessels present during those weeks in our northern waters, in the 700 kilometres between Broome and Cairns, it should have really taken a special interest in.

PARA.TAB: With that one caveat on my own part, I do think it is important nevertheless to say that the report put down by Mr Glenn does indicate that the sort of investigation undertaken by the Australian Federal Police, particularly given the excellent 100 per cent record I have adverted to over the last three years—

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not think police in these northern ports should have been alerted?

—I am agreeing with misgivings on that score, but exactly what they would have been looking for is a very different matter. It is recorded by Mr Glenn that even if the police in Weipa for example had been looking for a Malaysian with two children, they would not have seen a Malaysian with two children. That is the point I am making. I cannot go beyond Mr Glenn's report, obviously.

PARA.TAB: I do believe the attempt to locate the Gillespie children was undertaken in a wholehearted way. It was undertaken with very considerable resources being devoted by the Australian Federal Police, far beyond the norm. It is highly improbable that any further change to the direction of the investigation, which might have resulted from a reassessment whilst the matter was being monitored as it was by higher authorities within the AFP than just the family law squad in Melbourne or even the region, would have led to the recovery of the children. We will never know.

It is a great tragedy that the children were removed from Australia and I believe that, quite obviously, we need to ensure that steps are taken. I think Senator Hill has had conversations at the Estimates committee with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) about the extent to which Foreign Affairs has attempted to use its consular powers to help get access for Mrs Gillespie to the children. It must be most distressing to her that that has not occurred.

By the way, it is not true to say that the Federal Government has not attempted to assist the Gillespies in this matter. As Senator Hill will know, the overseas custody child removal scheme provides for Commonwealth legal aid for legal proceedings overseas to recover children where the applicant is suffering financial hardship and where the case has reasonable prospects of success. Senator Hill will be well aware of that provision.

At a meeting on 27 July between officers of my Department, the solicitors and a barrister for the Gillespies, the Gillespies were offered up to $2,500 for the costs of an opinion on their prospects of success in legal proceedings to be taken in Malaysia, plus the reasonable costs of preparing a brief for that opinion. The offer was subject to receiving a formal application for assistance and to being satisfied about hardship. These are normal criteria as Senator Hill will know. No formal application for assistance under the scheme has been received and it is now 8 October, so we have not been exactly heartless. We have tried to provide the Gillespies with a means of securing an opinion on how they should approach the Malaysian judicial authorities, but they have not taken up what assistance we have offered. They may say that it is partial, not enough or whatever, but there has been no formal application despite that offer having been made.

Honourable senators will realise that this is a particularly difficult matter. The judicial process to be undertaken is a difficult matter to speak about in the chamber. I can tell Senator Hill that warrants have been issued, not only in relation to the Prince but also in relation to one other person. Extradition, which I think Senator Hill raised, of course requires an approach from the appropriate authorities to the Attorney-General. That approach has not been made.

What extradition would succeed in doing if it were successful at all is securing the return of the Prince to this jurisdiction. It would not of itself secure the return of the children who, of course, would not be subject to extradition which has to do with alleged criminal activity. They are the victims in this scenario; they are certainly not the criminals. So they would not be returned to Australia simply because there had been a successful extradition of the Prince. So this is a very difficult matter.

I want to express very clearly my understanding right from the start. From the first few days of becoming aware of this matter I have been talking with the Commissioner and the Deputy Commissioner within the Australian Federal Police about the sense of urgency in this matter because of the distress no doubt being suffered by the Gillespies as parents with lawful custody of these children. That has motivated much of the very considerable effort which has been put into this particular search for the children. Unfortunately, it was not successful. With the one caveat I expressed, somewhat in harmony with Senator Hill's misgiving, and acknowledging that even a general alert to the Coastwatch may not have given it sufficiently precise tasking to enable it to locate the vessel, but having put that to one side, I believe a proper effort was made in this matter.

In so far as Mr Glenn indicates that the monitoring by the Australian Federal Police should have led to a difference in direction of the search, I take that and give it full weight. I know from speaking with Deputy Commissioner Bates yesterday about this matter that he acknowledges that that ought to be done to ensure that in those few exceptional cases where, despite the tremendous record of the last three years, it appears that ordinary methods, even beefed up, may be falling short we will see the AFP responding in a slightly different way.

Generally, in so far as Mr Glenn has pointed to any deficiencies, they have been noted. There is a determination between myself as the Minister and Deputy Commissioner Bates to ensure that, as far as is humanly possible, this sort of abduction does not occur in the future.

I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on this very important report. I hope that it leads to a revamping of the efforts by Australian agencies to ensure that their cooperation and coordination and investigation and search procedures allow us to ensure that the Family Court and its orders and, more particularly, the families concerned, who should be able to rely on those orders, are protected from the sort of criminal activity which has led to the very sad abduction of these children from Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on government companies and their reporting requirements. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Government response to the report on government companies and their reporting requirements from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration tabled its report on Government Companies and their Reporting Requirements on 2 November 1989. The inquiry, which focused on the formation, operations and accountability of government companies, was undertaken pursuant to the Committee's standing reference on companies and incorporated associations.

PARA.TAB: 2. In 1987 the then Minister for Finance set out a framework for the reform of GBEs in the policy information paper entitled Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises. These reforms were directed to improving the corporate financial structures of GBEs, replacing day-to-day controls with strategic controls and requiring enhanced accountability in terms of their performance. Achieving greater efficiency in the public sector via the GBE reforms is an important element in the Government's program of micro-economic reform.

3. Managers of GBEs have been given responsibility to manage, and the Commonwealth's attention is now directed at the enterprise's strategic plans and broad financial performance. This does not mean any lessening of the accountability of these enterprises—on the contrary, it has been made abundantly clear to GBEs that they are not only accountable in terms of discharging any legislative or Government policy obligations, but are accountable for their performance.

4. The Committee's report on government companies is thus a contribution directed to the development of improved accountability for these entities. The Government accepts the theme of the Committee's report.
5. The Committee's key recommendations propose:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the maintenance of a central register of companies and incorporated associations in which the Commonwealth controls or in which it has a substantial interest;
(b)that no direct government interest in a company be established without legislative authority;
(c)more stringent criteria for the establishment of government companies;
(d)more comprehensive reporting requirements for government companies;
(e)that all Commonwealth undertakings be audited by the Auditor-General; and
(f)that general provisions for formation, reporting, audit and disposal of government companies be set out in a Government Companies Act.

PARA.TAB: 6. Detailed responses to each of the Committee's recommendations are set out in the attachment to this document. Below are the Government's comments on some of the more significant issues raised by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Central Register of Companies and Incorporated Associations

PARA.TAB: 7. The Committee identified 208 government controlled companies, 55 associated companies and Commonwealth involvement in 58 companies limited by guarantee and 67 incorporated associations as at 1 July 1989. It indicated, however, that it could not be sure that it had identified all such bodies and recommended that a central register be maintained to record the Commonwealth's interest in companies and incorporated associations.

8. The difficulty with a central register is that it would add to the level of bureaucracy and suffer from the inherent difficulties of ensuring that such a register is current. Instead of endorsing the Committee's recommendation, the Government has already moved to have departments of State report information on companies and incorporated associations, which the Commonwealth controls or in which it has a significant influence, in their annual reports which are tabled in Parliament.

9. In addition, the Government proposes to include in the Aggregate Financial Statement prepared annually pursuant to Section 50AB of the Audit Act 1901 an additional Table listing Commonwealth Departments, Trusts, Other Agencies and Entities. This listing which includes government controlled companies, will also assist readers of that statement to place in perspective those Commonwealth controlled bodies which operate on the Commonwealth Public Account.

SPEECH.PARA: Legislative Authority to Establish Companies

PARA.TAB: 10. The Committee expressed concern that government involvement in companies may occur without any requirement for parliamentary approval or any need for Parliament to be informed, and recommended that no direct interest in a company be established without either general or specific legislative authority.

11. The Government takes the view that, consistent with the Policy Guidelines for the Commonwealth Statutory Authorities issued by the Minister for Finance in 1987, the Minister for Finance and the Attorney-General should be consulted in advance for proposals to establish or vary a direct Commonwealth interest in a company. As it would not always be practicable to seek prior Parliamentary approval of Government involvement in companies, the Government's intention is that the legislation replacing the Audit Act 1901 will include a provision requiring that Parliament be informed of any new or varied direct government involvement in companies.

12. Further, the Government endorses the principle that a Commonwealth body should not establish or acquire a controlling interest in a company which will engage in activities beyond the purposes for which the Commonwealth body was established, unless specifically authorised by Cabinet (and legislation, where the body was established by legislation).

SPEECH.PARA: Criteria for Establishing Government Companies

PARA.TAB: 13. The current criteria for establishing government companies were articulated in the May 1988 Statement by the then Minister for Transport and Communications on Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises. That Statement indicated that a government company structure is appropriate for those enterprises in direct competition with private sector competitors, or for enterprises which serve no explicit social objectives and have a well-developed commercial culture.

14. The Committee recommended that all these elements should be present before a government entity is incorporated and, in addition, recommended a further criterion that a company structure would result in clearly identified efficiencies and/or other benefits which cannot be obtained without recourse to that structure.

15. Although it is difficult to lay down in precise terms the circumstances which would justify the use of a company structure by a government entity, the Government has noted the Committee's views and proposes that the criteria for incorporating a government entity as a company be revised so that all existing elements must be satisfied, but with a modification to the element concerning explicit social objectives. The Government believes that there may be circumstances where it would be appropriate for a government company to undertake explicit community service obligations (CSOs) provided that the discharge of any explicit CSO be made visible, with costing and funding arrangements transparent. Accordingly the criteria proposed allow for this possibility.

16. Other measures being proposed to improve accountability of government companies (such as tabling annual reports in Parliament) should overcome the risk of reduced accountability referred to by the Committee when recommending the criterion that a company structure must `. . . result in clearly identified efficiencies and/or other benefits which cannot be obtained without recourse to that structure.' Furthermore, while evidence before the Committee suggested that there appear to be benefits in adopting a company form, it would in the Government's view be difficult to establish objective tests to assess any proposed efficiency increases. Against this background the Government is not in favour of adopting the Committee's proposed criterion.

SPEECH.PARA: Reporting Requirements for Government Companies

PARA.TAB: 17. Government companies report in accordance with the requirements of the Corporations Law. However, some government companies have been incorporated as exempt proprietary companies and are not required by the Corporations Law to prepare a full directors' report and financial statements as is the case for public companies. Further, there is no formal requirement for the annual reports of government companies to be tabled in Parliament.

18. The Government fully supports the Committee's recommendations that all government companies be public companies and that there be legislation requiring annual reports of directly controlled government companies to be tabled. Accepting these recommendations will have little impact on existing companies, as most currently table annual reports and the exempt proprietary companies do not take advantage of the range of privileges available under the Corporations Law.

19. The Government does not consider, however, that it is appropriate to require companies to abide by disclosure requirements which apply to statutory authorities. If a body is to be incorporated as a company, then the relevant disclosure requirements of the Corporations Law should apply; and equally, if the body is a statutory authority, the relevant guidelines for financial statements and annual reports should apply. In both cases the reporting requirements are specifically tailored to the reporting entity.

20. Nevertheless the Government recognises that there may be special circumstances where more frequent disclosure is warranted and proposes that the legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901 will provide that the Minister for Finance, after consultation with the relevant portfolio Minister, may require half yearly or quarterly financial statements to be submitted to the responsible Minister by Commonwealth entities. The responsible Minister will be required to table the statements in the Parliament. There will also be provision for the responsible Minister to obtain information confidentially.

SPEECH.PARA: Auditing Arrangements

PARA.TAB: 21. As previously announced, the Government has accepted the JCPA recommendation, which the Committee endorsed, that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities. However, the Government has also agreed that the Minister for Finance may provide exemptions in the case of Statutory Marketing Authorities and Government Business Enterprises where special circumstances dictate.

SPEECH.PARA: A Government Companies Act

PARA.TAB: 22. The Government proposes that the legislation currently being prepared to replace the Audit Act 1901 should include provisions requiring Parliament to be informed of any new or varied direct government involvement in companies, requiring government controlled companies to table annual reports and specifying the applicable auditing arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: CONCLUSION

PARA.TAB: 23. The Chairman of the Committee, Senator John Coates, and the Committee members are to be commended for undertaking this inquiry. The Committee raised a number of important accountability issues and the Government will implement the measures outlined in its detailed responses to the Committee's Report as soon as practicable. Where legislative changes are required these will be taken up in the drafting of the legislation to replace the existing Audit Act 1901.

24. The Government will continue to pursue a policy of reform aimed at providing incentive, enhancing efficiency and improving public accountability by moving from unnecessary detailed controls, which detract from enterprise performance, to a focus which places greater emphasis on bottom-line performance. It should be stressed that this Government regards enhanced accountability to the Executive and to Parliament as the essential concomitant of devolution of responsibility and the removal of detailed controls. The proposals outlined are a positive demonstration of this Government's commitment to that greater accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: COMMITTEE RECOMMENDATIONS AND GOVERNMENT RESPONSES
Recommendation 1 (paragraph 2.3.7)
The Committee recommends the establishment of a central register of companies and incorporated associations which the Commonwealth controls or in which it has a substantial interest.
Government Response

Rather than establish a central register and add to the level of bureaucracy, the Government has decided that details of all companies and incorporated associations which the Government controls or in which it has significant influence will be reported to Parliament in the annual reports of departments of State. This requirement, implemented in the Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports issued by the Prime Minister, will supplement disclosures currently required in the annual reports of statutory authorities and companies in respect of subsidiary companies.

PARA.TAB: 2. In addition, the possibility of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) identifying government companies on its national register of companies, introduced on 1 January 1991, and making information on that register available to the Parliamentary Library and the Department of Finance will be pursued. Such an arrangement would avoid substantial duplication of the ASC register and the procedures for companies to notify changes in their particulars as they occur.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 2 (paragraph 2.4.7)
The Committee further recommends that provision for the central register be made in the Government Companies Act recommended in Chapter 3.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 3. Refer to the Government Response to Recommendation 1.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 3 (paragraph 3.3.4)

If government companies are to exist, the Committee recommends that no direct government interest in a company be established without legislative authority. Such authority might be specific, in the form of an enabling act for each new company, or general in the form of a government companies act specifying procedures which will ensure proper accountability.
Recommendation 5 (paragraph 3.4.2)
The Committee recommends that general provisions for formation, reporting, audit and disposal of government companies be set out in a Government Companies Act.
Recommendation 6 (paragraph 3.4.3)
The Committee recommends that the proposed Act provide for certain minimum requirements.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 4. Due to the need, in some circumstances, to take decisions expeditiously in respect of government involvement in companies, it would not always be practicable to have specific legislation enacted prior to the government involvement. However the Government will introduce legislation which will improve accountability by requiring:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)Parliament to be informed of any new or varied direct government involvement in companies (direct government involvement does not extend to subsidiary or joint venture companies of existing companies or statutory authorities);

(b)Parliament to be informed of the extent of that interest, the reason for acquiring the interest, the principal activities of the company, the names of any other persons having a significant interest in the company, and the names of the directors in the company in conjunction with the information referred to above;
(c)half yearly or quarterly reporting by government companies as may be required by the relevant portfolio Minister;

(d)audit by the Auditor-General of all companies controlled by the Commonwealth, unless the Minister for Finance has provided an exemption, allowing for a suitable transition period where private auditors are currently appointed; and
(e)the annual report of directly government controlled companies to be tabled in Parliament within a specified time period.

PARA.TAB: 5. The new provisions will be included in the proposed legislation currently being developed to replace the Audit Act 1901.

6. Consistent with the 1987 Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises, arrangements provide for the Minister for Finance and the Attorney-General to be consulted in advance in respect of proposals to establish or vary a direct Commonwealth interest in a company.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 4 (paragraph 3.3.6)

The Committee further recommends that each department be required to list, in its annual report, all companies and incorporated associations within its minister's portfolio. The requirement should cover not only majority-owned companies but also all those in which the Commonwealth holds 20 per cent or more of the capital, companies limited by guarantee and incorporated associations of which the Commonwealth is a member or guarantor. The requirement need not apply to those subsidiary companies listed in the annual report of a statutory authority, or of a government company, but then only if there is a legal requirement for the report of the parent body itself to be tabled.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 7. The Government agrees with the Recommendation and, as indicated in the Response to Recommendation 1, has required departments of State to list in their annual report all companies and incorporated associations within their Minister's portfolio that meet the criteria specified by the Committee. In addition, the Government has decided that the requirement should extend to subsidiary companies to ensure that the portfolio listing is comprehensive and provides an index of all companies associated with the portfolio. These requirements have been implemented through a change to the Guidelines for the preparation of Departmental Annual Reports.

8. However the Government proposes to revise the Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports to incorporate definitions of control and significant influence consistent with the definitions established in the Australian Accounting Standards on Consolidated Financial Statements and the Equity Method of Accounting, now reflected in the Corporations Law and the Guidelines for Financial Statements of Commonwealth Entities. The definitions will also be reflected where appropriate in the legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 7 (paragraph 4.3.9)

The Committee recommends that, as is already a requirement for public and private sector companies, all statutory authorities should present consolidated annual accounts incorporating all subsidiary companies.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 9. The Government agrees with the Recommendation and notes that statutory authorities which are required to keep accounts in accordance with commercial practice and those which have subsidiaries have been required to prepare group financial statements since 1988-89; and all statutory authorities have been required to prepare group financial statements from 1989-90. From 1990-91 they must comply with the Australian Accounting Standard on consolidated financial statements.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 8 (paragraph 4.4.2)

The Committee believes that all three of the existing criteria should be present before a government entity is incorporated, that is, competition with the private sector, no explicit social objectives and a strong commercial culture.
Recommendation 9 (paragraph 4.4.3)

Because of the risk of reduced accountability associated with the use by government of the company structure, the Committee recommends that company status should be considered for government entities only where it will result in clearly identified efficiencies and/or other benefits which cannot be obtained without recourse to that structure.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 10. Although it is difficult to lay down in precise terms the circumstances which would justify the use of a company structure by a government enterprise, the Government has noted the Committee's views in revising the criteria which should be met before a government enterprise is incorporated as a company. The revised criteria provide that an incorporated company structure is appropriate for a government enterprise where:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the enterprise is in direct competition with private sector competitors;
(b)the enterprise has a well-developed commercial culture; and
(c)the discharge of any explicit community service obligations by the enterprise can be made clearly visible, with costing and funding arrangements transparent.

PARA.TAB: 11. With respect to the criterion that `the enterprise serves no explicit social objectives', the Government now considers that this is unnecessarily restrictive as there may be circumstances where it would be appropriate for a government company to undertake explicit community service obligations.

12. Furthermore, measures being proposed to improve accountability of companies (such as tabling annual reports in Parliament) should overcome the risk of reduced accountability referred to by the Committee when recommending the criterion that a company structure must `. . . result in clearly identified efficiencies and/or other benefits which cannot be obtained without recourse to that structure.'

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 10 (paragraph 5.1.7)
The Committee recommends that no government company be incorporated so as to be eligible for exempt propriety status.
Recommendation 11 (paragraph 5.1.7)

It further recommends that action be taken to convert to public company status all existing directly owned government proprietary companies. This would remove the exempt proprietary status of ASTA and ADI and prevent other government companies from seeking such status.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 13. The Government accepts these Recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 12 (paragraph 5.1.10)

The Committee recommends that the Minister for Finance, after consultation with the Auditor-General, draw up a set of reporting guidelines for all companies limited by guarantee and all incorporated associations of which the Commonwealth is a member. At a minimum, these should include full disclosure of the existence and operations of the companies and associations in the proposed central register of companies and in the annual reports of the department or authority holding membership of them or in annual reports prepared by them in their own right.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 14. The Government will amend the annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities (and has done so in the case of departments) to require reference, where relevant, to companies limited by guarantee and incorporated associations of which the Commonwealth is a member. The Auditor-General will be consulted in the preparation of the guidelines for statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 13 (paragraph 5.2.9)

The Committee recommends that all government companies which are not subsidiaries of other government companies or of statutory authorities should conform to the financial reporting requirements applying to statutory authorities, as well as to those set out in the Companies Code for listed public companies and that this be prescribed in a general government companies act.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 15. There are marked similarities between the financial reporting requirements for companies and statutory authorities. However, in some instances statutory authorities are required to disclose more detail e.g. in disclosing each material class of revenues and expenses and a summary of material foreign currency cash flows for each foreign currency. To require government companies which are in competition with the private sector to disclose more detail than their competitors is likely to place them at a competitive disadvantage. In addition, as the requirements are not synonymous, there are likely to be overlapping requirements for disclosure leading to confusion and/or duplication.

16. The Government considers that, as a matter of principle, companies should conform with the relevant requirements of the Corporations Law and statutory authorities should conform with financial reporting Guidelines which are issued by the Minister for Finance. In both cases the reporting requirements are specifically tailored to the reporting entity.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 14 (paragraph 5.2.9)
The Committee recommends that the annual reports of directly held government companies should conform to the guidelines set down for annual reports of statutory authorities.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 17. The Corporations Law provides for specific disclosures by Directors in respect of operations and results for the year, significant changes in the state of affairs of the company, and likely developments.

18. The Guidelines for the Content, Preparation, and Presentation of Annual Reports by Statutory Authorities, on the other hand, are specifically tailored for statutory authorities requiring disclosure, for example, of information on the authority's enabling legislation, powers, functions and objects, and the responsible Minister.

19. As indicated in the Response to Recommendation 13, the Government considers that government entities should conform with those requirements which are specifically tailored to the reporting entity i.e. the Corporations Law for companies; and the annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 15 (paragraph 5.2.11)

The Committee recommends that a statutory requirement be introduced for the annual reports of all directly owned government companies to be tabled in Parliament as well as being provided to the relevant Corporate Affairs Commissions. The same time limits as apply to provision of reports to the Corporate Affairs Commission should apply to tabling. This should also be included in a general government companies act.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 20. The Government will introduce a requirement in the proposed legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901 for all government controlled companies to table annual reports. Time limits proposed for tabling will be aligned with those proposed to apply to statutory authorities. In accordance with normal practice for both companies and statutory authorities, the annual reports would refer to the operations of subsidiary companies, where applicable.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 16 (paragraph 6.1.3)
The Committee recommends that all government companies be audited in accordance with the requirements of the Audit Act 1901 as well as those of the Companies Act 1981 or relevant Companies Code.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 21. The provisions of sections 63P and 51A of the Audit Act 1901 currently allow the Auditor-General to report to Parliament on the inspection and audit of the accounts and records, and the audit of the financial statements of government companies for which he has been appointed auditor. Hence government companies subject to audit by the Auditor-General are audited in accordance with the requirements of the Audit Act 1901 as well as those of the Corporations Law. The requirements are proposed to continue under proposed legislation that is to replace the Audit Act 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 17 (paragraph 6.6.8)
The Committee recommends that the Government give consideration to requiring the establishment of audit committees by all of its GBEs.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 22. Many GBEs currently have audit committees, involving board members, in place. The Government recognises the merit of the establishment of audit committees by GBEs and proposes to require all GBEs to establish Audit Committees in the new legislation that is to replace the Audit Act 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 18 (paragraph 6.7.14)

The Committee is firmly of the view, and recommends, that all Commonwealth undertakings, of whatever legal form, should be audited by the Commonwealth Auditor-General to the standards laid down in the Audit Act 1901. We endorse the recommendations of the JCPA set out in paragraph 6.7.2 above and urge the Government to implement them promptly.
Government Response

PARA.TAB: 23. The Government has decided that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities, including Statutory Marketing Authorities (SMAs) and Government Business Enterprises (GBEs), but has agreed that the Minister for Finance may provide exemptions to that mandate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report entitled Government Companies and their Reporting Requirements, to which the Government has just responded, was tabled in November 1989. I am the only current member of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration who was involved in the inquiry which produced it. The Committee considered its report on government companies to be an important one. I have previously expressed my disappointment at the length of time between the report and the response. It is outrageous that it has taken 2 1/2 years longer than it should have. In the interim, the headlong rush to create government companies and convert other entities into the company format has increased, and that is a development that I deeply regret.

PARA.TAB: However, my disappointment is mitigated somewhat by the generally positive and constructive nature of the response. I accept that the Government's consideration of the recommendations in the report was complicated by the need to reconcile those recommendations with the rewriting of the Audit Act that has been under way for the last couple of years. I also acknowledge that a vast number of portfolios were involved; it was not a response that could be done within one portfolio.

I am pleased to note that the Government's response meets many of the Committee's concerns. Potentially significant loopholes will be plugged. The Government will no longer operate through exempt proprietary companies which have minimal reporting requirements. The annual reports of all government companies will now be required to be tabled in Parliament. Further, audit committees will become a requirement for all government business enterprises.

Against that, I regret that there has clearly not been a pulling back from a commitment to the company road. Whereas the Committee had recommended that Parliament be involved in approving the formation of government companies, the Government response merely provides that the Parliament be informed of the formation of government companies. As far as I am concerned, that is an insufficient response.

While I am pleased to see that the Government has generally adopted the Committee's recommendation that the Auditor-General be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities, the Government has nevertheless agreed that the Minister for Finance may provide exemptions to that mandate. The Committee's position and my position is that there ought not be the possibility of such exemptions and that the use of the Auditor-General should be mandatory, although that ought not prevent the Auditor-General from being able to subcontract to other auditing organisations if need be; but that ultimate responsibility really ought to remain with the Auditor-General. It is an improvement, but it is not as good a response on that point as I would have hoped.

The underlying theme of the Committee's report was that much was misguided in what seemed in the late 1980s to be a rush to incorporate government bodies under the companies law. It was notable that no concrete evidence was presented to the Committee of any operational advantages provided by the company form as opposed to the option of a statutory authority. Some of us felt that we were observing a management fad rather than a reform.
The Committee noted the benefits on the efficiency of GBEs, some of which are companies and some statutory authorities, on a variety of government reforms. We reported:

SPEECH.PARA: It can be questioned . . . whether the legal form of the entity plays a decisive, or even a significant, part in the achievement of these desirable objectives.

The Committee was able to provide examples of statutory authorities operating with all the examples said to be available from the company form, and of government companies complaining of the disadvantages that some had said were exclusive to the statutory authority form.

PARA.TAB: I saw all this as a sad example of a then common practice in which senior people within the public sector itself tended to decry public sector efficiency and to unthinkingly adopt private sector forms. The myth of private sector superiority has now gone the way of the 1980s entrepreneur, and the strengths of the Commonwealth public sector are more clearly appreciated.

The measures proposed in this response will ensure that government companies are fully accountable to their owners—the people of Australia. The accountability mechanisms specified do not differ in any major way from the regime which applies to statutory authorities. This must bring into question the rationale for any widespread move to company reform in the public sector. I remain of the view, which was adopted in the Committee's report, that strong criteria should be met before the Government adopts the company structure.

Before concluding, I wish to raise a consistent concern of the Committee over many years—the need for a central register of government bodies. The Committee itself maintains such a register, but does so with some difficulty and with all the disadvantages of attempting such a task from outside the Public Service. In rejecting yet again the Committee's recommendation for an official register of government bodies, the Government has announced that a list of government companies might soon become available as a spin-off of the Australian Securities Commission's computer system.

If this transpires—it will be better than nothing—we will have the odd situation of there being a central register of government companies but no equivalent for the numerous statutory authorities and non-statutory bodies. I simply register again the belief that I and others hold that a requirement to list these bodies in appendices to the annual reports of departments is not an efficient or effective way of maintaining control of the non-departmental sphere of administration.

I would like to commend the efforts of members of the Committee which produced this report to which the Government has now responded. Senators Alston, Burns, Calvert and Durack and former Senator John Black have all moved on to other interests since it was tabled. I am sure they would join with me in welcoming this very constructive, on the whole, if belated, response by the Government.

As I have indicated, I have very mixed feelings about this response. I welcome the commitment to greater accountability. I wish the Audit Act rewrite was further advanced than it apparently is so that the positive aspects of this response can become a reality sooner rather than later. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee E.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities on relations between the Australian Securities Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions, together with the transcript of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the duties of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities is:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) to inquire into, and report to the Houses on:

PARA.TAB: (i)activities of the Commission or the Panel—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the ASC or the panel—
on matters connected with such activities, to which, in the Parliamentary Committee's opinion, the Parliament's attention should be directed . . .

During the first of a regular series of public hearings with the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Tony Hartnell, in August 1992 there was an extensive discussion on the place of criminal investigations in the priorities of the ASC and the relationship between the Director of Public Prosecutions and the ASC. It became evident during that briefing that the ASC had strongly held views that the principal role of the ASC was as a commercial regulator. It was also evident that there had developed a fundamental conflict between the ASC and the Director of Public Prosecutions about the relative emphasis to be given to regulatory and criminal investigatory functions.

PARA.TAB: The Committee subsequently invited the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Michael Rozenes, to canvass the issues further before the Committee. As a result of Mr Rozenes's evidence, the problems of the ASC-DPP relationship were widely debated in the media. The dispute centred on whether the ASC was primarily a criminal enforcement agency or a commercial regulatory agency. The Chairman of the ASC felt that its main role was a commercial regulatory agency while the DPP felt that insufficient priority was given to the ASC's role as an investigator of criminal matters. The method used to determine which cases should be pursued for criminal prosecution, as opposed to civil action, and the working relationship between the two organisations were also discussed before the Committee.

As a result of the disagreements which came to light during the Committee's hearing and the subsequent public debate, the Attorney-General, the Hon. Michael Duffy, decided to intervene. Earlier this week honourable senators will be aware that he issued directions to both the ASC and the DPP clearly outlining their responsibilities and setting down procedures to improve the working relationship between the two organisations. In its report the Committee concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The ASC must have an obligation to investigate matters which may involve serious criminality at least to the stage where an informed decision on whether or not to prepare a brief for the DPP can be made. The Committee considers that the demonstrated willingness of the ASC and the DPP to prosecute and seek punishment of corporate offenders is a major deterrent to criminal behaviour.

The Committee believes that the existing prosecution policy of the Commonwealth could, with modifications, form the basis for guidelines to the two organisations on which to base decisions to investigate breaches of the law with a view to criminal prosecution or civil remedies.

The Committee believes that the present financial arrangements with regard to funding prosecution exacerbates the tensions between the two organisations and is, at the same time inefficient. The DPP should be provided with the resources to fund prosecutions. It should not be dependent on the referring agency.

In this case, that is the ASC. The Committee will not seek further hearings into the issues raised at this stage. It believes that it is important to give both organisations an opportunity to give effect to the Attorney-General's guidelines and to develop an effective working relationship.

PARA.TAB: It should be noted here that the fundamental conflict of views giving rise to the difficulties between the ASC and the DPP are not unique to Australia. The Serious Fraud Office in the UK has also experienced considerable difficulty in preparing and prosecuting complex corporate crime cases such as the Blue Arrow and Guinness prosecutions and this has led to debate on how such matters should be handled, including, ironically, reference to our own method of dealing with things and the possibility that it could move in that direction, despite the fact that we are being critical of it at this stage. In the United States the reliance on racketeering legislation, which would be unacceptable in Australia, is an indication of the difficulties being faced there. However, the Committee will continue to monitor the work of the ASC and its relationship with the DPP and it will review the progress that has been made in resolving these problems at a later date.

It is a matter of some regret that this dispute became so public and required the Minister's intervention. Despite their differing priorities, many of the matters at issue could have been resolved much earlier by the two organisations. It has to be said that much productive work is done in many other areas.

However, there is a positive side to this. A potential problem of corporate law enforcement has been identified, discussed in public and remedial action has been taken. This is in contrast with the situation of the ASC's predecessor, the National Companies and Securities Commission, under the cooperative scheme, whose structure did not facilitate such rapid and decisive action and whose activities were not monitored by the Parliament in the direct way that the ASC is now monitored by my Committee.

Since the Attorney-General gave his directions to the ASC and the DPP, there have been comments reported in the media criticising them for placing excessive emphasis on the investigation and prosecution of criminal matters. I consider the statements overlook the clear wishes of investors in the general public that corporate criminals be vigorously pursued and are in any case premature. The Attorney-General's directions must be given time to be acted upon before any such judgments can be made. The Committee will in any case monitor developments, as I have said, and advise the Parliament if it considers that there is a need for further action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities tabled today. As Senator Beahan, the Chairman of the Joint Statutory Committee has said, the Committee has had an emerging role since its formation—about 12 months ago now—in overseeing the activities of the Australian Securities Commission specifically. That role, in the last few weeks, has been elevated by what had become a very public dispute, with the Committee having a regular hearing with Mr Hartnell, the Chairman of the ASC, followed by the response from the head of the DPP, Michael Rozenes, only a few weeks later.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Beahan has said, that debate in some ways was regrettable. Those two gentlemen were not able to sort those matters out between themselves in the normal course of their day-to-day dealings. However, the Committee was told at its hearing in Melbourne that 95 per cent of the work that those two organisations do together does actually proceed successfully and there is trouble in about only 5 per cent of cases. I reiterate the importance of the Committee's role in overseeing the Australian Securities Commission and bringing to public attention this debate which we would all hope has acted as a catalyst for change and will make things better in the future.

There are a few short points I want to make. The crucial element which this report brings to public attention, and which the whole public debate brings to attention, is the conflicting objectives which seem to have emerged from the Australian Securities Commission and, indeed, from Chairman Tony Hartnell during the months prior to the formal establishment of the Australian Securities Commission and since 1 January 1991 when the Commission was formally established.

We will all remember that Mr Hartnell initially came out with a hit list of, I think, 16 top corporate breaches or alleged breaches which he intended to ensure were brought to justice. It is fair to say that 12 months ago one had the impression of Mr Hartnell as someone who was more of a prosecutor than a regulator. It would seem that in the past 12 months Mr Hartnell has changed his public visage somewhat. He put on the record to our Committee at its hearing in Melbourne that he sees the role of the Australian Securities Commission more as a regulator, trying to create a healthy environment for business and commerce in Australia. Somewhere between those two objectives there is the balance that all of us seek.

Many of us have reservations about an Australian Securities Commission that has as its core objective—to use Senator Crichton-Browne's words from yesterday or the day before—to nail business scalps to the wall, to nail corporate scalps from the 1980s excesses to the wall, and to be able to then judge the success of the Australian Securities Commission by the number of scalps that are nailed to the wall.

That is not to say that to have successful prosecutions is not in itself some measure of success. If criminal activity, white collar crime, is going on within Australian corporations, it is the role of both the ASC and the DPP to work together to ensure that criminal activity does not take place. Those activities of a small handful of Australian businesses bring the activities of the majority—probably 99 per cent of Australian businesses—into disrepute and hurts our international reputation and discourages average Australians from investing their hard earned savings in Australian corporations—the sort of investment we need to get this country moving again. They are the conflicts that arise.

As Senator Beahan said during his contribution to the debate, a number of commentators have come out in the last 24 hours criticising the political intervention by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to resolve this dispute. I have grave reservations about that. I think all of us wanted to ensure the ASC and the DPP were independent bodies and that direct intervention by the Attorney-General and by the Attorney-General's Department would not need to take place. Again, the lack of focus, the lack of objective and the fight to use the limited resources available within the ASC and the DPP to achieve their objectives as organisations is an ongoing problem for them.

I know that Mr Hartnell has said—I think in this morning's Australian Financial Review—that they will abide by the Attorney-General's wishes. But we then have the very real problem of diverting resources currently provided for the regulatory capacity away from that objective towards prosecution. We all know, particularly those of us who are members of the Committee, that investigating complex white collar crime is a very expensive business, a very time consuming business, where one has to go through thousands and thousands of pages of documents; chase the paper trail. That takes the resources of well qualified lawyers and accountants and other people and it can take years and years and thousands of man hours to achieve what sometimes can be an elusive result. That is the very problem that Mr Hartnell and his investigators have been faced with.

We were told by Mr Rozenes during his evidence to our Committee that there has been some concern about the quality of briefs provided to the DPP from the Australian Securities Commission, but I reiterate in defence of the Australian Securities Commission that it was made quite clear that that is only in a small number of cases. Only yesterday, Mr Hartnell said in the Australian Financial Review that the ASC has brought 162 cases for prosecution to the DPP, so it is very hard to criticise that work.

I conclude by saying that I have always been somewhat amused or bemused by the high profiles and the big egos. There was Mr Henry Bosch, with his keen interest in almost doing corporate trial by media; then Mr Hartnell's extremely high public profile and the announcement of his hit list 18 months to two years ago; and now there is this seeming clash of corporate regulatory and prosecuting egos which has taken place as a consequence of our Committee's hearings in Melbourne and a month ago in Canberra. If the egos of the two gentlemen concerned and the high public profiles that both of those people have assumed were taken down a few notches, then both of them could concentrate on the very serious work at hand and we would not have needed this extremely regrettable intervention by the Attorney-General, which reminded me somewhat of the father pulling two feuding sons in and having a chat and banging their heads together.

I join with Senator Beahan, the Chairman of our Committee, in saying that our Committee will, of course, monitor the progress made, after the tabling of the Attorney-General's advice, in achieving the objectives of corporate regulation in Australia. It is fair to allow some time to see whether this works. I am sure our Committee will do what it has done so successfully over the last 12 months, that is, monitor, on an almost daily basis, the activities of the Australian Securities Commission and the DPP and ensure that the sort of battle we have witnessed over the past couple of months is resolved and does not happen again. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak to the National Health and Medical Research Council report of the 113th session held in Hobart in June 1992. In particular, I want to raise a point that I think is of great importance. The 7.30 Report in South Australia last week—I am not sure of which day—included in its coverage a piece attacking the NHMRC and this Government's `cuts' to medical research in this year's Budget. I think it is very important that any such public broadcast at least start with its basic facts right. The 7.30 Report clearly suggested that there had been cuts to the allocation of funds to the NHMRC in this year's Budget. Indeed there were not. The money allocated in the 1992-93 Budget for project grants was $108.7m—up from $103.3m in 1991-92. That is an increase of $5.4m actually and, if you allow for a 3.9 per cent indexation increase, it was a $1.5m increase in real terms.

So for any journalist to say in a report that there were cuts in the Budget when there was an actual increase, I think is very sloppy journalism at best and, indeed, very insufficient journalism. I think it is a disgrace. As well as the $1.5m real increase—that is, a $5.4m increase on the previous year—there was also the allocation of $5m over six years for research into mental health. All of this is in association with the $50m worth of capital grants to our large research institutions for medical research; that money coming through in the 1991 Budget and still being spent over five years.

For a journalist to run a report saying that there were cuts in allocations for medical research in the Budget is very insufficient. Indeed, I think it is disgraceful. The medical research in this country is brilliant and its allocation of funding has been very dramatically increased over the life of this Government. In 1982-83, the allocation for national health and medical research was $30m; that is now $108.7. In real terms, that is an increase of 100 per cent over the life of this Government. In fact, in this Budget there has been a further allocation and a real increase. It is very important that we recognise the quality medical research done in this country, and the range of medical research done with project grants in our specialist medical research centres, as well as in our large hospitals. And the majority of that medical research in hospitals is done in the public hospital sector.

So I would urge journalists, particularly the journalist who was responsible for this piece of reporting in South Australia last year, to make sure that in future they check their basic facts. Of course some researchers will want to say that they have cuts because they have not been allocated an increase in their funding. That is not the same as saying there have been cuts for medical research in the Budget. Indeed, as I have said, there were not. It is important that I have the opportunity to correct that very, very misleading and mischievous commentary on the 7.30 Report.

In the time remaining to me, I would like to briefly turn to page 14 of this report where there is a reference to the subcommittee on the ethics of the allocation of health resources. That subcommittee is being chaired by Robyn Layton and it is actually picking up on the references that came out of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, which I chaired. We recommended that, amongst other things, there will have to be an ongoing, rigorous and extensive public debate about how much health costs people in this community. That debate is beginning to be formed. We asked that the NHMRC ethics subcommittee do that. It is in the process of getting established so that the debate can be taken into the community. So I believe that this is a very useful report for two reasons: one, it allows me to correct the error from the 7.30 Report and, two, it allows me to acknowledge the continuing work done as a result of one of the recommendations of that Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training and Its Schools Council

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Tierney:
That the Senate take note of the documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training is yet another example of this Government's policy failure with regard to education in Australia. In this case, the ideas presented to the Government for improving the quality of teaching in Australia are again a case of a centralist government creating extra paperwork and more bureaucracy rather than effecting change at the classroom level where it will actually make a difference. The specific issues raised in the NBEET report are the establishment of a national professional body for teachers, the development of a systematic appraisal system for teachers and the establishment of an education industry training fund.

PARA.TAB: The establishment of a national professional body for teachers is an interesting concept; but what is it meant to achieve? Surely what will actually develop is a national body for teachers that duplicates what the State organisations can effectively achieve anyway. It is unlikely that the quality of teaching will be the primary concern if this duplication occurs. This proposed national body would merely become involved in industrial matters, rather than focusing on the improved standards of teaching in Australia. It is proposed that this national body would develop standards of behaviour and standards of teaching, but on what basis will this be done? This is not detailed in the report.

Similarly, the body would be giving advice on initial and continuing teacher education, but the report neglects to tell us where the money for the implementation of such a program is coming from. The report then goes on to point out that it would be a good idea to develop a systematic appraisal system for teachers which embodied a range a principles. These principles embody quality assurance, professional development, an integrated career structure and the idea that it be based on the teacher's work. Again, these are generally accepted principles, but they come very close to stating the obvious. The report completely neglects, however, to explain the mechanism by which these principles would be put into place or have any effect on the quality of teaching in Australia.

The report goes on to recommend the establishment of an education industry training fund, but it does not indicate the source of these funds. NBEET offers no suggestions as to the level at which the fund should be maintained or on what the contribution of the State governments, the Federal Government or any other body should be. The final line of the report by NBEET states that, overall, teachers should `increase investment of their own time in professional development'. This could well be regarded as the most realistic comment in the report. With the Government's neglecting this issue and NBEET's stating nice platitudes in reports such as this, it is obvious that nothing substantial is actually planned by this Government for improving the quality of teaching in this country.

So, on what basis can the Government assure quality? Under this scheme, it seems that this will be left to teachers and it will have very little support from government. This attitude by this Government stands in vivid contrast to the innovative policies outlined by the coalition in its Fightback reform program. Under the coalition, a special program will be funded to promote Australian best practice in professional development initiatives. These will be based on existing excellent professional development programs. Funds will also be provided under our quality of teaching program. Government and private agencies will be invited to tender for the development and production of professional development materials and for professional development programs. There is a particular call for such an initiative in areas where significant change has occurred, such as the teaching areas of technology, mathematics and science.

The principles outlined in this report are fine, but it is its failure to produce anything practical or constructive that is its downfall. There is a problem that is openly acknowledged, but this Government spends its time and its resources talking about the problem rather than doing anything practical to fix it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to Industry Commission report No. 24 on the Australian Horticultural Corporation, I wish to comment on some horticulture activities in Australia. In Australia, as in most other countries, the diversity of the horticulture industry distinguishes it from most other agriculture industries. Hundreds of products grown in Australia are generally classified as horticultural products. But there are no hard and fast rules as to what constitutes a horticultural product. Production occurs under a wide range of climates from tropical to cool-temperate. This seems to me to be a very comprehensive report on horticulture in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The report states that major production differences exist between product groups. For instance, most fruit and nuts are perennial crops with long production lead times, while many vegetable crops have short production cycles and require regular rotation to maintain yields. For some products the geographic dispersion and seasonal variation of production mean that different regions have dissimilar marketing requirements.
