For example, citrus growers in Queensland operate in different markets and at different times of the year from citrus growers in other States.

A table on page 6 of the report under the heading `Australian production of major fruits and vegetables, 1980 and 1990, kilotonnes' lists vegetables, bananas, potatoes, apricots, pineapples, citrus, pears, grapes, apples and peaches. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: While the volumes of some products such as apples, pears and grapes increased marginally during the 1980s, the production of several newer commercial crops such as macadamia nuts, avocados and mangoes increased significantly. . .

I was interested in that comment because at home on our property at Kingaroy we are growing avocados and mangoes. The mangoes from far north Queensland can be harvested a lot earlier than our mangoes. We grow the Bowen special type—I can recommend them, Madam Acting Deputy President, even though they do not come in at the same time as those from north Queensland. Because of this difference, people can buy mangoes over a wide time span.

PARA.TAB: I know that in our local Kingaroy area, quite a number of farms out Kumbia way which used to grow just peanuts or corn during the off season are now are growing lovely fruits such as peaches. There is even an orchard near Kingaroy that grows nashi. I do not know whether you, Madam Acting Deputy President, have actually tried this fruit, which is a cross between pears and apples.

TALK.START.PARA: —Delicious!

—That is right. They are very nice, indeed. I want to compliment the farmers in our area because they know the problems these days of trying to grow crops when dry land farming. People in the horticultural industry who are growing fruit have to have dams. We know, too, that farmers need to pump water to where it is needed. I can assure you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that there is a cost in terms of electricity.

PARA.TAB: When farmers cannot get enough income from their crops, it is important that they try to diversify. That is what people in our area are doing. Farmers trying to grow crops such as peanuts, maize and wheat have to provide the seed, fuel, fertiliser and wages—and, my word, the costs add up. We know what has happened to the sale of wheat at the present time. This is a real problem. A farmer near us at Kingaroy has the most beautiful crop of wheat. It really is lovely. I was telling his wife the other day how beautiful it looked as one drives past.

With the costs that farmers face and with problems such as those caused by the Americans subsidising wheat though the EEP, it is no wonder that farmers have to turn to horticulture to try to get a reasonable income. I wanted to make this important point while I was speaking to this Industry Commission report on the Australian Horticultural Corporation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Higher Education Council

SPEECH.PARA: Intrastate aviation services form an integral part of Australia's transport network. In many regions they supplement services provided by road, rail and, in some instances, coastal shipping. However, in some remote areas, intrastate air services provide the only practicable means of transporting inhabitants, tourists, food, medical supplies and other goods. Similarly, general aviation operators provide services, such as crop dusting and medical services, on which many rural communities are heavily reliant. As this report says on page one of the overview:

Given their important role in Australia's transport system, it is imperative that intrastate aviation services are provided efficiently. If they are not, segments of the community may be disadvantaged and the overall performance of the economy impaired.

PARA.TAB: I want to make a few comments in the few minutes I have today to speak on the disadvantages that are currently being faced by those in remote and rural areas because of the lack of services. In my own State of Queensland, where the majority of the population lives outside the capital city, it is essential to have an efficient and frequent air system to cover those vast tracts of land. Indeed, it is essential in order to provide a reasonable service to those living outside the major centres.

In two weeks time I intend to travel in far northern and western Queensland. It is a logistical nightmare to try to travel to and from each of the centres. The problem is that if an air service exists in some of these remote towns it operates only once a week. In essence, this means that if one were living there one would have to stay away for a week and pay the high costs of motel bills. Otherwise, the only alternative is to travel by road. Yet, these centres provide some of the highest earnings for Australia in export income.

People living in these areas are being disadvantaged as airlines either close down or cancel flights on those routes. This is due in some part to the economic recession we had to have, or otherwise to the dominance of the new wave of economic thinking which claims that all services and government activities should be dictated by market forces.
Only in the past month we have seen Australian Airlines cancel its services to the rich mining centre of Mount Isa.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—Yes, it is a shame. This can only impose a further disadvantage on anyone in that region wanting to travel elsewhere. It is all very good for governments and company officials to say that people can travel by road or rail. But I am sure that any official living in Sydney or Melbourne, or the bureaucrats here in Canberra, would not appreciate the amount of time taken and the wear and tear on vehicles that travel over badly deteriorated dirt roads. I can assure honourable senators that driving in those remote areas is not a leisurely Sunday afternoon drive through the suburbs.

PARA.TAB: Further penalties are placed on those in remote areas when if they do need to fly because of pressures of time, in many cases they have to charter a plane. Some find that the only way to cope with this no win situation is to invest in their own light planes or, otherwise, pay the costs of charter.

I can assure you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that in the current economic climate very few can afford to own and maintain light aircraft. This Government has made being on the land and living outside of Sydney and Melbourne a national disaster. Sometimes I think it deliberately penalises those who work in these remote areas because the Government does not believe that it needs their votes. That is not the way to run a country.

Some consideration should also be given to the fact that people in the western and northern areas of Australia provide the income which supports many who live in the cities. They are the ones who have to contend with the lack of educational facilities and high costs incurred just to send children to school, the high costs of health care, or the lack of it, the high costs of fuel—an essential commodity for travelling anywhere in those regions—the high costs of just essential goods and even the penalty of not being able to make a telephone call without being charged at high rates. This is what is called the tyranny of distance.

Governments have a responsibility to ensure that the fairest system is provided for all Australians. So when the Government considers this report and its recommendations, it should also look to the responsibility of providing a decent transport system for all Australians, not one based on market-based rational economics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks that have just been made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I know that she cares about people who live in remote areas, as I do. Sometimes the Government seems to forget that there are people who live and work in the far parts of our vast country. This report by the Industry Commission on intrastate aviation, dated 17 July of this year, on the first page of its overview states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Commission's view, the intrastate aviation sector is currently not performing to its full potential. Its present performance and future development is being hampered by a number of factors which are subject to the control of governments in Australia. The most significant of these is the economic regulation which continues to apply to intrastate airline operations in a number of states.

Hazelton Airlines was mentioned in the chamber today by Senator Collins when he tabled an aviation paper. Hazelton, I believe, is the most pure privately owned airline in Australia. Max Hazelton runs the company and does a fantastic job. The airline gives good service wherever it goes. In his submission to the inquiry he said:
The dice are effectively loaded against regional airline operators in New South Wales, particularly those who remain independent.

He said that this was because of the high concentration of ownership that is already evident in the aviation industry, with the Ansett group and Australia Airlines dominating interstate markets and controlling over 80 per cent of the intrastate market. That is a problem Australia has. The big are getting bigger, and the small are unable to compete in a fair and equitable way. Senator Collins should take a little more notice of that instead of trying to make cheap political points as he did in Question Time. The report also mentions that Hazelton has stated that true and open competition cannot be attained because of the marketing and distribution power held by the two major airlines, Ansett and Australian. We should all remember that. Ansett and Australian hold an unfair advantage.

PARA.TAB: Another area that has concerned me for a long time involves submissions by Hazelton Airlines and other commuter airlines in my State about the peak and shoulder surcharges that apply at Kingsford Smith Airport. This report said that those charges should be reviewed by an independent body. The problem has been caused by the peak charging coming on and the shoulders becoming just as congested. Those factors are increasing the costs for the operators of the commuter airlines.

It is important to remember that those commuter airlines face costs while in the circling pattern. I have had representations from commuter operators. One of them said that 18 per cent of all ticket costs at the moment are derived from government charges, including the CAA, the FAC, the ALOP and peak hour charges. That is another aspect that should be looked at.

Hazelton Airlines told me that peak hour charges are costing them $600,000 per annum. If that is a fair charge to a commuter airline, I believe the Minister should look very closely at ensuring that the third runway is built pretty quickly in Sydney so we do not have all the problems with peak charging and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree.

—I thank the Minister for recognising that. It is very important that we get that third runway going and operating and not just being talked about, which has been the case for so long. To reiterate the point made earlier today by Senator Short, GST will definitely help the airline industry. At least people will be able to afford to fly under our Fightback proposals because the economy will change. It must be remembered that 80 per cent of all tickets sold are business tickets, and business ticket holders will have the GST refunded. The other 20 per cent of ticket holders who do not have business tickets will definitely be better off anyway under our Fightback proposal, so they will be able to afford to fly anyway.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Report No. 61: Administrative Penalties in Customs and Excise

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is report No. 61 from the Law Reform Commission and it relates to administrative penalties in customs and excise. It is a particularly pertinent report in that it relates to matters that are being raised generally in the Estimates committees, but also in the Midford Paramount hearing dealing with the way Customs pursued matters where there are penalties and indeed settled them. It is also relevant to many of the complaints that are outlined by Mr John Richardson who has tabled a report, or had the President table a report in the Senate, and which could subsequently be the question of a privilege inquiry. Mr Richardson made some very substantial complaints about the way in which Customs prosecuted particular cases before the AAT.

PARA.TAB: These matters all related to the question of the strict liability system that was implemented for Customs whereby if any error was made in dealing with forms filled out by an agent, there was an automatic penalty. That penalty was set at a rate determined by the record of the agent completing the documentation dealing with the importation of goods. But Customs developed a practice of also taking into account penalties that existed against the importer himself or the firm of the agent concerned.

Over a period of time Customs attempted to tell us that it had ceased that practice. But on further questioning it was discovered that cessation had only occurred where one of the parties—that is, either the agent or the importer or the agent's firm—was prepared to wear the responsibility for having made the error. If nobody was prepared to wear the error, then indeed the same old practice was pursued, and on many an occasion these matters would end up before the AAT.

It is important to point out that the Australian Law Reform Commission analysed this strict liability situation. It has made many recommendations, but two of them are particularly important and ought to be noted. One is that the Commission recommends that a person who has paid an administrative penalty should not be able to be prosecuted for an offence based on the same facts. That is a very interesting recommendation. It goes on to say that if a person is prosecuted for an offence after he or she has made a submission to Customs in response to a pre-penalty notice, the submission should be privileged. Customs should not be able to use them as admissions in criminal proceedings against the importer.

Going back to some of the recommendations, I believe that the strict liability system is not in the interests of having a just system. The principle, however, about prosecution and an administrative penalty should apply not only in the area of Customs law but also in taxation law. On another occasion I will seek the opportunity to draw those parallels. We have seen instances where a penalty has been paid, the Taxation Commissioner has chosen to return the money paid and proceed with criminal proceedings, and indeed to query whether he has used admissions which ought to be privileged as part of his evidence. So the case that is made here in this report is applicable just as much in the taxation area and is an important parallel.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

However, the truth of the matter is that last year it made a trading loss of $32m but was allowed to treat its tax losses as an asset because, in the judgment of the Auditor-General, it was reasonable to expect that within three years a profit would be made and, therefore, one could treat the tax losses as an asset.

PARA.TAB: However, specifically in this year's report, the Auditor-General has said that the AIDC may not treat the $99m loss as an asset because he does not foresee that those losses can be reasonably used up. He has, however, allowed it to carry forward a sum now of $47m which is transposed to a figure of $53m in the report, the explanation of which I understand is due to a tax ruling on swaps. But the anticipation that the AIDC can trade its way out of its difficulty remains in doubt.

This report is signed off by the Auditor-General on 4 September. My complaint about the report is that at the Estimates Committee hearing on 22 September, I believe it was, we were told that the accounts were not ready and, therefore, we could not have them for the purpose of that hearing. Quite clearly, it was within the competence of the AIDC to let us have this document so that we could have questioned Mr Gurry, the Chairman, at that time about that report. I find that behaviour totally unsatisfactory.

The other thing I find utterly amazing is that in the Budget it was announced that the Government intended to sell another 30 per cent of the AIDC to take the Government holding down to 51 per cent, yet three weeks after the Budget Senator Button had to announce that that sale would not take place. The reason was very simple: in the interim the $99m loss was announced and, quite frankly, the shares were and are unsaleable. How is it that the Minister allowed a recommendation to go through for the Budget Papers that AIDC was saleable when somebody ought to have known—and the Minister ought to have known—that in fact it was making a $99m loss? To say that things were sloppy would be the understatement of the year. I think there are many more questions that need to be asked about the AIDC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)agrees to furnish the chamber with an Australian flag which is in keeping with the proportions and architecture of the chamber;
(b)notes that this:
(i)gives a permanent outward sign of the allegiance which we all owe to the nation of Australia,

(ii)shows respect for the commitment Australian men and women have demonstrated to the Australian flag throughout the history of Australia in times of peace and war, and now as the unifying symbol for our sports people in the international arena, and
(iii)demonstrates that the Senate is proud to display the Australian flag; and
(c)ensures that the flag is installed within three weeks after the passage of this resolution.

SPEECH.PARA: Some time ago I moved that the Senate be furnished with an Australian flag in a manner which is in keeping with the proportions and architecture of the chamber. That would give a permanent and outward sign of allegiance which we all owe to the nation of Australia, show our respect for the commitment Australian men and women have demonstrated to the Australian flag throughout the history of Australia both in times of peace and war, and be a unifying symbol for our sports people in the international area. That would demonstrate that the Senate is proud to display the Australian flag and I ask that the flag be installed within three weeks of the passing of this motion.

PARA.TAB: I am very proud to move this motion. I believe we are elected representatives of the community, the same as the members in the House of Representatives. Over in their chamber they have two Australian flags prominently displayed, but in the Senate we have never been able to proudly say that the Australian flag has flown in this chamber. The flag flies over the joint Houses of Parliament, and as it is seen in the House of Representatives, I believe it would complete the position if it were also displayed here.

There can be no better manifestation of the Australian people displaying their support for the flag than we saw at the opening of the Vietnam war memorial last weekend. We saw it on television and many people were fortunate enough to be present at the opening of the memorial when some 20,000 or 30,000 veterans visited Canberra to attend the opening. We saw a proud display of the Australian flag. In fact, Australian flags were flown representing the 504 veterans who made the supreme sacrifice and did not return to Australia.

It would be of very great benefit to have that flag in here to represent the strong feelings out in the community in support of the flag. I do not know which way the Labor Party will vote on this motion. I hope they will support it. I know that the Democrats have indicated that they will support it. It is part of the Labor Party's logo at election time. Members of the Labor Party stand behind it as they did in Victoria last Saturday, but not with particularly good results. They are very proud to stand behind it in times of election. It is now up to them to make up their minds because they have been equivocating as to whether they do or do not want the flag. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) certainly does not want the flag, but the hard men of the Labor Party, that is, Senator Loosley, Senator Ray and Senator Richardson, have advised the Prime Minister that he is on a losing tack by implying that he is not in support of the flag.

The flag has always had the support of the Australian people. Its birth is inseparable from the birth of our independent nation. The flag illustrates the symbol of our full nationhood. The design of the flag was not imposed from above. It arose from a public design competition in 1901 to coincide with Federation. Up until the last couple of months it has always had bipartisan acceptance by all political parties. In 1947 Prime Minister Chifley announced the Australian flag was to be flown freely and with appropriate respect. In 1953 there was bipartisan agreement between Prime Minister Menzies and the Opposition Leader, Mr Calwell, for the Flag Act whereby the Australian flag was definitely proclaimed as the national flag.

We have seen the Prime Minister criticise that flag over the past three or four months, although I must admit that in the last month or so there has been a deafening silence. The flag had never been officially criticised or derided until the Prime Minister made what I would term as his hysterical assault on the flag from April to June of this year. The Prime Minister chose very inappropriate times to criticise our national flag. On a visit to Indonesia on 22 April, in front of President Suharto—who I assume would have been embarrassed—and other Indonesian dignitaries, the Prime Minister made a speech that virtually said that Australia must change its flag. I believe that was an act of total disloyalty to Australia when he was visiting another nation.

On 25 April on a visit to Papua New Guinea he commented to patriotic, loyal and courteous flag waving school children that we had to change our flag and he would get them a new one soon. I find it very embarrassing that a Prime Minister could make those statements to children who came out to welcome him waving the national flag. At the launch of the Sydney Olympic bid in front of Olympians he again chose to criticise the flag.

The last we heard from Mr Keating was in June when he said he was going to make a Cabinet submission on ways to change the flag. That is when the factional leaders stepped in and said that he was causing the Labor Party to lose votes. That is very true. It does not matter whether people are traditional Labor or Democrat voters—and certainly among traditional National Party voters there is overwhelming support for the Australian flag, which I think would carry through to the Liberal Party voters—support for the Australian flag extends right across the whole party system. Now it is time for the Labor Party to decide whether it wants the flag or does not want it. This motion that I have put before the Senate is symbolic, because it gives the opportunity for the Labor Party and the Government to make up their minds. They have to make a decision whether they will support the flag or vote against it. If they vote against it, that is a signal to the whole of Australia that they are against the Australian flag. I say to them that the time for decision is now. The Government has procrastinated and equivocated for six months. Some members of the Labor Party have pushed their republican cause, but today is the moment of truth and a decision has to be made.

As Australians, we should be proud to stand by our flag as a symbol of our nation. That pride should be manifested in the displaying of the Australian flag in this chamber. This chamber must be one of the very few, if not the only chamber, of any parliament in the world that does not display its national symbol.

I have been told that the Australian flag has not been in the Senate for 92 years. The Senate chamber of the old Parliament House had the State flags proudly displayed on the front wall—or the back wall depending on how one looks at it. When we came to the new Parliament House the flags did not follow us because it was said that they would not fit in with the decor of the Parliament. I can certainly say that a flag displayed here would present no problems to the architecture of this chamber.

My motion calls for the flag to be put into this chamber within three weeks of its passing. I do not want to see this motion go to a committee where discussions will take place and it will get lost in a maze of paperwork. That has happened before. There have been discussions and the debate has been headed off to a committee on a number of occasions. As senators who represent the States and as senators who represent the Australian people, it is time we made a decision as to whether we want and are proud enough to display the Australian flag in the chamber. We believe that there is support amongst the Australian people to have the Australian flag displayed in both chambers of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I indicate that we will not be opposing Senator Boswell's motion. I have not been persuaded by the power of his argument; this is a position we took some time ago. Whatever the flag of Australia is, we support the concept of it being in this chamber. As Senator Boswell says, the flag appeared in the previous chamber and, as a consequence, we will not be opposing the motion. I would anticipate that there may not be a need for a long debate after this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also will not be opposing this motion. We support the motion. However, I would like to say a few words about what it really means to be Australian. While symbols are important, what it means to be Australian and the defence of what it means to be Australian is indeed far more important.

PARA.TAB: One can only reflect on some of the debates which have gone on in this chamber in recent times in relation to the very large number of unemployed and the degree of inequity which is increasing in the Australian community as a direct consequence of abstract economic models being imposed on this country by the Government and the model which would be imposed by the Opposition. I would say that that is very much un-Australian. It certainly bears on several answers we had in Question Time today.

Fundamental to being an Australian is the fair go and a reasonable degree of equity in society. As we have seen from the report of the Catholic Bishops and from many other sources, since 1983 the degree of inequity, the degree of poverty and the degree of concentration of wealth in this country has increased very substantially. That is not being Australian and that, in our view, is far more important than whether a flag is displayed in this chamber or not. The substance is more important than the symbols.
Yesterday we had a debate on the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. Senator Campbell talked about the wide brown land and I was reminded then of the lines:

SPEECH.PARA: Breathes there the man, with soul so dead,
Who never to himself hath said,
This is my own, my native land?

The concept of protecting in Australia what is uniquely Australian was also discussed in relation to the environment. Senator Campbell later on that day argued for mining in national parks and specifically for mining in the Marandoo National Park where there is a threatened species. It calls into question what it means to be Australian. To be Australian, surely, means protecting those things which are unique to this country. This includes the landscape and those species which have been absolutely decimated since European settlement. It raises also the issue that the Federal Government for years has promised legislation on threatened species. Even as we speak, the Government is attempting to water down that legislation so that we see either no legislation at all or, if we do see it, very weak legislation.

PARA.TAB: The original Australians in this land deserve a great deal more attention than they have been accorded. For years they were treated as a despised race. They were decimated, they were herded off their land, and they were treated with abysmal disregard. Only in recent times has some recognition been given to Aboriginal land rights, but again substantially opposed by the Opposition and the forces that support the Opposition.

Whilst we support this motion, we are very concerned that behind such motions which talk about symbols, which talk about flags in the chamber, we should also be thinking about what it means to be an Australian: the fair go for Australians, a greater degree of equity in Australia and the protection of the environment of this country which is absolutely unique and which deserves far more protection than is being offered either by the Government or by the Opposition with its callous disregard for the environment which is indicated by its wish to mine all the national parks of this country. With those few remarks, I indicate that we will support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no worries with this motion. I have no worries about a flag being in this chamber at all. I do not suggest that it will lift the standard of debate in this place at all. In fact, if the flag is to reflect the actual position of this Senate and the debates in this Senate from time to time, it will in most instances be flying upside down. But I do believe that it is appropriate that the flag of this nation is displayed in this chamber. Mind you, I would not mind seeing a bowl of flowers around the place here or there as well—
—Or a bowl of fruit.

—Or a bowl of fruit alongside the flowers. I envisage that the place to have the flag is at the back of the President's chair where that nice looking piece of wood is. I do not know what it is, although I should. It is quite fitting that it at least be in that vicinity.

PARA.TAB: I hope that we do not carry on in a jingoistic fashion, from time to time pointing to the Australian flag and appealing to national pride, et cetera. I would hate to see that happen in this chamber, because I do not think it is appropriate. After all, we are all Australians. In my humble opinion, I do not think it is appropriate to be gesticulating to the Australian flag and appealing to it for the purposes of getting over a political point from time to time.

I congratulate Senator Boswell for bringing the issue to our attention. It is something that, frankly, I had not thought of; I suppose not many of us had. Having it brought to our attention, I fully support what Senator Boswell is proposing. On reflection, I realise that it was a mistake not having the flag here before.

TALK.START.PARA: —As chairman of the Opposition's national flag task force, I want to reinforce the remarks that I made when Senator Boswell tried to bring on this motion earlier. I stand by the remarks that I made then, which included my being appalled at the Labor Party refusing to let that motion be debated at that stage and speaking against our flag. I am delighted to see that it has seen the errors of its ways and that it will be supporting the motion, together with the Australian Democrats, so that we will have our beautiful Australian flag present in this chamber as our most important and potent national symbol.

PARA.TAB: Almost daily I lodge petitions in this chamber from ordinary Australians around the country that call for our flag to be retained and for Mr Keating to quite frankly keep his hands off it; if he wants to change it, he should ask the people by way of a referendum. It is most significant that the Australian Labor Party has chosen to support this motion because, had it chosen not to and we divided on the issue, it could have been embarrassed by the result. I put on the record that I am delighted to see that the most beautiful flag in the world—that is, the Australian national flag—will be gracing this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, perhaps unusually for her, has been rather ungracious in a debate which I thought had been conducted quite graciously up until now. I thought that Senator Boswell's contribution was quite magnificent, as were the contributions of Senator Harradine and Senator Coulter; I thought that Senator Coulter made some very good points.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Labor Party has the Australian flag in its symbol. Let us be quite clear about this: the Australian Labor Party and senators on this side will always show loyalty and respect for the Australian flag. What is being debated is not the concept of a flag but the design of a particular flag. Those on this side belong to a party whose loyalty has been exemplary throughout the history of this nation. John Curtin led this country through its greatest crisis and did so successfully.

I thought that I would correct any sour note that had been introduced into the debate and make it quite clear that we welcome and join in the statements made by Senator Boswell, Senator Coulter and Senator Harradine. Many of the points raised by those speakers are worthy of debate. The debate as to the actual design of the flag will go on, but our loyalty to the flag is unquestioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on this topic and to confirm, as Senator Coulter has stated, that the Australian Democrats support Senator Boswell's motion. The flag is our national symbol. As Senator Cooney said, while the debate on the actual design may well continue, and rightly so, symbols in the life of a nation are important.

PARA.TAB: However, we should not confuse symbols with substance. There must be a slight twinge of regret that at this stage in the nation's development and the current economic and social state that this nation finds itself in, this chamber is spending time on this motion. I wish that it could have been disposed of much more quickly and that we could have addressed ourselves more directly to today's unemployment figure; the rising number of homeless people; the need to take some decisive action in industry development; the need to look at our protection policy; and to deal with what this chamber is intended to deal with, which is the social and economic challenges of our nation that we are facing today.

None of this is to say that I devalue in any way the proposal to have our national symbol in this chamber; it belongs here and rightly so. While debate over the design may continue, clearly, the flag will change as a result of that debate in due course. As I said before, I add my support to Senator Boswell's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike some of my colleagues, I do not lie over and meekly accept this motion. I oppose parts of it and, if there had been a division in the chamber, I would have voted against parts of it. I will explain that very briefly, being aware of the previous comment made by Senator Spindler, who made a lot of sense in what he put forward; there are more important issues in the community than this matter.

PARA.TAB: I do not have a problem with part (a), which deals with flying the current Australian flag in this chamber. However, part (b) concerns me. We talk about the flag being a permanent outward sign of allegiance. Perhaps it is, but let us look at that allegiance ourselves. When each of us in turn has been elected by the people of Australia in our respective States to serve in this Parliament as representatives of those States, we do not give an oath of allegiance to our nation; we give an oath of allegiance to the Queen of England as the Queen of Australia. The lady is in England and she is now the Queen of the United Kingdom, including Great Britain and Northern Ireland. She is not in Australia and she is not currently the—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the Irish have problems understanding things, but get it right.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator McKiernan has the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part (ii) of item (b) of Senator Boswell's motion is a very worthy part. Respect was shown for this flag last weekend in this city when a memorial service was held in memory of the events in Vietnam. More than 500 flags were carried through the city in memory of individuals who gave their lives, not only on behalf of Australia but on behalf of something else. The respect shown for the flag on that occasion made for a very moving ceremony. Unfortunately, I was not present at it, but I certainly saw it on television. That is one way that the symbol of a nation can be used to commemorate people.

PARA.TAB: However, it is unfortunate to note when we examine the Australian flag and when Vietnam days are brought to mind that Great Britain did not take part in that conflict. By a resolution of the British Government, Britain did not get involved, yet its symbol flew as part of the Australian symbol in Vietnam and here in memory of those Australians who gave their lives in that conflict.

I do not have a problem with the fact that the flag should be flown here within three weeks. It ought to be erected on a flagpole. I will not take up Senator Faulkner's suggestion as to what else would be put on the flagpole, but I think it is an eminently good suggestion.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that? I did not say anything.

—He knows and I know. As has previously been said by my colleague sitting beside me, Senator Cooney, the debate on the symbol will continue. It is a debate worthy of Australia in the latter part of the twentieth century as we prepare for the twenty-first century. We are a completely different nation from what we were 100 years ago when the debate on the flag was taking place.

PARA.TAB: What is often overlooked in the debate on the flag is the fact that it has changed on a whole number of occasions. Senator Boswell's motion mentions in part that the flag has flown in peace and war. To my knowledge, the current flag has never been carried into the battlefield by Australian troops.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is embarrassing; it is going into Hansard.

—I can defend it, Senator Tierney, and will do so. In talking with Australian troops who have gone into conflict, I have found that very few of them have gone into battle to defend a symbol or a piece of cloth. They have gone into battle to defend principles, which is much more important than the symbol that we are talking about here.

PARA.TAB: The greatest commitment our sporting people make is in the area of training, not just at times when the gold, silver or bronze medals are handed out. They do not need flags to progress them from training to reach the heights that they have reached, as was demonstrated in the two sets of international competitions held recently, namely, the Olympic Games and the Paralympic Games.
In relation to paragraph (c), I do not have a problem with the flag being erected in some form within this place within a three-week period.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—I would like to draw Senator McKiernan's attention to standing order 100(1) which indicates that while a division may be called for only by two or more senators, one senator calling for a division shall be entitled to have that senator's vote recorded in the journals. Since Senator McKiernan referred in his speech to the opportunity to express his view being denied because there is no division, I thought I would draw that to his attention so that he could reflect on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I wish to ask you a question in regard to that. I only object to part of it. How would I go about opposing part of it?
—Then you would have to consider whether you could ask the Senate to have it put in parts. That is not a matter I can deal with now. It is something you might like to consider.
—I will. I thank you for your advice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I wish to thank all parties of the Senate for their support for this motion.
—Some of it was qualified.

—Yes, some of it was qualified, but let us be generous today because it is a big day. It is a day where we basically have agreement right across the chamber. We certainly note Senator McKiernan's differences, but I do not think we ought to accentuate his differences. The Labor Party has indicated that it will support the flying of the flag in the chamber. It is an historical symbol of Australia. We are going to get it into this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop, as chairman of the Australian flag task force, has expressed the view that she is very pleased that the flag be put in the chamber. Senator Coulter has said that we must never forgo the symbol for the substance. There would certainly be no disagreement with anyone in this chamber about that, but symbols are representations of a country. We cannot run Australia up a flagpole when someone is proudly standing to receive a gold medal, nor can we run a State up a flagpole. That flag represents what Australia is all about. Senator McKiernan cannot say that people go to the Olympics because they want to hurt themselves training by swimming up and down a pool for four or five hours in the morning or running around a track for four or five hours every day. They do it to honour their country. They do not do it for the pain they are going to gain in training. The gain that they make is to lift Australia's sporting prowess in the Olympics or whatever competition they are participating in.

To pick up Senator Harradine's point, certainly we had flags in the other chamber. He and I were down there for a number of years. I do not at any time recall his pointing to the Tasmanian flag or my pointing to the Queensland flag to make a political point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see it; it was behind me.

—It was not; it was in front of you. I certainly take Senator Harradine's point. I do not think we will see any evidence of people wrapping themselves up in the flag or pointing to the flag. It is one of those days when I feel the Senate has achieved something by displaying the symbol of Australia. I hope it will be a unifying force in this Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 4 March, on motion by Senator Tierney:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I imagined that somebody from the Opposition would have supported Senator Tierney's Bill. I rise to support the Australian National University Amendment (Autonomy) Bill. I see it as a very important piece of legislation not only from the point of view of what the Bill seeks to do, but also because of the symbolic significance of it. I suppose in that sense it is a little like the motion we have just been debating.

PARA.TAB: This Bill will amend the Australian National University Act 1991 to ensure that the responsibility for the application of funds appropriated by the Parliament to the Australian National University rests with the University Council. In other words, it is aimed at preserving the autonomy of the university and, by extension, the autonomy of universities and tertiary educational institutions in general.

The Bill seeks to amend section 42 of the principal Act, the section dealing with finances of the university, to regulate the Minister's powers in relation to money payable to the university. Currently, subsections 42(2) and 42(3) allow the Minister—this is an important point—to determine the amounts and the times at which money allocated by the Parliament to the university is to be paid to the university. In other words, the Minister has usurped that right and in so doing has undermined the autonomy of the university.

The two new subsections (4) and (5) therefore prohibit the Minister from divesting control of the university funds to external bodies. In effect, the amendments reinforce the powers of council in section 9 which proclaims that the council has `entire control and management of the university'. That is a very important principle and one which in various ways and various guises has been consistently undermined by this Government over all the years that it has been in power.

It is a measure designed to safeguard the autonomy of the Australian National University and its prestigious John Curtin School of Medical Research in light of the decision by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, the Hon. Peter Baldwin, to transfer its funding from DEET to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. This decision sparked a national debate over institutional autonomy—and so it should—prompting a Senate standing committee inquiry into the Minister's role and the perceived threat to the ANU's autonomy. As I argued in an earlier debate in this place, and as I argued just a moment ago, it also threatened the autonomy of tertiary institutions generally around Australia.

In April, the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training tabled its long awaited report on the JCSMR. My opinion and that of the Democrats in this matter is reflected in the minority report. I do not believe the Minister overstepped his brief, but I do not support the funding transfer on the grounds that there has been no demonstrable benefit to the school and, as the report states, it did constitute `a threat to the autonomy of the school'.

The inquiry investigated the sensitive matter of ministerial interference in the administration of the university and the freedom of universities to exercise control over institutional funding allocations. We maintain that, in the case of the JCSMR, funding allocation should return to DEET and the directors of the research school. The Minister's Department still faces confusion as to how the new funding arrangements will operate. However, this debate is not simply about the funding transfer but goes to the very heart of government interference in education.

The Australian National University Amendment (Autonomy) Bill 1992 seeks to avert any such threat in the future and to protect the freedom of higher education institutions to determine their own research and teaching priorities, and that is a very important principle which should be jealously guarded. It gives an assurance to the Australian National University and to other universities that their autonomy will be preserved.

The Democrats support the training and funding arrangements. However, an acceptance of the need for centralised funding arrangements does not condone government interference or threats that are tantamount to blackmail and an attempt to redirect by government fiat research and teaching in our universities. Similarly, the Democrats support the process of institutional profiles to ensure that institutions meet access and equity criteria. So we have no problem with those general conditions being imposed on universities. The overwhelming majority of higher education institutions have demonstrated a willingness to participate in this process.

This issue of autonomy is indeed a very potent one. This year there has been an ongoing debate on this issue, especially surrounding the controversial relationship between vice-chancellors and the Government. This stems from what one vice-chancellor has described as `the seamless drift from accountability to control'. I might just add that it is my view that, with the amalgamation of universities which has been going on apace over many years now, the vice-chancellors were far too compliant in that process and should have raised their concerns much earlier and simply not laid back and allowed the Government to get as far as it did before it attempted to proceed with this particular quite iniquitous intrusion into the Australian National University.

It is a prevalent notion that, with the Dawkins led reforms of the higher education system—the abolition of the distinction between CAEs and universities—new measures of accountability have been introduced that encroach upon the universities' traditional freedom. That institutions should be pressured over funding levels as well as the manner of that funding is quite unacceptable. While I would strongly defend the freedom of the universities, as I have been doing, nonetheless that does impose a responsibility on the universities to reflect on the direction of society—to hold, as it were, a mirror up to society—to play a very critical role in relation to government and other activities in society in general; to help society make different decisions about different directions; and to open up different options for it.

Of course, one needs only look at recent criticisms of the economic rationalist model being pursued by Government and Opposition by people such as Professor Russell Mathews or various other authors to see that government would have found this criticism unpalatable. In that one can find reasons why governments would want to control the universities. The function of the universities in being critical of government and critical of other activities in the community is an absolutely essential activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner I was speaking on the Australian National University Amendment (Autonomy) Bill 1992 introduced by Senator Tierney. I made the point that this Bill addresses a very significant attack by the Government on our universities, not least through the attempt to control the funding for the John Curtin School of Medical Research at the ANU but also, in a more insidious way, in terms of the threat that it held for tertiary institutions more generally. I then made the point that universities, through their independence, had a very important role to play in our society by holding a mirror up to society. After all, they contain some of the more intelligent and better educated members of our community. They therefore have a very strong responsibility to be critical of governments and institutions and of the direction in which society is going, and also to hold out before society the alternatives that lie before it so that they can help to guide a more intelligent and more rational direction for society.

PARA.TAB: I would not argue for a moment that the universities have always played that role. They certainly have not. However, to restrict their freedom to play that role and to try to tie them down to what the Government in its narrow vision conceives as a single vision future for the country is simply to deny them the ability to ever play that very productive and creative role.

One can already see the failure of the Government's proposal, not only in relation to the universities but also in relation to the CSIRO, in a number of very important respects. I remember asking Senator Button a question in relation to how much time CSIRO scientists spent making applications for funding, given the fact that the Government had imposed on it a requirement to get 30 per cent of its funding from private sources. Senator Button replied that they spent 20 to 25 per cent of their time applying for grants from private sources and then responding to the grant givers by way of reports. I remind the Senate that these people are highly competent scientists who should be spending that 20 to 25 per cent of their time on research work.

In a more sinister fashion, Senator Button in his reply went on to explain that he thought that this was a very good thing because—and I quote his very words—`this close association also helps to set the agenda for the research scientists'. That pressure for close liaison between research and immediate profit—something to which Senator Tierney drew our attention in his second reading speech—and away from the greater value of the long term research work which only these high powered research institutions can do, is extremely dangerous.

In the case of CSIRO, one can point to many specific areas in which high quality research work has been impeded by the emphasis on that requirement. I cite, for instance, the attempt through genetic engineering to put the chitinase enzyme into sheep so that they would become totally resistant to blowfly strike. That work was being funded through government sources and it was totally halted for a period of four or five months once that requirement came in. That was because, quite clearly, private interests, particularly those that make chemicals for the treatment of blowfly strike in sheep, do not have an interest in that sort of work and it really undercuts their profitability.

More directly in the area of universities, one could point to the work of Professor Derek Rowley from the University of Adelaide on a highly effective cholera vaccine which he could produce for as little as between 4c and 10c per shot. But no commercial interests are interested in cholera vaccine at 4c to 10c per shot for Third World countries. He was told by the commercial interests that, if he could make it available for people in First World countries who were going into cholera prone areas and sell it for $20 per shot, he might be in business. That very important research work, which went on over about 25 years, is now languishing despite many millions of dollars having been spent on this development.

So that close linking between research and private sources for funding is often inimical to the very research that we should be attempting to carry out. That is another reason why this particular proposal by the Government should be resisted and why we support Senator Tierney's Bill.The insistence in the White Paper that university governing bodies be modelled on boards of large public companies has also resulted in considerable tension between the Government and university administrations. The concept of autonomy can, of course, be all things to all people. The freedom to determine research and teaching initiatives, however, is absolutely fundamental.

As I have said, freedom for research does not mean licence. With freedom comes rights and responsibilities, and I stress again that it is important that our universities demonstrate their commitment to the achievement of the highest academic standards, as well as equity of access, and also to intrude where they think it is appropriate into the workings of society to exercise their greater skills, knowledge and access to alternative views for the greater benefit of society at large. They should not simply wall themselves up in ivory towers.

The freedom which universities experience, of course, does not extend to allowing institutions to charge fees or to discriminate against different groups in the community on unlawful grounds, a point which I mentioned briefly earlier. So clearly there is a general responsibility to observe those requirements, but they should not intrude into the general question of academic freedom.Therefore, in these respects the concepts of the traditional university autonomy and of university accountability are not incompatible. The internal funding allocations must remain free of external interference, and this includes not only pressures from government departments and their Ministers but also the pressures of industry and business.

In relation to the coalition, however, we find that it too, in a rather different way, would intrude into the freedom of the universities through its insistence that the marketplace be the dominating force there. If that comes to dominate our academic institutions, again, we will miss out on the high quality academic and intellectual research work which universities should carry out. So I sound that note of warning. So, while we are supporting the Opposition in relation to this particular Bill, we do not want it to be interpreted as generally supporting the policies outlined in Fightback—far from it; we believe that there are very considerable dangers in going down that path as well.

In summary, we take the view that universities must be free and unfettered in terms of the research work they take on. They must be free to teach, to criticise and to fully exercise the intellectual and academic activities traditionally associated with a university, and that carries with it the responsibility to do that at the highest possible standard and, through that, among other things, to be critical of all aspects of the society in which they operate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think another Government senator has spoken in the debate so I will put the Government view on the record. So far in the debate we have heard quite a lot of carping about the John Curtin School of Medical Research. It has been said time and again in debates in the Senate that the ANU retains ultimate control of the administration of the John Curtin School. As the Senate knows, we have spent lengthy periods debating this in this chamber. Funds for the purpose of the John Curtin School have not been transferred to the National Health and Medical Research School, as originally was proposed by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) but rather to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

PARA.TAB: It is important to get our facts straight here. This was done after lengthy consultation with the ANU and with the agreement by both the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe). The new arrangements for the John Curtin School of the Australian National University implemented by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services do not threaten the integrity nor the autonomy of the university. The ANU does retain ultimate control of the John Curtin School.

At the risk of boring the Senate again, I will outline the facts which led to the Minister's decision. Minister Baldwin announced on 27 March 1991 new arrangements for the Institute of Advanced Studies at the ANU, including the Government's response to the report of the committee to review the Institute of Advanced Studies, the Stephen Committee. The Stephen Committee comprised members of outstanding scholarly reputation, including international representation, and was chaired by Sir Ninian Stephen. The review was requested by the ANU and the membership of the Committee was agreed to and by the university. I repeat: the university wanted the review and agreed to the composition and membership of the review committee.

Minister Baldwin's March 1991 statement announced the Government's acceptance of the Stephen Committee's recommendation that responsibility for funding of the John Curtin School should be transferred to the NHMRC. The Stephen Committee report, while acknowledging that there were areas of considerable research strengths for the JCSMR, made some emphatic recommendations in relation to the John Curtin School which were not present in other schools or centres of the IAS. These problems were of long standing and were well documented in, for example, the reports of the reviews of the school in 1987-88 and 1988-89. They included problems of strategic planning, lack of evident leadership, poor public perception and low morale.

The Stephen Committee report found that whatever the causes of the problems, complex as they were, the status of the school was unacceptable. I will not read out the boring sections of the report because the people who have spoken in this debate would know them very well.

In his statement, Higher Education Funding for the 1992-94 Triennium, Minister Baldwin announced that $16.1m would be transferred from the Department of Employment, Education and Training to the Health, Housing and Community Services portfolio for the funding of John Curtin School. Administrative arrangements for funding of the ANU through the Department have been worked out between the ANU and the school. An agreement was signed between the ANU and Health, Housing and Community Services on 12 May 1992. This agreement includes the establishment of a liaison committee to oversee the implementation of the agreements between the university and the Department.

The agreement also provides for quintennial reviews of the school, which will be coordinated with the reviews of other research schools. Such reviews will provide the John Curtin School with the opportunity to confirm its standing in the research community. The Government believes that there is merit in the argument that there is some advantage for the school being linked, through association with HHCS, to the mainstream Australian health and bio-medical research networks.

I reiterate for the Senate's benefit that the John Curtin School remains a part of the ANU. The new arrangements threaten neither the integrity nor the autonomy of the university. If the Government had not acted on the recommendations of the Stephen Committee, the Opposition would be criticising us here tonight for not taking seriously the very recommendations of the Stephen Committee. Any responsible government could not disregard those recommendations.

Senator Tierney's proposal would have the ANU with absolute autonomy over the use of public funds. Would he have a university system with autonomy and no public accountability? What this Government has put in place is a well balanced system of accountability and autonomy which have been recognised by the system itself. Senator Tierney's proposal would render illegal the very profile system which this Government has established to balance autonomy with accountability—a system which the university system itself approves of.
The Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee—if you like, the universities' lobby group—has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The AVCC believes that the profiles and present data collection arrangements provide an excellent accountability mechanism and enable the Government to be reassured about both educational quality and the efficient and effective operation of the institutions.

To separate the ANU in the manner proposed by Senator Tierney would really put the ANU at odds with the rest of the system. Governments do not control higher education institutions. They are autonomous, self-governing and self-regulating organisations. This Government has recognised and strengthened this position.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services' statement on Higher Education: Quality and Diversity in the 1990s recognised this and has built in measures which give the system even further autonomy over its operations. This is evident in the Government's commitment to triennial funding, the recently announced roll in of capital funds into the operating grant and the proposed quality measures which will see the universities themselves ensuring the continued high quality of the higher education they provide.

The Government's approach is sensible, balanced and pragmatic. It recognises all the different influences on the system—that is, academic freedom and institutional autonomy, student interest in quality, and national interest in increasing participation and relevance in teaching and research.

The Opposition's policies endanger the autonomy of higher education institutions. The Opposition's proposed system of fees and vouchers will have the very effect that it accuses the Government of. Of course, the Opposition has still given us no details of how its fees and voucher system would work; what the value of the vouchers will be; how it will ensure that these vouchers are not used for the very attractive courses which lead to lucrative career paths; how the smaller institutions will remain viable; and how the Australian higher education system will function under its policies.

The Government is not moved by the reasons put forward by Senator Coulter and Senator Tierney. I think I went far enough at school at least to be able to count. I do not think we will seek to divide on this. I suggest that we will just let the legislation spend a fair bit of time on the House of Representatives agenda paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take only a minute to add my support to the remarks that were made by Senator Tierney during his second reading speech. What he said is supported by the Opposition. I have been very disappointed at the way in which this Government has, for some years, approached the Australian National University and at what it has tried to do with the university in terms of amalgamation and demolishing the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

PARA.TAB: We want the Australian National University Amendment (Autonomy) Bill to pass the Senate tonight. Therefore, I will not spend time canvassing the issues that have already been raised. Earlier in the debate Senator Coulter commented that nobody supported Senator Tierney. I do not know whether he meant that in the sense that Senator Tierney stands alone without support. But I feel very strongly on this issue and I totally support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I sat amazed listening to the comments of Senator Ray. I cannot really believe that he believed the things he was saying in the first part.
—I was definitely the monkey and not the ventriloquist.

—I am not too sure whether Senator Ray is the monkey or the ventriloquist in all of this. But I know that he read from some brief that he had been given. I will return a little later to speak in more detail about some of the points that he raised in debate. I will, however, put aside his gratuitous remarks on Fightback. I do not think we should go into that at this stage of the debate. In a number of other debates in this chamber I have made comments on how Fightback will affect education. In particular, I have commented on the totally inadequate way in which reports on education have been brought down by government departments and on how Fightback will fix this up. But I will leave that for another time.

PARA.TAB: The remark made by Senator Ray that I found most disturbing was that which indicated his attitude to private members' Bills. Senator Ray, just towards the end of his speech, said that this private member's Bill `will sit on the House of Representatives Notice Paper for a long time'. I think it is a great pity that a Minister of the Government has that attitude to private members' Bills. I believe that in this place they are a real opportunity to bring matters of great concern to the community before the Government—and I assure the Minister that the community is extremely concerned about what this Government is trying to do to the Australian National University by removing control of the John Curtin School of Medical Research from the ANU and, flowing from that, the implications for the autonomy of other universities. I thank Senator Coulter for his remarks in support of this Bill. I just want to outline to the Senate the nature and purpose of this Bill. The only effect of the Bill is to ensure that the Council of the Australian National University is solely responsible for the allocation of money appropriated by the Parliament for the purposes of administering the University.

The Australian National University was established under its own Act of parliament. The Act specifically states that within the university there shall be a research school of medical science, and that school shall be known as the John Curtin School of Medical Research. It is therefore indisputable that the JCSMR is an integral part of the university. This was clearly the intention of the founders of the university and that is why such a specific provision is contained in the Act to establish the university.

The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, has taken it upon himself to overrule these intentions and to circumvent the will of the Parliament by deciding to sever funding control from the ANU Council and, instead, to give it to a government department, namely, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. This is clearly an invasion of the autonomy of the Australian National University.

I was interested in Senator Ray's comments on autonomy. How he can actually reconcile the taking of a section of the university and putting it under the control of a government department that is not related to the Department of Employment, Education and Training and then claim that that is not breaching autonomy I think defies logic. The Minister's action in breaching the autonomy of the ANU has in fact created outrage on the campus of that university.

The ANU Council has voiced its opposition to this issue. The Minister mentioned in his speech that the ANU had been consulted. What he did not tell the Parliament was that the ANU did not agree. As a matter of fact, the Council has passed resolutions opposing this move. In the end the Government, of course, had the whip hand with financial control and then had its way with the ANU. The staff of the ANU have also been very opposed to this proposal. They have held public meetings which have condemned the Minister's action, and they have called for the financial control of the ANU School of Medical Research to remain within the University.

Two prominent Australians who were among the founding fathers of the ANU, Sir Mark Oliphant and Dr H.C. Coombs, have expressed their disgust at the Minister's actions. These men know what they are talking about. They were prime movers in the establishment of the ANU and were justifiably horrified at the proposal to dismember this university by allowing ministerial intervention

SPEECH.PARA: which would have the effect of moving funding away from the ANU to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Under this plan the Minister will be responsible for funding this integral part of the ANU under the health bureaucracy of the Federal Government. Thus the Department will be able to influence the research profile of the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

PARA.TAB: Research in Australia has suffered enough under the policies of the Australian Research Council and the educational profile process. Handing over the funding responsibilities of the JCSMR to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services is simply paving the way for even more centrally determined research priorities. One wonders whether this is not the hidden agenda that is behind the Government's actions. What it might do is actually stifle and hinder the outstanding and creative work undertaken by research scientists of the JCSMR.

Centrally funded research results in blinkered research. There needs to be a plurality of funding so that research may expand into a variety of areas. In this way the research can produce a variety of benefits. Government interference with and intervention in higher education have been both disruptive and destructive. This disruption now threatens the future of the JCSMR.

As I have repeated consistently, the John Curtin School of Medical Research is a world class bio-medical research institute and undertakes important work that is not always politically popular but is important long term research. It takes years of effort and ultimately yields results that are extremely beneficial. The research record of this school over the last 30 years stands in testimony to this. The actions of the Government to attempt to sever the JCSMR from the ANU could curtail this essential type of research.

The John Curtin School is part of the Institute of Advanced Studies within the ANU. The institute is a magnificent institution made up of various research schools of which the JCSMR is one. Interdisciplinary areas of science are growing rapidly, and the results of such studies are becoming more and more important. The communication between the various research schools as part of the ANU is absolutely essential for this type of research. By giving funding to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services to support the JCSMR, the communication lines are broken—the funding lines are all so different. The John Curtin School loses that vital link with these other schools in the ANU as a result of this action by the Minister.

Australia cannot afford to let that happen to one of our best research institutions. Also the Government must not be allowed to intervene at any time in the affairs of what should be an autonomous university as it sets a dangerous precedent. It was this consideration and, in particular, concern for the JCSMR that led the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training to investigate the Minister's decision. This is something that the Minister, in not telling us the full story, did not refer to. He told us the story of the committee entitled the Stephen Review of Higher Education in the ACT.

But if the Minister had taken the trouble to read the highly regarded report of the Senate Standing Committee of Employment, Education and Training inquiry into the John Curtin School, he would have found in it that the findings of the Stephen Committee were seriously deficient. I will illustrate in what ways they were deficient in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was asked to pay particular attention to the most desirable mechanism for control and administration of the school—and here we found great deficiencies in the Stephen Committee report. This was the report on which the Minister based his decision to transfer the control of the John Curtin School from the Institute of Advanced Studies in the university to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Committee found serious shortcomings with both the information gathering process of the Stephen Committee and the processes which it went through. To quote from the Senate Committee report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Committee is unanimous in its concerns over the shortcomings in the processes followed by the Stephen Committee during its review insofar as this related to the John Curtin School. The Senate Committee considers that such shortcomings diminish the value of the decision arrived at.
The eight members of the Senate Standing Committee—four Labor, one Democrat and three Liberal—endorsed that particular quote; we had serious concerns about what we found.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that many of the findings of the Stephen Committee can be questioned. The process of collecting evidence, communicating with the school and consultation with the ANU were completely unsatisfactory. As a result of the Stephen Committee misinterpreting its terms of reference and its poor information gathering techniques, it appeared that it received a narrow range of opinions on the school and a disproportionately negative range at that.

The Stephen Committee relied heavily on another review of the school in 1988, yet it failed to hold discussions with the persons who undertook that review. It spent very little time actually talking to the people at the John Curtin School, did not give any hint to the JCSMR staff of its concerns, thereby denying in its information collecting process a right of reply; yet it came up with recommendations in direct conflict with those of the 1988 review.

The Senate Committee was not convinced that the Stephen Committee report demonstrated that the problems it identified would be resolved by the solutions that it proposed. The Senate Committee found that the shortcomings of the Stephen Committee review process detracted from the validity of its conclusions and bring in to question actions predicated upon its findings.

This is the report on which the Minister based his decision to transfer the funding of the ANU to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Clearly, the Minister had been given poor advice by this Committee and the Senate inquiry has proved that. Now that the Minister's policy has been shown to have been poorly thought out and based on inadequate information and knowledge of the situation, he should not continue with it.

Unfortunately, the Minister is too stubborn and pig-headed to admit that he is wrong. The ANU is against him, the staff of the John Curtin School of Medical Research are against him, the founding fathers of the ANU are against him, the committee members of the 1988 review of the school are against him and the Senate Committee report is against him; yet he persists with this ridiculous idea that the John Curtin School would be better off amputated from the Australian National University and centrally funded through the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

The effect of this Bill, if passed through the Parliament, would be to force the Minister to relent. The Bill seeks to overturn the Minister's decision and return to the previous funding arrangements. Presently, the John Curtin School of Medical Research is in a position where it is easier to accept funding from the Department of Employment, Education and Training through the ANU council than continue down the current road to centralise funding from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

In the view of the ANU—and we have had this as recently as a week ago—it is easier to go back to the previous funding arrangement than to go forward with the Minister's poorly thought-out plan. Those senators on the Senate Standing Committee who felt that the funding should stay with the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services could not find one reason why that funding should not be returned to the ANU. It is even questionable whether the funding for the JCSMR, as given through Appropriation Bill No. 3 to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, is by law required to go to the JCSMR. There is nothing stopping the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services from diverting the John Curtin School funds to other areas of medical research.

Serious consideration should also be given to the fact that the funding of the John Curtin School has been coming through the National Health and Medical Research Council. This is despite the fact that when the Senate Committee looked at this issue it was told that the National Health and Medical Research Council wanted nothing to do with the John Curtin School. Clearly, the Minister's arrangements have not been well planned and are subject to change without notice.

Again, I urge all honourable senators to support this Bill to ensure that the standards of higher education in this country are not eroded any further. This action by the Government must be reversed and prevented from recurring. The most desirable mechanism for the control of the administration of the John Curtin School is through the Australian National University as it was originally established, not through the arm of a government bureaucracy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
