TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report Super and the Financial System as Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. This report, which was tabled this morning, is the third in a series the Committee has tabled and the sixth document the Committee has prepared. The first of our reports was entitled Safeguarding Superannuation and the second report dealt with various issues relating to the superannuation guarantee levy or charge.

PARA.TAB: The Committee has prepared three other documents: one dealing with superannuation, the overseas experience; a second paper dealing with, regrettably, two cases of fraud, one known as the Burnwood case and the other ABC Engineering; and the third paper was a discussion paper on fees and charges. There will be a fourth report from the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation which will deal primarily with some recommendations on the issue of fees and charges as they relate to superannuation.

The report tabled in the Senate this morning deals with various aspects of superannuation and the financial system. It deals with future developments of the financial system as they relate to superannuation. In part by necessity, as we are dealing with the future and at least in some areas with estimates of the likely effect, the consequences of superannuation are in some ways imprecise. The report examines trends that are now apparent and emerging and deals with recommendations largely concerned with monitoring the developments of superannuation and its effect on the financial system. The report makes six recommendations and I am pleased to say that those recommendations are unanimous.

In this country at present contributions in the area of superannuation are rapidly expanding. Presently, there is some $150 billion in superannuation. It is estimated that by the year 2000 there will be some $600 billion in superannuation funds. Just to put these figures into perspective—they are rather hard to grasp when talking in hundreds of millions of dollars—if the figure rises to $600 billion, it will be approximately twice the total value of the capitalisation of the stock market or, putting it another way, approximately five and a half to six times the total expenditure of the Federal Budget. So we are dealing with a massive amount of capital funds in this country.

Indeed, this has been stimulated by the passing of the superannuation guarantee charge or levy, which has established a floor of 3 or 4 per cent superannuation contributions at the present time rising to some 9 per cent by the year 2000. It is estimated that this measure will lead to an increase in total superannuation moneys accumulated of some 39 per cent. It is against this background of the expansion of superannuation that there will be certain pressures placed on the financial system.

The Committee report examines a number of issues: superannuation contributions, fund assets, the market for Australian shares, managed funds, the issue of national saving and the long term interests of contributors including the scope for criminal and fraudulent activity in the industry. Finally, we touch on the issue that we examined earlier in the superannuation guarantee charge report—the unfunded liabilities of Commonwealth and State public sector superannuation funds.

I intend to deal with a number of the areas that the report deals with this evening in the time available to me. I note that my Senate and Committee colleague Senator Watson will also be speaking on the report.

In terms of the assets in superannuation, there is no doubt there will be an increased competition for savings, particularly vis-a-vis the banking system and the superannuation funds. The banks are clearly stepping up competition for the superannuation dollar because they believe, although the evidence to this point in time is to the contrary, that they will suffer a net drain of funds away from banking institutions.

In relation to the superannuation assets invested in Australia, it is interesting to note that 11 per cent is invested in property, 36 per cent in equities, 23 per cent in long term securities, 6 per cent in loans and 10 per cent is invested short term.

There is some doubt as to the capacity of the share market to absorb the expansion of superannuation moneys. There will be pressure on high quality shares. That pressure will grow and indeed may outstrip supply. The third recommendation of the Committee is that the Government, through the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, monitor the trends and changes in the investment portfolios of superannuation.

In regard to fund management, superannuation funds are using professional fund managers to the same extent as the total investment market, but much of this management of funds is concentrated in the hands of a few who could exert undue influence on the market. Some observers, in their submissions to the Committee, believe that the fund growth will stimulate the entry of new fund managers and will even lead to an increase in competition. But the Committee has recommended that there be a monitoring to ensure the maintenance of competition in the superannuation sector.

On the issue of national saving, as superannuation grows it is likely that other forms of personal saving will probably fall. However, Treasury estimates are that there will be a net increase in savings owing to the compulsory vesting and preservation requirements.

There are some long term issues that I would particularly like to touch on. Firstly, the Committee received some in camera and confidential advice from the National Crime Authority which touched on the potential for money laundering and the infiltration of organised crime into superannuation. I would like to emphasise that the National Crime Authority's submission to the Committee emphasised that there is minimal money laundering and minimal organised criminal involvement in the superannuation industry. However, there have been a number of cases of money laundering. To put the matter into perspective, amounts of money involved are minimal and are less than the amount taken through bank robberies during a single year.

Nevertheless, there is cause for concern because there are some obvious weak points in the administration and supervision of superannuation. We highlighted those weak points in our earlier report Safeguarding Superannuation. I refer, for example, to the powers of the regulator, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, its staffing and its ability to carry out spot audits. In this regard I would say that there has been a welcome expansion of the staffing and the auditing staff of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission following the last Budget.

The Government is yet to hand down its paper on the safety aspects of superannuation, but I certainly do not have any doubt that this Government will give the recommendations we made earlier in the year the maximum consideration. I understand that paper is due to be released in the next few weeks. That will also deal with such issues as information to be provided to members, the way in which trustees are to be monitored, the way in which fund managers are to be monitored, disputes mechanisms and a variety of other reform measures.

Another area is the role of friendly societies. The Committee believes that friendly societies that are providing a superannuation product should be under the monitoring supervision of a national authority—in this case, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. We recommended that the Treasurer and the Attorney-General should examine the potential for fraud and money laundering within funds and develop effective countermeasures in addition to those recommended by this Committee on a previous occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Super and the Financial System is the third report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. In terms of performance, output and workload, this Committee, under the chairmanship of Senator Nick Sherry, has a record far surpassing most of the standing committees of the Parliament. It has indeed been a good Committee because it has brought before the nation and this Government many of the vulnerable issues in relation to superannuation.

PARA.TAB: As we progress down this road and have the advantage of some hindsight, some of the concerns that the Opposition drew attention to very early in the piece are being brought to light. I draw attention to the question of the validity of some Treasury assumptions, which the coalition had some concern about. This report even acknowledges that, in the light of the current very low interest and inflation rates, the validity of those Treasury assumptions about the earnings rate of superannuation funds and the rate of inflation may be questioned. The assumptions made about them have implications for the future in the effect of the superannuation guarantee charge on the financial system.

The Committee came to the conclusion that it is important that future governments monitor medium and long term fund performance and, if required, be in a position to promote a more efficient and competitive capital market if returns fall below the required benchmark. Most senators would have had concerns from constituents in recent times about the very low returns that they are receiving from superannuation funds and ADFs in the current environment.

This question of the rate of return and the impact on cash flows was also echoed in a submission from the Assistant Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Graeme Thompson. Whilst acknowledging that the growth of superannuation will provide competition to savings in other forms, he expressed an opinion that some views on the impact on cash flows have been somewhat overstated and have underestimated the capacity of financial markets to deal with these sorts of changes. Certainly the banking sector is quite concerned about the potential impact of the transfer of savings out of bank accounts into superannuation funds on the level of savings and their ability to productively move those savings back into the community.
We acknowledge this recognition of concern in the community about the very low returns that are being given back to it at page 9:

SPEECH.PARA: Committee members have received a number of comments from retirees about disappointing returns on their rollover products. Some of these comments could have indicated that cross subsidisation between rollover funds and other savings vehicles in the one institution has been occurring.
If this is the case, it is somewhat serious.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, on page 11 we issue a very strong warning to government in terms of legislation that has been introduced into the Parliament and which I understand has subsequently been withdrawn to be redrafted. That legislation relates to the taxation of interests in foreign superannuation investment funds as far as it affects superannuation. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee observes that the extent to which off-shore diversification is pursued by superannuation funds may in future be limited should the Government's proposal to tax unrealised gains by Australian interests overseas be implemented. Also included in the proposal are arrangements to change the tax treatment of insurance/superannuation policies which are brought into Australia by migrants. If the initiative is made to apply to superannuation funds, it could limit their ability to maintain an appropriately diversified portfolio and thereby produce satisfactory rates of return on funds under investment. The cost of compliance with the provisions of this policy may also detract from the performance of superannuation funds.

Basically the big life offices and superannuation companies are not into the tax avoidance racket, so there is really good scope for insurance of this nature where the products are widely held to be outside the ambit of such a net. We have to be very careful that investments overseas are not taxation driven rather than risk and rate of return driven, which is important.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry raised the issue of the impact of the growth of superannuation funds on the funds management industry, which is very narrowly controlled. The report says that only a handful of very large funds control the bulk of superannuation assets. This could mean that the poor investment decisions of a few large funds managers could have a disproportionate consequence for the wider Australian economy.

In recent days, we have heard the term `computerised selling' used. If this computerised selling notion is adopted very widely, it will have an accelerating or snowballing effect if a particular share is seen to be out of favour. It can have some disastrous results, particular examples being the recent experiences with the Bank of New South Wales and Pioneer International. Perhaps the market has severely over-reacted in relation to those shares because, as we found with the City Bank case, banks have a great capacity to rebound in terms of profit performance. I am sure that this will happen with Westpac, although it might take a few more months for that to happen.

The Reserve Bank also admitted that it did not know whether aggregate savings were affected by changes in members' contributions. We devoted quite a significant portion in the report to the point of view of the Reserve Bank on the impact of savings. It believes that, particularly for low income earners, it was very difficult to come to a conclusion, because during the 1980s there was a very low contribution rate, particularly from those low income earners.

What concerned me was some comments from representatives in Queensland about unfunded liabilities. I draw the Senate's attention to whether, in the light of hindsight, their statement is really accurate. It is accurate in a sense, but in respect of the ramifications, there is a big question mark as to whether there is a reserve in terms of those superannuation funds really being fully funded. Those who made that contribution did not examine that aspect perhaps as carefully as they should have. This may be the subject of some further investigation, certainly within the Queensland Parliament, if not within this Parliament. They presented a somewhat misleading position.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some people in society at the moment who believe that superannuation is the panacea for many of our economic ills. In particular, there are those who would say that superannuation will solve our national savings crisis. I do not believe that that is a fair comment. Over the last nine years we have seen a decline in aggregate savings in this country when savings are measured as a percentage of disposable household income. In the first year of Labor savings as a percentage of disposable household income accounted for something like 9.54 per cent. However, in the 1991-92 financial year they slumped to a level of 6.57 per cent. In the previous financial year I understand that the figure was as low as 5.7 per cent.

PARA.TAB: It is incorrect to say that the growth of superannuation funds will and of themselves increase our national savings base. That must be a reason for concern because, as everybody in this chamber knows—in fact, as everybody in Parliament knows—we have a massive problem in terms of funding new investment. That has been the principal cause for the rise in our foreign debt. There has been a lack of money to fund borrowings and a lack of money to fund lending by banks and as a result the banks have had to go off-shore. The funding has come in from overseas and our foreign debt has blown out. Everybody knows that the rise in foreign debt under the Labor Government has been astronomical. It has risen from about $23 billion in net terms in 1983 to $150 billion currently.

Of course, there are some who would say that superannuation and superannuation schemes generally will be the basis for funding new investment via the Stock Exchange. Again, I think we must have grave doubts about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will help.

—It may help and I wish to address that matter in particular. During the 1990-91 financial year total capital raisings on the Australian Stock Exchange amounted to just $6.596 billion. Of this new capital raising, something like 33 per cent was accounted for by dividend reinvestment. A further 36 per cent was accounted for by rights issues. Admittedly, some of the rights issues may have been funded by superannuation but only to the extent that the superannuation funds actually held shares in those companies to start off with and were willing to fund the rights issue. In fact, not all rights issues have been taken up. We have seen that in recent months. That means that just 31 per cent of the new capital raisings, or roughly $2.045 billion, actually constituted new capital raised from new sources. The really disturbing thing in terms of those of us who would like to see new companies expand and come onto the Stock Exchange is that of that $6.596 billion only $112m was raised to start up new companies.

PARA.TAB: The superannuation industry would say that it is making a major contribution to funding investment. At the same time as the new issues increased by roughly $6.5 billion, the amount of money invested in the superannuation market grew by $24 billion. So it is simply absurd to say that the superannuation funds could invest even a reasonable portion of their money into new shares on the Stock Exchange. The amount of money that was raised in new capital raisings was roughly one-quarter of the amount of money invested in the Stock Exchange. Roughly one-twelfth of the total increase in the superannuation pool would be accounted for by flotations on the Stock Exchange. There are very real reasons to have concern about exactly where the money is going. Of course it is a fact that up to 60 per cent of the money that flows into many funds is invested in shares already on issue. This money never flows through to the companies that issue the shares because the shares were issued years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It pushes the price up.
—Senator Watson is quite correct; it does push the price up.
—And it lowers the yield.

—And it also has very dramatic effects in terms of exactly what sort of asset backing there is to the shares. Twenty per cent to 30 per cent of the amount of money that goes into the funds actually gets invested off-shore. Less than 10 per cent is available in some funds to go into traditional forms of saving or into the stock exchange.
—Only 14 overseas.
—It varies from fund to fund. I hear that in some funds it is between 20 per cent and 30 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Senator O'Chee, I am glad you heard that but the chair did not. Senator Watson, if you are going to interject can you let us all participate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a major problem because we will be superheating the stock exchange. We will be bidding up the price of shares. They will not be based on the performance of the company because, as Senator Watson points out, the yield is sliding down. We are bidding up the price of the shares but it is not related to the company's performance. Therefore, we must have doubts about the underlying value of the investments that have been made by the superannuation funds.

PARA.TAB: Many of the people who are investing in superannuation are my age so they will probably be retiring 35 to 40 years hence. Statistically, we should be able to expect two, maybe even as many as three, major falls in the stock market over that 40-year period. The problem is that people who are investing in the superannuation funds are being led to believe that that money will always be there and that growth will always be maintained at the time they take their money out.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's why we raised the reservation.

—They have to understand that there is no guarantee that the money will be there. As Senator Watson says, that is why the reservation was raised. I do not believe that anybody on either side of Parliament has yet confronted or been able to come up with a suggestion as to what an Australian government would do if, for example, the stock market were to collapse by 50 per cent tomorrow and all of the aggrieved investors in the superannuation funds said, `Where's our dollars?'.

PARA.TAB: It is quite correct that the coalition has an excellent policy in relation to retirement. That policy includes the option for future retirees to put their money into a retirement savings account with the bank and to get the same tax benefits. Incidentally, these are tax benefits that this Government has taken away in the last few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet; it is not law yet.

—Not yet, but I am sure Senator Sherry and his Democrat mates will do the deal. It will go through and they will rip off the Australian populace again. I can see he has the grin of a man who knows that the money is in the bag.

PARA.TAB: We face the prospect that if this Government continues in the fashion in which it is going people will have no opportunity to lay off their investment into alternative forms of investment such as retirement savings accounts and there will be a major problem. Unless money goes back into the banking system we have the situation where we are bleeding regional Australia into superannuation funds where the moneys are punted on the Stock Exchange. A decline in deposits in banks in regional Australia ultimately means a decline in the available lending in regional Australia. So this Government's policy will make regional Australia poorer.

In addition to embracing the coalition's idea of retirement savings accounts, we also need to improve the liquidity for saving in the market by developing a real and effective secondary market for debt products in terms of personal debt products, mortgage backed securities and a secondary debt market for corporate debt. Although we have a bond market, the secondary debt market for single bank lines is very much constrained and is very much the victim of stamp duty on the loan transactions in most States in Australia. I believe much more work needs to be done and I hope the Government will recognise the sense of what the coalition is saying.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed from 17 September 1992, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate take note of the document.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed.
Clauses 12 and 13—by leave—taken together.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We concluded earlier in the day those parts of the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 relating to the Automotive Industry Authority Act with regard to the weights and measures question and the changed arrangements for the head of the CSIRO. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate, I believed that the weights and measures provisions of the omnibus Bill were the most significant; indeed, I objected to there being an omnibus Bill at all.

PARA.TAB: We are now proceeding to the proposed section of the omnibus Bill dealing with trademarks. We had reached the stage where I indicated that the Opposition would not be agreeing to the amendments of Senator Sowada. She was proposing to increase the size of the penalty, in financial terms, while still leaving what I find to be the most objectionable part of the Bill, that is, the intention to put in gaol for up to two years people who manufacture a T-shirt and use the word `Hermes' or `Chanel' or a little alligator without the permission of the owner of that intellectual property. I said that I believed these provisions were a sledge-hammer to crack a nut. I am still of that opinion. I said that therefore we would not be agreeing to Senator Sowada's suggestion to increase the financial penalty.

Senator Sowada was also keen to insert a new provision relating to a test of reasonableness, and I indicated we would not be supporting that as there is already in the provisions as circulated by the Government a reasonableness test set out in proposed new section 99 and proposed new section 109—otherwise known as clauses 14, 15 and 16. That is where we are presently.
Clauses agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Ray) proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: (4)After Part 4, page 5, add the following new Part:

PARA.TAB: "14. In this Part, `Principal Act' means the Trade Marks Act 1955(4).
"15. Section 98 of the Principal Act is amended:

TAB.TAB: (a)by omitting from subsection (1) paragraphs (a) and (b) of the statement of the Penalty and substituting `Imprisonment for 2 years';
(b)by omitting subsection (2).

PARA.TAB: (c)have in his or her possession for sale or for the purpose of trade or manufacture;

PARA.TAB: `(2) A contravention by a person of subsection (1) is an offence punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding $500 for each item of goods to which the offence relates or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 2 years, or both.

`(3) If a fine is imposed on a person because of subsection (2) in relation to an offence committed by the person and there are 2 or more items of goods to which the offence relates, the fine imposed in respect of that offence must not exceed $50,000.
`(4) For the purposes of establishing a contravention of subsection (1), if, having regard to:

the person ought reasonably to have known that the trade mark is a registered trade mark, the person is taken to have known that the trade mark is a registered trade mark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a range of amendments relating to this section. Senator Bishop has already quite lucidly outlined what those amendments are all about, and I do thank her for her contribution. My amendments Nos 3, 4, 5 and 7 relate to the issue of the fines which Senator Bishop has already outlined are substantially increased by this legislation. It has been raised with me by the anti-counterfeit action group that courts really are very reluctant to provide and in fact impose hefty fines for what is theft of intellectual property.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crowley)—Senator Sowada, could we clarify the position? You listed Democrat amendments 3, 4, 5 and 7. Our understanding is that there is also an amendment No. 6.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does include No. 6, but at the moment I am speaking to the fines. I will address my remarks to amendment No. 6 in just a minute.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crowley)—But you are actually moving amendments 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I seek leave to move Democrat amendments 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Amendment of Government amendment No.4, clause 15, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "(15) Section 98 of the principal Act is amended by omitting the penalty and substituting the following subsections:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)A contravention by a person of subsection (1) is an offence punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding $500 for each item of goods to which the offence relates or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 2 years, or both.

(3)If a fine is imposed on a person because of subsection (2) in relation to an offence committed by the person and there are two or more items of goods to which the offence relates, the fine imposed in respect of that offence must not exceed $250,000.".
4.Amendment of Government amendment No. 4, clause 16, proposed subsection 99(3), omit "50,000", substitute "$250,000".
5.Amendment of Government amendment No. 4, clause 16, proposed subsection 100(3), omit "50,000", substitute $250,000".
6.Amendment of Government amendment No. 4, clause 17, proposed paragraph 106(1)(a), insert "or could reasonably be expected to have known" after "if the person knows".
7.Amendment of Government amendment No. 4, clause 18, proposed subsection 118A(3), omit "$10,000", substitute "$50,000".

As I have said, it has been put to me that courts are extremely reluctant to provide for maximum fines. A number of cases have been brought to my attention where people have been prosecuted for selling counterfeit goods at markets and so forth. It is a concern that courts are in general unwilling to apply the full extent of the law. Of course, the size of the fine depends on the nature of the offence, but I think there is a very good case to be made for substantially increasing the fines provided for under the Trade Marks Act.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop has suggested that putting someone in gaol for the minor offence of selling and printing a couple of T-shirts with a fake trade mark is perhaps a bit excessive, but I think that one would be pretty hard-pressed to find someone who would be slapped into gaol for a fairly minor offence under this legislation. What we are talking about are fairly major offences of forgery of trade marks. For example, some of the cases that I have been provided with involve 15,000 T-shirts, 150 screens, bromides and sketches of one manufacturer alone. Fifteen thousand T-shirts is a lot of T-shirts and a fairly high volume counterfeiting operation. An offence of that magnitude, of course, would hopefully attract a fine of similar proportions. One would be pretty hard-pressed to find a court that would slap someone into gaol for printing two T-shirts and selling them at a market.

There has been a great deal of concern raised about the level of fines and I do accept and recognise that the Government has based these fines on the Copyright Act and I think that is a fair thing to do. However, if the Government is using the Copyright Act as a benchmark for fines, perhaps it is time that those fines should likewise be revised in the light of concern in the business community about theft of intellectual and trade property.

In respect of my amendment No. 6, again it has been put to me by the anti-counterfeit action group that a test of reasonableness should be included in clause 106 of the Government's amendments. That is not a tremendously significant amendment, but I think it is something that the Government could certainly see its way clear to accept. For example, there are a number of cases whereby people have hidden behind the definition of having known that the trade mark is a registered trade mark.

For the benefit of senators present, I will refer to the details of one case whereby, in Canberra, a legal aid office defended a Vietnamese person who was charged under the Trade Marks Act. The case was dismissed because the defendant stated that he had no knowledge of copyright or trade mark because his wife did the shopping. The magistrate bought the story and dismissed the case. Since then, the legal aid office has made it clear that it will use the case as a precedent in other cases. End of story!

That is simply one of the many examples that the anti-counterfeit action group provides of where people simply hide behind language, their newness to this country or a range of other things. If the test of reasonableness was applied that they should reasonably have known that the trade mark was a counterfeit or a forgery, that, I think, would enable businesses to more adequately protect their intellectual and trade property in the courts.

I do not want to prolong the debate on this matter any further. I think we will all be pretty glad to see the back end of this Bill. I commend the amendments to the Senate and suggest, particularly in respect to the reasonableness test, that the Government may be predisposed to accept that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to reaffirm, as I said before, that the Opposition will not be supporting any of the amendments of the Democrats concerning this section of the Bill, for the reasons I outlined earlier.

—As I understand it, the Government will not be supporting amendment No. 3. It would need further amendment because it is technically not quite accurate. Section 98 of the Trade Marks Act deals with the forging or falsely applying of a trade mark and not with goods per se; therefore, the amendment changes the meaning of it. I think we were quite satisfied with the $50,000. We are not moved to increase that to $250,000. I am informed that amendment No. 6 is covered later in the Act. We probably do not need to insert that at this stage.
—That is a matter of opinion.
—Yes, that is a matter of opinion. I suppose that when we get to that stage we can reassert it and that will be taken into account when the Act is interpreted.
—Minister, are you saying that the Government is not accepting amendment No.3?
—We are not accepting amendments 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7.

—I guess it is a matter of debate as to whether the question `could reasonably be expected to have known' is covered later in the Act. It was put to me by the anti-counterfeit action group that it is not. I submit that the group has had legal advice on that question as well. As Senator Ray has indicated, I guess it is a matter that will be tested by the courts at some later stage.

PARA.TAB: I suggest to the Government that it would be an opportune time to re-examine the level of penalty applied to this offence, given that I am aware it is using the Copyright Act as a benchmark here. But I believe that it is time to re-examine the level of penalties here, as we are talking about a significant offence against intellectual and trade property rights. It is a legitimate way of protecting Australian business, industry and intellectual achievement.

We believe it is vitally important that businesses are protected adequately, that they have confidence in the legal system and that the fines for crime are adequate. I know that some questions have been raised and there has been a lot of debate about the adequacy of fines given by courts over a whole range of offences. I leave with the Government that perhaps it is an opportune time to deal with a range of penalties for offences of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that we are looking for the section where amendment No. 6 of the Democrats is covered. I understand it is in section 106 of the principal Act where it is sought to be amended. It is covered in a couple of the paragraphs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just on that point, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is correct. It is proposed section 99—section 106 of the principal Act—which states very simply in (1) that a person is precluded from selling, exposing for sale or having in his or her possession for sale for the purpose of trade or manufacture goods which are a forgery, et cetera. Proposed section 99(4) states:

PARA.TAB: (4) For the purposes of establishing a contravention of subsection (1), if, having regard to:
(a) a person's abilities, experience, qualifications and other attributes; and
(b)all the circumstances surrounding the alleged contravention of that subsection;

SPEECH.PARA: the person ought reasonably to have known that the goods are goods of a kind referred to in that subsection, the person is taken to have known that the goods are goods of that kind.
That exact provision is repeated in the amended section 106 of the principal Act; so the test of reasonableness is already incorporated into the amendments of the Government.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sowada's) to Senator Ray's amendment be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Government amendment No. 4 agreed to.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
