DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill is to extend the Commonwealth guarantee on the borrowings of the Australian Industry Development Corporation, or AIDC as it is commonly known, from its current expiry date of 30 June 1994 to 30 June 1998. The Bill also ensures that the guarantee does not continue on moneys reinvested after the statutory limit on the Commonwealth guarantee has expired.

PARA.TAB: The Bill reduces the size of the AIDC's board because, since AIDC Ltd was publicly floated, the Corporation has basically been a holding corporation and the requirement for a large board is no longer appropriate. The Bill also defines the powers of the AIDC to enter into swaps and other financial transactions.

The AIDC was established to provide what is termed `development funding' for Australian companies. The functions and objectives of the Corporation are set out in section 6 of the AIDC Act. In summary, they are: to facilitate the establishment, development and advancement of Australian industries and the participation in those industries by Australian residents by providing finance to those engaged in the industries and by participating in enterprises or projects.

According to the latest annual report of the AIDC, the priority areas for the Corporation's focus in performing its functions are the manufacturing, processing or transportation of goods and natural resources, internationally competitive service industries, including tourism, and the development or use of new or improved technology. The annual report states:

It is an objective of the Corporation in the provision of development funding to Australian companies that the efficiency and competitiveness of those companies will be enhanced, that long-term viability of some industries will be achieved through reconstruction, and that new industries that have good growth prospects will be established.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report also points out that:

PARA.TAB: An overriding statutory requirement for the Corporation is to act in accordance with sound business principles in performing its functions.

SPEECH.PARA: An examination of the accounts of the AIDC reveal that the Corporation has, on a generous interpretation, not been, from all accounts, acting in accordance with sound business principles in performing its function. We find that the AIDC, like so many like corporations that have been run by Labor governments both federally and at State level around Australia, has been often used for making high risk investments, both on and off the stock market. The result of this high risk strategy, like so many others who played the game of high risk strategies in the 1980s, has been massive losses, write downs and write offs.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, the Australian taxpayer is fortunate that the AIDC has not gone as far as the Victorian Economic Development Corporation, which is similarly constructed in terms of its objectives and which, of course, collapsed in a ball of flames in the late 1980s with a deficit of well over $100m. The disclosure of the collapse and the mismanagement within the VEDC was the start of the evidence that came forward in a rush from thereon to indicate just how incompetent the Victorian Cain and subsequently Kirner Labor governments were. This led to the overwhelming defeat of the Kirner Government last weekend. As I say, it was the collapse of the VEDC, which in many ways is a similar type of organisation to the AIDC, that began the downfall of the Cain and Kirner governments.

The AIDC is now in a financial situation where it is left with a meagre equity of just $145m. Against that, it has debts of $2,900m and assets of just over $3,000m. In other words, it has gross assets of about $3 billion, debt of about $2.9 billion and a very meagre equity left of about $145m. That constitutes a debt to equity ratio of a whopping 19.7 : 1. That is an extraordinarily highly geared financial operation by anyone's standards, particularly in the more conservative financial environment that applies increasingly today.

Last year the Corporation posted a loss of over $91m. When one has a total equity of only $145m, one obviously cannot afford losses of that magnitude too often. So it is no surprise that the AIDC requires the extension of the government guarantee and that is the main purpose of this Bill. If this extension is not granted, quite obviously the Corporation, in its present financial situation, would have a great deal of difficulty in borrowing further on the markets and in refinancing any of its maturing debts.

The coalition does not oppose this Bill. It does not do so simply for the reason that we can see no other reasonable course of action that would prevent the AIDC collapsing. We are reluctant to extend the guarantee in the way that the Bill proposes. But if that guarantee is not extended, the financial risk facing the Corporation and, through the existing guarantees, the taxpayer, would be considerable indeed.

We have a policy of privatising the AIDC on coming to government. The present Government has already started down that road with some privatisation of the Corporation. We propose to take that all the way. Obviously, there is no need for a government, particularly in the 1990s—and in earlier decades as well—to support or own organisations such as the AIDC. Experience has shown all too well how much of a mess governments can make of owning corporations such as this and the problems that that causes for the taxpayer, financial markets generally, and companies and ventures in which such corporations invest. This all adds up to one unequivocal bottom line, and that is that governments should get out of the business of trying to run businesses and particularly financial institutions.

We will be adopting that policy on coming to government. Obviously we want to have the Corporation in such a shape that it will be an acceptable proposition so far as a potential buyer in the private sector is concerned. In order to achieve that, we see no alternative but to extend the guarantee on the Corporation's borrowings, and for those reasons we will not be opposing the Bill.

The Corporation does have a relatively new managing director, Mr Gerry Van Der Merwe, under whom there has been a considerable reshaping of the direction in which the Corporation is heading. He has made it clear through various statements that the shift in the AIDC's strategic focus will be more to concentrate on infrastructure and natural resource projects. Whether that is a good or bad thing is a matter for judgment. But I come back to the essential point that government ought not be a shareholder, particularly a majority shareholder or total owner, of corporations such as this which are required basically to be taking investment decisions relating to the normal processes of the private sector. I close my remarks on that basis. We will not be opposing this Bill. We reluctantly support it for the reasons I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Likewise, the Australian Democrats will not be opposing this legislation, although we do share some of the concerns about the financial management of the AIDC that have already been outlined by Senator Short.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill gives an extension of the Commonwealth guarantee from 30 June 1994 to 30 June 1998; it also clarifies the AIDC's trading powers brought into contention by a UK court decision; and it also reduces the size of the AIDC board. While these seem to be fairly minor amendments, we believe they are in fact significant, especially the extension of the guarantee.

The AIDC is the holding corporation for AIDC Limited, the operating company of the group—a company which lost $31.1m of taxpayers' money last year and has just posted a whopping operating loss before tax of $98.6m for this year. That is a $130m loss in two years which has resulted in the Corporation having a net consolidated operating loss of $84.4m after tax and excluding outside interests.

The Corporation was expected to give an average return on capital and reserves of 13 per cent per annum. It is no wonder the Government is granting an extension of four years, for it is clear that without this extension the AIDC and AIDC Limited would be in serious trouble.

I reiterate that the Democrats will be supporting this very necessary amendment to the AIDC Act. We hope that in future the reforms which have just been put into place and which were announced by the Minister on 4 September, relating to redefining the strategy and business focus of the AIDC and the other changes that have been brought to bear on the organisation, will produce some more solid financial result for taxpayers in the coming years. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill that is now before us to extend the government guarantee comes to us in a climate where over the past two years the AIDC, shall we say, stands under a cloud.

PARA.TAB: On the last occasion we met together for Estimates in December of last year, I asked many questions about the AIDC's accounts. A statement had been made to the stock exchange that the AIDC or AIDC Limited had made a loss of $8.8m for the previous financial year. Yet in November of that same year Mr Hawke, the then Prime Minister, in his employment statement, which was repeated in this chamber by Senator Button, said that the AIDC had made a profit of $9.6m in that same financial year, whereas, as I have said, only the day before it was announced to the stock exchange that AIDC Limited had made a loss of $8.8m.

Mr Hawke's statement said that AIDC was to be allowed to keep the $10m-odd, which was the alleged profit, because it could be added to the amount of money that it could make available to Australian industry. Indeed, the AIDC was seen to be a tool of government industry policy. We see the ridiculous situation whereby the AIDC, the Corporation itself, has a charter as set out in its establishing Act of 1970, but where AIDC Limited, which is in fact a merchant bank and is described as such its memo and articles, is exempt from that charter in terms of its memo and articles.

It is fettered in some way to be connected to Australian industry, but what we have seen is a policy by the AIDC to invest in almost anything, except that which would assist Australian industries either with import replacement or exports or the sorts of things it is meant to focus upon. We can argue that it ought not to be forced to focus on those things, but that was the intent and purpose with which the AIDC was established.

Now we have seen AIDC Limited announce to the stock exchange a loss of near on $99m. When I went back 12 months and looked at why I was interested in the figures that were then released, I decided to go back further and take a good look at the company's consolidated accounts. Indeed, the AIDC in the previous financial year made a trading loss $32m. It was allowed to carry forward some tax losses from previous years and add to them a further $22m in tax losses which gave it a total of $47m in tax losses. That amount was shown as an asset, which is how that company read down the loss that it had made to $8.8m.

The fact of the matter is that this year the Auditor-General said in the AIDC report, a report that came to this Parliament only in the last 48 hours, that he would not allow the tax losses or the losses that have been suffered to be stated for tax purposes as an asset because he did not believe it was foreseeable that in the next three years—which is the usual accounting period for this sort of forecasting—the AIDC would make sufficient profit to utilise those tax losses. Indeed, if the AIDC next year does not make a profit sufficient to use up the $47m carried forward, which earlier in the day I said has been adjusted to $53m because of a different tax ruling on swaps, then it will lose the right to express those as an asset.

In other words, the AIDC is in a very precarious state, and yet AIDC Limited carries a triple A rating. Why is that so? Answer: the government guarantee. Why is the Government guarantee being extended to 1988 past the usual forecasting period for accounting purposes and auditing purposes? We could well ask the question. If we took away the government guarantee, we would indeed find that the AIDC would probably fall over. It would be forced to make a decision as to whether it could survive by perhaps seeking a banking licence, or indeed fall over.

If we take a look at AIDC's associated companies in the annual report, of the 14 companies that are listed, six of them are in receivership. If we look at the point I made last year, we will see that in the organisation's accounts last year there was a provision for contingency liabilities, but only provisioning for $129m relating to those matters on the balance sheet.

The question I would like answered is whether or not part of that $99m loss is attributable to one of the contingencies in fact being fulfilled and their occasioning that loss. I asked Mr Gurry and Senator Button at Estimates the question as to why the Government was not informed or did not know that the loss was to be as great as it was, thereby allowing the Government to put a proposed sale of a further 30,000 shares in AIDC Limited on to the private market; in other words, to reduce the Government's holding in AIDC Limited from 81 per cent down to 51 per cent. That was announced on 18 August.

On 4 August the Auditor-General signed off the accounts. On 4 August Senator Button had to recant and put out a statement that in fact those shares would not be sold because he would not sell them until they could at least reach asset backing. Asset backing is presently expressed to be $1.23 a share and that includes the asset of tax losses. The tangible assets are around $83 or $87 a share. I forget the precise figure. In other words, the shares were trading at around 46 cents.

On 18 August the Government said, `We are going to sell more shares onto the market'. On 4 September, barely a fortnight later, the Auditor-General signs the accounts and there is a $99m loss. On that same day Senator Button has to recant and say, `We will not be selling the shares at this stage because we cannot make asset backing as the price'.

The question is: why did not the AIDC know it was in a loss situation; why did it not tell the Minister; and why did the Minister not make it available to the Government in its pre-Budget negotiations so that it would not make an absolute fool of itself by saying, `Here is a product that is valid to be sold', and then having to turn around and say two weeks later, `No, it is not'?

Quite clearly, there are questions to be answered. Again the AIDC came to the Estimates committee hearings. Senator Button argued that it ought not come to Estimates committee hearings because the AIDC did not get an appropriation. Wrong! The Government guarantee acts as a virtual open-ended appropriation to the AIDC and, quite properly, it should appear and answer questions. To allow that proper discussion to take place at Estimates committee hearings, it is necessary for the Committee to have at least a draft annual report, if not the annual report itself.

If one takes a look at the Hansard of those Estimates committee hearings, one is led to believe that the annual accounts would not be available until the end of October, yet the Auditor-General signed them on 4 September. The annual report of AIDC Limited was tabled with the stock exchange only 48 hours ago. Quite clearly, those figures were available to be made available to the Estimates Committee. Indeed, the Senate was misled. I was interested to read in the Australian Financial Review of 7 October an article on the AIDC which states:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the cultural changes that we are trying to bring to bear is to change to our approach to teamwork.
The other cultural style we are trying to develop is greater accountability, increasing the focus on profitability.
AIDC, which lost $98 million in the year to June, had got to a point where our whole direction and strategy had become fuzzy.
Fuzzy! We are talking about a $32m loss which was covered up last year and a $98m loss this year. The article continues:

We reached the stage where the board certainly felt that the company had lost direction, it wasn't clear to the board precisely what it was we wanted to be. We have got a good relationship with both the government and the opposition, we try to keep them involved and informed as to what we do.

Informed? Nothing could be further from the truth when it comes to informing this Parliament and the Parliament through its proper committees, because the information imparted at those Estimates Committee hearings was simply not adequate. It would have been far better had we had the accounts to work with. Those were denied us and, as I said, from the dates that are shown, they were denied us for no good reason.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems with this whole system of arrangements is that when we had the AIDC the Minister was responsible. AIDC Limited is now a corporate entity. It lives off in a sycophantic manner the AIDC corporate entity which does all the borrowing because it has the guarantee and then it on-lends. That is the way it works. We, the taxpayers, are the people who are propping it up. If that Government guarantee was taken away tomorrow, that AAA rating would disappear immediately.

It is important that people understand precisely what is involved. One of the other truly amazing statements made in the Estimates Committee hearing was when I asked the question, `What business did the AIDC have investing in Venture stores, which is in receivership?'. I was given the answer that, because there was a monopoly situation in the retail trading area, it was considered desirable for manufacturers in Australia of textile, clothing and footwear products to have an alternate market to which to sell their goods. In other words, it was being asserted that it was a proper investment for a government entity to make into that particular venture—pardon the pun—because it was almost an extension of textile, clothing and footwear protection policy. Yet the reality is that Venture was one of those stores that certainly acted on a strong import policy.

There is a very large building in the Perth CBD and the first mortgage is held by the AIDC. If my memory serves me correctly, the original mortgage was for $75m. It had been written down last year to something like $43m and this year Mr Gurry would not tell me what the value of the mortgage was because that was commercial in confidence and would set the benchmark. God only knows what it is.

Quite clearly, the lending policy of the AIDC through this period right up until now has not been reflecting its charter. Yet, as I explained, AIDC Limited, the corporate entity, which actually spends or lends the money raised by AIDC courtesy of the Government guarantee, is not bound by that charter; it is bound by its own memorandum and articles. So we have this nonsensical position where the Minister can say, `It is a corporate entity. It is at arm's length. I cannot talk to you about it'. It is simply pushing government responsibility off budget and it has got to stop.

The reason I am speaking at length on this Bill is that there needs to be greater scrutiny. I apply this across the board to all corporatised entities or pseudo-GBEs. When we are dealing with taxpayers' money—and a government guarantee is taxpayers' money because if that entity falls over the taxpayer picks up the bill—there ought to be more information available through the Parliament to the public to know what is going on.

There was something called short term or temporary borrowings permitted under the charter which are not included in the borrowing limits as set down in the legislation. One could ask oneself just what are temporary borrowings. Presumably, they include the general public's deposits which are advertised for. Presumably, they extend to overdraft. One can but guess at how the AIDC defines temporary borrowings and how in the future it will define temporary borrowings.

Then there is another question: whether or not any new products which the AIDC Limited may develop in a desperate attempt to become profitable will in fact be a legitimate use of the Government guarantee. Presumably, that is a question that can be answered only by a correct audit by the Auditor-General. As we are here projecting this Government guarantee out till 1998—way past the normal three-year accounting forecasting period—I think it is very important that people be made aware of just what it is we are guaranteeing and whether it is a proper use of taxpayers' funds.

As Senator Short has said, the Opposition will not be opposing the Bill. We will allow the Bill to pass and the Government guarantee to be extended to 1998. But the Government should be under no illusion—once we take office we will move to privatise or to change the circumstances of the AIDC so that it is no longer in its present form, privatisation being the preferred option, and the Government guarantee will be at an end. So although we are agreeing to this Bill tonight, it is not set in cement and when we come to office there will be a change in arrangements of the AIDC, hopefully a privatised arrangement, and the Government guarantee will come to an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their support and their contributions to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS REGULATIONS APPLICATION BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations Application Bill 1992 was directed at overcoming a potential legal problem relating to the incorrect passage of the legislation through the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Bill allows for the regulations made on 30 June 1992 under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 to have the same effect as they would have had if the Superannuation Guarantee Administration Act 1992 had received royal assent before those regulations were made.

PARA.TAB: Although the coalition opposed the Bill when it was introduced, because this Bill contains no policy changes and is purely administrative the Opposition will not oppose it. This Bill is necessary because royal assent was not given due to some technical errors discovered after the original Bill passed through the Parliament. However, we do take this opportunity to debate the issues because of our reservations about the superannuation guarantee arrangements.

It needs to be said from the outset that the concept of the Government's policy was certainly mistaken and in all likelihood a provision for retirement, such as an employer funded compulsory superannuation guarantee charge, really will take decades to significantly increase national savings. Also, the coalition has doubts that it will contribute to individual retirement income in a way the Government is promising.

Events in the last few months have given no cause for joy so far as the Government is concerned with the terms diminishing and some funds showing negative returns. We expressed concern about the Treasury's assumption of the 8 per cent nominal earnings rate of superannuation over 40 years. Certainly it has not got off to a good start.

We have said before that that legislation would cost some people their livelihoods. I will give a very simple example. Recently a Launceston taxi driver explained to me that he was a victim of the guarantee charge because, as he said, his boss could not afford the extra cost so he substantially reduced the driver's casual time and the boss is now driving more hours himself. There are people in this situation all over the country and I ask: where is the human face of this Government which turns its face from the sufferings of Australian families?

A further problem with the whole concept is revealed when, time and time again, people come into our office with superannuation when they have only casual earnings. In the latest case, a person had earned something like $1,000 and within 12 months, apart from $2, it was completely wiped off on account of government charges, taxes, administration fees and so on. Who are the real beneficiaries of this legislation, and how will it benefit particularly the lower paid and casual people? It is incomprehensible that the superannuation levy has been introduced during a severe and worsening recession. It will have a real impact on and be a further cost increase to Australian employers.

The employers of most of those 1.5 million workers to whom I have referred will be required to change from contributing nought to contributing 3 or 4 per cent, or 5 per cent for the bigger ones, in just one year as the legislation has been implemented. It will cost around about $2 billion a year. That is on top of the 4.5 per cent wage claim that has been pursued by the ACTU and other costs such as the training guarantee levy and payroll tax. These are the reasons it is not difficult to demonstrate that over recent times the cost of employing labour has increased by approximately 10 per cent. At a time of recession the timing could not have been worse and the principle, I think, has to be severely questioned.

I must point out that the Australian work force and Australian employers are being made to carry the cost of a pre-election accord between the then Hawke-Keating Government before the last election to cement the support of the ACTU. It has indeed been a high price for a lot of bosses. The ACTU, which sets itself up as the guardian of the future of the working class people of Australia, has done so little to encourage the Government to go to employers and say, `We want to reduce as much as we can of the oncosts of employing labour'. Of course, this is a fairly naive assumption on our part.

I think it is important to mention that there is a stark contrast between the Government approach, which is aimed at loading the oncosts of business, and the coalition's approach under Fightback, which is to reduce costs of business, reduce overheads. This amounts to a reduction of something like $20m in costs to business. Therefore, job opportunities increase and Australian products become more competitive when they are faced with imports. It is just another indication that this Government has the wrong approach to bringing about the sort of basic recovery that is needed in Australia. Seeing as there have been no policy changes—it is a technical correction—the Opposition supports these changes, although in principle it is very much against the concept of the superannuation guarantee charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that we are here to re-canvass the whole SGC debate. We are here to talk about this relatively simple piece of legislation—the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations Application Bill 1992—which deals with a technical legislative problem that arose in respect of the package of Bills which included the superannuation guarantee charge. That package of Bills was passed by the Senate in June, and it anticipated a 1 July commencement date of universal superannuation arrangements.

PARA.TAB: We all know that, unfortunately because of a clerical error, the table of amendments sent to the House of Representatives was not an accurate representation of what we had agreed to in this chamber. It was not picked up at the time, so the House of Representatives agreed to legislation which was different from that agreed to by the Senate. The error was detected while the legislation was awaiting royal assent. The Senate dealt with the error by way of resolution shortly after the commencement of the Budget sittings. The legislation then duly passed through the other place and received royal assent.

Since the legislation operates from 1 July, supporting regulations were made on that date. These regulations are crucial to the operation of the superannuation guarantee charge system in a number of ways. They allow superannuation funds to accept contributions made by employers under SGC arrangements, even if there are some conflicting provisions in existing arrangements. They also provide a degree of protection for employees, firstly, by stipulating that all contributions have to vest immediately in the employee and, secondly, by placing responsibility on trustees to obtain and provide employers and the ISC with specific actuarial information.

The Democrats support these regulations; we think they are very important. However, because of the administrative hitch in the SGC legislation, these regulations were made before the legislation was enacted. So the validity of these regulations is open to question, at least in the period between 1 July and the date of royal assent of the SGC legislation.

It is unclear what the precise legal position is, so it is clearly a sensible and responsible action to clarify the operation of the regulations from 1 July. We have recently had to deal with the awful mess of sales tax on in-ground swimming pools because of an adverse judgment dealing with the method of enactment. That case demonstrates the need to get it right in the first place and that sometimes remedial action might be prudent to avoid failure of law on a technicality. The Democrats support this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson and Senator Kernot for their positive contributions to the debate on the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations Application Bill 1992. I do not want to say much because we can adjourn as soon as I finish, which is always a good incentive to not speak for too long. Important as the issue is, the Bill is merely a validation of something which is now in some doubt. Ironically, it is not certain that the Bill is even necessary, but it gives a guarantee of validity that otherwise might not be there and would therefore mean that a very undesirable level of uncertainty might operate in an area where it is very important to give people confidence that the arrangements that they have entered into have all the necessary backing, legally and otherwise.

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators have said, the Bill proposes to ensure the validity of amendments to the occupational superannuation standards regulations to reflect the superannuation guarantee arrangements. I will not go over the circumstances that led to us needing this validity; it is something perhaps better not referred to any further.

Originally, the advice to the Government was that the regulations could proceed and come into effect from 1 July. There is now some doubt about that, so it has been agreed by all the parties and all the members of Parliament that it is appropriate that we legislate to guarantee the validity and application of the Bills. Therefore, I thank honourable senators and the Senate for their support for this second reading and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very rarely rise to speak on the adjournment debate, but I do so tonight—I know that I will be followed by my colleague Senator Tambling—to pay tribute to the former member for Arafura in the Northern Territory Parliament, Stan Tipiloura. He was the person who took that seat for the Labor Party after I vacated the Northern Territory Parliament to come to the Senate. He died just a short time ago at the tragically young age of 35.

PARA.TAB: I first met Stan when he was a teenager and I was working for the CSIRO division of wildlife research in Darwin. We had an Aboriginal trainee program operating at CSIRO. Along with Nigel Gellar and David Yates, Stanley Tipiloura was one of three Aboriginal trainees who worked for CSIRO. Even then he was obviously a person who stood out from the crowd. He was a very big man physically—he was well over six foot—and an outstanding footballer, being highly intelligent and extremely strongly motivated. Despite his very large size, he was a very gentle and courteous man in every sense of the word, which is something everyone who knew Stan noted.

That association with Stanley led to a close friendship between us which lasted fundamentally for 20 years of his 35-year life. After leaving CSIRO, Stan became the first police aid in the Northern Territory and subsequently—and this was unique—a commissioned constable in the police force who served on general duties in Darwin for some time, where he won the respect of all his fellow officers. This was demonstrated, in a way that was deeply appreciated by his family, by the very large presence of police officers, including the Commissioner of Police for the Northern Territory, at not just the requiem mass that was held at the cathedral in Darwin for Stan but also at the funeral service at Bathurst Island.

At a remarkably young age Stanley took a very active interest in the affairs of his own community and subsequently became President of the Council at Bathurst Island. He was certainly one of the youngest Aboriginal people ever to go into that sort of position that I am aware of, which indicated the very great respect in which he was held by the Aboriginal community. Subsequently, he entered politics and, as was remarked in the Northern Territory Parliament at the time by Terry McCarthy, a member of the Country Liberal Party who also knew Stan well, it was something that did not come as a surprise to anyone. Because of his intelligence and the way he could articulate the concerns that he had on behalf of the Aboriginal people that he represented, it seemed like a natural transition for him.

I probably campaigned harder in that first election for Stan in Arafura than I campaigned for anybody, including myself. I worked as his electorate secretary—I do not think anyone had a more efficient electorate secretary than Stan Tipiloura had—on the princely sum of $19,000 a year at the time. The reason I mention that is that one of the personal traits that this person had, which was remarked upon by everybody who knew him, was his personal demeanour—that is, what an open, honest, friendly and gentle person he was. That was one of the happiest six months that I have spent in politics.

When I worked for Stan, and in helping him to win the subsequent campaign as well, he was regrettably suffering the onset of the kidney disease that took his life. During the last campaign, an indication of the standing that he had established in the community was that, despite the fact that he was in hospital in Adelaide receiving a kidney transplant—this happened at a time not of his choosing—and was personally absent from the campaign, he achieved 65.5 per cent of the primary vote. That was an indication of the regard in which the electorate held him.

Stan's time in politics was not without controversy. I noted this publicly at the time in the Northern Territory. He was wholly Aboriginal and very proud of his race, his own people, the Tiwi people, his language and his culture. But at the same time he had a philosophical view which was not shared by other people who criticised him publicly for it. I could sum it up best by saying that his view was, `I'm black and you're white, but we're all Australians, so let's get on with it'. That fundamentally summed up the man.

The problem of kidney failure that Stan tragically had is a problem endemic among the Tiwi people in the Northern Territory. It is not known why it occurs in that area. The Menzies School of Health Research in the Northern Territory is carrying out a research project on it. Dr David Pugsley, Stan's specialist physician from Adelaide—a wonderful bloke and a highly dedicated physician—said to me that it may be 10 years before the team of three medical researchers who are stationed permanently on Bathurst Island investigating this problem find an answer.

Tragically, at the beginning of what everyone acknowledged from both sides of Parliament was an extremely promising political career, Stan was struck down with this Tiwi problem of kidney failure. He went on dialysis for some time and thought at that time that his political career was finished but, fortunately, by the very generous act of his uncle—at least the person that we would term his uncle, the person whom Stan related to as his father since the death of his natural father, Bernard Tipiloura—he got a kidney.

The difficulty and the problem was that the condition that Stan suffered from—a syndrome which was a combination of medical symptoms—subsequently led to the failure of that transplant. What was particularly distressing for me personally was not only the fact that about a fortnight before his death he and I spoke about the prognosis that his doctors had given him, which was a fairly unhappy one, but also fundamentally that he would have had to go back on dialysis in December this year with no real prospect of ever getting another transplant. As his doctor said to me, and rightly, kidneys are a scarce resource. The medical people in Australia who are world leaders in this area have to provide this resource to people who can make the best use of it. Stan had the double blow of being told not only that his kidney had failed when he had a brief taste of a relatively normal life with the new kidney but also that he would have to go back on dialysis and for the rest of his life.

One of the things that he was down and depressed about was the fact that he would obviously have to retire from politics. He could not possibly effectively represent an electorate when he was tied up to a dialysis machine for eight hours a day Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays of a working week. Stan's preoccupation—and the reason I am accounting this, as it was very much a product of the sort of the bloke he was—was his unhappiness about the prospect of having to resign while Parliament was in session because he did not want to have to go through the speeches of people saying nice things about him and how sorry they were about him leaving. I said, `Look, the simplest way of handling that is that it is fundamentally the end of the parliamentary year already. The Northern Territory Parliament only sits once every blue moon anyway and you only have half a dozen sitting days left for the rest of the year. Why not quietly wait until the end of the year, resign over the Christmas break, and you will be relieved of all that tedium'. He was happy about that and that was the agreement.

To our total distress and shock only a fortnight after that, early on a Sunday morning, I received what to me was the appallingly tragic news that Stan had died in Melbourne. As I said before, Stan was a passionate and a very good footballer. He was a passionate advocate of Australian Rules, as all Tiwis are. He was in Melbourne supporting the Tiwi football team that played at the MCG and sharing a room in the motel with two other Tiwi footballers when he died. It was of great comfort to his family that he died at least under those circumstances.

Tragically, he was the first member of the Northern Territory Parliament to die in office at the very untimely age of 35. He was elected to Parliament in March 1987 and died on 20 September this year. Senator Tambling would testify, and no doubt will, that his funeral was testimony to the regard in which Stan was held. It bowled me over. A requiem mass was held for Stan in the cathedral in Darwin—not a small building—for the benefit of those many friends that Stan had from both sides of political life, from all sections of the Northern Territory community, and for those people who would not be able to get to the funeral service at Bathurst Island. The cathedral was packed out; there was standing room only. It was a tremendous comfort to Stan's family to see the level of support for the job that he had done in the tributes that were paid to him by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and by all members of the Northern Territory Parliament.

Stan was a great ambassador for the Northern Territory, a very effective one. He travelled widely in the 5 1/2 years that he was a member and many members of the Northern Territory Government spoke about this. The feedback that everyone got from Stan's visit overseas, particularly on behalf of the Territory, was that he was an extremely effective ambassador for the Territory. Without question, the fact that he was black had a lot to do with it. There were only two full blood Aboriginal members of parliament in Australia: one of them was Stan and the other is Wesley Lanhupuy, who is also a member of the Territory Parliament, now in his third term.

The fact that this articulate, young, black Australian politician was able to visit countries such as the United States of America, Canada and Germany as an ambassador for the Northern Territory was of enormous benefit to the Territory and to everyone who served in public life. We all shared a bit in the reputation that Stan Tipiloura had. We all dearly regret his passing.

I rise tonight to pay tribute to the public service he gave as a politician, as a parliamentarian, as a passionate and articulate advocate for the Aboriginal people that he represented in parliament, and to pay tribute to the service that he gave them. I simply close by saying that it is a tragic fact that, as we speak, in 1992—today—the average life expectancy for an Aboriginal male in the Northern Territory is 40 years of age. Stan tragically never made even that relatively short life span.

I finish on a positive note. I am very pleased to say that, following Stan's death, I have been advised by the Tiwi Land Council, by the social club at Bathurst Island and by a number of other organisations, including the football club, that were associated with Stan, that there is now an intention to endow in his memory a trust fund that will be used to further the kidney research that is being carried out among the Tiwi people by the Menzies School of Health Research in Darwin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, this evening I would certainly like to be associated with the tributes and condolences that Senator Collins has just expressed with regard to the very sad passing of our political colleague and good friend in the Northern Territory, Stan Tipiloura. People from the Tiwi Islands travelled to Darwin a week or so ago to `smoke' the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in honour of the late Stan Tipiloura.

PARA.TAB: Stan, a Tiwi Islander and the honourable member for Arafura, died on 20 September at the tragically young age of 35 after a long battle with kidney disease. Some 60 of his fellow islanders performed the smoking ceremony in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and in Stan's old office to farewell his soul and to ensure that other members of the Legislative Assembly were protected and made proper decisions. That smoking ceremony, said to be the first in any Australian parliament, highlighted the strength of Stan's culture and the strength of respect for the `big man' across the Assembly and the Northern Territory community.

Born in 1957, Stan Gabriel Tipiloura was, according to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, a man who represented Aboriginal Territorians with passion and conviction and a Territorian of whom all Territorians could be proud. His electorate covered the Tiwi Islands and the north and west parts of Arnhem Land. Chief Minister Perron told the Legislative Assembly last month:

SPEECH.PARA: The respect and support which he enjoyed in the community was demonstrated overwhelmingly when he first ran for Parliament in 1987 and won with three times as many votes as his nearest opponent. Even though he fought the last election from his hospital bed, he again won convincingly by capturing two-thirds of the vote. In this Assembly, he was always a gentleman and spoke from his heart, quite forcefully on occasions.
The Labor Opposition Leader, Mr Brian Ede, also reflected on the last election campaign when he said Stan became affectionately known as the `menace on the mobile'. Mr Ede said:

Stanley had a mobile phone and he would be forever ringing up various people asking what was happening and whether one thing or another had been organised. People would say that the "menace on the mobile" was at it again. He was as susceptible to election jitters as any of us.

Stan Tipiloura entered parliament just six months short of his thirtieth birthday and over the next five years served as shadow Minister for portfolios such as local government, administrative services, police, fire and emergency services.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins has already alluded to the fact that he served well in his parliamentary responsibilities. I pay tribute as a shadow Minister to the functions he carried out in the Northern Territory as a shadow Minister in the Northern Territory Parliament. A fellow Aboriginal member of the Legislative Assembly, Mr Wes Lanhupuy, said he often drew strength from Stan and considered him both a friend and a colleague. In fact, Mr Lanhupuy related an amusing story from Stan's trip to Germany in 1988 with the then NT Minister for Tourism, Mr Ray Hanrahan.

Apparently, the two were preparing for an important interview when reporters and camera crews, confused as to who the Minister was, turned their attention to Stan. He did, after all, tower over Ray Hanrahan. According to Mr Lanhupuy, someone then asked Stanley who the little white guy was and Stanley referred to him as his baggage man. Let me support the words of Chief Minister Perron who described Stan in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: A person of unquestioned honesty and integrity, he was seen as having good judgment, confidence and a willingness to stand alone when the situation demanded it.

Stan Tipiloura, the man who in his maiden speech in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly pledged to work for the benefit of the people of his electorate and the people of the Northern Territory, will be well remembered. Unfortunately, I was overseas at the time of Mr Tipiloura's death and I was unable to attend the funeral in Darwin, which Senator Collins has already referred to, at which so many Territorians paid their last respects and tributes. I would have loved to have been there because of the personal affection that I felt for Stan. Certainly, we all share in conveying condolences to his mother, Scholastica; his wife, Patricia; and his four children—Gwain, Christophina, John Boy and Anna.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins referred to the fact that Stan probably intended to retire in the not too distant future because of the nature of his illness. I only wish that that had been his luxury, in particular, because he was a politician just like Senator Collins and I and he would have enjoyed the ensuing politics of the subsequent changes. The Labor Party in the Northern Territory has already endorsed another one of Senator Collins's proteges—a well known Aboriginal footballer, Mr Maurice Rioli. He has family links with the electorate and I am sure he will make a good candidate for this coming election. I am pleased that my own Party, the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party, has also entered into the political game that now has to be played in the filling of this particular situation.

The pre-selection process for the seat of Tiwi in my party was concluded this evening. It was concluded, with a great deal of sophistication and a democratic process whereby it attracted a number of candidates for pre-selection. In fact, there were four candidates, all now quite publicly recognised and known. They were Mr Jimmy Tipungwuti, Mr Marius Purantatameri, Mr Teddy Portaminni, and the successful candidate for the Country-Liberal Party pre-selection, Mr Bernard Tipiloura who, coincidentally, is the uncle that Senator Collins referred to earlier of the late Stan Tipiloura.

Naturally, I wish Bernard Tipiloura well in the election. I am sure that the ensuing election campaign is one that Stan Tipiloura would have relished watching and participating in, as I am sure that both Senator Collins and I will both be active during this coming election campaign as with our colleagues from both sides of politics in the Northern Territory. Certainly I am pleased tonight to join the comments of Senator Collins. We have both lost a friend. Parliament, the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, and the Northern Territory have lost a very fine politician.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish tonight to refer briefly to the events which occurred in Canberra last weekend. I refer to the dedication of the Vietnam veterans' memorial, an event that I was very pleased and honoured to be able to attend. The Senate has passed a motion commenting upon the event and congratulating the organisers and I, too, share that sentiment. It was a most well organised event which could not have been easy with so many people coming from so many places—many of them arriving no doubt as events were about to take place. In some ways, it was almost an understated event, which added to the emotion of it, and there was a simplicity about it that everybody felt.

PARA.TAB: Just standing and watching the 504 flags carried past representing those who died in Vietnam was indeed a very moving experience for everybody. That was how I felt about it. One can only conjecture how those who were actually involved must have felt, but it was very obvious that it was a weekend of great emotion, tears, memories, reunions, pride, joy, sharing and the reliving of incidents that occurred. There was the sound of the Iroquois helicopters overhead that, I think, made an impression on all of us who heard them. King O'Malley, in 1911, said at the launching of the international design competition for this, the national capital of Australia, `This city must be the finest capital city in the world'.I think we can say to him that that has turned out to be the case.

There are the memorials, the great monuments and the beauty of this city, and it is the symbol of our federation. But it is the people who give it its warmth and charm, as was very apparent last weekend. I could not tell you them all tonight, but there are just so many stories of the role played by the police, the taxi service, the families who took veterans into their homes, looked after them and drove them around, stories of the people just out and about who saw them here and there and offered them lifts from one place to another. There were the members of Lions and Rotary who got up early and provided breakfasts at the dawn service for those who were there, and there were many other stories that could be told.
Let me quote from a letter by Peter Taylor from Queensland published in today's Canberra Times:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you in particular to the Commonwealth police officers and security staff at the old Parliament House who assisted me, wheelchair bound, during Sunday's concert.

As I have said, there are so many of those stories about the weekend. I would like to conclude by asking that I could have incorporated into Hansard another letter from today's Canberra Times written by Peter Hulsing which sets out his feelings about the weekend and the city in which it was held. I think it shows the national capital to be the place that it was set out to be. It is the people who live here who very much contribute to the warmth of the city, as was seen at its very best last weekend. My congratulations to Peter Poulton and all of those who worked so hard for so long to raise the money to put on an event of such importance to this nation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Vietnam Mates Remembered
October 6
I was one of the thousands of ex-Vietnam veterans who invaded Canberra over the long weekend to attend the opening of the Vietnam memorial.
During this weekend, we met, talked, cried, hugged and celebrated. We met up with other veterans not seen since those days of jungle, sweat and tears.
We relived bitter moments that can only be experienced by mates living under the most arduous conditions.
We remembered.
The memorial invoked so many memories, each line written there commemorates incidents of anger, hurt, humour and, above all, honours those who are now at rest at last. Together.
The weekend was spent in the companionship of mates; the years forgotten, the grey hairs and bulges not noticed.
None of this, however, can take away Canberra's contribution to this event.

Your welcome and support, your assistance and indulgence was magnificent. From the grossly overworked cabbies, who would still find time to give some of us guided tours in the middle of the night, to the night staff in motels filling glasses with no bottoms till the early hours of the morning.
Your massive attendance at the march to welcome us. Wherever we went, we encountered wishes of good luck and friendship.
Thank you Canberra, in so many ways you helped us to `come home'. Our mates can now rest in peace in your beautiful city. It is good to know they're in safe hands.
PETER HULSING
1st Australian Civil Affairs Unit
Australian Army Training Team

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to express my appreciation for the preceding adjournment speeches which have just been presented by Senators Collins, Tambling and Reid. I think we have been deeply moved by what we have heard.

PARA.TAB: My speech tonight relates, perhaps in an ironic way, to the last speech. I rise tonight to express my concern, and I hope that many other honourable senators share this concern with me, at the rising tide of replica weapons which are being offered for sale in this country. Indeed, far from merely expressing concern, I want to draw attention to what I consider to be a distressing and also dangerous piece of marketing.

A number of honourable senators have fought in various wars for this country and have demonstrated a degree of courage which, thankfully, is rarely required of a country's citizens. They are in no doubt about the killing capacities of weapons of war. Just this last weekend we have seen a reminder of the tragedies of war, and thankfully a healing time for those tragedies.

Why is it then that people seem ready to accept as legitimate marketing exercises and profit making ventures the selling of replica weapons? It may well be argued that a replica gun cannot kill, and that is correct. But, in my opinion, a replica gun is still related to the original by way of its symbolic value. I remember well the bewilderment of a prisoner, whose name was Francois, when he received a three-year sentence for armed robbery. He protested, `But it was only a water pistol'. Guns and their replicas demonstrate that the violent resolution of conflict, which has its ultimate expression in war, is legitimate.

However, replica guns are not the only form in which this dubious trade demonstrates itself. A constituent, who is also an old friend, Mr Bill Bradbury, rang my office recently to complain about a brochure which was tucked into many weekend papers in Western Australia. The brochure offered for sale at extraordinary prices—some $195—replica knives. I am not sure that I know what a replica knife is. I do not think it is made of rubber. Surely, it is still a knife. The particular well known company which specialises in marketing collectibles is offering a set of knives comprising one each of the most famous commando and strike force knives of World War II. There is the famous Australian knuckleduster SAS knife, a German knife and so on.

I want to raise three major objections about this piece of marketing. The first is that it is seeking to cash in on a certain ghoulish interest in war. For those who fought in World War II and in Vietnam, such a knife may have been a valued piece of survival equipment or a potentially lethal weapon in the hands of an enemy. I doubt that anyone here would want to own a replica of that. Perhaps those who fought may well value the genuine article as a souvenir, and it is not for me to gainsay their right to such a memento. However, I believe that such replica items can only foster a sick attitude to war, as something to be glorified and dwelt over, which I am sure no-one who has been to war would want to do.

My second objection is that a replica knife, unlike a replica gun, can still kill. The knives in question are advertised as being the same as the originals in size as well as design—some 12 inches long. In this country we have a growing concern about crime—violent crime in particular—and about crime involving weapons. Does it make sense then for companies to be marketing extra weapons to be kept in the home?

We have a major problem with domestic violence. A significant number of people are murdered each year in acts of domestic violence—mainly wives. Do we, then, want to put extra weapons into the home—weapons which may appear to some as ornaments but which to others may fall easily to hand in a heated dispute? We are also at a stage where there is, regrettably, an increasing incidence of breaking and entering into houses. The possibility of assault and assault causing fatal damage is much greater if there are weapons easily at hand on display.

I also want to raise the question of policing in relation to these replica knives. In Western Australia, anyone who carries a knife in public is liable to be charged by the police. That is as it should be. We do not want to live in a society where people routinely carry weapons. Nonetheless, society's double standards encourage weaponry and, as young boys seem more responsive to this than other groups, this makes them vulnerable not only to crime but also to police harassment.

In conclusion, if one has paid $195 for a replica World War II knife and it is ready to hand on display in the lounge room at home, is it an ornament or a lethal weapon? The original was made to protect service people from death and to inflict death on an enemy. Is the replica somehow innocuous by virtue of its being a replica? I think not.

My predecessor, Senator Vallentine, proposed in this chamber a Bill to stop the marketing of war toys. I would hope that we include these expensive war toys in the provisions of such a Bill when it is reintroduced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the adjournment debate yesterday I brought to the Senate's attention the case of seven children from the Coffs Harbour region. I did so from information supplied to my office several weeks ago. More recently I received another package in the mail which tells a story about another region of Australia—the Mitchell Valley, Lindenow, near Bairnsdale in East Gippsland, Victoria. Contained in that package was a report entitled `Toxicology of Pesticides in use in the Mitchell Valley'. That was a study undertaken by the Mitchell River Valley Rural Safety Awareness Group in response to a significant local concern about aerial spraying in close proximity to the Lindenow Primary School, Pre-school and the Infant Welfare Centre. While the report goes into some detail about the toxicity of 66 insecticides, 95 herbicides and 37 fungicides, it conveniently ignores the question of aerial spraying in the district, despite the fact that 41 per cent of chemical application in the area is from the air.

PARA.TAB: Needless to say, the people who first raised the issue are totally dissatisfied and frustrated with the lack of response to the issue and have requested help from the Democrats to expose this practice and the detrimental effects that it is causing throughout Australia. The story covers a 12-month period between March 1990 and June 1991 during which there were four separate instances of aerial spraying near those schools.

On 9 March 1990, lorsban, an organophosphate, and a poison of S6 rating, was aerially sprayed close to the pre-school. The Directress of the pre-school locked the children inside and sealed the doorways and vents with towels. Play equipment was then washed down to prevent any possible dermal absorption of the chemical. It took three months to find out from authorities what had been sprayed. When inquiries were made concerning the toxicity of that chemical from that same authority, a print-out of the chemical container label was the only information available.

On 25 June 1990, lime and potash was being applied to the paddock directly below the pre-school. The updraught was such that the pre-school was totally enveloped in a white cloud. The pre-school building was not visible 50 metres away. There was concern that this cloud would reach the school. At the pre-school the children were locked inside, but this did not stop the children from being affected. The children's and teachers' eyes were red and smarting and those asthmatic children present were particularly affected.

On 13 November 1990, sumicidin was aerially sprayed near the pre-school. This is a synthetic pyrethroid, an S6 poison. Precautions were once again taken to try to eliminate possible contamination by that chemical. On 5 June 1991, ronilan and sumicidin were aerially sprayed near the pre-school and school. Spray was seen drifting towards the school while the children were in attendance. On that morning children were not in attendance at the pre-school, but the Infant Welfare Centre was open for young mothers and babies to attend. Play equipment at the pre-school was washed down for the afternoon session.

Local initiatives and actions were taken on all of the above occasions. However, because of the complacency of the authorities concerned, the threat of recurrence remains. In addition, concerns have been raised for children who have been travelling on school buses through the vegetable growing area in this vicinity. Aerial spraying occurs during the vegetable growing season.

The chemicals used in the Mitchell Valley are registered for use and are quite legal, but the toxicology data available suggests that health problems are associated with their use and that the chronic or long terms effects remain unknown. The acute effects or short term problems associated with chemical exposure often go undiagnosed and are not considered to be serious but still cause great discomfort.

Thirty known compounds and 76 different chemicals are in use in vegetable production in the Mitchell River Valley area. The synergistic or cocktail effect of these chemicals is of great concern, as research has not been done in this area. It is a fact that the effect of chemicals on developing children remains unknown as well.

Many of those chemicals used in the Mitchell Valley have a high toxicity rating, as is borne out by the report of the Safety Awareness Group. Spraying often occurs on Saturday mornings near the pre-school and the school. As the many chemicals used there are of high toxicity and have a long half-life, contamination of the grounds of the pre-school and school is seen to be a problem if spray drift occurs.

From information on the particular products that we have gained from the chemical companies, they have continually emphasised that their chemicals should not enter watercourses and domestic water supplies. However, this has not been adhered to—and I would suggest it is very difficult to ensure that it can be adhered to—because of the closeness of the Mitchell River to the vegetable farms. The Mitchell River is one of the main tributaries of the Gippsland Lakes.

Response from government departments in Victoria has been such that, because laws have not been broken, they have been unable or unwilling to act in any effective capacity. The Victorian health department has ignored the situation. The education department refuses to get involved. Yet the concerns of ordinary people are, of course, very real. A member of the National Health and Medical Research Council said he would not like to send his children to the school in Lindenow because of the chemicals used in the vicinity. A health surveyor in the area had his job threatened if he continued his involvement in endeavouring to expose the problem. Women in the area, including many vegetable growers' wives, have privately expressed their fears. But, because of the small, closed community, public support has not been forthcoming.

The package that I received which contained this information also included a copy of a letter dated 14 February 1992 to the Hon. Ian Baker, MLA, the Minister for Food and Agriculture in the Kirner Labor Government. The final paragraph of the letter sums up the frustration being felt by an increasing number of people throughout rural Australia. I will conclude by quoting that final paragraph, which reads:
We feel you and your department have overlooked our main concern. That is the exposure on four occasions in the 12 month period—1990/91.

Let it be stated that this is not the first time locals have complained—this is the first time we have taken issue on the matter! We find it to be completely unsatisfactory that each time they aerial spray, the children have to be taken indoors or some defensive action has to be taken. What is the department planning to do to address this ongoing problem?

Since the report was published we have had access to more comprehensive information and health data on many of the compounds used in the Mitchell Valley. It is extremely disturbing to note that many have been banned overseas and/or severely restricted for agricultural use. This gives cause for concern also in relation to the far reaching effects on ecosystems; in particular the Mitchell River and Gippsland Lakes environment. We have enclosed this information for your perusal and comment. We would like to know why it is that in Australia, and in particular in Victoria, these chemicals are used on a regular basis in food production and adjacent to urban areas?

SPEECH.PARA: This is yet another of the continuing saga of contributions that have been sent to me by Australian citizens who are concerned that their voice is not being heard in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my condolences to those of Senator Collins and Senator Tambling. Tonight I wish to raise the issue of a report in this morning's Courier-Mail relating to a decision of the Australian Press Council. As some honourable senators would know, I am not in the habit of criticising the media for the job that it does. Nor am I someone who runs to the Press Council with complaints about misrepresentation. In fact, to my knowledge, I have never referred anything directly to the Press Council, though I must admit that I have suggested to some people who have been concerned about how they have been presented in the media that they always have available the avenue of referring their concern to the Press Council.

PARA.TAB: However, I must admit that I am absolutely amazed that the Press Council has decided that it upholds the right of newspapers and magazines to publish pictures which it says many readers will find `undoubtedly offensive'. It is reported that the Press Council's findings are likely to be used as a benchmark in future Council hearings when the question of taste is balanced against the freedom of the press.

Again, I do not lightly speak about an issue relating to freedom of the press. But I speak about a particularly gross and offensive photograph on the cover of the March People magazine which shows a naked woman in a particularly sexual position wearing a dog collar around her neck. Clearly, that photograph is more than offensive. It is an absolute insult to 51 per cent of the population of this country. I am pleased to say that the magazine has actually been withdrawn in Western Australia in accordance with a State Government regulation.

While I would, of course, uphold the principle of freedom of the press, I find it offensive—I am sure that the vast majority of women around the country will find it quite unacceptable—that the Council can rule in favour of the publication of photographs because they are in context with an accompanying story. The accompanying story was `Woof! More wild animals inside'.

We all know that Australia has a higher than average reputation in terms of violence against women, particularly sexual violence against women. Here we have the Australian Press Council upholding the right of People magazine not only to publish this photograph but to continue to publish such offensive photographs. The Press Council says that it is okay to do this.

I do not know how the Press Council has come to its decision. I went to the trouble of finding some information about the Press Council. I have obtained a Press Council document entitled Aims, Principles, Constitution and Complaints Procedure. In a summary of how it hopes to operate, the Press Council states quite categorically that the industry wanted a Press Council because `it had come to accept that there was a need for a body to act as watchdog over the ethical standards of the press'. If the Australian Press Council thinks it is ethical for a magazine to have a naked woman with a dog collar on the front page, or anywhere else, in a magazine that is generally available and is displayed for all and sundry to see, I am not quite sure why it bothers to publish anything about ethics. I cannot see that there is anything ethical in presenting women in such a vulnerable and demeaning light.
The Press Council goes on to say in point 7 of its statement of principles:

SPEECH.PARA: A newspaper has a wide discretion in matters of taste—
and I would agree with that—
but this does not justify lapses of taste so gross as to bring the freedom of the press into disrepute.

Is the Press Council really suggesting that photographs such as the one that appeared in the People magazine of March this year are so acceptable that they can proliferate in the Australian media? I certainly hope not. But the Press Council has lost the opportunity even to comment on the matter.

PARA.TAB: In point 8 the Press Council says:

SPEECH.PARA: The publication of material disparaging or belittling individuals or groups by reference to their sex, race, nationality, religion, colour, country of origin or intellectual or physical disabilities is a breach of ethical standards.

I cannot see that the front page of People magazine is anything else by a breach of ethical standards. Quite clearly this material is grossly disparaging and belittling to groups—as I said, 51 per cent of the population—by reference to their sex. I do not care whether there is a story inside People magazine about animals or anything else. This was a photograph of a naked woman with a dog collar around her neck. Quite clearly, the Australian Press Council cannot be bothered to read even its own criteria and principles when making a judgment on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The third area in which the Press Council is in breach relates to the claim in point 10:

SPEECH.PARA: If material damaging to the reputation or interests of an individual, corporation, organisation or specific group of people is published, opportunity for prompt and appropriately prominent reply at reasonable length should be given by the newspaper concerned, wherever fairness so requires.

I cannot think of anything much more damaging than this photograph. If the Press Council were to uphold its own principles—principles that it does not seem to be interested in—I believe that quite clearly People magazine should, at the very least, have been asked to give a reply. The material is clearly damaging to both the reputation and the interests of a specific group—that is, women—and therefore a prompt and appropriately prominent reply should have been given by People magazine.

PARA.TAB: I will be writing to the Press Council to ask at least for a copy of how it came to make the judgment that this particular photograph is acceptable. I hope that many women and, indeed, men around Australia who find this type of material very offensive and totally unnecessary will also take the issue up with the Press Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —While you are about it, why don't you also ban X-rated videos?

—That is a totally different issue. We can debate X-rated videos in this place, as indeed we will with the private member's Bill that Senator Walters has brought forward. But X-rated videos—and I should not allow myself to be distracted, but I will as Senator Newman and I are both interested in similar subjects in this regard—are not openly displayed and available at the corner store; they are not generally available as a magazine, as is People magazine.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about the responsibility of the Press Council to comply with its own principles, aims and standards—and I believe in this case it has clearly ignored them. I will be seeking a response as to how it has made that judgment, and I certainly hope that other people around Australia will ask for a similar explanation and, hopefully, further action on the matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the advertisement appearing in the Sydney Morning Herald on Thursday, 21 May 1992, and the Australian on Tuesday, 26 May 1992, entitled `ANSTO—There's a trace of us':
(1) When did this recent advertising campaign by the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) commence, and when is it due to conclude.
(2) In how many, and in which newspapers, journals and magazines did the advertisement appear.
(3) By whom and when was the decision made to undertake the advertising campaign.
(4) What are the aims of the advertising campaign.
(5) What is the total cost of the advertising campaign.
(6) What is the total advertising and publicity budget for ANSTO for 1991-1992.
(7) How many similar advertising campaigns has ANSTO run in the past and in what years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) ANSTO placed two separate newspaper advertisements during May on its work in nuclear medicine. The first advertisement was placed in the Sydney Morning Herald on 12 and 14 May, while the second (the subject of Senator Sowada's question) was placed in the Sydney Morning Herald on 19 and 21 May and the Australian on 26 May. That completed the campaign.
(3) The decision to place these advertisements was taken in early May by ANSTO's Executive Director, as part of ANSTO's overall public relations program.

(4) The aims of the advertising campaign were to assist in informing the public on the contribution of nuclear medicine in the health care of Australians and the fact that radiopharmaceuticals produced by ANSTO form a valuable, and, at times, the only, diagnostic tool for medical physicians.

(6) ANSTO's public affairs budget for 1991-92, excluding staff-related costs, was $305,000 which encompasses ANSTO's requirements to provide statutory publications, brochures, scientific photography, educational resources, advertising, community liaison, site visits and open days.

(7) ANSTO and its predecessor, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, have placed advertising material in print media from time to time for many years. These advertisements have been intended to provide information (to the public, Members of Parliament, the scientific community) on particular developments of general interest and to inform industry of ANSTO's scientific and technological capabilities.

Apart from specific purpose advertisements for such matters as site Open Days and advertisements in trade journals, five sets of, or single, advertisements were placed by ANSTO in 1990-91 (one extended into July 1991), and three were placed in 1991-92 (in addition to the advertisements referred to in the answers to (1) and (2) above). In 1992-93, there has been only one comparable activity, to date, and that involved a letter box drop in the Shire of Sutherland.
