TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 4 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to question on notice no. 1987, 28 May 1992, regarding the clearance of anti-personnel mines in Cambodia, and the Minister's answer received on 24 June 1992:
(1) Has the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia had any correspondence or consultation with any Australian organisation on anti-personnel mine clearance operations.

(2) Has the Australian Government, Austrade, or any other Government organisation had approaches from Australian firms, Austsar, Exat or any other company, seeking assistance to cement contracts for mine clearance in Cambodia; if any such approaches have been made, what advice and assistance were they offered.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Government is not privy to consultations between the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC) and Australian companies. However, on 8 April 1992, Austrade received through its Washington office, a UN tender for the supply of demining kits to UNTAC. The tender was faxed to Australian firms with a known capacity or registered interest in this area. Because Austsar is a UN registered supplier, it had received a copy of the tender from the UN in New York. Austrade invited Austsar to seek its assistance if required.

(2) I was approached by Mr Eddy Andrews, Managing Director of Austsar, in January 1992, about Austsar's proposal to undertake demining activities and instruction in Cambodia. Mr Andrews also approached my Department and Austrade. The Australian Mission to the UN was requested to provide Austsar with assistance in presenting its tender to the relevant authorities in New York. I am not aware of any approach from Exat.

In May this year Sidney Alford Ltd, an explosive engineering firm in the United Kingdom, approached the Australian Defence Force offering assistance to the mine-clearing program in Cambodia. As Australia is not directly involved in that program, the company was referred to the New Zealand Defence Force which is involved in mine-clearance in Cambodia.

Austrade has recently appointed a Trade Commissioner in Phnom Penh who is following up on trade opportunities emanating from UNTAC. To date, no Australian company has been contracted by the United Nations for mine-clearing activities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 6 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What discussions have taken place between Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and Australian Government agencies on the possibility of keeping the spent fuel currently stored at Lucas Heights in Australia.
(2) What measures have been suggested to deal with the low, intermediate and high level wastes that have arisen from reprocessing Australian spent fuel and which could be returned to Australia.
(3) Has ANSTO, or any other Federal agency, investigated above ground dry stores for long term storage of spent fuel in Australia.
(4) To date, how much Federal Government money has been allocated to Synroc research.
(5) Have any approaches been made by foreign governments for the use of Synroc.
(6) How much fuel will need to be imported for the remaining life of the presently operating reactor.
(7) To whom is the National Health and Medical Research Council's Working Party on the Disposal of Radioactive Waste accountable.

(8) Can details be given of overseas visits made by ANSTO officials and representatives since its inception in 1987, where those visits involved direct talks and negotiations with ANSTO and contracts or deals with foreign companies, governments or nuclear agencies; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(2) The only spent fuel returned by ANSTO overseas for reprocessing to date was in 1963 when 150 spent fuel elements were sent to the United Kingdom for reprocessing. The reprocessing agreement included retention of all wastes in the United Kingdom.

(3) Above ground dry storage is one of several options for possible long term storage of spent fuel in Australia. Reprocessing and disposal of the wastes overseas is the preferred option at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 9 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many ships pass through Torres Strait per year.
(2) What revenue is generated by collection of levies from international shipping in this region.
(3) What progress has been made in requiring all foreign vessels to take on board an Australian pilot.
(4) How many pilots are located in: (a) Thursday Island; (b) Cairns; (c) Townsville; (d) Mackay; (e) Rockhampton; and (f) Brisbane.
(5) How can pilots monitor all relevant standards appropriate to passage through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In 1991, 1337 piloted ships transited the Torres Strait. A further 70 ships are believed to have passed through the Torres Strait without taking a pilot.

(2) There are no specific levies imposed on shipping transiting the Torres Strait. All vessels calling at Australian ports are subject to a range of Commonwealth levies including the Marine Navigation Levy, which covers the provision of navigation aids to shipping using Australian waters, including the Torres Strait. Pilotage fees are prescribed under Queensland regulations and are collected by the Queensland Coast and Torres Strait Pilot Service.

(3) Compulsory pilotage for specified ships navigating through the inner route of the Great Barrier Reef or when passing through Hydrographers Passage was introduced in October 1991. Since that time there appears to have been almost 100% compliance—only one prosecution has been necessary.

There is no requirement for ships transiting the Torres Strait to take on a pilot. However, a recommendation, which covers all ships 70 metres and over and all loaded oil tankers, chemical tankers or liquefied gas carriers, irrespective of size, was adopted by the International Maritime Organization in November 1991. Approximately 5% of ships transiting the Torres Strait in 1991 were unpiloted.
In view of the status of the Torres Strait as an international waterway it is not intended that pilotage in this area be made compulsory.

(4) Pilots of the Queensland Coast and Torres Strait Pilot Service are not located at any specific ports along the Queensland coast but operate on a call in system as required. There are presently 44 pilots employed in the service.
(5) Pilots are employed to assist the master of a ship on navigational matters only. They are not employed to monitor any other standards.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Torres Strait

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security upon notice, on 9 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many staff are based in Torres Strait.
(2) How many staff are indigenous.
(3) What strategies are being implemented to ensure more Torres Strait Islander staff move into senior positions.
(4) How is housing allocated to prevent discrimination against Torres Strait Islanders.
(5) What processes are in place to ensure regular communication and liaison between departments and with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Island Coordinating Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are currently 5 Departmental staff in the Torres Strait. They are based at the Thursday Island Department of Social Security Sub-Office. There is an intention to recruit a Youth Trainee from the Outer Islands.
(2) All staff at the Thursday Island Department of Social Security Sub-Office have been recruited locally.
(3) The Area administration responsible for Thursday Island has developed strategies to ensure that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff have priority access to developmental opportunities.

The Department is in the process of implementing its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Employment Strategy. This Strategy contains initiatives to ensure that more Torres Strait Islanders move into senior positions within the Department. These include the Department:
aiming to maintain the level of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff at least at 3% nationally;
establishing and maintaining a mentoring program for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander recruits;

developing guidelines for selection delegates and selection advisory committees aimed at ensuring the fairness of selections involving applicants from EEO target groups, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander applicants;

providing training in interview and job application techniques for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff and ensuring that the training is effective by monitoring and evaluating its impact on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff;
ensuring that training needs analyses are carried out for all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff in the Department;

ensuring that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff in identified positions are given the opportunity to compete for mainstream positions by providing training and developing structured career paths; and

continuing to increase access by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff to Public Service Commission and Departmental developmental programs and enhancing the skills of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff by providing formal on-the-job training together with staff development to help overcome barriers to career progression.
(4) There is one Departmental house available on Thursday Island. It is occupied by Torres Strait Islander staff.

(5) Commonwealth employment, education and training and economic enterprise programs for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) under the Aboriginal Employment and Development Policy. The Department of Social Security is currently represented with DEET and ATSIC on the Aboriginal Employment and Development Policy Committees at national, state and regional levels, including the Aboriginal Employment and Development Policy Committee in the Torres Strait.

The Torres Strait Aboriginal Employment and Development Policy meeting is convened on a monthly basis to discuss employment and training issues. The Department of Social Security, DEET, ATSIC, the Island Coordinating Council and State government departments have representatives at this forum.

A formal six monthly meeting for all service providers in the Torres Strait is convened to discuss with the Chairperson of the Island Coordinating Council all issues affecting Torres Strait Islanders.

The Secretary of the Department of Social Security has written to all the Department's Area Managers telling them to work closely with ATSIC Regional Councils and Aboriginal Employment and Development Committees in planning service delivery strategies for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in their Areas.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Can the Minister explain why the nuclides Kr-85, Ni-63, Pu-238 and Am-241 are not included in tables three and four, `Generic Concentration Limits', of the National Health and Medical Research Council's (NH&MRC) Draft Guidelines on Radioactive Waste disposal in Arid Areas; and (b) are wastes containing these nuclides not suitable for disposal by shallow-land burial, or are they included as beta/gamma emitters.
(2) Is there any reason for Co-60, Cs-137 and Sr-90, listed separately in the 1990 Draft Guidelines generic concentration limits, no longer to be so listed.

(3) Can the Minister explain why the concentration limit for tritium in category A waste has been raised by a factor of two from the 1990 Draft Guidelines to the 1992 Draft Guidelines, and why the limits for C-14, natural uranium and radium have also been raised.

(4) Can the Minister explain why, in the case of category B waste, the concentration limit for radium has actually been raised by a factor of 50, while the limit for Tritium has been removed altogether.

(5) Can the Minister comment on Greenpeace's statement in its commentary on the Draft Guidelines that much of what is included in category B, notably gauges and sealed sources used in industry, medical diagnostic and therapeutic sources and solid waste, is properly classed as intermediate-level waste.
(6) Can the Minister explain why NH&MRC has not chosen to state outright that these items are, indeed, intermediate-level waste and not low-level waste.
(7) Can the Minister explain why the NH&MRC in its 1992 Draft Guidelines has now omitted the reference to 0.5Msv as the limiting dose from a possible dump site.

(8)(a) Does the NH&MRC believe that there will be no competing sources of radiation per exposure, and that they can therefore safely allocate the whole 1 Msv/a to the dump-site; and (b) does NH&MRC and the Minister's department believe that there will be no radiation doses from other man-made phenomena such as nuclear testing.

(9)(a) Is it a fact that a section of the Code of Practice states that `Site rehabilitation plans should include the proper provision of site markers and exclusion barriers and the removal of all superfluous surface structures which may encourage occupation of the site and building'; (b) is it further a fact that the very next section of the code talks of returning the site to unrestricted access; (c) can the Minister explain how a place bearing warning signs can be considered suitable for unrestricted access.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Am-241 is included in the tables referred to. Pu-238 is included by default as an alpha emitting radionuclide. Similarly Kr-85 and Ni-63 are included by default as beta/gamma emitting radionuclides. The NH&MRC Working Party considered that an exhaustive list of radionuclides would result in an unnecessarily complicated table.
(b) Provided that wastes containing these or other radionuclides comply with the provisions of the draft Code of Practice they are acceptable for near-surface disposal under the Code.
(2) Co-60, Cs-137 and Sr-90 are listed in the 1992 document. They are grouped together with other similar radionuclides in a generic grouping for ease of reference.
(3) See answer to part 1(b) of Question 2091.
(4) See answer to parts 9 and 10 of Question 2038.
(5&6) See answer to part 1(a) of Question 2091.
(7) See answer to part 1(b) of Question 2091.
(8)(a) No. (b) No. See answer to part 1(b) of Question 2091.
(9)(a) Yes. These things should be done when the site is closed to waste disposal operations.
(b) Yes. However, the site is not to be returned to unrestricted access upon closure but at the end of the institutional control period.

(c) The section referred to says that while ideally the site should be suitable for unrestricted access at the end of the institutional control period, any proposed use of the site should require an assessment of the new proponement's intentions. The honourable senator will be interested to know that the current draft of the Code now expressly specifies in this section that any fences, site markers, etc. are to be removed at the end of the institutional control period.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 29 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: What is the annual cost of removing the assets test for those over 75years of age not currently in receipt of a pension or pension entitlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Data are not available on the assets of non-pensioner aged persons and it is not possible, therefore, to provide an accurate and up to date estimate of the likely cost. Based on numbers affected when the assets test was introduced in 1985 and making several adjustments for changed circumstances since that time, a possible order of magnitude is in the vicinity of $55 million in a full year for the Department of Social Security (DSS) alone. This excludes the cost—about another $10 million—of applying only the income test to current part-rate assets-tested pensioners. These estimates are likely to be on the low side, because data from the Australian Taxation Office indicate that there are many more persons of age pension age who have taxable income below the pension income limits but have not claimed a pension. The above estimate does not take into account behavioural effects of persons rearranging assets to avoid the income test. The cost to the Department of Veterans' Affairs of removing the assets test for veterans aged 75 and over would be in addition to the figures quoted above, but cannot be calculated by DSS.
